From:	Dan and Melva <krisand1@verizon.net>
Sent:	Saturday, November 18, 2006 10:43 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Proposed New Fee at the University of Florida to Avoid PrePaid Tuition Plan

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing to voice my displeasure of the proposed new fee of $500 per semester at U of F, which will be classified as non-tuition.
We have paid into the Prepaid Tuition Plan for both our children.  The State encouraged us to do this to lock in tuition rates that would be dramatically higher when our children became college age.  The structure of this new fee as a "fee" instead of an increase in tuition is simply to avoid the benefits to forward thinking families whom have paid into the Florida Prepaid Tuition Plan.  The main reason for the "fee" is to increase faculty and faculty pay which is a direct expense paid for by tuition.  This is very unjust.
 
I hope you will champion efforts to thwart this deceptive and unjust classification of this proposed "fee."
 
Sincerely,
 
Dan and Melva Murphy
 
 
P.S.  You have been an outstanding Governor.

Subject:	No home for the holidays

Hi Mr. Bush,

I am writing this e-mail on behalf of my mom and I, seeking your assistance. 
My mother and I reside in Orlando Florida, we are both Native floridians. My 
mother and I moved to Orlando a year and about six months ago because I was 
accepted into the Nursing program here. I am in my senior year and have a 
semester and a few more weeks to go before I graduate. My mom has been most 
instrumental in me continuing my education. She has contributed alot to get 
me where I am.
As you know as a second degree seeking student you are limited to the types 
of financial aid that is available to you. Since coming back to school it 
has been quite expensive and consequently financially draining. We had been 
doing well until financially everything snowballed into what it has become 
today. This semester I received just enough to cover tuition and nothing 
else. I have a part time job and my mom is on a fixed income. My mom has 
given her all. Because nursing school is very demanding I have had to cut 
down on my hours at work.  I tried to get assistance with rent so that I 
could keep a roof over our heads but every place that I called required us 
to have a child before they would help. My mother is a Senior Citizen, she 
is 66 years old, she is a veteran and unable to work. We have been evicted 
from our apartment because we weren't able to pay the rent. We have never 
been evicted from anywhere and have never been homeless. I tried to get us a 
place to lay our heads at night at the local shelters but they either 
provide shelter for women and children or they are overcrowded. I have 
contacted HUD and other Senior programs to get my mom senior housing but 
they state that they have waiting lists going back two to three years. I 
desperately need your help. My mom is a diabetic and she isn't eating the 
way she should. She is loosing weight and its tough on us both. We are 
presently sleeping in our car. It is cold and unbearable at night. I have 
mentioned my predicament to others and have even gone to a church to seek 
help. It brings heartache to know that I pay taxes and have given to 
charities and when I have need, I can't get any help. We are both honest, 
decent people, I am a College student living on the streets trying to finish 
my education with my mom who is sick. I need you to please make a way that 
at least my mom can find senior housing somewhere As soon as possible.  I 
can't even afford to keep my cell phone on, so the only way for you or your 
staff to contact me is by e-mail. I feel really bad having to be in this 
predicament and equally bad having to beg others for help, but I am 
desperately trying to complete school so that I can build a stable future 
for me and my mom. Thank you sincerly for reading this e-mail and I hope to 
hear from you soon.

Sincerly,

Mrs. Yvonne Banks
and Daughter Katrina Banks

From: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
To: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Sent: Saturday, November 11, 2006 8:07 AM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, November 9, 2006


> For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
> Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
> http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
> The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
> $1.2 MILLION GRANT TO EMPOWER FLORIDA ADULTS AND YOUTH WITH DISABILITIES
> ANNOUNCED
>
> Last Friday, I was pleased to announce the U.S. Department of Labor 
> awarded
> $1.2 million to the Florida Agency for Workforce Innovation to increase
> opportunities for persons with disabilities to become entrepreneurs.
> Persons with disabilities make a valuable contribution to the character of
> our state, the quality of life in our communities and the strength of our
> economy.  This funding will play a vital role in ensuring individuals with
> disabilities have the necessary tools to optimize their talents and 
> achieve
> their goals. The Self-Employment for Adults and Youth with Disabilities
> Research and Technical Assistance Grant will fund pilot projects and
> research to develop systems models designed to increase self-employment
> opportunities for individuals with disabilities.  The partners will 
> evaluate
> three demonstration models currently being used in Florida for self
> employment and entrepreneurial activities, expand technical assistance and
> training opportunities for interagency staff that serve persons with
> disabilities, and identify barriers and challenges to implementation of
> these models.  In addition, best practices and strategies to overcome 
> these
> barriers will be identified.  Three sites in Jacksonville, Lakeland and 
> Ft.
> Lauderdale/Miami have been selected for intensive training and technical
> assistance and will serve as incubators for further expansion of the 
> models.
> More information can be found at www.floridajobs.org.

From:	angela.strickland@fpic.com
Sent:	Tuesday, October 10, 2006 2:34 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Child Support Enforcement

Mr. Bush,

 

It is with deep regret that I must contact you again regarding my child support case # [REDACTED].  I am the custodial parent of Bryan Bush and am having no luck with enforcement of my child support case.  Enforcement of my case has been previously delayed due to the automated enforcement system.  Since that time, I have waited patiently and all automated forms of enforcement have been completed.  Tallahassee has requested the local office to proceed with a court date to find the non-custodial parent in contempt-of-court.  Per my conversation with the Tallahassee today, the case worker (Ed Cason) still has not responded to Tallahassee's request. 

 

I myself have personally contacted Mr. Cason (and Lynn Davis) regarding enforcement and have concerns regarding Mr. Cason's disposition.  My first concern was the manner is which he addressed the monies owed.  I was advised by Mr. Cason it wasn't "but just $2,100" at the time I made the call.  I advised Mr. Cason this wasn't including the arrearage which now totals to date $4,400.  For many (including Mr. Cason), this may not seem like much.  But for me and my son, we need every penny just to survive.  

 

My second reason for concern is Mr. Cason's defense of Mr. Henderson (the non-custodial parent).  Per Mr. Cason, Mr. Henderson isn't working and can't make the child support payment based on a telephone call his office had with Mr. Henderson.  Mr. Henderson advised he was in a vehicle accident and is disabled.  However, disability hasn't been filed nor has there been any proof of such accident or inability to pay the child support.  Regardless, I find it highly unlike that he can't pay the child support since the State of Florida has evidence that he owns several of his own businesses in which he receives income.    

 

I questioned Mr. Cason regarding the request for suspension of Mr. Henderson's drivers' license, but have also had no luck in this area of enforcement.  Although Mr. Caso did state his office advised Mr. Henderson he could file an affidavit with the court to keep from having his license suspended since he needed them to work (but yet he's disabled and unable to pay child support).  My last call to Mr. Cason's office resulted in Mr. Cason placing me on hold and never returning to my call.  Nor has he made any attempt to call me back.

 

I also want to make you are that the State is aware of Mr. Henderson's threats of non-payment and physical threats in 2005 if I did not drop my request to have the State re-evaluate the amount of child support to be paid.  The State is also aware that Mr. Henderson has been active throughout his community including coaching little league baseball and is not disabled as reported.  The State is aware of the denial to have a "change of venue" to the county in which my son and I have resided for many years so that Mr. Henderson may receive preferential treatment through his local, rural county judge (Judge Land) even though I objected to Judge Land residing over the case due to his "personal" relationship with Mr. Henderson in which the judge admitted in court.  And the State is also aware that Judge Land failed to order the amount of child support due my child based on Mr. Henderson's income due to the preferential treatment received in Lafayette County. 

 

Mr. Bush, can you please help me to help support my child?  My child and I are struggling to get by.  Unfortunately for the past year, I've had to work longer hours just to provide for my child.  I do not qualify for assistance through the State such as AFDC or Food Stamps because I do work.  The only help I'm requesting is to enforce the non-custodial parent (William "Bill" Henderson) to help me support my child (which he chooses to ignore even exists).

 

     Thanks, 

    Angela Bush Strickland    

     Dental Underwriter

       FPIC Insurance Group, Inc.

       1000 Riverside Avenue, Suite 800

       Jacksonville, FL 32204

 

       (904) 360-3282 - direct line

       (904) 354-5910 ext. 3282 - main line

Charge: Lewd/Lascivious Battery on Child over 12 YOA but less than16 YOA

 

As Ms. Baker explained, my son served for a year in Baghdad, Iraq with the Fl Army National Guard.  Just after returning home, he became romantically involved in a consensual relationship with a 15 year old girl who he had known for several years.  The young lady’s mother became irate when she discovered the relationship and pressed charges against my son. After two years in the court system, the case was settled with a plea bargain.  He pled no contest and adjudification was withheld.  He received a 10 year suspended sentence with 7 years of Sex Offender probation.  He is now a registered as a Sex Offender, a label which will last his lifetime.

 

My son realizes this relationship was wrong.  He has no excuse for his behavior and is accepts responsibility for his actions.  Sadly, the law today makes no distinction between a true sexual predator, and a young man like my son who let romance lead him to a gross error in judgment.  As I’m sure you understand, the designation as a Sex Offender restricts his ability to get a respectable job, it restricts where he can live, where he can go, and requires Sex Offender counseling for problems he doesn’t have.  It restricts his life to the point that it is very difficult for him to be a productive member of society.  Instead, it sets him up for failure.  

 

I sincerely appreciate the interest that you took in my son’s case.  Your ability to see the human side to situations, and your understanding that legislation doesn’t always turn out the way we planned is clear in the way you have governed.  Thank you so much for offering to begin the process for granting him clemency.  I have attached a complete explanation of the events that occurred, if you have the time, I ask that you please read it.  I know you understand how it feels to have a young adult child in trouble and I truly appreciate your willingness to reach out to us during this time.  Please let me know if you need any other information.  My son and I look forward to talking to Ms. Brennan and again appreciate your help in this matter.  

Sincerely,

I wish to appeal to you on behalf of DANNY ROLLING, who is due to be executed on October 25.  My sympathies go out to the family and loved ones of Christina Powell, Sonja Larson, Christa Hoyt, Manuel Tobada and Tracy Paules, and I agree this was a very tragic event that cannot go unpunished. However, the death penalty—which only serves to create more victims and perpetuate a cycle of violence—is not the right punishment for DANNY ROLLING. 

While these crimes are heinous and inexcusable, the death penalty is not the right choice for Danny Rolling.  Rolling grew up in a dysfunctional household with an abusive father.  Furthermore, he suffered from emotional and psychological problems, as noted in one appellate judge’s opinion of his sentencing.  Rolling pleaded guilty in his 1994 trial, where it was established that at the times of his crimes, he had the emotional maturity of a 15-year-old and that he suffered from extreme emotional disturbance.

Executing DANNY ROLLING would violate the right to life as proclaimed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and constitute the ultimate cruel, inhuman, and degrading punishment.  Please find it in your heart to spare the life of this human being.

From:	celeste gruenstein <celeste@decordirect.net>
Sent:	Thursday, September 28, 2006 3:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Good News Story: Exemplary Florida Citizen & LCDR Deserves Recognition for Humanitarian Acts In Afghanistan

Hello Governor Bush, 

 

I think I came across a story yesterday that you’ll want to know about, if you don’t already. Your trips overseas to visit troops are famous, and both your actions and words show you care deeply about the morale and success of our soldiers.  Well, yesterday I came across a good news story about Floridians among our troops in Afghanistan that need our help. 

 

In the past, I have had the good fortune to be able to participate in the Any Soldier program, where members of the general public can support our troops overseas with letters, supplies, and morale boosters.  But, yesterday I learned about humanitarian requests from one our fellow Floridians and a UF grad (go Gators!), LCDR Sheldon A. Chatman.  LCDR Chatman, who is stationed in Khowst, Afghanistan, has given up the opportunity to request creature comforts on the Any Soldier web site for his own troops’ behalf, and instead is using this platform to request supplies that will serve the humanitarian needs of the community around their base.  

 

Although I’ve never met this sailor, his actions are clearly heroic.  His Florida based group of 20 sailors seem to be on the forefront of being able to single-handedly change perceptions of the Afghan people about America.  My staff and I are already putting together some care packages that he requested to help the local children have shoes in time for winter.  

 

But, this sailor deserves recognition by our State, and the citizens of our great State deserve to hear more stories about exemplary Floridians who are making a difference in the world.  What will be more important to him, I believe, is help with three deathly ill Afghan children that were brought to him for medical assistance.  Although I am also contacting friends who are physicians who may be able to suggest some alternatives, I wanted to send email to you as the Governor, who may be able to bring the power of the State to more quickly address the urgent health needs of these three children.  

 

I’ve never written to any of my elected officials, but this is a good reason to start.  I am more than willing to do anything I can to assist.  I’m thanking you in advance for any advice, leads, or any recognition that you can offer LCDR Sheldon A. Chatman, as an outstanding example of humanitarianism and what being a proud Florida citizen is all about.  

 

Here’s the link to the Any Soldier Site: http://anysoldier.com/WhereToSend/

Search Florida, and you will find the link for: LCDR Sheldon A. Chatman 

 

Very truly yours,

Celeste Gruenstein

(UF Law 1984)

Vice President, Decor Direct, Inc.

881 Freeling Drive

Sarasota, FL 34242

(H) 941-349-1132 

(M) 941-321-8907

You went before the BRAC 2005 Commission with Mayor Peyton with outdated maps and ignored the responsibility of doing your due diligence. I would go as far as to say that you perjured yourself by the extent of your misrepresentation of the true facts regarding the homes, schools, and churches that would be negatively impacted if the jets were to return to Cecil Commerce Center (which you stated was an economic jewel, and is one of Florida’s last megasites to attract big businesses). Your grossly inflated West Florida Impact Study has even been disproved by Virginia’s own economists.

Enough is enough. The last year and a half of my life has been spent standing up for my property rights. I moved into my home in April 2005. In June I found out about your intention to put the East Coast Master jet base in my backyard. Instead of enjoying my new home and my family, my little boy has had to sacrifice a good deal of time with me while I have done extensive research and lobbying to protect our home from your dogged pursuit of political pork.

I know what my rights are. I will pursue legal action with hundreds of others if your plan comes to fruition. Leaving hundreds of lawsuits in your wake will not be how you will want to be remembered when you leave office, I imagine. 

Please let those of us who live around Cecil live in peace. If you only knew how many people you have negatively affected by bringing this upon us. It has been the worst year in many of our lives. Please leave it alone.

 

Sincerely,

 

Elizabeth Lowenthal

Subject:	Walk for Education October 21, 2006

 

September 28, 2006

 

 

Dear Govenor Bush ,

 

Advocates for education in cities and towns around the world will take to the sidewalks, parks, and malls for the 3rd Annual Phi Delta Kappa (PDK) International Walk for Education on Saturday, October 21, 2006 at 7:45 a.m. - 9:30 a.m. The walk covers 2.5 miles. The Walk spotlights international and local educational needs. The event raises money for each school club under the Brevard Future Educators Association and the Phi Delta Kappa Educational Foundation, which is the national parent organization of the Future Educators Association.  

 

The Brevard Future Educators Association would like to take this opportunity to invite you to participate with us in this excellent event in support of our teachers and education.  It would be an honor to have you participate with Our Superintendent, Principals, Teachers, Mayors, Police and Fire Chiefs, Commissioners, City Council Members, students, parents and many other community members as we 'Walk for Education'. 

 

This exciting event will be held at the Viera High School's track on Saturday, October 21, 2006 at 7:45 a.m. - 9:30 a.m.  Please arrive no later than 7:30 a.m. to begin our walk on time.

This premier event is intended to showcase schools, teachers and students around the world, and will coincide with the 2006 Phi Delta Kappa's Summit on Public Education, which also celebrates their 100th anniversary. 

 

It would really be wonderful to have you participate with us.  We anxiously await your response.

 

Sincerely,

-----Original Message-----
From: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Sent: Sun, 3 Sep 2006 2:37 PM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, September 1, 2006


For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDA STUDENTS TAKING SAT AND AP EXAMS

On Tuesday, Education Commissioner John L. Winn joined me in announcing
record numbers of Florida students are taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test
(SAT) and Advanced Placement (AP) exams.  A record-breaking 94,601, or 63
percent, of Florida's 2006 high school graduates took the SAT.
Additionally, Florida saw the greatest increase in public school AP
exam-takers compared to all other states from 2005 to 2006.  Through our
partnership with the College Board and the new reforms in the A++ Plan for
Education, we are preparing students for success during and following high
school.  For more details, please visit www.fldoe.org.


SPACE FLORIDA NAMES PRESIDENT

On Wednesday, I chaired a meeting of the Space Florida Board of Directors
where we named Steve Kohler president of Space Florida.  In a unanimous
vote, the board ratified the selection of Kohler as Space Florida's first
president and charged him with strengthening, diversifying and expanding
Florida's role as a global leader in space and aeronautics.  Steve's
leadership will be a tremendous asset to Space Florida as the organization
leads the state's efforts to continue attracting aerospace businesses that
create quality, high paying jobs for Floridians.  Growing Florida's economy
through the space and aerospace industries is critical to the state's
long-term prosperity.  For more information, please visit
www.spaceflorida.gov.


GOVERNOR BUSH PROMOTES JOBS FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES

On Thursday, I was joined in Jacksonville by area leaders and members of the
First Coast Business Leadership Network to launch a campaign encouraging
employers to recruit and hire qualified individuals with disabilities.
Florida's growing economy and job market should be open to the largest
minority group in our state - persons with disabilities.  By fostering
employment opportunities, we can empower persons with disabilities to live
the American dream. For more information on hiring qualified workers with
disabilities or joining the First Coast Business Leadership Network, visit
www.apd.myflorida.com or www.MyAbilities.org. 


COLLEGE BOARD'S NEW "EXCELerator" PROGRAM APPLAUDED

Also on Thursday, I applauded the College Board's national education reform
efforts to ensure more students graduate from high school ready for college
and the workforce.  The College Board announced that Duval County was
selected as one of the first school districts in the nation to participate
in the innovative "EXCELerator" Schools program.  Through a $16 million
investment from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the College Board will
complement its promising school development efforts in New York with the new
program in 11 high schools in Chicago, Washington, D.C. and Duval County.
Four Duval County schools have been selected to participate, including
Samuel Wolfson, Terry Parker, Sandalwood and Robert E. Lee High Schools. For
more information, please visit, www.myflorida.com or www.collegeboard.com.


ASSISTANCE FOR FLORIDA'S SEVERELY INJURED VETERANS

On Friday, I announced the start of a pilot program which provides the state
with timely veteran contact information from the U.S. Department of Veterans
Affairs (VA), allowing the Florida Department of Veterans' Affairs (FDVA) to
reach out to severely injured servicemembers inbound for treatment at a
Florida-based VA facility.  The program allows VA staff members assigned to
Department of Defense medical facilities to contact injured servicemembers
headed to VA treatment facilities in Florida, and provide an opportunity for
them to authorize contact by FDVA representatives.  For information on FDVA
and benefits offered to Florida veterans, log on to www.FloridaVets.org.


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO ELSE HOFFMANN

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8148


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
       
____________________________________________________________________
Volume 8, Issue 35
Copyright(c) 2006 State of Florida
 
If you would like to change your subscription or unsubscribe, please go to:
http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html


Thank you.

From:	Kester, Robin <rkester@co.pinellas.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 27, 2006 6:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	The nomination of Judge Dorothy Vaccaro to the circuit court bench, 6th Judicial Circuit

Dear Governor Bush:  
 
I am writing in support of County Court Judge Dorothy Vaccaro's nomination to the circuit court bench in the Sixth Judicial Circuit.  I have practiced law in the Sixth Circuit for almost twenty years.  I have known Dorothy, both personally and professionally, for fifteen of those years.  I first met her when she was an Assistant State Attorney and I was an Assistant Public Defender in New Port Richey, Florida, where we regularly worked on opposite sides of the aisle, so to speak.  I found her then and I find her now to be conscientious, clever, dedicated, organized, consistent, and fair.  
 
Dorothy has been a county court judge for over four years and has mastered the job with good humor and grace.  She would be an asset to the circuit court bench just as she currently is to the county court bench.  I cannot speak highly enough about her.  She has personal and professional integrity which is, perhaps, the most important attribute a person can possess.  I recommend her without reservation.  
 
Sincerely,
 
Robin L. Kester
Assistant Public Defender
Pinellas Criminal Justice Center
14250 49th Street, N.
Clearwater, FL  33762
(727) 464-6516

From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, September 27, 2006 4:14 PM
To: Brooks, Charles (Com US)
Subject: RE: Insurance price gouging ?



Thank you for your letter about property insurance.  

 

Insurance is the number one issue facing our state today.  Two unprecedented back-to-back hurricane seasons – with eight hurricanes and four tropical storms – caused $36 billion in insurance claims.  According to the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund, annual insured losses in years without a major storm average $2.8 billion.

 

Predictions of more catastrophic hurricanes making landfall in the U.S. have triggered significant increases in insurance premiums to cover potential future losses.  Many insurance companies have dropped policies and restricted new policies to avoid high risk areas and reduce overall exposure in Florida.  Homeowners who cannot get private insurance have only two options, no insurance or insurance from Citizens Property Insurance Corporation, which has the highest rates in the state.

 

This is a serious situation.  Higher rates and the inability to get private insurance have created a significant hardship for many homeowners and small businesses. Moreover, Florida cannot maintain a robust economy and high quality of life if our state continues to sustain tens of billions of dollars in damage every year.  

 

The key to solving the problem is fortifying Florida against the potential damage of future storms.   Reducing the risk of damage will reduce estimated cost of future disasters, which should stabilize rising insurance premiums.

 

You can take steps today to protect your home and reduce your insurance premium.  Florida requires insurance companies to give a discount on insurance premiums – as much as 44% on your wind policy – for certain improvements that guard against wind damage.  Choosing a higher insurance deductible, either 2% or 5%, can also reduce your premium.  

 

To help homeowners make these improvements, the state is providing $250 million for the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program, a new program to perform free home inspections and provide matching grants to qualified homeowners who harden their homes against wind damage.  Qualified homeowners that make approved improvements to their primary residences may be eligible for reimbursement by the state, dollar-for-dollar up to $5,000.  Qualified low-income homeowners may be eligible for up to $5,000 in improvements without providing any matching funding.  The Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program is managed by the Department of Financial Services.  For information about how to apply for the grant, please visit www.mysafefloridahome.com.     

 

To provide immediate relief to policyholders, the state provided $715 million to Citizens Property Insurance Corporation to offset the company’s deficit and reduce the surcharge assessed on all policyholders – not just those with coverage from Citizens.  Without this funding, your insurance policy would have increased an additional $172.48 for every $1,000 of your insurance premium.

 

To increase the availability of private insurance, the state is providing $250 million for a new Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program to provide matching funds for insurance companies bringing new capital to the market.  This program will enable private insurance companies to underwrite more policies.  

 

On August 8, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings held the first meeting of the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee.  This committee is open to all ideas to bring down the cost of premiums, increase availability of affordable insurance and reduce the risk to homeowners and taxpayers.  If you would like to make a suggestion, please visit www.myfloridainsurancereform.com. 

 

Thank you again for your letter.  I am committed to finding a solution to ease the financial burden that you and many other Florida homeowners are facing with the rising cost and declining availability of insurance.

 

                                                            Sincerely,

 

 

 

                                                            Jeb Bush

 

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Brooks, Charles (Com US) [mailto:brooks.charles@siemens.com]

But, why did my other perils premium go from about $1000.00 to $2600 ???  
 
Is the insurance commission looking into the breakdown of rates ?  I think other peril coverage should not have gone up %150 !   I think the Attorney General should be looking into this issue  !
 
Sincerely,
Charles Brooks

Subject:	CMS Senior Executive Position Opportunity

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

 

 

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush, Governor of Florida

  

Medicaid Commission

200 Independence Ave., SW

Suite 450G

Washington, DC 20201

 

Dear Governor Jeb Bush:

 

The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is currently recruiting for the Medicaid Integrity Group Director, a Senior Executive Service position.  The Director will provide executive leadership and direction in the implementation and administration of the Medicaid Integrity Program which will have a far reaching impact upon States’ Medicaid financial responsibilities.  

 

We are looking for a senior-level executive to serve in this position as a key member of CMS’ executive management team.  The Director will serve as a strategic partner with the Secretary, White House staff, and other key department, government, and state officials to collaborate on sensitive issues with national impact on the fiscal integrity of the Medicaid program and the quality of services provided to beneficiaries.  

 

Please assist us in reaching qualified professionals interested in a challenging and rewarding career opportunity with CMS by distributing and/or posting the attached job announcement.  Additional information regarding employment in the Senior Executive Service can be located on the U.S. Office of Personnel Management’s website at:  http://www.usajobs.opm.gov/ei30.asp

If you have any questions, please contact me at 410-786-5554 (TDD: 410-786-0727).

Subject:	Surplus equipment

Wednesday, September 27, 2006

 

 

Greetings!

 

            My name is jeffrie vinson and I am the computer lab manager for Goodwill Industries here in Tallahassee. Here at Goodwill, we have a computer lab where, free of charge, people from the community can come to learn basic computer skills as well as some of the more popular software applications used by businesses in the area. Our goal is to help people better their job skills so that they might have a chance of finding employment or bettering their social standing by becoming productive members of society.

 

            Soon we will begin to offer a 4-month course that covers everything from how to dress for a job interview to computer skills and software applications. This, of course, brings me to the reason behind this letter…

 

            Currently we are in need of surplus computers. Fortunately, for us, the lab here in Tallahassee is in a better situation than most of the other Goodwill Industries computer labs in the state. Right now, most of our machines are under 5 years old and I would consider adequate for the type of work for which they are needed. Unfortunately, though, we still are in need of at least five more machines that are capable of running Windows XP so that we can fully furnish our classrooms. I would like to stress that these machines are for students of the free computer courses that we offer and would NOT be resold or given away to staff!

Subject:	Hispanic Heritage Essay Contest

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am not sure whether or not you will actually receive this but if this gets anywhere close to someone in a position of authority, I will be satisfied.  I am writing because, my daughter Chalisse Morse, a senior at Freedom High School in Tampa, worked very hard on an essay for consideration for the Hispanic Heritage Scholarship contest.  Since it is such a wonderful scholarship opportunity I personally stayed on top of her to make sure she completed the essay and submitted it on time.  

 

She originally submitted her essay via email the day before the deadline and the next day received an email back stating that the essay needed to either be in Word or Rich Text format.  We weren't sure why we got the email back considering that the essay was written in Word.  I also personally typed and electronically signed off on the parental waiver.  I did this in Word too.   When Chalisse told me about the email that she received back, I told her there must have been an error in transmission and to resubmit and to make sure she was very careful about attaching the documents.  This all happened late the night before the deadline but she still resubmitted before the deadline.

 

The next morning, I began to think about the essay and the email she got back about it being in the right format and I told her, just to be sure that the document is received and readable to cut and paste the essay and the consent form into the body of the email with an explanation about why she was sending it again.  She did this.  We didn't hear anything back.

 

On Friday of last week, something told me to call the Scholarship Coordinator, Nadia Helberger, to make sure that she had, in fact, received all 3 of the submissions.  Ms. Helberger told me she did receive all three but that the first two were not readable because they came through as a "zip" file and that they are not allowed to open "zip" files and that it would have to be submitted in either Word or Rich text.  I explained to her what happened, that the essay was written in Word and that I personally typed the parental consent form in a Word document and that was the format that the first two submissions were made.  I told her that neither of us attached a "zip" file and that my best guess is that by sending it via AOL, perhaps AOL, "zips" the file but we would have no way of knowing that since all we did was attach both Word documents to the email.  I told her that I don’t even have anything that zips files and that I have never zipped a file before. I also told her that I had Chalisse resubmit the essay and consent form into the body of the email because the next morning I found myself concerned that there may have been another transmission error.  I assured her that we were tried to do everything that we could to make sure that we met the deadline and the fact that she submitted the essay three times was proof that she was trying to get it submitted in the correct format and on time.  I also reiterated that we had no way of knowing that the file was getting “zipped” because she simply tried to attach Word documents.  Ms. Helberger notified me that since the final submission, which was readable, was received the following morning that she would not be able to consider the essay at all.  I asked if there is someone with whom I could speak that I could appeal the decision.  She told me no.  She was very polite and nice but  I really feel like this warrants additional consideration.

 

Mr. Bush, I understand about meeting the deadlines, and she DID try.  The fact that she submitted the essay and consent form, two times prior to the deadline and hours after the deadline shows that she was trying.  We would have never even known that the second submission was unacceptable if I hadn’t called.  I am not trying to get special consideration, just a fair shot for my daughter who worked very hard on this essay.  Whether or not she is the selected winner is less of an issue for me at this point than the fact that she can’t even be considered.    I think that there should be another person who weighs in on the final decision especially because it is a scholarship opportunity of such a great magnitude!

 

Having learned my lesson, I am also including her essay into the body of this email.  Please have someone on your team at least reconsider the decision not to allow her essay into consideration.  Thank you in advance for the opportunity to raise this issue.

 

Sincerely,

 

Khadeeja Morse

813 361-8200

 

Chalisse Morse

9548 Pebble Glen Ave

Tampa, Fl 33647

(813) 361-8200 or (813) 361-8840

Freedom High School, 12th

 

The Importance of the Hispanic Culture in Florida

 

Why is learning about Florida’s diverse Hispanic heritage and culture important?  It’s important because the Hispanic story is our story, the American story.  Hispanic heritage and culture can be seen, felt, heard and experienced all across the country and especially in Florida. Without it, the United States and especially Florida wouldn’t resemble all that we have come to know and love.  

 

Without Hispanic heritage and influence, many things we take for granted might be very different.  From the places we live, to the food we eat, to the way we celebrate and have a good time!  Let’s imagine it... 

 

Imagine living in a state with a different name.  Florida may not have been called Florida, if Ponce De Leon hadn’t named the land for the Spanish term for Easter.  He did this since it was the first land he saw during the Easter season.  We would notice the difference in our city names too.  It’s hard to imagine cities like St. Augustine, Pensacola, Sanibel and the wonderful Ybor City with different names.  

 

Can you imagine not knowing about foods like tacos or empanadas?  How about not knowing about wonderful desserts like honey drenched sopaillas or creamy flan? 

 

Imagine not having a great time at a Cinco de Mayo celebration or not catching beads at the Gasparilla parade.  What would children’s parties be without the fun of a piñata just waiting to be burst open? 

 

What would reruns of “I Love Lucy” be like without the rumba sound of Ricky’s band?  From Tejano music made popular by Selena, to Caribbean soul sung by Gloria Estafan to the smooth pop sounds of Carlos Santana. We have all enjoyed music that is rich in Hispanic heritage and culture.  We have enjoyed listening to these sounds while doing dances like the Conga, the Tango, the Lambada and the Macarena.  

 

How about missing out on outstanding athletes like Tino Martinez or soccer legend Pele?  Pele’s influence can be felt all across Florida every weekend as soccer parents sit on the sidelines cheering on their future “Pele”s.  

 

Imagine not hearing our fusion of English and Spanish words in everyday conversations.  Imagine conversations without phrases like “hola, chica and chico, rapido, que pasa, un momento, comprende”.    

 

As if all of these things were not enough, imagine not learning the valuable lesson that the Hispanic heritage and culture teaches.  The lesson that despite the fact that people of Hispanics descent come in all colors, races, religions, and locations, they are all still embraced as one. What an incredible message about valuing each member for their unique contribution to a beautiful mosaic of heritage and culture based on unity and love.  

I don’t want to even try to imagine that!  

 

Like I said earlier, the Hispanic story is our story.  That’s why it’s so hard to imagine life without the wonderful influences of Hispanic culture and heritage.

From:	valencic_r@firn.edu
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 6:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] notary public office complaint

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am writing to you since I seem unable to make telephone contact or have a call returned by your notary public office. To say that I am unhappy with this program office would be an understatement.

 

Last month I filed a complaint with the notary office, provided them with the necessary documentation, and even researched the statute referencing what had been done wrong and where it violated the statute. 

 

Your notary section has not done anything to the violator except issue a slap on the wrist in the form of a written reprimand for actions that the statute clearly states constitutes a third degree felony. The referenced section of the law is Section 117.105, Florida Statutes. 

 

Your office has chosen to issue a reprimand when the called for action on the part of your office by statute would be prosecution for the felony. In the letter of reprimand it clearly states that the notary in question, Alan Lindsay, The letter acknowledges the failure to legally take an acknowledgement of a written instrument as a notary public and further acknowledges that what he did was the false or fraudulent taking of an acknowledgement. Mr. Lindsay did not do this just once, but three times he falsified a document.

 

What Mr. Lindsay did falls under the purview of Section 117.105, Florida Statutes, and this section does not state the responsible party may or might be guilty of a felony, but clearly states that they are guilty of a third degree felony. The statute does not allow room for mistakes.

 

Even worse in his response to your office it is obvious that Mr. Lindsay’s entire written demeanor is flippant and cavalier. 

 

Governor Bush, I believe that there is something that truly stinks about this resolution as any of the many people I know who are notaries have told me that they would expect to loose their license and quite possibly be prosecuted for this type of action and failure. Yet, all Mr. Lindsay receives is a slap on the wrist reprimand? I do not believe it is within the purview of your office to pick and choose, which sections of law apply, but I do believe that it is your responsibility as governor to enforce the laws. Therefore, I am requesting that this matter be brought before the Palm Beach County State Attorney for prosecution of the violations of law as is required by the law. 

 

 

Ralph Felix Valencic, Jr.

1122 Rosewood Drive

Tallahassee, Florida 32301

850-878-2711

850-933-1644

Valencic_r@firn.edu

 

From:	Paul Edward <paulpcb@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 3:34 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	fhp@hsmv.state.fl.us; executivedirector@hsmv.state.fl.us
Subject:	Trooper R. A. McSwiney

Honorable Governor Jeb Bush,
 
I am a Citizen of the Great State of Florida. I personally campaigned for and voted for President Reagan; for your Father, for "W" and you, Sir! I am a die-hard Republican and I would give my life for my Country now, tomorrow or whenever I am needed. I am a 100% Disable Combat Vietnam Veteran; also I am a Non-Denominational Minister with a Doctorate's in Divinity. Also, I have two PhDs; Counseling; Drug and Alcohol and am finishing up a 3rd in Psychiatry.
 
I would not normally make a complaint to my State Government, especially about a Law Enforcement Official, however, I feel this instance warrant's reporting. On 7/24/2006, I was driving east on Thomas Drive to a medical appointment at the Panama City VA Outpatient Center. At 9:27 A.M. I was stopped by State Trooper R.A. McSwiney, Badge 944, ID#2329, Troop Unit A. My citation number is 3751-SFX.
 
I pulled over and stopped; Trooper McSwiney came up, I let down my window and ask was there a problem? In a very belligerent voice, he responded "you bet your ass there is a problem....your were speeding"! I asked "Sir"? He blared out "you were doing 50 in a 35"! Again, I asked "Sir"? He replied, "you heard what I said"! He then asked for my driver's license, registration and proof of insurance.  I commenced to get the documents out and stated " I was not doing 50MPH, my cruise control was set at 40 MPH". He snapped back "that's a lie!" I said "no Sir I was doing 40; can't you give me a warning ticket for only 5MPH over the speed limit". The Trooper snapped back sarcastically "I don't give warning tickets"! I advised I will be late for my appointment at the VA Outpatient Clinic and he replied "well now that's your problem not mine"! I handed the Trooper my registration and proof of insurance, and advise "my driver's license is at home on my printer; I had to make a copy to send and forgot to put it back in my wallet". He took what I gave him and stated, "I'll be right back, you better not go no where"!
 
The Trooper came back to my car and stated, "you have two citations, one for speeding 50 in a 35; and one for driving without a license. You can take the license ticket and your license by the Clerk of Court and that will take care of that ticket". He then gave me a pamphlet and stated "send your fine in this envelope to take care of the speeding ticket"! I advised "I am going to Court Sir, because I was not doing 50 MPH". That appeared to anger the Trooper. He stated, "you just as well go ahead and pay your fine, it won't do you any good to go to court!. I stated, we I am, it's not right to be ticketed for something I was not doing" 
 
The Trooper then angrily demanded, "sign here on both the tickets"; pointing to the bottom line where his signature was at. I stated, "Sir I have never been required to sign for a ticket in my life; there is nothing requiring me to "sign for these tickets"! At that point, the Trooper backed a couple of steps away from my vehicle and placed his hand on his weapon and shouted, "I am requiring you to sign them; now you either sign the tickets or I am going to put your ass in jail!" I stated "If I did not have my VA Doctor's appointment, you could take me to jail, but under the circumstances, however illegal, I don't have any choice, do I"?. He yelled, "you can bet your ass, I'll lock you up if you don't"! I suggested to the Trooper that if hates his job that much, he might consider another line of work, because he certainly does not have any patience, communication skills, respect for and certainly does not work well with the public. At that point he grumbled something and returned to his vehicle and I continued on to my Doctor's appointment. I was 15 minutes late; however my Doctor was running behind and she was able to see me about the time I walked in the Clinic.
 
I respectfully request that Trooper McSwiney be reprimanded for his belligerent attitude and conduct. He is a public servant, not a vigilante and his badge should not give him the right to abuse me, intimidate me, hassle me, threaten me, curse at me and treat me as if I were a common criminal.
 
Respectfully,
 
Dr. Paul E. Webster, PhDs, DD

Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my concerns about illegal aliens in Florida and for that matter America. Last year while working Hurricane claims in Miami, I was shocked to find that I was not in America at all. From the billboards, to the street signs, to the person checking me out at a grocery store everything was in Spanish. I thought that I lived in America. I truly felt like a minority.

I am the daughter of a deceased Colonel in the Air Force. He fought for our freedom, and taught me first hand what a privilege it was to be from a country like America. I have lived and visited many countries all over the world and know firsthand what a privilege to be American. Now I go to a city in America, and it’s as if I’m visiting another country. I don’t know of any other country where you make a phone call and they ask you to dial 1 to have the conversation in English. I don’t know of another country where Americans get free health care – even if I came into their country illegally.

I am concerned about the state of our country if we continue to allow the Aliens to mandate such changes. This is America, English is our language, and we Americans have to follow the laws that “we the people vote for” – they should as well. Send anyone that has not entered the country through legal means back to where they came from. Do not allow immunity for anyone who is here illegally. Send them home. Stop accommodating them – speak English only! 

Below was in an email that I received and I had to wonder how different it was here???? 

 

“Illegal Immigrants: Equal Medical Care Or Better Medical Care? -- by Bryanna Bevens , military wife 

"As I mentioned in a previous column, I am hugely fat pregnant right now 
(by the time this is published I may have had the little critter.hopefully) so I have baby issues on the brain. 

 

"Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas, Texas is a fairly famous institution and for a variety of reasons: 

 

1. John F. Kennedy died there in 1963 
2. Lee Harvey Oswald died there shortly after 
3. Jack Ruby-who killed Lee Harvey Oswald, died there a few years later..by coincidence 

 

"On the flip side, Parkland is also home to the second busiest maternity ward in the country with almost 16,000 new babies arriving each year. (That's almost 44 per day---every day) 

 

'"A recent patient survey indicated that 70 percent of the women who gave birth at Parkland in the first three months of 2006 were illegal immigrants.' Crikey, that's 11,200 anchor babies born every year .just in Dallas. According to the article, the hospital spent $70.7 million delivering 15,938 babies in 2004 but managed to end up with almost $8 million dollars in surplus funding. Medicaid kicked in $34.5 million, Dallas County taxpayers kicked in $31.3 million and the feds tossed in another $9.5 million. 

 

"'The average patient in Parkland's maternity wards is 25 years old, married and giving birth to her second child.' She is also an illegal immigrant. By law, pregnant women cannot be denied medical care based on their immigration status or ability to pay. OK, fine. That doesn't mean they should receive better care than everyday, middle-class American citizens. But at Parkland Hospital, they do. 

 

"Parkland Memorial Hospital has nine prenatal clinics. NINE. 

 

"The Dallas Morning News article followed a Hispanic woman who was a patient at one of the clinics and pregnant with her third child---her previous two were also born at Parkland. Her first two deliveries were free and the Mexican native was grateful because it would have cost $200 to have them in Mexico. This time, the hospital wants her to pay $10 per visit and $100 for the delivery but she was unsure if she could come up with the money. Not that it matters, the hospital won't turn her away. (I wonder why they even bother asking at this point.) 

 

"How long has this been going on? What are the long-term affects? 

 

"Well, another subject of the article was born at Parkland in 1986 shortly after her mother entered the U.S. illegally---now she is having her own child there as well. (That's right, she's technically a U.S. citizen.) These women receive free prenatal care including medication, nutrition, birthing classes and child care classes. They also get freebies such as car seats, bottles, diapers and formula. 

 

"Most of these things are available to American citizens as well but only for low-income applicants and even then, the red tape involved is almost insurmountable. 

 

"Because these women are illegal immigrants they do not have to provide any sort of legitimate identification---no proof of income. An American citizen would have to provide a social security number which would reveal their annual income---an illegal immigrant need only claim to be poor and the hospital must take them at their word. 

 

"My husband is a pilot for the United States Navy 
(yes, he fought in Iraq) and while the health care is good, we Navy wives don't get any of these perks! "Car seats? Diapers? Not so much. "So my question is this: Does our public medical care system treat illegal immigrants better than American citizens? Yes it does! 

 

"As I mentioned, the care I have received is perfectly adequate but it's bare bones, meat and potato medical care---not top of line. 

 

"Their (the illegals) medical care is free---simply because they are illegal immigrants? Once again, there is no way to verify their income. 

 

"Parkland Hospital offers indigent care to Dallas County residents who earn less than $40,000 per year. (They also have to prove that they did not refuse health coverage at their current job Yeah, the 'free' care is not so easy for Americans.) 

 

"There are about 140 patients who received roughly $4 million dollars for un-reimbursed medical care. As it turns out, they did not qualify for free treatment because they resided outside of Dallas County. So the hospital is going to sue them! Illegals get it all free! But U.S. citizens who live outside of Dallas County get sued! How stupid is this? 

 

"As if that isn't annoying enough, the illegal immigrant patients are actually complaining about hospital staff not speaking Spanish. In this AP story, the author speaks with a woman who is upset that she had to translate comments from the hospital staff into Spanish for her husband. The doctor was trying to explain the situation to the family and the mother was forced to translate for her husband who only spoke Spanish. This was apparently a great injustice to her. 

 

"In an attempt to create a Spanish-speaking staff, Parkland Hospital is now providing incentives in the form of extra pay for applicants who speak Spanish. Additionally, medical students at the University of Texas Southwestern for which Parkland Hospital is the training facility will now have a Spanish language requirement added to their already jammed-packed curriculum. No other school in the country boasts such a ridiculous multi-semester (multicultural) requirement. 

 

"In the meantime, I have to end my column here. I have to go buy a car seat." 

 

(Ed: Sorry for the length, but this needs wide circulation----particularly to our "employees" in the Congress.) 

 

Quote of the Day 

 

"Once the coffers of the federal government are opened to the public*, there will be no shutting them again." -Grover Cleveland

 

Thank you for your time and consideration,

 

 

Teresa Bergh

1521 Valparaiso Blvd.

Niceville, FL 32578

 (850) 685-4561 cell

9901 Foxboro Rd.

September 25, 2006
 
 
 
Governor Bush:
 
It has been over a year since I contacted your Haitian recovery office. At that time I did not realize that the temporary government would not or could not commit to long term agreement. This year we have been working with the elected government and they have embraced our long term recovery plan for an aggregate, crushing plant on the West coast of Haiti including a port, a block plan and construction company to bid on road projects. We have also given them a plan to revive the Autoboite Valley for growing of grain to feed the people and start a livestock industry in the same area.
 
The problem is the investment money for Haiti has dried up. The only investment money that we have found in the last year is one that wants 30% money up front and control of the company. I had a conversation with one of the largest mining companies in the South east last week and was told not one dime for Haiti but they will buy our material if we could put the project together. I had not presented our plan offshore until last week. I got a response today that there was no money to be had for Haiti.
 
Over a five year time there will be forty to fifty-million dollars invested in Haiti. After the first two years the project will support most of this investment.
 
Governor, I know at one time you where very interested in Haitian recovery. We have now spent over two years and have run out of options. We need 1.5 Million dollars to start the project and to carry it for two years. The Haitian government is waiting on us to notified them that we are ready to start. If you have any suggestions they would be appreciated.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Louis J. Stephens
479-629-6880
ljsfs@aol.com

> FOURTH ANNUAL HISPANIC HERITAGE MONTH UNDERWAY
>
> Last Friday, First Lady Columba Bush and I encouraged Floridians to
> participate in the fourth annual statewide Hispanic Heritage Month that
> runs
> through October 15. A schedule of events are lined up and designed to pay
> tribute to Florida's Hispanic culture. The theme for this year's Florida's
> Hispanic Heritage Month celebration is "La Florida: Honoring Our State's
> Spanish and Latin American Influences".  Columba and I are proud to
> celebrate the achievements and contributions of our state's
> Spanish-speaking
> cultures and communities with Floridians across the state.  As we embrace
> Florida's diversity, I hope future generations of Floridians will become
> inspired to honor and embrace our state's rich heritage.  For a list of
> events and more information on Florida Hispanic Heritage Month, please
> visit
> www.floridahispanicheritage.com.
>
>
> 12 FLORIDA BUSINESSES RECEIVE DIVERSIFICATION AWARDS
>
> On Monday, I honored 12 Florida companies at the Governor's Business
> Diversification Awards banquet, held at the Governor's Mansion in
> Tallahassee.  The awards program, developed by Enterprise Florida,
> Inc.(EFI), recognizes companies for their efforts to diversify and enrich
> the state's economy by creating high-wage jobs and investing in their
> communities. The ceremony kicked off Florida's 22nd Annual Industry
> Appreciation Week, created to spotlight excellence in Florida's business
> community.  I have committed to the people of Florida to build policies
> and
> programs that stimulate the growth of a stronger, more diversified
> economy,
> and that offer a higher quality of life.  I am proud to recognize the
> companies and organizations that create high-value jobs and invest their
> resources to build better communities throughout the state.  For more
> information on business diversification and a list of business receiving
> awards, please visit www.eflorida.com.
>
>
> "FORTIFY FLORIDA!" BRINGS PREPAREDNESS HOME TO PENSACOLA
>
> On Tuesday, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings, Chief Financial Officer Tom
> Gallagher, Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty, Gulf Power President
> Susan
> Story and Escambia County Commission Chairman Mike Whitehead announced
> Fortify Florida: Pensacola Prepares!, the second in a series of town fairs
> around the state to provide homeowners with a one-stop-shop of information
> about hardening their homes against hurricanes and reducing their
> insurance
> premium.  The town fair is scheduled for Saturday, September 30th from 10
> am
> to 4 pm at the Pensacola Civic Center.  Insurance companies, home
> improvement stores, emergency managers, non-profit organizations and other
> government and private-sector partners are participating in the town
> fairs,
> which are free and open to the public.  Fortifying Florida is essential
> for
> instilling a 'culture of preparedness'.  For information on creating a
> Family Disaster Preparedness Plan, please visit www.floridadisaster.org.
>
>
> SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION CONFERENCE HELD IN ORLANDO
>
> On Wednesday, First Lady Columba Bush, Director of the Florida Office of
> Drug Control Bill Janes and I kicked off a three-day conference for drug
> prevention leaders, community-based prevention organizations, law
> enforcement officials and students at the 2006 Florida Statewide Substance
> Abuse Prevention Conference in Orlando.  Prevention is the key to reducing
> substance abuse among Florida's youth.  This annual conference provides
> local leaders and students with the knowledge and tools necessary to build
> safer, healthier communities for Florida's families.  According to the
> 2005
> Florida Youth Substance Abuse Survey, drug use in Florida is declining.
> Compared to 2000, the survey showed a 45 percent drop in tobacco use, a 66
> percent drop in heroin use and a 47 percent drop in heroin and crack
> cocaine
> use.  For more information on Florida's Drug Control strategy, please
> visit
> www.flgov.com/drug_control/.

From:	José Geraldo R. de Alckmin Filho <odi@apoiocom.com.br>
Sent:	Monday, September 25, 2006 10:47 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Produção de  Álcool no Brasil / Alcohol's Production in Brazil
Attachments:	"AVG certification"

Prezado Sr. Bush
 
 
Eu sou engenheiro mecânico, trabalhei como pesquisador no projeto do desenvolvimento do motor à álcool , aqui no Brasil nos anos 1970's e começo do 1980's, dentro do Instituto de Pesquisas Tecnológicas do Estado de São Paulo - IPT .
 
Há certos dados que gostaria de levar para aqueles que querem produzir combustíveis a partir da biomassa, como é o caso dos Estados Unidos
 
1.- Hoje com a tecnologia que a SASOL da África do Sul desenvolveu nos últimos 50 anos (e que atualmente se associou à CHEVRON dos Estados Unidos ), é mais produtivo  produzir álcool metílico a partir da madeira ( se produz oito vezes mais álcool a partir da madeira do que a partir da cana de açúcar, considerando a mesma massa de madeira e de cana);
 
2.- Com essa mesma tecnologia da SASOL, se produz 120 litros de álcool METÍLICO por tonelada métrica de bagaço de cana, enquanto se produz usualmente menos de 100 litros  de álcool ETÍLICO  por tonelada de cana. Esse aumento de produtividade se dá devido ao processo FISCHER-TROPSCH, de produção de combustíveis a partir de biomassa, ao invés do processo tradicional de fermentação e destilação que é o processo atualmente utilizado no Brasil;
 
3.- Considerando que graças às condições geo-climáticas do Brasil a taxa de crescimento florestal é de 50 (cinquenta) toneladas de madeira, por hectare , por ano, a produção de álcool de madeira é 4 (quatro) vezes maior em relação a produção do álcool de cana (utilizando o processo FISCHER-TROPSCH);
 
4.- O Processo FISCHER-TROPSH permite também a produção de combustíveis (gás de cozinha, gás industrial, gasolina, óleo diesel e querosene) e lubrificantes sintéticos (óleos e graxas), todos eles a partir da madeira. Segundo estudos teóricos , para cada tonelada métrica de madeira se produz : 18 % de óleo diesel; 42 % de gasolina; 10 % de óleo lubrificante; 15 % de querosene; 15 % de gases industriais e graxas.
 
Se os investidores dos Estados Unidos pretenderem investir aqui no Brasil na produção de combustíveis a partir da biomassa, sugiro que façam um estudo juntamente com a SASOL / CHEVRON, visando otimizar a produção de combustíveis por unidade de área plantada.
 
Atenciosamente
 
Eng.º José Geraldo R. de A. Filho 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Mr. Bush
 
 
 
I'm mechanical engineer, 55 years old, and I was a former  researcher  of the project to development of alcohol's fueled engines,here in Brazil, in the 1970's  and begining of 1980's , in the "Instituto de Pesquisas Tecnológicas do Estado de São Paulo - IPT".
 
There are some data I wish that people who wants produce fuels from biomass, just as the case of USA .
 
1.- Nowadays with South African SASOL's technology developed at last 50 years ( see SASOL / CHEVRON partnership in USA), is more profitable to make METHYL ALCOHOL from wood ( eight more times alcohol than sugar cane, for the same original mass);
 
2.- With the same SASOL's technology it produces 120 liters of METHYL ALCOHOL, for one metric ton of sugar cane bagass, while usually we can produce circa of 100 liters of ETHYL ALCOHOL. This alcohol's amount increase is obtained by FISCHER-TROPSCH process , that is diferent of the traditional process of fermentation and destilation of sugar cane molasses;
 
3.- With Brazilian geo-climatics conditions, the growing forestry rate per year , per hectare, is 50 metric tons. On this way the METHYL ALCOHOL's production (by FISCHER-TROPSCH) is 4 ( four) times larger than ETHYL ALCOHOL obtained by traditional process from sugar cane , considering the same area;
 
4.-  Also from FISCHER-TROPSCH process it obtains fuels and lubricants like gasoline, kerosene, diesel oil, waxes, greases, etc,  all them from woods. Theorycally from 1 (one) metric ton of wood we can have : 18 % diesel oil ; 42 % gasoline; 15 % kerosene; 15 % gases and greases.
 
If american investors pretend put their money here in Brazil to produce fuels from biomass origins, I suggest you to make a study with SASOL/CHEVRON, seeing to optmize fuel 's production  by area unity.
 
Att.
 
Eng.º José Geraldo R. de A. Filho

From:	Suehospice@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, September 24, 2006 6:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... REQUEST

Hi!  Next week, could you please mention that October 1-7 is Mental Illness Awareness Week in the newsletter?  Severe mental illnesses are biological brain disorders, and are not the fault of either the individual or the family.  They affect nearly one million Floridians, most of whom suffer from lack of good treatment, discrimination, and fear over what is happening to them.  They live lives of shattered dreams, poverty, and often homelessness, yet many who receive the health care and support they need are great members of their communities, and often the best volunteers for community projects.  Mentioning the week will continue our efforts to bring more public awareness to these illnesses.  Thanks in advance, Sue
 
"We cannot do everything at once, but we must do something at once." Anonymous

Dr. Susanne F. Homant
Executive Director
NAMI Florida
911 West Park Avenue
Tallahassee, FL 32312
850-671-4445
(Fax: 850-671-5272)

The “Signature Place” development in downtown St. Petersburg will be the tallest building in Pinellas County at 35 floors and is the largest private construction project in Tampa Bay’s history at $150 million dollars.  It is being designed by a world famous architect, Ralph Johnson.  The project was featured in the Wall Street Journal and in 244 newspapers around the U.S. and even in the China Post for its stunning design.  The project marks the renaissance of St. Petersburg, we have asked Mr. Crist’s to join us also since Signature is in his home turf.  Mr. Crist is familiar with the Signature Place project as it is located next to his residence at Bayfront Tower. In November 2003, I wrote you and your office and your sectary informed me to apply for a clemency hearing. I still have not heard any answer to when a hearing will be held. Now I am 35 years old and my 3 children are entering into their teen years. I have went to all the branches of the military to try make a better life for myself and my kids. I have been told that now the rules have been changed and I could get in if I could get the clemency up till I am 40 years of age. 
All I am asking is for at least a hearing before you and the board to plea my case and to have the chance to fight for my country as my father did in Viet Nam and to continue to serve my community in the best ways I know how. My father has even tried to get me into county jobs (corrections officer, animal services, park ranger etc...) and I have been turned away for the very same reasons as every where else. My 12 year old record. 
Sir, I understand that I was at fault for my actions but I am still an American and can't stand by and watch from the side as my countrymen and women are fighting for freedom. 
Thank you for your time. 
Sincerely, 
David A. Rios

From:	Marvin <drmarvin@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Saturday, September 23, 2006 11:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Broward

Dear Governor Bush,

 

My son, Victor Manuel Silverman, is one of the many applicants for the Broward School Board District 1 interim appointment, and he is one of the few who actually live in District 1 and have children in District 1 schools. I have taken the liberty of writing to you to tell you a little bit about Victor.

 

I adopted Victor from Santiago, Dominican Republic in 1984 when he was 8 years old, and he is one of 3 children I adopted internationally. I also have volunteered for 25 years and serve as Adoption Program Director for Universal Aid For Children, an international non-profit adoption agency in Broward from which I adopted my children. Victor resided in a one room shack with a dirt floor and no plumbing or refrigeration in the Dominican Republic. He attended a school there that had no electric. Upon his arrival here, he entered what, back then, was called English as a Second Language (ESOL) in Broward Schools. At that young age he experienced a change of cultures, separation from family members, and language issues.

 

As the years passed, he progressed rapidly, became a naturalized citizen, and maintained pride in his heritage as well as his new country. Shortly after reaching adulthood, he entered the US Army and served for 6 years in the 82nd Airborne, and two of his three children were born at Fort Bragg. Then he returned to Florida and worked in the Security field. 

 

Because Victor’s oldest daughter, Isabel, age 9, has a language disorder and learning disability, he has seen the frustrations parents go through in trying to get ESE services for their child in a timely and competent manner. Consequently, I suggested that he start getting involved in parent advocacy.  

 

Victor, as a man of 30 years old now, is an excellent and hard working father. I am very proud of my son and my grandchildren. Victor is a true representation of the people who live in District 1. His is Latino and bilingual (he was also a certified Army linguist in Spanish). He was also raised by a Jewish family. Both backgrounds truly reflect the diversity of District 1. Although he is a Republican, he is the type of person that people in both parties can accept. He is non-political, will not run for the office, people now respect young men who have served their country in uniform, he lives in the District, and he has children in the District’s schools. 

 

Victor also has a good support system around him. I understand you have been sent emails from a leading Latino Republican leader in Broward and a well-respected education advocate and President of a state-wide education reform group who supported school choice and FCAT. I am a licensed School Psychologist, former guidance counselor, and former member of the Broward Schools District Advisory Committee, and other committees as well. I know several board members quite well. One of the current School Board members was friends with my kids growing up and we traveled with her family and the kids would spend nights and time at each other’s homes. The non-elected support people around him, including a member of the Audit committee, will be able to review the meeting packets with him, and make sure that he gets a quick orientation so that he can adequately represent his community, even if it is just for a matter of weeks.

 

Although ethnicity should not part of the criteria for selecting a Board member, the community knows that there has not been a Latino on the Broward School Board in many years, and there is no Latino running for School Board in any Broward district this year. So whether it is Victor or one of the other Latino applicants, it would be a nice gesture, particularly for the pride of the Latino students in Broward’s schools.

 

Thank you.

 

Sincerely,

 

Dr. Marvin Silverman

Dear Governor Bush:

Please spare the life of Danny Rolling despite the seriousness of the accused 
crime.  Cancelling the execution and commuting the sentence to 
imprisonment would show humane consideration and civilized governance.  
New evidence and questions about proceedings may appear long after judicial 
decisions have occurred.

There are possibilities of mistaken identities, coerced confessions, inaccurate 
accusations, and wrongful dispute and judicial proceedings.  State killing works 
against dignified authority of state governance.  There are many arguments that 
state killing violates the constitutional prohibition of cruel and unusual 
punishment.  More than one hundred nations have abolished the death penalty.

Sincerely,

Martha L. Reiner
Coral Gables, Florida

From:	harrylsoule@cfl.rr.com
Sent:	Saturday, September 23, 2006 1:54 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Proper relief or pardon

Subject: appropriate steps for proper relief or pardon

 

Governor Jeb Bush,

 

I have recently been denied employment by the Department of Justice Bureau of Prisons.  The reason for denial of employment was because of a 3rd degree felony arrest for burglary of an unoccupied structure on my record while I was in High School in 1991.  At that time, I had never been in trouble before and qualified for a state diversionary program known as Pre-Trial Intervention.  The case never went to court, I was never prosecuted and one charge was dropped and the other administratively dismissed after completing the program.  Since that time I have never been in trouble and I went on to join the United States Marine Corps from 1994-1998 in which I held a secret security clearance.  I was honorably discharged in 1998 after completing my four year enlistment.  I have been married now for 8 years and am attending FMU, pursuing a degree in Criminal Justice; building on my military experience.  I have come across certain situations in which I have been denied employment because of the aforementioned arrest record particularly in the criminal justice field, even though it never went to trial.  I have heard that I may be considered for employment only after being granted the proper relief or pardon for the incident in question which occurred fifteen years ago.  My question to you Governor Jeb Bush, is there a system in place, do I qualify, and how do I go about taking the appropriate steps?  I believe I would be a great asset in the field of criminal justice and that my arrest record does not represent who I am today.

 

Thank You,

Harry Louis Soule 

[REDACTED]

7444 Crooked Lake Circle

Orlando Fl 32818

harrylsoule@cfl.rr.com

From:	Sean Hogan <hogan@clearwire.net>
Sent:	Saturday, September 23, 2006 9:57 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thank you

Dear Gov. Bush,

I just wanted to say thank you for all that you have done for our state
during your years as Governor.  I know many times the job you do is
thankless and requires long hours, but I hope you have seen how many of your
initiatives have been put into action and are doing great things for our
citizens.

As a native Floridian, I am biased in believing that our state is one of the
greatest in the Union.  My husband (who is under your command as a National
Guard officer and pilot) and I have lived in several other states and can
honestly say that we chose to remain in Florida for it's educational
opportunities for our children as well as the job opportunities for my
husband.  He is an active duty pilot with the RAID program out of
Jacksonville and I am a stay at home mom raising our four children.  During
your time as Governor, you have worked on those issues which were of
greatest importance to our family; education, safety of children, support of
our military, and state support during hurricanes.  Our state is a model in
hurricane preparedness and I am very grateful and proud by how
well-organized our local, state, and federal programs are.  Your leadership
during difficult times was truly comforting.  Our children's elementary
school is 17th in the state and is a Blue Ribbon school, which you awarded.
While my husband was away on an overseas deployment, you came to support the
National Guard and their families at an event at the Jacksonville Landing.
For all these things and many more, again, I thank you.

I was a Political Science major and graduated from University of Florida and
worked with Connie Mack on his Senatorial campaign and on staff in
Washington, DC.  I was able to meet your father during his campaign for
President.  I have followed the careers of many people and have an
understanding of the difficulties involved with being in office.  I just
wanted to tell you that I hope you continue to serve our state and country
as admirably as you have already done.  It is obvious that you have been
raised in the tradition of serving and that is how we are trying to raise
our children.  My husband, who is a World War II history buff, is a fan of
your father and marvels at his exploits during the war, of which your father
downplayed most of the time.  I believe that speaks to your father's
character and his serving nature which he obviously passed on to you and the
rest of your family.

Thank you for your time and all that you have done.

Carissa Hogan
Orange Park, FL
