From:	Kim Walden <twistedsisterami@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 22, 2006 9:31 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Paul B. Johnson

Dear Governor Bush.
 
I know that your elected time in office is coming to a close.  Each year I pray for this, and each year goes by unanswered.  
 
On January 09,  1981 my husband took the day off because it was his birthday.  A Polk County Deputy by the name of Theron Burnham covered his shift.  That night Paul Johnson not only brutally killed Deputy Burnham in cold blood but several others.  All appeals to this point have been denied.  
 
On January 09, 2001 I watched my husband place a cross in the exact spot TA Burnham was killed feeling guilty that it was not him.  Each year that passes, he looks for the day Mr. Johnson will face his crime.  
 
My question to you is after almost 30 years...and several denials of appeals...why does this person continue to live off the tax payers he so choose to kill without remorse?
 
Our family supported your first election and re-election in hopes that the right thing would be done.  Meaning the offenders on death row would be sent before God for their final assignment. 
 
My husband will always have guilt, and the families in which he robbed, will always feel a loss for this mans one night of arrogance.  
 
My husband would also like to be present to see Paul Johnson meet his maker so he can move on with his life.  I tend to think almost 30 years is enough of a burden to bare for any individual.
 
I am sure this email will be filtered though many individuals.  Some will think it is important...others will not.  
 
What is boils down to is doing the right thing.  Here is in hopes you take this under consideration with the utmost respect in which it was sent.
 
Wishing you a long and happy life.
 
God Bless and take care.
 
 
Kimberly Walden

From:	Brian Adams <stevenson7280@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 22, 2006 7:41 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] death warrants

Governor Bush
 
 After Clarence Hill was executed Wednesday evening, I guess it is fair to say that executions here in Florida are no longer on hold. I checked the Florida Supreme Court page with pending death warrants and it shows that Arthur Rutherford and Danny Rolling both have execution dates set for next month. As a supporter of the death penalty, I'm glad to see this. Both these men deserve to die for their crimes, and they shouldn't be crying for sympathy from you to spare them from execution. There are others who have been on death row longer though who have lost appeals in the 11th circuit court of appeals. Charles Foster is one example. The guy has been on death row since the 70's, and it appears that the 11th circuit denied him a COA. His case seems pretty confusing, but I don't understand why you don't sign death warrants on a more consistent basis to expedite the appeals process.
 
 Any death warrant that is signed after the 11th circuit denies relief should be considered very serious. All the appeals are expedited too. Why not carry more executions out at a quicker pace by signing death warrants opposed to waiting for years just for a meritless appeal to be resolved.

  _____

After we were approved and recieved our Agency Lic., we were then allowed to submit bids for work of which it was to late to get the contracts.

They come in and cut the bids below what we offer to keep the price down and the pay rates as low as possible. By doing this they get anyone from making a higher wage.
 
When our business was opened, no one from any of the Governmental offices at any level, came by to welcome us or shake our hand for being here. Everyone said that Florida was the place to come and do business and we wanted to provide our services to our community here in Pensacola.

We started this business to help supply jobs to the area. Get people off the unemployment line and back to work. The Sheriff's Department has Deputies that charge more money than we do to provide Security during their off duty hours and keeps the little guys like us from getting any of the Security jobs here. What do we do???
 
Will you call us and see if you can help us keep our doors open??? We are owed and operated by a female and she is certified in the State of Florida.  We have done everything we know and we have no choice but t now come to you and ask for help.

On a side note, we have invited you several times in the past to come visit the Naples High School Library Media Center, especially in connection with your visit to Naples to promote reading. Each time we were either too late, or there was a conflict. I am issuing an invitation to you way in advance to visit our school and our library, why?
 
1. We have one of only a handful of high school Reading Is Fundamental (RIF) programs in the nation. We distribute free books and dictionaries to students in intensive reading and English as a Second Language programs, based on the generosity of local groups and foundations, three times a year.
 
2. We have an after school book club that reads and analyzes books and is so large that we aren't able to recruit new members. 
 
3. We have been recognized nationally by School Library Journal as being leaders in the nation in library services. One member of our staff has been asked to attend a "summit" of school library professionals in Chicago this November.
 
4. Our new principal has instituted a "Drop Everything and Read (DEAR)" program every Friday.
 
5. We take 40 of our Advanced Placement Laureate Program students on an annual field trip to Florida Gulf Coast University where the library staff there guides our students to books to support our student's research.
 
6. Our virtual library website has been recognized, again by School Library Journal, as one of the best in the nation:
 
http://collier.k12.fl.us/nhs/lmc
 
We know that reading to elementary school students is a great photo opportunity, but it would be an unusual and welcomed opportunity for you to promote reading by teens. I hope you are amenable to our request.
 
You our cordially invited to visit Naples High School and, if possible, to address our students on the importance of reading, on your next visit to Naples.
 
A sincere thank you.
 
Adam Janowski
Library Media Specialist
Naples High School
Naples, Florida

If this is something you are still interested in doing, please let me know and we'll make it happen. I really think a speech by you, here at the state's flagship law school, about your experience with important legal issues facing Floridians, would make for a unique public education event, something that would benefit not only the law school and university community, but all Floridians.

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing you this letter to plead for your help.  My name is Robert Marcelo and 10 years ago when I was 15 years old I committed a horrific crime. Since that time I served 3 years in prison, 1 year house arrest and 4 years of probation. I have served my time for my crime but I am still not able to live a normal life. Isn't the purpose of the criminal system to rehabilitate and reform?  I can not live a normal life and put this behind me because the judicial system will not allow me to. Honestly, most people who have been charged with similar offenses have not made it through all that time without having another criminal offense.  I have paid for my crime and since that time I have tried to do nothing but better my life.  
 
Recently I have been volunteering in the community with the elderly population and have decided that I would like to become a firefighter/paramedic, but because of my conviction I can not receive licensure within the state of Florida. Looking for a job when criminal background checks are a must is also quite a challenge. 
 
I recently contacted my lawyer Mr. Richard Sharpstein, who represented me 10 years ago. I had contacted Mr. Sharpstein in hopes that he would be able to help me either seal or expunge my criminal record, but do to the terms of my conviction, I am not able to do either of these. Mr. Sharpstein informed me that the only option is a governor's pardon. I am currently looking for legal representation to begin this process, but from what I understand this is a lengthy and political process.  
 
Governor Bush, I have done nothing but try to erase the terrible crimes that I committed when I was only a minor, but these charges seem to haunt me when I look for employment due to criminal background checks. I need your assistance to help me receive a pardon so that I can go to school to become a firefighter/paramedic and receive licensure in the state of Florida. I want to give back to the community. I hope that you will be able to help me, and I appreciate you taking the time to hear my case.  
 
Thank you, 
Robert Marcelo

Davie, Florida 33314

From:	Pgilbertsr@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, September 21, 2006 5:52 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	UNITED STATES FLAG CODE REGULATIONS AS SPECIFIED IN 07-11-06 E-MAIL

Dear Governor Bush:
 
     On July 11th, 2006, I sent you an e-mail pertaining to the U.S. Flag Code Regulations. To this date I have not received a response.
 
     Therefore, I am sending the information again and I would greatly appreciate a response from you or a member of your staff.
 
     Info is as fols:
 
     The United States Flag Code specified that the Flag is to be flown at half-staff in mourning for designated principal governemnt leaders and upon Presidential Order.
 
     In the event of the death of a present or former official of the governemnt of any State territory or possession of the U.S., the Governor of that State territory, or possession, may proclaim that the National Flag be flown at half-staff.  And, that ONLY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OR A STATE GOVENOR HAS THE AUTHORITY TO ORDER THE FLAG BE LOWERED  TO HALF-STAFF.
 
     The National Flag Foundations (NFF) has issued guidance on this subject in order to preclude good-faith misunderstanding or abuse of the Flag Code and Flag Etiquette, both of which are all too often violated by Civilian and Government Officials.  For example:  Janet Reno, while U.S. Attorney General, ordered the American Flag flown at half-staff in honor of several DEA Agents who had died.  The Flag Code does not give her the authority to issue that Order.  In addition, the Mayor of Pittsburg, Pa., ordered Flags flown at half-staff to honor the victims of a plane crash.  A well intentioned gesture, for which, no authority exists.
 
     The NFF points out tha these "GOOD-FAITH" misunderstandings are not to criticize or embarass anyone, but rather to head off growing trivilalization of this memorial salute, and to preserve the dignity and significance of flying the U.S. Flag at half-staff, and believe that proper respect for our flag must be maintained, no matter the circumstances.
 
     I feel that it is a violation of the Flag Code and Flag Etiquette when Sheriff Ed Dean of Marion County, orders the Flag flown at half-staff.  He recently ordered the Flag to half-staff upon the death of a retired Police Officer and has on similar occasions in the past, without, to my knowledge, authorization from you, the Governor.  He and other Officials take it upon themselves to lower our Flag to half-staff without the proper authorization.
 
     It appears to me that remedial action pertaining to the proper Flag Etiquette and Flag Code needs to be addressed.
 
     This is the information that I e-mailed to you on July 11, 2006, for which I have not received a reply.  Your attention to this is appreciated.
 
     Sincerely,
 
     Phil Gilbert
     3620 S.E. 131 Place
     Belleview, Fl 34420-5656
     (352) 347-2446

Dear Governor Bush,

You are painfully aware of the lack of proper government in Yankeetown. That is exactly what you have right now in Yankeetown, even after your efforts with state assistance. As time passes more improprieties will become evident as the newly elected officials come under close scrutiny based on their illegal actions and forceful personal rule as evidenced by three people making decisions in direct contradiction to your sunshine rules and regulations. 

You have a choice to make now. Do you end it all by withdrawing Yankeetown’s charter, or do you stay away and let the fighting continue for months or years, after which our town will surely be in pieces and in need of help anyway.

You should withdraw the charter today. I will speak up and support you when you do. As you could see by the voting results in the past elections, there are many people in our town who do not want to see us get drawn into a lawsuit over development. Development is going to happen sooner or later, so why not make the best of it? As a small business owner in Yankeetown, I’ve had it with all the negative press these leftwing activists have gained. It has just about sunk my business which relies on travelers and vacationers who are not returning to Yankeetown based on the aggressive nature of the anti development crowd.

Our town government has been deliberately dismantled by a bunch of malcontents and misfits that won’t listen to anyone who isn’t in their little ruling den. They will (have) run Yankeetown into a hole so large it will never recover. For the sake of my business and others here, shut down this dysfunctional government now, and transfer power over to Levy County where a government exists that can manage our water and fire services. After all, the state has asked the town to correct the water problem on numerous occasions, but the very people in charge now have publicly stated that they rather drink poison water than allow development to occur.

The time to act is right now, today. These people act as if they have total impunity from the law and your office. 

Regards,

Carl Hanover

18 year resident of Yankeetown

From:	MTPJWP@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, September 20, 2006 2:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Florida Arts Council - Resignation


The original of the following letter has been mailed today.


 


                                                                September 20, 2006


                                     

The Honorable Jeb Bush

Governor of State of Florida

State Capitol

402 S. Monroe Street

Tallahassee, FL  32399-1300

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

It is with deep regret that I must tender my resignation as a member of the Florida Arts Council.  Earlier this month my wife Joanne was diagnosed with Lymphoma, and last week it was confirmed malignant.  The good news is that it is treatable with an excellent track record of success, but we will be spending much of the coming season up North while she undergoes treatment.  I therefore will be unable to fulfill my duties as prescribed by your appointment.

 

I want to tell you how much I appreciated your trust in me and your response when your help was needed to support the integrity of FAC.

 

Throughout my two terms, I have enjoyed working with JuDee Pettijohn, Sandy Shaughnessy and their most capable staff at the Division of Cultural Affairs.  I have made new friends both among the staff and my fellow FAC members and look forward to continuing serve the arts in Florida once our tribulations have passed.

 

I do hope our paths will cross, perhaps if you come to Hobe Sound to visit your Uncle Bucky.

 

With best personal regards to you and yours.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

                                                                        John Whitney Payson

 

JWP/sp

 

cc:  jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing to both thank you for what you have done in giving the electorate in Yankeetown the privelege of electing their own government, and to urge you to allow the process to continue.  Please, do not revoke the town charter as the recently resigned "mayor" has desperately requested.

The now resigned mayor, instead of being "a part of" the town, has been "apart from" the town.  The recently resigned mayor was elected approximately a year ago, unopposed, while the developer who initiated this situation was "secretly negotiating" with at least two if not more of the town council members (the mayor was a member of that council).  Instead of clearing the air and explaining how this happened, she set off on a course that she now acknowledges of attempting to appease the developer with the primary goal being to avoid litigation.  Yankeetown deserves more than appeasement...Yankeetown deserves what you have given it, the ability to make the decisions that will affect it's future in an open and honest political atmosphere.  
 
Our town council now has a quorum of three, with another election approaching in a month that will fill the two open council seats.  Please allow the good and honest folks of Yankeetown to continue down the road you have graciously provided, since your allowing an election, an honest and informed election, has given us a light at the end of our tunnel.  Please allow us to continue to pursue our own destiny.  
 
John Ward Smith
 
 
P.S.  This has nothing to do with Yankeetown, but I wanted to tell you how highly I think of your father.  I had met your father at a couple of political fundraisers, but I obviously didn't know him.  Then about 10 years ago a good friend of mine who was a Pearl Harbor survivor (and who your father had called every year while in office) was dying of cancer.  My law partner wrote to your father, who was apparently in Africa on a hunting/fishing trip with his grandchildren.  Your father wrote a hand written letter to Tom that brought tears to his eyes.  Your father took time from his busy schedule to make an old war veteran's day.  He had no political motive, but instead was motivated by his decency as a human being (and perhaps as a fellow veteran of the Pacific theatre).  You have to be exceedingly proud.

close margin in general.  Two, Mr. Hill has a mitigating circumstance 
in that he was a victim of post-traumatic stress disorder stemming from 
his service in the military in Vietnam.

him to life in prison without parole possibility.  Thank you for your 
urgent action on this immediate matter.

From:	Kathleen Baranowski <kassylake@aol.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 19, 2006 10:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Illegal Immigrants

Kathleen Baranowski
1218 Gladys Avenue
Lakeland, FL 33805-3952


September 19, 2006

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of Florida
The Capitol, 400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


 Governor Bush:

A friend sent me an article from the Birmingham News, in Alabama.  I 
inclose the article for your perusal.  But to give a brief synopsis, it 
reports that Alabama has joined in a program with the federal government, 
that with training, it allows local law enforcement in Alabama to 
participate in and enforce immigration laws.  The article also talks about 
the specific cities that have holding facilities that are used to retain 
suspects.   

This sounds like an excellent program and I would like to see Florida 
participating in this.  Will you take the necessary steps to set this 
program up for the state of Florida?  I hope that you will. 

 While Florida has held its arms open to many who have sought sanctuary in 
our wonderful country, we have also seen a huge increase in illegal 
immigrants that have placed a burden on our schools, medical facilities, 
communty services and treasuries.  We can no longer afford to keep our 
arms open for those living in peril in other countries, if we do not start 
fully enforcing our immigration laws.  Will you serve our state's best 
interests and institute this program?  Please?

Following is the article that I referenced.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
----------- » More From The Birmingham News   

Two cities to hold immigrants

Saturday, September 09, 2006 
MIKE CASON
News staff writer 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement will set up facilities in 
Montgomery and Dothan to temporarily detain and investigate those 
suspected of being illegal immigrants. 

The facilities, modular buildings of about 2,000 square feet, will be used 
by state troopers who have completed special training in immigration law 
and procedures, said Roland Jones, assistant special agent in charge of 
the ICE Office of Investigations in Gulfport, Miss. 

Equipment in the facilities will allow state troopers to identify suspects 
through digital finger scans and photographs checked against national data 
bases. 

The same technology is used by ICE agents at their offices in Birmingham 
and Mobile. 

Col. Mike Coppage, director of the Alabama Department of Public Safety, 
said he expects the facilities to be in place in about six weeks. 

Jones said ICE will pay for the buildings but did not know the cost. The 
facilities will be the only ones of their kind in the state. 

Alabama is one of a handful of states to enter agreements with the federal 
government to allow state or local police to enforce immigration laws 
within certain restrictions. 

Under the Alabama agreement, state troopers who have completed a training 
course can detain those suspected of being illegal immigrants, provided 
that they encounter those suspects during the course of normal law 
enforcement, such as issuing a speeding ticket or investigating an 
accident. 

The state troopers are the only Alabama police agency who have entered an 
agreement with ICE for immigration enforcement. Fifty-eight active state 
troopers have completed the five-week course. The agreement does not allow 
troopers to seek out illegal immigrants at businesses, construction sites 
or other workplaces. 

Jones said the Montgomery and Dothan facilities will have holding cells 
for male and female suspects. They will not be for overnight detention. If 
an investigation determines that a suspect needs to be detained because of 
an immigration violation, ICE will transport them to the Etowah County 
Detention Center in Gadsden, Jones said. ICE also has an agreement with 
the privately owned Perry County Correctional Center, near Uniontown, to 
house illegal immigrants awaiting hearings or deportation. 

Jones said he did not know of plans for any more facilities after the ones 
in Dothan and Montgomery. He said the two cities were picked partly 
because their location would improve the efficiency of processing 
immigration suspects. 

"What ICE is trying to do is provide some of this infrastructure 
throughout the state," Jones said. 

Sincerely,


Kathleen Baranowski
863-686-4967

I have spoken to one of your assistance regarding a specific matter and would like to request a few minutes of your time to discuss this with you.
 
The nature and background to the issue is that of my Residence combined with Property Tax's.
 
I moved to Clearwater in June 04 with my wife and 2 children from the UK. I am sponsored by my employer and have a VISA which is in the process of review for a Green Card. Until such a time as my application is accepted my property tax's increase at a phenomenal rate as I am unable to participate in the 'Save Our Homes' project as I am not considered a resident.
 
At this stage I am bemused as to what resident means. (1) We live here 365 days a year, (2) The home is a permanent residence and not a vacation home, (3) I get paid in US $'s and pay tax's as a permanent resident and (4) My children attend local schools.
 
Last year my property tax's increased by $4k and this year by a further $3.5k, with no increase in the services that I receive. Unfortunately my salary does not increase at such rates.
At this stage we are having to seriously consider relocating to enable us to maintain our standard of living.
 
I know as fact that if a US Citizen was to move to the UK then they would not be discriminated against as we are.
 
I look forward to speaking with you.
 
Regards
John Myers
(727) 230 9934

From:	Willocks, Curt <CWillocks@ci.gulfport.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, September 18, 2006 4:05 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	campaign@charliecrist.com
Subject:	FDLE Commissioner


Dear Gov. Bush, 

        I need to preface this by stating that I've not been asked to write this, it is of my own volition and is the result in my interest in the future FDLE Commissioner being the most qualified for our State.

        
        I am sending this information to you, because I know you have many difficult decisions to make, daily, and one of the most important in the coming days is the appointment of a permanent Commissioner for FDLE.  First, let me say that FDLE is a fine organization that does an exceptional job in assisting local agencies.  It has been my experience that the leadership of the Dept. of Law Enforcement is an important factor in how policing is conducted on a day to day basis throughout the state.   Moreover, that leadership must have credibility with police officers.  I know that you will make this appointment based on the needs of the State and the ability of the individual to instill confidence and maintain the highest ethical standards.

        I am taking it upon myself as a citizen to suggest the name of Everett Rice, former Pinellas County Sheriff, for this position.  I have been in policing in this state for over 35 years and have found Everett to be a consumate professional with the highest of ethical standards.   It is probably unusual for a Police Chief to forward the name of a Sheriff for this position, but in my fifteen years of working with Everett on everything from street crime issues to legislation, I can tell you that his decision making has always been in the best interest of  the citizens he serves.  I know that Everett is a lawyer and that he has served in the House of Representatives,  and he is an excellent administrator, but his strongest asset is that he is a cop, and a good one.  In my business, that is high praise.  He has never compromised his principles or the law for political expediency.  Everett is respected in all areas of law enforcement and his efforts have contributed greatly to making the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office one of the best in the country.

          It is important that the Commissioner of FDLE understand that what they do, the legislation they support and the role they play in the Criminal Justice Standards and Training Commission impacts every officer, probation officer and correction officer in Florida.

        I am just a small town police chief,  but I can tell you that this appointment will impact ALL small town police chief's and there are many of us.  Everett understands the constraints and the responsibilities we share.   More than once in these past years I've had occasion to call on Sheriff Rice for assistance and I have never  been let down, even a small town police chief.   I believe he would serve the State well.  Regardless of your decision, I have faith in your judgement.  Thank you for hearing me out.  If I can ever be of service, please do not hesitate to give me that opportunity.


G. Curt Willocks 
Director of Public Safety 
City of Gulfport

Dear Governor Bush,
 
My name is Bailey and I am ten-years-old and I live in Niceville, Florida.  When I was seven I started an organization called Hero Hugs that sends care packages to soldiers serving in Iraq.  So far I have sent more then 16,000 packages valued at more than $145,000 to our troops.  I also have a bear named Hero I made at Build-A-Bear Workshop I sent to the soldiers to keep them company.  When the soldiers started sending me photos of Hero being a soldier, I thought of a way to help kids who have a family member serving in Iraq.  The Adventures of Hero show kids in a kid friendly way what life is really like for our soldiers in Iraq and kids are less scared about their mom or dad being there.  I have won lots of awards and recently teamed up with the Department of Defense and America Supports You to be sure our soldiers know people are thinking of them.
 
The reason I am writing you is because I would really like to meet you and would like for Hero to meet you too.  After three years in Iraq, some soldiers surprised me and brought Hero home for some R&R because they knew I missed him.  Hero has had his photo with a lot of famous people and he is a pretty famous bear.  I even wrote a book about him I am hoping to have published soon.  Since you have been my state's Governor during the time Hero was in Iraq, I thought it would be really cool for Hero to get to meet you and have a photo of you with me and Hero for his scrapbook.  Eventually Hero will probably go to a museum and I think a photo with our state's Governor would be a special part of his collection.
 
I know you are really busy, but I only live a few hours away and I am sure my mom would bring me over to Tallahassee if you could find time to meet Hero.  My fourth grade visited the capitol last year and I hoped we would meet you then, but you had some important meetings that day.  Or it would be really cool if you wanted to visit my school which is Longwood Elementary in Shalimar, Florida and help me and my classmates pack some of the packages for the soldiers.  I always thought it would be good if your brother the President could help us pack packages because so many people don't agree with us being in Iraq and maybe if they saw him helping kids pack packages for the soldiers they would at least remember that we should always think of our soldiers even if we don't like what they are doing or how they do it.  Our soldiers are just trying to make the world a better place for us to live in.  It might make some big people change their minds about things.  
 
The holidays are coming up and that is a really hard time for the soldiers.  Getting our packages really help them feel better.  A lot of soldiers from Florida have gotten a package from Hero Hugs and I bet one of them would be especially surprised if they got one with a card signed by our governor.  And maybe seeing you help us would encourage more people to be sure and do something special for our soldiers during the holidays since people look up to you.  I partly started Hero Hugs after I saw some people being mean to soldiers after a hurricane.  The soldiers were passing out ice and water and people were just complaining about the lines being too long and not getting enough.  They forgot I think that the soldiers were just there trying to help us.  We should have been thanking them instead because they could have been home with their families and power instead of there trying to help us.
 
I really hope you will have time to meet me and Hero or visit my class and help with packages before you leave office.  It would really mean a lot to us.
 
Sincerely,
Bailey Reese  
 
P.S. - You can visit my website www.HeroHugs.org to see some photos of Hero in Iraq!

From:	monty wilson <mwilson5@valp.net>
Sent:	Saturday, September 16, 2006 12:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	EGLIN

It is beginning to appear that it will take an act of Congress to stop the move of the 46th Test Wing from Eglin to Edwards.  If I didn’t know that the figures being used to justify this move are skewed, and didn’t feel that this is a huge mistake for national security, I might not be as upset.  Consider this one example:

 

One major Eglin facility slated to be closed next year under this plan is making money for the Test Wing, and will continue to for at least the next five years.  To close the facility would cost nearly $20 million, so it was decided to just “mothball” it instead.  The logic is that of the money it takes in, about $1-million is Air Force money that will no longer be spent.  However, it will cost about $2.2-million a year to mothball it (being kept quiet) so end result is the Government will spend $2.2-million a year in order to save $1-million.

 

Even people out west are pointing out that they can’t support the work they have already, and routinely have been sending work to Eglin for years.  They want to know how they are going to be expected to do what they have now, plus all they send to us, plus all the Eglin work also.

 

Please do all you can to stop this move that makes no sense!  PLEASE call the secretary, the President, or whomsoever it takes!

 

Respectfully,

 

Brannon M. Wilson

From:	Kat Candler <katcandler@gmail.com>
Sent:	Saturday, September 16, 2006 10:46 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Film Screens for Suicide Prevention and Mental Health Awareness

Mr. Bush,
My name is Kat Candler and I'll be bringing my film jumping off bridges to the All Saints Cinema through the Tallahassee Film Society the weekend of 10/6 and 10/7 and 5:45pm and 7:30pm each night.  I'd love to be able to spread the word about the screening through your contacts, staff and board of directors.  We've had great success and responses to the film from the suicide prevention and mental health communities.  We're targeting counselors, support groups leaders, social workers, activists, government agencies .... We're also working with the American Counseling Association to bring attention to the film to counselors across the country  
 
I'm attaching a press kit to give you more of an idea about the film and a photo that can be forwarded with any emails.  You can find out more about the film at www.jumpinpingoffbridges.com and  http://www.tallahasseefilms.com/ 
 
We appreciate any help you might be able to provide in spreading the word about the film.  .
Thanks so much and I look forward to talking with you.
Kat Candler
Writer/Director
jumping off bridges  
 
 

Storie Productions 
P.O. Box  301463
ilm Austin, TX 78703-0025
512.302.4430 
info@storieproductions.com 
www.storieproductions.com 

 

Independent film jumping off bridges screens in Tallahassee on U.S. Fall Tour for Suicide Prevention and Mental Health Awareness 

 

Contact: Storie Productions

512.771.5863

info@storieproductions.com 

 

( Austin , TX ) In conjunction with National Suicide Prevention Week, the independent film, jumping off bridges, will screen in over 20 cities across the United States from August through November.  Storie Productions will partner with local and national suicide prevention organizations, mental health awareness groups and organizations that deal with grief and loss to use jumping off bridges in an outreach effort to spread awareness.  The film will screen in Tallahassee , FL the weekend of October 6th and 7th at the All Saints Theater through the Tallahassee Film Society. 

 

Inspired by invincible friendships, junior high journal entries, heart breaking crushes and the complexities of losing loved ones, jumping off bridges follows a carefree, adventurous group of four best friends deep in the trenches of adolescence.   Written and directed by award-winning filmmaker, Kat Candler (cicadas, Roberta Wells ), the film features Michael Emerson (Henry Gale on the hit television series LOST) and Rhett Wilkins from the Sundance darling, The Puffy Chair .  Since its festival premiere at the 2006 South By Southwest Film Festival, jumping off bridges has enjoyed sold out screenings and rave reviews.   Lauded by the Austin Chronicle as "a realistic narrative portrait of love, death, and human debris as anything you're ever likely to see onscreen."   

 

In many cities, a Q&A panel of experts will follow the screening to discuss suicide and mental health issues, statistics, warning signs and preventative measures. 

 

The script was a finalist in the 2002 Chesterfield Fellowship, a participant in the 2002 IFP Market (Emerging Narrative) and a Semi-Finalist in the 2002 Sundance Screenwriter's Lab. The film was a recipient of a 2005 Texas Filmmaker's Production Fund Grant and a participant in the 2005 IFP Rough Cuts Lab. 

 

To learn more about the film, jumping off bridges, or to download a press kit, please visit our website: www.jumpingoffbridges.com .

 

 

What the critics are saying …

 

" Austin filmmaker Kat Candler is one of the most astute observers of teenage behavior working behind a camera today, and jumping off bridges , her powerful, resonant examination into the impact of suicide on those left behind is as realistic a narrative portrait of love, death, and human debris as anything you're ever likely to see onscreen." -- The Austin Chronicle 

  

"Candler demonstrated a deep understanding of teen anxiety, angst and alienation. An emotional, smart movie." -- Moving Pictures Magazine 

  

"Kat Candler's moving Austin-made teen drama has enjoyed sold-out crowds and raves." -- Austin American-Statesman 

 

"Candler's ability to take some of the darkest and most jagged truths about fear, regret, sadness, loss, suffering and pain and break them open for her audience to experience in ways that are both optimistic and honest makes her one of the most important and promising young filmmakers on the cinematic landscape." -- Filethirteen .com 

"Candler is very much in touch with a particular sort of teenaged sensibility. She knows the difference between sadness and the petulance it is often mistaken for, and she treats her sullen girls and boys with the sort of patience and understanding their parents (and, perhaps, some audience members) can never quite muster." -- Ain't It Cool News 

 

" jumping off bridges is a wonderfully delicate, authentic portrayal of teenagers and their families." -- Cinematical.com

 

"Truly wonderful work" -- Filmmaker Magazine

 

"Sensitively handled and refreshingly naturalistic" -- The Florida Times Union

 

"Deserving of some art house play" -- Dallas Observer

 

****************************** *********************************

 

"Wonderful.  It captured how painful and isolating losing a loved one to suicide can be." 
Lidia S. Bernik, M.H.S. 
Program Coordinator 
Suicide Prevention Action Network USA 

"Sad, genuine and beautiful.  The issues surrounding grief, guilt, depression and sadness are uneasy and beautifully rendered in your story and your actors' performances." 
Lisa Sargese, M.T.S . 
Adjunct Professor, Dept of Philosophy & Religion; 
Counseling & Human Services 
Montclair State University 

 

"Wow, what a movie.  Absolutely must be seen, by survivors and not alike.  A very gripping powerful film."

Lin Ortwein MSW

Suicide Bereavement Support, Portland, OR

From:	cynthia correa <cynthiacorrea@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Saturday, September 16, 2006 4:21 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; mbicksler@co.stephenson.il.us
Subject:	HELP!!!!!

Whatever happened to the "dead beat dad" legislation? 
 
I have been a single mom for 13 years (my daughter is 14) and have been trying for that amount of time to get the government to enforce the court order on my ex-husband to pay his child support- to no avail- AND I HAVE MANY "SINGLE MOM" friends who say they are battling the same demons.
 
 I am inclined to believe that us single moms have been forgotten in this state and in this country. It's really tough out there in today's society to juggle a demanding career and raise a child by ourselves. And it's made no easier by a government that ignores (worse, doesn't even respond) to our repeated cries for enforcement of our child support orders. It's actually easier to come to terms with the fact that you have NO HELP and that NO ONE cares about your fight for your LEGAL RIGHTS, than it is to get something done about it.  ARE WE REALLY THAT INVISIBLE AND THAT UNWORTHY?
 
Won't you, PLEASE, take mercy on us single moms who struggle- and just give us the support we need to help us collect on court orders that say a father should participate in the support of his child(ren)?
 
We complain in this country about how the "unattended children" should have more parental guidance, but it's made impossible for us to feed our children unless we work 2 jobs. Tell me, do you know how to be in two places at once (home and work)?
 
I have records of the countless attempts made over the years to enforce my court order. However, if I can't afford to shell out hundreds of dollars to a private attorney to help me fight this legally, I'm out of luck. Seriously, if I had the money to hire an attorney, why would I be fighting for the measly $343 a month he's supposed to have been sending in the first place ?
 
Please prove me wrong in my thinking that today's politicians mostly show no concern for the little people. I promise that if you get on your soap box and fight for us, you will find admiration, loyalty and support from the "single mom" community- of which there are hundreds of thousands in the US.
 
Screaming for help, 
 
 
Cynthia Correa
Transworld Business Brokers
5400 NW 21st Terrace
Ft. Lauderdale, FL  33309
cynthia@tworld.com
Office 954-772-1122
Cell 954-663-3136 (Please leave a message and return phone number if not answered).

Dear Governor Bush:

September 15, 2006



Dear Governor Bush:

Hi, my name is Sherry Keyes and I am writing this letter on behalf of my 
cousin Dennis Sochor.  The Holy Spirit touched my heart to get in touch 
with my cousin in April of this year.  During a sermon our pastor was 
giving on reaching out to the oprhans, widows and captives.  During the 
sermon I was prompted by the Holy Spirit to get in touch with my cousin, 
Dennis Sochor who is at Union Correctional Institute in Raiford, FL.  My 
cousin has been on death row since November 1987 for a crime that took 
place in January 1982 in Broward County.  I wrote my cousin in April and 
the letter I received back was the most spirit filled and loving letter I 
had ever received.  This man has so much love to offer and loves the Lord 
so much.  Dennis, sent us visiting papers to fill out, which we did and in 
the middle of April we made our first visit to him.  Ths was the first 
time I had seen my cousin in 36 years and we have been back several times 
since.  We did alot of praying with Dennis and prayed for the 
manifestation of the truth.  After talking with Dennis, and reading his 
transcript, he has been convicted of a crime that he did not commit.  He 
could not afford an attorney nor did her have any family support.  He was 
convicted of murdering a girl in Broward County on New Years Eve.  Dennis 
younger brother Gary Sochor was with Dennis that evening when Patricia 
Gifford came up missing.  The law I'm sure was not given to his brother 
about testifying against his own.  His parents were not contacted until 
the conclusion of the guilt phase trial and was asked to fly from Michigan 
to Florida.  They maybe spent a half hour with counsel and then was asked 
to prepare a statement to present to the jury the next morning.  His 
brother Gary testified against him.  Even in the courtroom it says In God 
We Trust.  How can anyone convict another person when there is no physical 
evidence.  No body was ever recovered and no investigation was pursued 
after a coerced confession.   In the transcript for case 01-0885 it states 
that without his brother, Gary Sochor testimony the State would not have 
obtained a conviction and that Gary had been cornered into making a untrue 
statements throught techniques more usually seen in a third world 
dictatorship, they would not have believed this testimony, and no 
conviction would have resulted.  Gary's testimony regarding the promise of 
immunity by a police officers is equally something that the jury should 
have been made aware of.  The lower court found Gary's testimony to be 
unreliable and not credible.  How can anyone be convicted of a crime with 
no physical evidence and why has not Dennis Sochor been DNA tested.  What 
I need to do is to get an audience together with the Gov. Jeb Bush so the 
truth can be revealed and he can be set free.  We are only asking the 
courts to reopen this case, Dennis deserve's a fair trial.  We do not have 
the financial means and we are seeking to prove Dennis innocence.  Please 
let me know what I need to do and where to start and thanking you with all 
of my heart for helping my cousin.

Sherry Keyes
21307 Percy Ave
Port Charlotte, FL  33952
941-240-2561      

Sincerely,


Sherry Keyes
9412402561


From:	tahimy welch <tata_305mami@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 15, 2006 7:38 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	essay contest

It is really important to learn about Hispanic heritage for many different reasons. My opinion why it is important to learn about different cultures and languages are because we are living in the same world and were are not all the same, we have different believes and different religions and it’s really important to know about others and all of the different people that share this world with us. We have to know what’s right and what’s wrong and why not everyone is the same. We all eat different foods, we do different things at home and we all have different ways of doing things. Also it’s really helpful for the future, you never know if one day you have to travel around the world and all those things you learned about Hispanic heritage may come in handy. Many other reasons are because, this country that we live in (United States of America) is a free country that opens doors to everyone of other places and believes and heritages, and by learning about Hispanic heritage it is a way to connect/communicate with other people that come from other places. To become a citizen u also must know about al those things and why people don’t think the same way and why they do not have the same living style. Many of us go to friends houses and we see new things everyday and maybe when we go to one of our friends houses we might see something weird that we are not use to seen everyday, but by learning, and studying about heritages we might know why you see different things everyday and why families aren’t the same. Not only is it important because of those reasons , but by knowing those things not only do we understand each other ,but there is no vandalism and there is world peace. 
 
Jennifer leite
18004 sw 154 ave miami,fl
33187 (786-)4578709

From:	Mike Marsolek <marsolek@gmail.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 15, 2006 3:31 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Death Penalty - Commutation for Clarence Edward Hill

(I apologize if you are continually inundated with mail from people who are not your constituents, to which I am adding my letter, but please still review it.)

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to ask you to commute the death sentence of Clarence Edward Hill, on the grounds that he was a functioning member of society who worked to help support his family until shortly before the murder, indicating he is not a hardened criminal nor the worst of the worst, and furthermore to execute him will only communicate to society that violence is an acceptable means to deal with your problems.  It is precisely this way of thinking that leads to many of these violent crimes in the first place.

On this point, a study conducted for the United Nations found: "Recent crime figures from abolitionist countries fail to show that abolition has harmful effects. In Canada, the homicide rate per 100,000 population fell from a peak of 3.09 in 1975, the year before the abolition of the death penalty for murder, to 2.41 in 1980, and since then it has declined further. In 2002, 26 years after abolition, the homicide rate was 1.85 per 100,000 population, 40 per cent lower than in 1975." (Hood, Oxford University Press, 2002)

I do not condone the actions of Clarence Hill, they were abhorrent and he deserves punishment, but he was a contributing member of society with a caring and nonviolent history, and to execute him will only propagate the very attitude that leads to many violent crimes in the first place.  Please commute the death sentence of Clarence Edward Hill.  Thank you.

Sincerely,
Michael Marsolek

3261 Franklin Ave. E., #8
Seattle, WA     98102

From:	lynette250@bellsouth.net
Sent:	Friday, September 15, 2006 1:18 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	SISTER SAYS BROTHER DID NOT HARM BROTHER.  WILL THE TRUTH AND JUSTICE PREVAIL?

Importance:	High

                                                                             Judy Thompson Little						             11726 Poydras Lane						              Jacksonville, Fl 32218									September 15, 2006

GOVERNOR JEB BUSH and THE BOARD EXECUTIVE CLEMENCY:

RE: RONALD NEIL THOMPSON      DC#068736
		
Over the years beginning, 2004, I have written many, many letters on my brother, Ronald Neil Thompson’s behalf for justice.  From The President to The Governor; as well as many others in-between, Judges, Attorney's, Senators, The Sheriff, The Mayor, Dr. Phil, Oprah, just to name a few. I felt that people generally did not care, until I received responses (2005) from The President, The Governor, Senator Stephen Wise and wife of The Jaguars (football) owner, Delores Weaver. 		
We recently submitted to the office of Mrs. Janet Keels (I never met her, but she is a wonderful person, she bought some joy inside my tears) a Waiver Request with all the required paperwork, plus supporting legal documents that our brother, Reginald Thompson the alleged victim in the case has been on a mission to get Ronald locked up since, 2001 (case #01-2067 DV.   Ronald has appeared before several Judges, 2001-2005 in an attempt to get an injunction for protection from Reginald, as well as myself and other family members).  For unknown reason the waiver for clemency was denied, August 2006.  I find it hard to understand how and why after reading all the information that I provided in this case, anyone not to see the unjust and not feel compelled to grant Ronald, clemency, modification or a suspended sentence. I guess it is easier for me, because he's my brother and I love him.  Most importantly I was with Ronald when our brother, Reginald Thompson, the alleged victim had him arrested.

If I had to pull at least two compelling statement from the information I provided in the Waiver/Clemency packet, it would be the following:
1. THE PETITION FILED IN RONALD'S CASE, #05-594 CF, STATES "Ronald Neil Thompson on July 8, 2005, in the County of Nassau and the State of Florida, did own or have in his care custody, possession or control a firearm, to wit; a pistol, having been convicted of a felony in the courts of the State of Florida, to-wit; Escape, in Circuit Court in and for Hillsborough County Florida, May 12, 1998 contrary to the provisions of Section 790.23 Florida Statue." 
    A.   THEY FOUND NO GUN ON RONALD, NOR IN HIS CAR (which they still have). Ronald was in their custody appropriately 18 hours before I bonded him out and they found no gun-powered residue on him.
    B.   RONALD'S RECORD WILL SHOW THAT HE HAS NEVER ESCAPED FROM ANYWHERE. BECAUSE OF THIS ERROR, RONALD WAS SENTENCED ACCORDINGLY.  PERHAPS IF THEY HAD FILED THE PETITION WITH THE CORRECT INFORMATION, THEY MAY HAVE OFFERED RONALD PROBATION OR A LESSER SENTENCE. If one would do a name search on the Department of Correction, web site, they will find, three (3) Ronald Thompson's. The Ronald Thompson DOC #069189 is William J. Thompson (AKA Ronald Thompson).  William Thompson’s record clearly shows that he is the one that had been charged with escaping in Hillsborough County.  My brother, Ronald Thompson has never escaped from nowhere, which his record clearly shows. (as stated in the packets, Ronald was advised by his Public Defender, Brian Morrissey that if he did not accept the 5-years in and 5-year probation, the Prosecutor, Doc Burgess offered, Mr. Burgess would file a petition as a habitual offender and Ronald could receive a mandatory sentence of 20-years).

SECONDLY: Ronald was arrested three (3) times within a three week period in the same case, with the very same information, the Sheriff's Department had from day one. Ronald was given three (3) different bonds by the same judge. I have always been told that this was a violation of his rights (habeas Corpus).  Our brother, the alleged victim, Reginald Thompson repeatedly went to the Prosecutor (Doc Burgess).  Seven-days after the first arrest, the Officer stated, “Your brother said you had a gun and your brother is not going to lie on you”.  Reginald reported that he asked, Mr. Burgess “Why y’all keep setting a low bond on a convicted felon?  Y’all arrested a white man for shooting a gun in the air and gave him a bond $150,000… I know I’m a black man, but my life is valuable too, I told y’all he tried to kill me”.  Ronald’s Public Defender is aware that the alleged witness, Thomas Blue, (retired school principle, minister) accepted money in this case.  Included in the Clemency packet, I provided legal documentations of how Reginald has been on a mission to get Ronald locked up, since 2001. It all started when Ronald got our mother, Delores Thompson, who suffered with Alzheimer’s out of a nursing home and took on the responsibility of her care.  Doing things I couldn’t, changing her, bathing her etc, plus working 40 plus hours, 3rd shift at Southeastern Metal, never missed a day.  Ronald has appeared before several Judges, 2001-2005 in an attempt to get an Injunction for Protection form Reginald, Case #01-2067 DV.   This is how my writing campaign started to Judges, Chief Judge, Sheriff’ the Mayor, The State Attorney (included Incident numbers from police reports, who always referred us to state attorney) begging for help to end Reginald’s violent attacks and prevent a tragedy.  Case #04-2920 DV, our mother’s caretaker, after several attempts, was finally granted an injunction/protection after Reginald pulled a gun on her and her two daughters; and followed them to school.  Case #04-14616 CC, Reginald attempted to evict our mother and everyone in the house.  He wanted our mother placed back in the nursing home, so that he could rent her house out for $800.00 a month.  I am a Juvenile Probation Officer with the Department of Juvenile Justice and have been for 27-dedicated years, since graduating from the University Of Florida.  Part of my responsibility is to perform Court Liaison duties on Weekends and Holidays.  One Sunday, I was in Court with the Honorable Judge Emmett Ferguson and felt lead to talk with him about my family situation.  That very next morning Ronald called me at work.  The Sheriff’s Officer gave him 15 minutes to get out of the house, including our bedridden mother.  I was able to pick up the telephone, 10:15 AM and talk with Judge Ferguson.  The Judge was able to intervene, pending a hearing with the judge that signed the eviction (divine intervention).  Of course, what Reginald did was not legal and therefore no one had to leave.  

Also included in the Clemency package, forwarded to Mrs. Keels, arrest reports showing that Reginald has turned his violence towards our brother Larry Thompson.  Going to Larry’s resident beating him with a hammer, head, back and chest and tried to run Larry over with his car.  Larry’s injunction/protection from Reginald was denied (case #06-979 DV).  On April 21, 2006, I was finally granted an Injunction for Protection from Reginald in my Case #04-3952 DV.  I’ve had to move in with Larry to protect him from Reginald, since I’ve been granted an injunction and Larry was not; just like Ronald???

There has been so much going on and I’ve tried to make this as short and detailed as possible.  However, all documents supporting the above statements have been submitted to Mrs. Keels.    
 The waiver of the Rules states "a waiver may only be granted by the Governor with the approval of at least one member of the Clemency Board". 

Governor Jeb Bush, Sir, before you leave office, would you please give justice to my brother Ronald Thompson.  I was with Ronald when this situation occurred and knows he is innocent and does not deserve to be incarcerated for a crime he did not commit.  In fact there were 4 of us with Ronald and they can meet with you as well. 
	Enclosing, I am available at any time that you may have so that we can meet if need be.  I can be contacted at (904) 757-1405 home; (904) 798-4707 work.  I am truly looking to hearing from you.  Thank you for your consideration to this matter.

Dear Governor Bush;

 

RE:  Appointment of Broward School Board and Rescind Executive Order 06-211

 

I respectfully request that Governor Bush rescind Executive Order number 06-211 and appoint a qualified Republican to fill the Broward School Board District 1 position until the next general election shall be held in September, 2008.  I base this request upon the facts of this case and the Florida statutes pertaining to filling vacancy.

 

It appears that the Governor’s Executive Order was based on misinformation provided in Carole Andrews’ letter dated, September 12, 2006 which lead to a misinterpretation of the situation and a conclusion that a special election would be required immediately upon the heels of his appointment of a replacement.

 

Due to the actual fact that Carole Andrews won reelection on September 5, 2006, no Special Election is needed.  After the Governor appoints a replacement, that person will serve until the next General Election which will be September, 2008.  

 

The Governor’s Executive Order was based upon misinformation provided by Carole Andrews in her letter of resignation dated, September 12, 2006. (See the attached letter and note, the date appears to have been altered as the number “12” is handwritten, not typed.) In the letter, Andrews said, “Likewise my health prohibits me from continuing as a candidate for reelection to the School Board of Broward County at the November 2006 general election.  Accordingly, I regrettably must withdraw as a candidate for reelection as well, in order to permit the voters of Broward County to have the ability to choose my successor from a full range of qualified candidates.” 

 

The letter gives misinformation because Carole Andrews was reelected on September 5, 2006, therefore she was no longer a “candidate for reelection” and she was not required to have a runoff or any participation in the November 2006 general election.  Therefore she can not “withdraw as a candidate for reelection.”  She won reelection and has now announced in the letter that she is retiring immediately for health reasons. 

 

Another possible issue is that her letter is of “retirement” not resignation and her retirement could reasonably be required to begin upon the completion of her current term, November, 2006.  Carole Andrews has been absent from many School Board meetings for a long time so her absence for another School Board meeting, if she chooses not to attend until her “retirement” date arrives would not be an undue hardship on her or the citizens.  It does not appear that her “retirement” would need to be effective immediately.  

 

Because she was reelected for a four year term (more than 28 months) on September 5, 2006, her “retirement”/resignation is to be filled by an appointment of the Governor as per

FL Statute 100.111 (1) (a) If any vacancy occurs in any office which is required to be filled pursuant to S. 1(f), Art. IV of the State Constitution and the remainder of the term of such office is 28 months or longer, then at the next general election a person shall be elected to fill the unexpired portion of such term, commencing on the first Tuesday after the first Monday following such general election.

 

Thank you for your urgent attention to this matter.  The immediate rescinding of the mistaken Executive Order and correction of this misunderstanding will provide for an orderly transition, giving the Governor the opportunity to appoint a qualified person who can serve for two years before standing for election.

 

The Broward County School Board has nine members and although it is a non-partisan elected position, all nine are Democrats.  Broward County has one of the largest populations of Republicans in Florida and it would be greatly appreciated by Broward’s Republicans if Governor Bush took this opportunity to appoint a qualified Republican to this position.

 

I hope Carole Andrews’ retirement letter was not a deliberate misrepresentation of the facts, but now that the actual facts are known please rescind your order, correct the mistake and appoint a qualified Republican for the Broward School Board vacancy.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

Margaret Hostetter

 

Attached:  (1) Carole Andrews letter September 12, 2006  (2) Governor’s Executive Order 06-211

Subject: Soil and Water Conservation Districts
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
In 2004, I was encouraged to seek an elected position on the Dixie 
Soil and Water Conservation Board.  Which I did and entered office unopposed.  As you know these boards were created during the depression era to solved major conservation challenges the Oklahoma dust bowl and other resource challenges existing at that time.  I will be leaving my post this December.  The remaining board members will have to appoint someone to fill my vacancy because no one else was interested in running for the position.
 
I am leaving this position because I believe the Districts no longer are of benefit to the public.  Environmental concerns they were created to correct have been implemented, and agencies such as the Water Management Districts and the Department of Environmental Protection are doing what needs to be done.
 
I would encourage you and the legislature to sunset these districts as they are just a layer of government that really have neither resources nor authority.  The District’s advisory role with NRCS and the Department of Agriculture and Consumer Affairs has been dominated by a single member’s operation who is no friend to your party.  Before I joined the board a local cattleman had requested assistance only to be denied because he could show no record of water use for 2 of the 5 previous years.  This cattleman had been in the business all of his adult life.  While a fellow District member had received assistance on several center pivot systems.
 
In just the past month I watched a position get filled for a technician to be based in Gilchrist county where a qualified applicant did not even get an interview.
 
It isn’t violations of the Sunshine law because the collusion seems to be between individual members and State and Federal chiefs. 
 
In closing I have just become disappointed with the system, and I believe my life is too short and my time too valuable to continue this association.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Raymond H. Hodges, Jr.
Member, Dixie Soil and Water Conservation District

Please grant him the right to live behind bars but to live and to try to make as meaningful a life as his God will allow.  You do have the right to do this for him; the Supreme Court has given you the right to do this.  I believe all the people in Florida would understand that the Supreme Court has more power than a time limit question.
 
Would you please allow him to live?  All religions have issued a statement against the death penalty-we do not have the right to take his life.
 
Thank you, sir.
 
Sincerely,
 
Marsha A. Lyons

September 14, 2006

Dear Governor Bush, 

I was very sad to hear about Carole Andrews' resignation from the Broward County School Board.  I understand that you will be appointing her successor to serve in an interim capacity until a new election can be held.

I would like to express my interest in being considered for this appointment.  Although I have not had the opportunity to meet you in person, I believe that you have met my in-laws--George and Helen Weaver on a number of occasions.  I live in Davie, Florida, and have been married 25 years to my husband, Jefferson, who works as a real estate attorney.  I have 5 children--3 boys and 2 girls, whose ages range from 23 to 5 years of age.  They have all come through the Nova schools in Davie, Florida.

I am a long-time supporter of the Republican Party and I have worked in the Broward County PTA for the last 17 years.  Our school, Nova Blanche Forman, has a student enrollment of almost 900 children.  I have served as PTA President, Vice President, Advisory Chair and Mentor.  I am on the I-Zone Committee, SAC and SAF and have served on numerous other education-oriented committees  through the years.  I have supported and worked with Broward County Council Presidents Kathy Rayson and Elinor Adler in their recent endeavors to support the children in the Broward County schools.

I have attended Legislative Conferences for PTA in Tallahassee but regret that I was not able to meet with you during those conventions.  You may also recall that I invited you to attend our 40-year Celebration at Nova Blanche Forman but your schedule did not permit you to attend.  However, I greatly appreciate the gracious letter of support you sent to our school regarding our anniversary.

I am motivated to seek the school board position for a number of reasons.  I am concerned that the Broward County School System must address the concerns of so many different constituencies that it sometimes forgets that the children attending the schools are our most important consideration.  We need to be the advocate of our childrens' interests 24 hours a day, seven days a week.  I also want to make sure that tax dollars are allocated equitably and fairly so that no student is left behind.  I am also struck as to how huge differences in the physical plants of schools that are located only a few miles apart from each other can exist; I worry that we are not using our scarce resources in the most efficient and effective ways possible.  We have problems in the schools in 2006 that were virtually unheard of even 20 years ago and the schools, like it or not, have become the surrogate parents of many of our children.  This unprecedented situation has made remedying the shortcomings of the educational system all the more pressing.

I do not want to overstate the difficulties facing the Broward County School System.  There are many talented and dedicated people who work within the system and I believe that we can effect great changes if we can work together and focus on improving our schools even more.  In closing, I believe that I can bring energy, integrity, enthusiasm and creativity to the Broward County School Board and would greatly appreciate any consideration you might give.

Should you need any additional information, I can be contacted at 954-551-8986.  Thank you for your time.


Sincerely,


Shelley Weaver

From:	Linda hubner <lmhubner@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Thursday, September 14, 2006 5:46 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Clarence Hill execution





Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to you to ask you to stay the scheduled September 20th execution of Clarence Hill. It has been statistically proven that executions sanctioned by the state do not help the victim's family recover from their loss, nor do they deter other capital crimes from occurring. Our society is morally diminished by executions, and children are exposed to violence perpetrated by adults they should be modeling. Capital punishment makes no sense if its motivation is a reduction of violence. Prison terms with no hope of release are an alternative to capital punishment for the most violent among us. I leave you with one question:

"Why do we kill people who kill people to show that killing people is wrong?"

Not in my name,

Linda Hubner

 Dear Governor Bush,

            There is no reason to execute Clarence Hill right now.

            There are three good reasons not to.

1.     The U.S. Supreme Court has declared that our method of execution may indeed be forbidden under the Constitution as cruel and unusual punishment.

2.     Our method of execution, a combination of chemicals prohibited for euthanizing animals, may indeed be inordinately painful.

3.     The death watch is an expensive process which is unlikely to result in an actual execution.

 

What’s the rush? There’s always another opportunity for death, but life comes only once.

From:	Isabel Cosio Carballo <isabelc@sfrpc.com>
Sent:	Thursday, September 14, 2006 1:43 PM
To:	Openshaw, Scott
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; Carolyn Dekle; Peggy Tadej; Rhonda Noah
Subject:	Mega Region information for Governor Bush
Attachments:	florida.gif; South Florida Mega-Region Counties by RPC.pdf; America 2050 Briefing Book - Feb 2006 Roundtable.pdf; AM2050mastermap.gif

Importance:	High

Mr. Scott Openshaw

State of Florida

OTTED

(850) 487-2568

 

 

Hi Scott,

 

On behalf of my executive director Carolyn A. Dekle and our Council, it is my pleasure to forward to you information related to the proposed Florida “Mega-Region” and the national mega-region effort. 

 

As I mentioned in my phone message, our understanding from Peggy Tadej of NARC is that the Governor will be interviewed for the NARC/EDA Telecast that will be broadcast in October.   Please find below, and attached, information related to the proposed Florida Mega-Region, which we currently refer to as the “South-Central Florida Mega-Region,” and the national mega-region effort.  

 

Peggy’s email message, which I have amended slightly to reflect recent changes in the South Florida line up of interviews and remove references to two mega-regions (our understanding is that we are talking about one 32-county mega-region at this time), includes general information about the telecast as well as Peggy’s contact info.  I hope that this information will be helpful to you and Governor Bush.

 

Please do not hesitate to contact me if I can be of additional assistance.

 

Sincerely,

 

Isabel Cosio Carballo

Coordinator, Legislative & Public Affairs

South Florida Regional Planning Council

(954) 985-4416

Cell: (954) 240-2575

Email: isabelc@sfrpc.com 

 

**************************

 

The effort to promote the concept of “mega-regions” is being spearheaded by the Regional Plan Association of New York, in partnership with the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy and Southern California Association of Governments, under the auspices of America 2050 (www.america2050.org).   The academic literature describes mega-regions as “an extended network of metropolitan centers and surrounding areas, often crossing county and state lines, linked by transportation and communication networks, as well as by geographic, environmental, economic, and social factors.”  The key points of the initiative as described in an America 2050 briefing paper are as follows: 

 

*     New forecasts of population growth in the United States predict a 40 percent increase over current levels, to reach a total population of 430 million by the year 2050.

 

*     This new growth will be concentrated in ten or more emerging “mega-regions” – large, connected networks of metropolitan areas.  Mega-regions are projected to absorb 70% of the population growth and 80% of the economic growth that the United States will experience between now and 2050. 

 

*     These mega-regions, which are defined by environmental, cultural, infrastructure and functional characteristics, will experience five key demographic and spatial challenges as they continue to take shape in the coming decades.

o       Rapid population growth

o       Build-out of metropolitan areas

o       Uneven and inequitable growth patterns within and between regions

o       Stressed ecosystems (“eco-structure”)

o       Aging infrastructure facilities

 

*     The “mega-region” concept provides a spatial framework for organizing planning investments and policies in the United States to address these future challenges such as “future federal surface transportation bills, the reorganization of Amtrak, protecting major ecosystems and watersheds from unrestrained development, connecting bypassed cities and regions to sources of growth, and preparing infrastructure and disaster response systems.”   

 

*     Similar networks of metropolitan areas in Asia and Europe are being seen as the new competitive units in the global economy, and major public and private investments are being made in those areas in high-speed rail, broadband communication, goods movement systems and other infrastructure to strengthen transportation and economic connections between their component cities.

 

*     Without similar investments, mega-regions in America will face common problems associated with the rapid influx of population and fail to capitalize on their potential for economic growth.

 

*     A new initiative called “America 2050: Towards a National Strategy for Prosperity, Equity and Sustainability” has been launched to address America’s anticipated growth before the year 2050 and the challenges and opportunities associated with the emergence of mega-regions.

 

Studies and published reports have been done to define the following mega-regions:  the Northeast, Piedmont Atlantic, Arizona Sun Corridor, Southern California and Cascadia Ecopolis.  However, a formal study of the South-Central Florida Mega-Region has not been initiated. 

 

On September 21st the South Florida Regional Planning Council is hosting a policy discussion with a small group of national and regional experts and academics.  Guests at this initial policy roundtable will discuss the national mega-region effort and the proposed South-Central Florida Mega-Region including boundaries; whether or not this construct makes sense for south-central Florida; identification of key influences affecting the mega-region; and next steps, including whether or not to initiate a formal study of the South-Central Florida Mega-Region. 

 

It is expected that similar policy discussions may be hosted in different areas of the South-Central Florida Mega-Region in the months to come. 

 

 

 

 

From: Peggy Tadej [mailto:Tadej@NARC.org] 
Sent: Tuesday, September 12, 2006 4:26 PM
Subject: Economic Development Today Telecast

 

September 12, 2006 

 

Dear Telecast Participants:  

 

On behalf of the Department of Commerce, Economic Development Administration, and the National Association of Regional Council’s, we appreciate your participation on our telecast called “Economic Development Today.

 

This telecast will showcase “best practice” examples of regional economic development in Florida, and will feature interviews with Florida Governor Jeb Bush and other leaders from the public and private sectors who are collaborating across political boundaries to meet the challenges of 21st century economic development. 

 

The show will also feature a part of NARC’s 5th Annual Metropolitan Regions Forum that will focus on Florida, and bring together the twenty largest metropolitan regions across the United States. 

 

Topics addressed will include:  infrastructure (transportation, environmental, financing), linkages to the global economy, politics of development, workforce development, and faith-based initiatives.  We want you to focus on the solutions to the growing mega-region.  

 

Host

Matthew E. Crow

Director of Communications

 

Panelists 

Interviews South Florida 

Carolyn A. Dekle, Executive Director, South Florida Regional Planning Council

James F. Murley, Director, Florida Atlantic University Center for Urban and Environmental Solutions

Neisen Kasdin, Chair, The Beacon Council

Paul Wallace, SFRPC Board Member

 

Interview with Florida Governor 

Governor Jeb Bush

 

Interviews Tampa Bay/Clearwater/Sarasota

Rick Baker, Mayor St. Petersburg 

Frank Hibbard Mayor of Clearwater

Pam Iorio, Mayor of the City of Tampa

Daniel Bernard, President Somebody Cares Tampa Bay 

 

The telecast is a one-hour broadcast that will go on air October 5th, 2006 from 3 PM to 4:00 PM EDT.  

 

The targeted audience for this telecast is economic development practitioners; State Economic Development Offices; nationwide Regional Councils and Economic Development Districts that represent local governments and their elected broad of directors; Chamber of Commerce; and University Centers.  

 

I will be contacting each of you to work on a set of questions that the host of the show will be asking you, the telecast participants.  To assist in the process, I will need information to prepare the script for the host to tell your story.  The following information is what I will need from you.  

 

1)          A bio of yourself

2)          A short paragraph on the project(s) you will be describing

3)          Background information on your projects

4)          Between 5-7 questions for the host.  

5)           Ideas of Graphics and/or B-Roll that will showcase your region    

  

After the filming of the program, a copy of the entire broadcast will be available for you.  

 

I do hope your schedule will allow you to join this important telecast.  To see an example of the previous telecasts go to the EDA website: http://www.eda.gov/NewsEvents/NewsEvents.xml

                                                                              

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me.  

 

Thanks for your collaboration and cooperation.  

 

 

Peggy Tadej

Director of Environment and Special Projects

Nat. Association of Regional Councils

1666 Connecticut Ave., NW Suite 300

Washington, DC 20009

202-986-1032, ext. 224

202-986-1038 fax

Hello again,

I am in the process of making my plans for next week and need to know

only person giving testimony on behalf of Taylor Wells. There will be  
no family or friends  present in Tallahassee.  I am recommending   
that at whatever time Taylor is released he should live outside  
Brevard County to show respect for Mrs. Codgen and other family and  
friends who may still feel he should serve his mandatory sentence. I  
have agreed to assume the role of lifetime mentor for as long as that  
is in Taylor Wells' best interest.

Goodyear, Case Agent for the David Codgen homicide.  However, I am  
not forwarding it to you as I previously planned because Agent

culpable co-defendants are out of jail, etc. and that is not where I  
want to focus this case.  I am affirming that the system worked in  
its conviction of Mr. Wells under the felony murder rule, and that it  
doesn't matter who does or doesn't remain in prison, who was youngest  
and least culpable,etc.
This process is about admission of guilt, expression of remorse,  
plans for restitution, and pleas for mercy and forgiveness.
