From:	vicki shaffer <furbygirl30@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, September 14, 2006 3:19 AM
To:	Jeb Bush 2; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please investigate political matter now

The Hon. Jeb Bush, Governor of the State of Florida:

There is a need for Appointment of Special Prosecutor To Investigate 
and
empanel grand jury regarding Improper Use of Official Positions and
Unlawful Use of Taxpayer Funds to Influence Judicial Election and
Outcome of Terri Schindler Schiavo Case
 
   On or about July 2, 2004, a political commercial promoting the
reelection of George W. Greer to the office of Sixth Judicial Circuit
Court Judge, Group 18, was filmed on government property, a courtroom 
in
the Pinellas County Courthouse. Participating in the political activity
on governmental property in uniform, allegedly while on duty, was
William Cunningham, a deputy with the Pinellas County Sheriff's
Department.  Deputy Cunningham engaged in the political activity with
the full knowledge and consent (and perhaps order)  of Sheriff Everett
Rice, according to Marianne Pasha, PCSO public information officer, and
according to payroll records, was paid with taxpayer funds for doing
so.  Deputy Cunningham appeared in the political with a
government-owned vehicle, a Pinellas County Sheriff's Department patrol
car. 
   Also appearing in the political ad with their names and positions
identified in writing on the screen were James Hellickson, assistant
prosecutor in the office of Sixth Circuit state attorney Bernie McCabe
and Paula Shea, assistant in the office of Sixth Circuit public 
defender
Bob Dillinger, allegedly unlawfully using the influence of their titles
and positions to attempt to influence a judicial election.
   Also appearing in the political advertisement, allegedly
improperly, were court officers and employees of the Sixth Circuit,
names unknown.
   Public officers Everett Rice, Bernie McCabe and Bob Dillinger in
addition to William Cunningham, James Hellickson and Paula Shea
knowingly, willfully and intentionally used the influence and power of
their offices and positions and in the case of at least William
Cunningham, with the use of taxpayer funds, to attempt to influence the
outcome of a judicial election, in essence controlling a judgeship and
controlling the outcome of the Terri Schindler Schiavo case at a time
when Sheriff Rice and Prosecutor McCabe had steadfastly refused to
perform the duties of their respective offices to investigate matters 
of
alleged criminal wrongdoing in the Schiavo case.
 
   Under Article IV, Section 1(a) Florida Constitution, the governor
is vested with "supreme executive power".  Further, the Governor
"shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed" and commissions
"all officers of the state and counties".
   Under the general law of the state, the governor may, by
executive order filed with the Department of State, assign state
attorneys "one of more specified investigations, cases or matters.
Specifically, Section 27.14(1) Florida Statutes provides if any state
attorney is disqualified to represent the state in any investigation,
case or matter pending in the courts of his or her circuit or if, for
any other good and sufficient reason, the Governor determines that the
ends of justice would be best served, the Governor may, by executive
order filed with the Department of State, either order an exchange of
circuits or of courts between such state attorney and any other state
attorney or order an assignment of any state attorney to discharge the
duties of the state attorney with respect to one or more specified
investigations, cases or matters specified in general in the executive
order of the Governor.
   In this case, it is mandatory that a special prosecutor be
assigned to investigate this matter as Mr. McCabe, state attorney for
the Sixth Circuit, is directly and personally involved in the matter 
and
would be a subject of the investigation as well as an employee of his
office, therefore Mr. McCabe has a prohibited conflict of interest and
must be disqualified.
   As Governor, you frequently issue executive orders appointing
another state attorney to investigate and prosecute cases free from the
taint of appearance of conflict of interest or impropriety.
   Good and sufficient reason exists for the Governor to determine
that the ends of justice would be best served by assigning another 
state
attorney to investigate the alleged improper use of public office,
public funds and government property to influence the outcome of a
judicial election and ultimately the outcome of the high profile 
Schiavo
case.
   "A public office is a public trust" Section Article II, §8(a)
Florida Constitution. Moreover, "the people shall have the right to
secure and sustain that trust against abuse. 
   The issue at hand involves official misconduct in Pinellas County
related to the judicial election of George W. Greer during 2004 and in
particular, the Primary of Aug. 31, 2004 as it relates to his political
commercial aired between Aug. 9, 2004 and Aug. 30, 2004.
   The matter involves some or all of the following acts or
omissions:  Abuse of the pubic trust (Art. II, Section 8(a) Florida
Constitution, breach of the public trust for private gain and inducing
others to breach the public trust for private gain (Art. II, Section 5,
Florida Constitution) violations of Florida's Code of Ethics including
but not limited to Section 112.313(2) FS, 112.313(6) and 112.317.
   The immediate assignment of a special prosecutor to investigate
this matter is requested
Sincerely,
Vicki L. Shaffer
138 Glen Abbey Lane
Morgantown WV 26508
 




Vicki

Sent:	Wednesday, September 13, 2006 2:21 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Illegal Immigration

Illegal immigration is a big problem with me.  My ancestors came here legally, except for my Cherokee side who were already here! If you think about the problem as written below, I think a solution is evident.

 

A lady wrote the best letter in the Editorials in ages!! It explains things better than all the baloney you hear on TV.............

 

Let's say I break into your house

 

“Recently large demonstrations have taken place across the country protesting the fact that Congress is finally addressing the issue of illegal immigration. Certain people are angry that the US might protect its own borders, might make it harder to sneak into this country and,

once here, to stay indefinitely. Let me see if I correctly understand the thinking behind these protests.

 

Let's say I break into your house. Let's say that when you discover me in your house, you insist that I leave. But I say, "I've made all the beds and washed the dishes and did the laundry and swept the floors; I've done all the things you don't like to do. I'm hard-working and honest (except for when I broke into your house).

 

According to the protesters, not only must you let me stay, you must add me to your family's insurance plan, educate my kids, and provide other benefits to me and to my family (my husband will do your yard work because he too is hard-working and honest, except for that breaking in part). If you try to call the police or force me out, I will call my friends who will picket your house carrying signs that proclaim my right to be there. It's only fair, after all, because you have a nicer house than I do, and I'm just trying to better myself. I'm hard-working and honest, um, except for well, you know.

 

And what a deal it is for me!! I live in your house, contributing only a fraction of the cost of my keep, and there is nothing you can do about it without being accused of selfishness, prejudice and being an anti-housebreaker.

 

Oh yeah, and I want you to learn my language so you can communicate with me.

 

Why can't people see how ridiculous this is?! Only in America....if you agree, pass it on (in English). Share it if you see the value of it as a good smile,

 

If not blow it off along with your future Social Security funds.

Dear Governor Bush:

 

It is my understanding that Nathaniel “Nat” Kidder has been recommended for two circuit judicial positions that are open at this time and that an interview is scheduled on September 13, 2006.  

 

I am requesting you give serious consideration to appointing Mr. Kidder.  Summarily, he 
is a traditional family man with fair and honorable values, and simply a many who knows and loves his work. 

 

A recent St. Petersburg Times quote stated that he is “a highly regarded veteran attorney.”  Other quotes excerpted from the St. Petersburg Times state the following:  “Kidder’s legal colleagues offer nothing but praise for his professionalism, legal talent and temperament.”  "Kidder also has the experience of having been both a prosecutor and defense attorney. He is widely viewed as fair, smart and able."

 

Mr. Kidder has been a lawyer for nineteen years. His practice has ranged from criminal prosecution and defense work to complex civil litigation and family law. Nat has represented clients in both federal and state courts. He has experience in over sixty jury trials and has represented clients before the Second and Fifth District Courts of Appeal. 


Nat is a former United States Marine and has been a resident of Pinellas County for 23 years. He is married and the father of five children.  Nat Kidder has been awarded an "AV" rating by Martindale-Hubbell, the nation’s premier attorney rating service. This rating indicates that Nat's peers have rated his legal ability as "Very High to Preeminent."  He was selected on three separate occasions for judicial office by the Judicial Nominating Commission of the Sixth Judicial Circuit. 

 

Again, please consider Mr. Kidder for a circuit judicial position.  Thank you for your time and consideration.

 

Sincerely,

 

Marlene S. Shaw

From:	westmorelandt@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, September 12, 2006 3:45 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thank you for your support at Camp Blanding on September 11, 2006

 Dear Governor Bush,
 
I want to thank you for the incredible job you have done for Florida and as Commander-in-Chief of the Florida National Guard.  I have the dubious distinction of being the First Sergeant of the first soldier in the Florida Army National Guard to die in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom.  Sergeant First Class Lloyd S. Clements was one of my platoon sergeants.  He was  a hard-working, dedicated to the mission, and completely trustworthy soldier.  He was one of the finest men I have ever met and a devout Christian.  I was among the privileged guests present at the dedication of the Camp Blanding Memorial.  It was a beautiful and fitting ceremony.  Thank you for taking the time to speak and talk to the families of the fallen soldiers.  I know it meant a lot to them.  
 
I had the honor of introducing you to my wife Karon Westmoreland, who started as a volunteer years ago and now is a member of the State Family Readiness Program.  I must admit, Sir, that in your presence I was a bit nervous.  Knowing that your time was limited, I tried to be as brief as possible and spoke out of context.  I told you that I had met your wife, Columba, and she said that I was much bigger than yourself.   When I had met Mrs. Bush, she knowing that I was a soldier, gave me a hug to thank me for my service.  I had to lean over really far to give her a hug and that is when she said that I was so tall that she thought I was even taller than yourself.  The words just came out and sounded wrong.  I do apologize.  I hope you got a chuckle out of it.
 
Once again, thank you for the being my Governor and I will continue to support you in all future endeavors.
 
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Master Sergeant Todd G. Westmoreland
USAR Retired
Florida Army National Guard

From:	Darla <letournd@peoplepc.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 12, 2006 10:17 AM
To:	Army
Cc:	Senator Bill Nelson; Senator Mel Martinez; barbara cooley; Maureen Valiquette; 'Bob Janes'; 'Doug St. Cerney'; 'John Albion'; 'Ray Judah'; 'Tammy Hall'; Governor Jeb Bush; Kyle, Bruce; Kottkamp, Jeff; Rubio, Marco; Grant, Michael; Kreegel, Paige; Williams, Trudi; Saunders, Burt; Aronberg, Dave; 'Senator Ken Pritt'; 'Senator Lisa Carlton'; 'Senator Mike Bennett'; 'Carla Johnston'; 'City Council'; 'Jim Jennings'; MickDenham@aol.com; 'Steve Brown'; 'Tom Rothman'
Subject:	Comments on Lake O Regulation Schedule

Dear Sir:

I’m a resident of Sanibel Island and have become increasingly concerned about the impact of Lake O releases on our estuary.  The damage being caused by the Lake O releases down the Caloosahatchee are killing our waters, our wildlife, our way of life, and hurting the economy of Southwest Florida, which hurts the overall health of the State economy.  After last summer’s crisis, the communities of Florida affected by the Lake O releases have been vocal and organized in sounding the alarm and getting the attention of policy makers--locally, state-wide, and in Washington--and the media has kept the focus on the problem and its dire consequences.  We really thought that the policy makers “got it”…then suddenly, the draft Lake O regulation schedule comes out and we’re back to square one!  What happened?  How could the Corps ignore the impacts on the estuaries when setting these regulations?  The lessons of Katrina should not be “protect the dike at all costs”.  Don’t hide behind that argument, and create another disaster.  The solution to this problem requires shared sacrifice, it requires using the best & most up-to-date data, and it requires balance and fine-tuning.  The Lake O regulation schedule must not permit releases into the estuaries that exceed biologist’s limits for environmental safety.  The Corps protocol must maintain the Lake at a lower level by having ongoing low-level releases sent in ALL directions—not just down the Caloosahatchee.  There is land owned by the Water Management and by the Corps where excess water can be stored in emergencies and this should be part of your regulation plan, NOW.

 

The Charlotte Harbor is a NATIONAL ESTUARY, part of EPA’s national estuary program that is supposed to afford it extra protections.  There’s a management plan that all parties have agreed to help implement.  Why is one arm of the Federal government destroying a resource recognized by another part of the same Federal government as a treasure to be protected and preserved?  Please change the regulation schedule before you create another disaster that cannot be undone. 

 

I am unable to attend the Corps’ public hearing on September 14th but wanted to add my voice to those attending that important meeting.  Please listen to the participants at that meeting and to the many other residents of Southwest Florida.  We are well informed, we’re passionate, we’re dead serious, and you know we’re right.   

 

Sincerely,

Darla Letourneau

 

Darla Letourneau

1679 Serenity Lane

Sanibel, FL  33957

letournd@peoplepc.com

(239) 472-1179

cell: (239) 850-3219

Dear Governor Jeb Bush, 
 
My name is Kay Thacker, I live in Key Largo, unincorporated Monroe County, my phone and fax number is 305-451-3929. I am secretary of Sexton Cove Property Owners Association, Inc.; I serve as executive board member on the Island of Key Largo Federation of Homeowners Association, Inc. There is a special BOCC ( Board of County Commission) meeting in Key Largo on Wednesday September 13, 2006. It is a special meeting for budget, but as I was reading the agenda Item F #1 caught my eye.
 
Monroe County Board of County Commissioners
 Spacer
Agenda- Special Meeting

 
 
F.      COUNTY ATTORNEY

1.      Approval to advertise Notice of Intention to Adopt, and forward notification to DCA, of a Proposed Amendment to the 2010 Comprehensive Plan,~ to provide additional density bonuses and .5 ROGO allocations for affordable housing units between 400 - 750 square feet and 
 
 
*******relaxation of the 35 foot maximum height limitation under certain limited circumstances using the expedited adoption proceeding provided in the Community Workforce Housing Innovation Pilot Program ("CWHIP").
 
Key West was allowed to vote on a similar issue in the September 5, 2006 primary and it was voted down 2 to 1, 35 ft height increase to 37 ft...we are not even being given the chance to vote on our height increase from 35 to 37ft. The over all consensus in Monroe County is NO HEIGHT INCREASE FOR MONROE COUNTY. 
 
Our county officials are setting this ambush up according to our 2010 Comprehensive Plan so that this can be voted on by your appointed Commissioner Glenn Patton and not our elected Commissioner Sylvia Murphy...the voters have spoken and this is one of the reasons I am e-mailing your office.  I will following up with a phone call to your office this morning.  You have already allowed John Dick, elected school board official to take his seat, and you have allowed Mario DiGennaro County Commissioner of district 4 to take his seat, please help expedite fair Government.  I am urging all citizens of unincorporated Monroe County to call or email our Governor on this matter.
 
I AM REQUESTING THAT YOU REMOVE INTERIUM COUNTY COMMISSIONER GLENN PATTON AND ALLOW OUR ELECTED COMMISSIONER SYLVIA MURPHY TO TAKE HER SEAT SO THE VOTERS HAVE A CHANCE TO BE HEARD. THE VOTERS OF MONROE COUNTY HAVE SPOKEN, PLEASE CONSIDER THIS.  
Thank You for your consideration in this matter.
 
Kay Thacker

From:	Dianne Walker <djwalker@htc.net>
Sent:	Monday, September 11, 2006 11:04 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	DOE@dos.state.fl.us; kmole@dos.state.fl.us; klparker@dos.state.fl.us; secretaryofstate@dos.state.fl.us
Subject:	UNLAWFUL POLITICAL ACTIVITY---SPECIAL PROSECUTOR DICTATED

UNLAWFUL POLITICAL ACTIVITY---SPECIAL PROSECUTOR DICTATED

  I join with others in petitioning Gov. Jeb Bush to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate unlawful political activity and the unlawful use of position of various public officers and employees to influence an election and court case.

 TO: The Hon. Jeb Bush, Governor of the State Of Florida

850-488-4441 (phone)

850-487-0801 (Fax)

e-mail: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

 

RE: Need for Appointment of Special Prosecutor To Investigate and empanel grand jury regarding Improper Use of Official Positions and Unlawful Use of Taxpayer Funds to Influence Judicial Election and Outcome of Terri Schindler Schiavo Case

 

   On or about July 2, 2004, a political commercial promoting the reelection of George W. Greer to the office of Sixth Judicial Circuit Court Judge, Group 18, was filmed on government property, a courtroom in the Pinellas County Courthouse. Participating in the political activity on governmental property in uniform, allegedly while on duty, was William Cunningham, a deputy with the Pinellas County Sheriff’s Department.  Deputy Cunningham engaged in the political activity with the full knowledge and consent (and perhaps order)  of Sheriff Everett Rice, according to Marianne Pasha, PCSO public information officer, and according to payroll records, was paid with taxpayer funds for doing so.  Deputy Cunningham appeared in the political with a government-owned vehicle, a Pinellas County Sheriff’s Department patrol car.  

   Also appearing in the political ad with their names and positions identified in writing on the screen were James Hellickson, assistant prosecutor in the office of Sixth Circuit state attorney Bernie McCabe and Paula Shea, assistant in the office of Sixth Circuit public defender Bob Dillinger, allegedly unlawfully using the influence of their titles and positions to attempt to influence a judicial election.

   Also appearing in the political advertisement, allegedly improperly, were court officers and employees of the Sixth Circuit, names unknown.

   Public officers Everett Rice, Bernie McCabe and Bob Dillinger in addition to William Cunningham, James Hellickson and Paula Shea knowingly, willfully and intentionally used the influence and power of their offices and positions and in the case of at least William Cunningham, with the use of taxpayer funds, to attempt to influence the outcome of a judicial election, in essence controlling a judgeship and controlling the outcome of the Terri Schindler Schiavo case at a time when Sheriff Rice and Prosecutor McCabe had steadfastly refused to perform the duties of their respective offices to investigate matters of alleged criminal wrongdoing in the Schiavo case.

 

   Under Article IV, Section 1(a) Florida Constitution, the governor is vested with “supreme executive power”.  Further, the Governor “shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed” and commissions “all officers of the state and counties”.

   Under the general law of the state, the governor may, by executive order filed with the Department of State, assign state attorneys “one of more specified investigations, cases or matters. Specifically, Section 27.14(1) Florida Statutes provides if any state attorney is disqualified to represent the state in any investigation, case or matter pending in the courts of his or her circuit or if, for any other good and sufficient reason, the Governor determines that the ends of justice would be best served, the Governor may, by executive order filed with the Department of State, either order an exchange of circuits or of courts between such state attorney and any other state attorney or order an assignment of any state attorney to discharge the duties of the state attorney with respect to one or more specified investigations, cases or matters specified in general in the executive order of the Governor.

   In this case, it is mandatory that a special prosecutor be assigned to investigate this matter as Mr. McCabe, state attorney for the Sixth Circuit, is directly and personally involved in the matter and would be a subject of the investigation as well as an employee of his office, therefore Mr. McCabe has a prohibited conflict of interest and must be disqualified.

   As Governor, you frequently issue executive orders appointing another state attorney to investigate and prosecute cases free from the taint of appearance of conflict of interest or impropriety. 

   Good and sufficient reason exists for the Governor to determine that the ends of justice would be best served by assigning another state attorney to investigate the alleged improper use of public office, public funds and government property to influence the outcome of a judicial election and ultimately the outcome of the high profile Schiavo case.

   “A public office is a public trust” Section Article II, §8(a) Florida Constitution. Moreover, “the people shall have the right to secure and sustain that trust against abuse.  

   The issue at hand involves official misconduct in Pinellas County related to the judicial election of George W. Greer during 2004 and in particular, the Primary of Aug. 31, 2004 as it relates to his political commercial aired between Aug. 9, 2004 and Aug. 30, 2004.

   The matter involves some or all of the following acts or omissions:  Abuse of the pubic trust (Art. II, Section 8(a) Florida Constitution, breach of the public trust for private gain and inducing others to breach the public trust for private gain (Art. II, Section 5, Florida Constitution) violations of Florida’s Code of Ethics including but not limited to Section 112.313(2) FS, 112.313(6) and 112.317. 

   The immediate assignment of a special prosecutor to investigate this matter is requested.

 Sincerely,

Dianne Walker

From:	Mysteriousdiva88@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, September 11, 2006 7:46 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; cfo@fldfs.com; Bronson, Charles H.
Subject:	Important:Letter on behalf of Lorenzo Barajas

  
Dear Governor, Members of the Clemency Board, and whomever it concerns,
 
On September 21, 2006, you all face the difficult task of determining the fate of those who wish to have their civil rights restored and those seeking clemency, a predicament which my father, Lorenzo Barajas faces. My name is Sonia Barajas and I am the proud daughter of Lorenzo Barajas, a human being who was wrongfully accused and convicted of a crime he never committed. I write the following letter because it hurts me to see the situation my father is in. My father is my inspiration. He works vigorously in order to provide for our family. He is viewed in our community as a hard worker and dedicated father. My father would never hurt anybody. His only mission in life seems to be providing for his family, and protecting his family. Many years ago, my half-sister accused my father of molesting her. This whole evil scheme was brewed up by her mother who was filled with envy at the thought of my father being with my mother and not with her. Although proof of this so called molestation was never attained my father was convicted and therefore many years later he still carries the burden of that horrible lie. I know my father is innocent and I have never doubted it for a minute. My father and my mother have been together for the past 19 years. We are a happy family composed of five children. My younger brother is 12 years old and is in the 6th grade and on the honor roll. I also have a brother named Raul who is 15 years old and in the 10th grade. He is viewed by his teachers as a young man with excellent manners whose presence always cheers up the day. My sister Emma is 16 years old and in the 11th grade. I am proud to say that my sister is enrolled in honors classes and also is known to make the honor roll. My brother Antonio is 17 years old and is in the 12th grade, a senior in high school. He will be graduating on May 2007. As I mentioned before, my name is Sonia and I am 18 years old. I graduated from Glades Central High School in Belle Glade, Florida on May 19, 2006. I am a member of the NAACP, and also actively participated while in high school with the International Thespian Society, Future Business Leaders of America, and served as a member in the Criminal Justice program at Glades Central and also I still give back to my community through volunteering. I go above and beyond my responsibilities because my father always taught me to help those who are in need. He has a significant influence on me and because of that I try to push myself to the outermost limits. My father has always taught me to challenge myself. With his help I attained one of my goals which was to be the first child to graduate from high school. My father has four other children from his previous marriage who never graduated and decided to drop out of school. They are still, to this day, feeling the effects of their decision to give up, struggling with their own children and minimum wage jobs. My dad supported me and gave me all the encouragement I needed to keep going even when I felt like giving up. It is because of my father that I feel I have to further pursue my education by attending college. I hope to major in Criminal Justice or Political Science. Since my father was declared a sexual offender, it is very hard for him to get a good paying job. We are quite a large family and working in the sugar cane is just not cutting it. My father is capable of achieving so much more, but due to him being labeled, he is not offered the opportunity to exemplify his great capabilities. The reason I have  decided to write this letter, is because I know you will realize that my father is just a victim of the system. It is a great honor to be able to say that Lorenzo Barajas is my father. If my father is denied, I plan to keep fighting until my father’s name is cleared up and the truth is finally set free. I am a believer of the following quote:” Happy are those who dream dreams and are ready to pay the price to make them come true.” My dream is to one day witness my father finally declared innocent of the crime he allegedly committed, and although I know this will be a tough battle, I know that our family is prepared to support my father one hundred percent. I thank you for your time and really appreciate you taking your time in reading this letter. I have faith in this great system and know that everything will be cleared soon. May God Bless, and once again I trust that your judgment will be favorable to my father.
Once again thank you, 
 
Sonia Barajas

From:	James Gangle <james_gangle@yahoo.com>

Dear Mr. Governor,
  Thank You for your consideration to this serioius matter.  I am well aware of the constitutional seperations that would preclude any intervention from your office.  I am, and will continue to handle my family's issues.  My primary concern and my desire to meet with you is in an effort to get any ideas as to how to achieve massive reform in the Family Law arena.
  What is currently going on is just plain "wrong".  I realize that nothing is going to resolve my personal concerns.  My desire is to see to it that these things don't happen to other fathers in the State of Florida.

Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> wrote:

Dear Mr. Gangle: 
Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush requesting assistance with a child custody matter.  He has asked me to respond.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor’s intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  
Custody and visitation rulings are under the jurisdiction of the judicial system.  Under Florida law, the court’s decision in these cases is based on the best interest of the child or children involved.  Judges review all of the information presented to them and apply the law to make their decision.    If you are unhappy with a ruling or feel a case has not been handled according to the law, you should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or the county legal aid association has information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number of Florida Legal Services is (850) 385-7900.  Those dissatisfied with their representatives should consider choosing another attorney.

Of course, should you suspect a child is in any danger, notify your local law enforcement or the Department of Children and Families’ hot line, 1-800-96-ABUSE.

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.  Please know this is due to lack of jurisdiction, not lack of concern.

Sincerely, 
  
Warren Davis 
Office of Citizens’ Services 


  _____

-----Original Message-----
From: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, September 8, 2006


For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


2006 STATEWIDE READING IN THE ARTS CONTEST ANNOUNCED

Last Friday, First Lady Columba Bush and I launched a statewide Reading in
the Arts contest for Florida's middle school students centered on the New
York Times Best Seller "Peter and the Starcatchers" by Dave Barry and Ridley
Pearson.  The contest, Florida's Journey into Neverland, is sponsored by
Just Read, Florida! The contest is the final component of Florida's
year-long reading initiative Shoot for the Stars: A Record-Breaking Year for
Middle Schools.  The Reading in the Arts contest is a wonderful opportunity
for middle school students to get wrapped up in a great book and showcase
their creativity and imagination.  Winners will be selected in the following
categories: Illustration, Short Essay, and Short Video.  The contest is open
to all students in sixth to eighth grades in public, private and home
schools.  To learn more about the contest, please visit
www.justreadflorida.com.


JUST READ, FLORIDA! CELEBRATES FIFTH ANNIVERSARY

On Thursday, I recognized our reading initiative, Just Read, Florida!, as it
celebrated its fifth anniversary. Since its inception, Just Read, Florida!
has provided training to more than 45,000 Florida teachers, 4,000 principals
and 2,500 reading coaches to promote and improve reading skills and literacy
for Florida students.  Since the Just Read, Florida! initiative launched,
record numbers of Florida students are reading at or above grade level.  The
Just Read, Florida! initiative strengthens our education system by helping
us reach the goal of every student reading successfully by 2012.  This
research-driven program is helping Florida students make progress in reading
-a necessary skill for success in life.  Established in 2001, the Just Read,
Florida! initiative uses the latest in research-based reading instruction to
boost the reading ability of students.  The program facilitates instruction
for educators, parents and students, while empowering school districts to
implement scientifically-researched reading programs and strategies to
improve student learning.   Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test (FCAT)
results this year show three-fourths of all Florida third grade students are
reading at or above grade level-the largest number in state history - up
eight percent from last year.  Florida is also closing the achievement gap
in reading.  This year, 61 percent of African-American students are reading
at or above grade level, up from 37 percent in 2001.  Hispanic students
recorded similar increases with 70 percent reading at or above grade level,
up from 46 percent in 2001.  For more information about Just Read, Florida!
visit www.justreadflorida.com.


MINORITY ENROLLMENT IN FLORIDA'S PUBLIC UNIVERSITIES INCREASES

On Friday, Carolyn Roberts, chair of the Florida Board of Governors, and I
announced a 4.8 percent increase in minority enrollment in Florida's public
universities. Overall enrollment in the State University System of Florida
increased by more than 7,300 students, to 288,413, a 2.6 percent increase.
Additionally, state universities graduated more than 61,000 students in
2006.  One of Florida's great strengths is our diversity, and the State
University System is building on that strength by providing greater access
to higher education to all our students.  As Florida's accountability
reforms continue to produce record learning gains, more and more students
leave high school ready to pursue a college education.  Enrollment of
African-American students increased by 1.6 percent and enrollment of
Hispanic students increased by 7.3 percent. Minority students now comprise
35.7 percent of students in the 11 institutions of the State University
System, up from 35 percent in Fall 2005. Since 1999, enrollment in Florida's
public universities has grown by more than 55,000 students, or 24 percent.
To view current university enrollment data, please visit www.flbog.org. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO RUBY CLAY

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8163


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

Volume 8, Issue 36

http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html


Thank you.

This commun-  ication originates from the Law Offices of Wollinka & Wollinka Attorneys at Law, and is protected under the Electronic Communication Privacy Act, 18 U.S.C. S2510 -2521.  The information contained in this e-mail message is intended for the use of the individual or entity to which it is addressed and may contain information that is proprietary, privileged, confidential, and exempt from disclosure under applicable laws.  If the reader of the message is not the intended recipient, or the employee or agent responsible for delivery to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any use, printing, reproduction, disclosure or dissemination of this communication may be subject to legal restriction or sanction.  Personal messages express views solely of the sender and shall not be attributed to the law firm. For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


2006 STATEWIDE READING IN THE ARTS CONTEST ANNOUNCED

Last Friday, First Lady Columba Bush and I launched a statewide Reading in
the Arts contest for Florida's middle school students centered on the New
York Times Best Seller "Peter and the Starcatchers" by Dave Barry and Ridley
Pearson. The contest, Florida's Journey into Neverland, is sponsored by
Just Read, Florida! The contest is the final component of Florida's
year-long reading initiative Shoot for the Stars: A Record-Breaking Year for
Middle Schools. The Reading in the Arts contest is a wonderful opportunity
for middle school students to get wrapped up in a great book and showcase
their creativity and imagination. Winners will be selected in the following
categories: Illustration, Short Essay, and Short Video. The contest is open
to all students in sixth to eighth grades in public, private and home
schools. To learn more about the contest, please visit
www.justreadflorida.com.


JUST READ, FLORIDA! CELEBRATES FIFTH ANNIVERSARY

On Thursday, I recognized our reading initiative, Just Read, Florida!, as it
celebrated its fifth anniversary. Since its inception, Just Read, Florida!
has provided training to more than 45,000 Florida teachers, 4,000 principals
and 2,500 reading coaches to promote and improve reading skills and literacy
for Florida students. Since the Just Read, Florida! initiative launched,
record numbers of Florida students are reading at or above grade level. The
Just Read, Florida! initiative strengthens our education system by helping
us reach the goal of every student reading successfully by 2012. This
research-driven program is helping Florida students make progress in reading
-a necessary skill for success in life. Established in 2001, the Just Read,
Florida! initiative uses the latest in research-based reading instruction to
boost the reading ability of students. The program facilitates instruction
for educators, parents and students, while empowering school districts to
implement scientifically-researched reading programs and strategies to
improve student learning. Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test (FCAT)
results this year show three-fourths of all Florida third grade students are
reading at or above grade level-the largest number in state history - up
eight percent from last year. Florida is also closing the achievement gap
in reading. This year, 61 percent of African-American students are reading
at or above grade level, up from 37 percent in 2001. Hispanic students
recorded similar increases with 70 percent reading at or above grade level,
up from 46 percent in 2001. For more information about Just Read, Florida!
visit www.justreadflorida.com.

On Friday, Carolyn Roberts, chair of the Florida Board of Governors, and I
announced a 4.8 percent increase in minority enrollment in Florida's public

increased by more than 7,300 students, to 288,413, a 2.6 percent increase.

From:	E. Maxcy Ordway <emordway@comcast.net>
Sent:	Monday, September 11, 2006 3:24 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Special Prosecutor

UNLAWFUL POLITICAL ACTIVITY---SPECIAL PROSECUTOR DICTATED

  I join with others in petitioning Gov. Jeb Bush to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate unlawful political activity and the unlawful use of position of various public officers and employees to influence an election and court case

 

TO: The Hon. Jeb Bush, Governor of the State Of Florida

850-488-4441 (phone)

850-487-0801 (Fax)

e-mail: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

 

RE: Need for Appointment of Special Prosecutor To Investigate and empanel grand jury regarding Improper Use of Official Positions and Unlawful Use of Taxpayer Funds to Influence Judicial Election and Outcome of Terri Schindler Schiavo Case

 

   On or about July 2, 2004, a political commercial promoting the reelection of George W. Greer to the office of Sixth Judicial Circuit Court Judge, Group 18, was filmed on government property, a courtroom in the Pinellas County Courthouse. Participating in the political activity on governmental property in uniform, allegedly while on duty, was William Cunningham, a deputy with the Pinellas County Sheriff’s Department.  Deputy Cunningham engaged in the political activity with the full knowledge and consent (and perhaps order)  of Sheriff Everett Rice, according to Marianne Pasha, PCSO public information officer, and according to payroll records, was paid with taxpayer funds for doing so.  Deputy Cunningham appeared in the political with a government-owned vehicle, a Pinellas County Sheriff’s Department patrol car.  

   Also appearing in the political ad with their names and positions identified in writing on the screen were James Hellickson, assistant prosecutor in the office of Sixth Circuit state attorney Bernie McCabe and Paula Shea, assistant in the office of Sixth Circuit public defender Bob Dillinger, allegedly unlawfully using the influence of their titles and positions to attempt to influence a judicial election.

   Also appearing in the political advertisement, allegedly improperly, were court officers and employees of the Sixth Circuit, names unknown.

   Public officers Everett Rice, Bernie McCabe and Bob Dillinger in addition to William Cunningham, James Hellickson and Paula Shea knowingly, willfully and intentionally used the influence and power of their offices and positions and in the case of at least William Cunningham, with the use of taxpayer funds, to attempt to influence the outcome of a judicial election, in essence controlling a judgeship and controlling the outcome of the Terri Schindler Schiavo case at a time when Sheriff Rice and Prosecutor McCabe had steadfastly refused to perform the duties of their respective offices to investigate matters of alleged criminal wrongdoing in the Schiavo case.

 

   Under Article IV, Section 1(a) Florida Constitution, the governor is vested with “supreme executive power”.  Further, the Governor “shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed” and commissions “all officers of the state and counties”.

   Under the general law of the state, the governor may, by executive order filed with the Department of State, assign state attorneys “one of more specified investigations, cases or matters. Specifically, Section 27.14(1) Florida Statutes provides if any state attorney is disqualified to represent the state in any investigation, case or matter pending in the courts of his or her circuit or if, for any other good and sufficient reason, the Governor determines that the ends of justice would be best served, the Governor may, by executive order filed with the Department of State, either order an exchange of circuits or of courts between such state attorney and any other state attorney or order an assignment of any state attorney to discharge the duties of the state attorney with respect to one or more specified investigations, cases or matters specified in general in the executive order of the Governor.

   In this case, it is mandatory that a special prosecutor be assigned to investigate this matter as Mr. McCabe, state attorney for the Sixth Circuit, is directly and personally involved in the matter and would be a subject of the investigation as well as an employee of his office, therefore Mr. McCabe has a prohibited conflict of interest and must be disqualified.

   As Governor, you frequently issue executive orders appointing another state attorney to investigate and prosecute cases free from the taint of appearance of conflict of interest or impropriety. 

   Good and sufficient reason exists for the Governor to determine that the ends of justice would be best served by assigning another state attorney to investigate the alleged improper use of public office, public funds and government property to influence the outcome of a judicial election and ultimately the outcome of the high profile Schiavo case.

   “A public office is a public trust” Section Article II, §8(a) Florida Constitution. Moreover, “the people shall have the right to secure and sustain that trust against abuse.  

   The issue at hand involves official misconduct in Pinellas County related to the judicial election of George W. Greer during 2004 and in particular, the Primary of Aug. 31, 2004 as it relates to his political commercial aired between Aug. 9, 2004 and Aug. 30, 2004.

   The matter involves some or all of the following acts or omissions:  Abuse of the pubic trust (Art. II, Section 8(a) Florida Constitution, breach of the public trust for private gain and inducing others to breach the public trust for private gain (Art. II, Section 5, Florida Constitution) violations of Florida’s Code of Ethics including but not limited to Section 112.313(2) FS, 112.313(6) and 112.317. 

   The immediate assignment of a special prosecutor to investigate this matter is requested

 

Thank you

E. Maxcy Ordway        

10333 Anson Rd 

Jacksonville, Florida  32246

 

 

From:	Nanjedwardsinc@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, September 10, 2006 8:33 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	troxler@sptimes.com; markadamsjdmba@hotmail.com; RANDYHEINE@MSN.COM; allentatler@yahoo.com
Subject:	Florida native vernacular and populism

Mr. John Bush

Chairman of the Board 

Enterprise Florida Corporation

Orlando, FL 

 

Dear Chairman Bush, 

 

I know you like to be called by your first name; it’s not my preference. 

However, since this seems to be a ‘folksy’ preference of yours, I will do so in the body of this letter. 

 

After reading the newspaper today, I decided to offer my personal opinion

of your article “driving our economy higher, with Integrity ‘ . 

 

Jeb, ‘chummy’ with large industry was not a good idea. It cannot be undone. 

 

What do you mean” with integrity “? “ EFI board members do not vote or offer 

their input. “

 

These people don’t vote on the boards. They don’t have to, as the tax payers subsidize their meetings and CEO’s large salary (such as Mr. Adams). 

 

The same people on the EFI boards are your advisors / investor board, also lobby the legislature and are ‘ guest speakers’ at Public service commission meetings. 

 

I read the CEO of a large company influenced YOU to apply for a Federal Grant. I don’t know if this is true. I don’t know if he could have signed it himself. I don’t think he could sign one now. 

 

I note new interest in the company assets of that public ticker.  

 

I see sharks circling.  They will certainly give you up before themselves.

Do you know a colloquial meaning of ‘chum ‘in Florida? I’ve been here all my life and you now appear to be ‘chum’ of potential ‘investors’. 

 

It’s risky business to swim with sharks.  I’d watch my back if I were you. People with that much money and influence could tap phones, hack computers and do anything to achieve their requisite purpose. 

 

I read you’re the “E governor”! You must like high tech stuff. I read of commercial C band satellite for survellaience with microwaves. How cool might this be ? Wow ! 

 

What you have ( or did  have ) , was the trust , monies,  land and other properties of the residents of this state. 

 

As far as accountability goes; I noted the state audit on line and it appears there are red flags in regard to DEP land transactions. 

 

When there are private interests involved, it’s difficult and tedious to determine who got what and for what value.  

 

When there are many parties rivaling for the assets (taxpayers included), eventually somebody is thrown behind the boat. 

 

I did read many years ago, you said you couldn’t find a decent cup of coffee in Tallahassee. Jeb, there’s plenty of good coffee in Tallahassee. No one was pouring any in your cup. 

 

That’s from me, 50 year old Leon County; CAPITAL CITY girl. 

 

 

Yours very truly I am, 

 

Nan J. Edwards (Native Floridian)

President and Chairman of the Board 

Nan J. Edwards Inc. 

 

 

 

 

 
From:	Jeff Chesak <jeffch3@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Sunday, September 10, 2006 7:53 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject:	Firefighter with Muscular Dystrophy asking for help

Good evening Governor Bush and Lt. Governor Jennings, 

 

I want to start off by saying congratulations on eight great years for the State of Florida.  I look forward to your future political endeavors.

I’m writing to request a simple favor of you.  I’d been employed with Orange County Fire Rescue in Orlando for just over 20 years, until this past April.  Four years ago I was diagnosed with muscular dystrophy that has slowly affected my ability to climb ladders and stairs.  Because I have a family history of MD, I was expecting this, so I became a training officer as not to affect the safety of my crew.  After four years in the training division, with very little progression of the disease, the Fire Chief in Orange County decided ‘This is the new fire department, and we don’t accommodate anyone anymore.’   As you can imagine, I was floored by this news.  I had spent several years preparing for this position and acquiring the necessary instructor certifications through the State of Florida, only to be told that my years of experience and knowledge as a Fire Officer and Paramedic were no longer valid because of my limited disability.  This termination came less than five years from reaching my retirement date.  Not to mention, at a time when I have two children in college.

 

I’m simply asking if you could discuss this matter with Mayor Crotty in Orange County.  All of my inquiries to him have been unanswered, and I would appreciate if you could pass on my information so I might meet with him.

 

I appreciate your time and want to thank you again for your service to our great State.

 

Sincerely,

 

Jeff Chesak

 

1121 Monteagle Circle

Apopka, FL 32712

407-383-2212

Jeffch3@cfl.rr.com

The Capitol
PL05
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

Nathaniel B. Kidder, Esquire is a nominee for a Circuit Judge vacancy in Pinellas County. I am writing this letter of recommendation to respectfully request that you appoint Mr. Kidder to that position.  He has earned unprecedented respect from the legal community, attorneys and judges alike. As a Judge, his ability to remain impartial would never be questioned.

 

I have known Nat Kidder for over 15 years, both personally and professionally. He is an individual of integrity and honesty. To those he serves, he is not only a scholar of the law, but a hard working, tenacious and compassionate professional. He is a man of the highest personal standards and treasures his family life.  

 

Mr. Bush, you have the opportunity to select the most qualified and best suited individual to serve as a Judge.  I urge you to show your full and unqualified support to Nathanial Kidder by appointing him to Judge of the Circuit Court. 

 

Thank you for your time.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

 Murray N. Collector, DC, FICC

Subject:	PARDON me....help!

Dear Governor:
 
     I am desperate for assistance and not exactly sure it is you who can help, but Lord knows I have prayed my heart out over this matter, and believe I may have a good chance with you.  I am a Christian in an excellent church.
     I am a single mom in Key West, FL doing everything in my power to excel for the sake of my little girl - she's 6.  I recently graduated from the Community College here (FKCC) with an Associates in Arts degree AND a Certificate degree in Addiction-Studies.  I am pursuing my dream of Counseling addicts and alcoholics...I wish to have a title: Certfied Addiction Professional (CAP) under the Florida Board.
     The stumbling block in my path is an extreme criminal history...mind you, they are only felony charges of my past addiction (almost 13 yrs of crack abuse and prostitution from 1985 - 1997...in Prison 4 different times).  I have been totally sober 9 years. I will also tell you, regretfully, that my child's father had me charged with Stalking him ( sentence completed Feb 2005)...I was only chasing my Child Support, but needless to say I had no choice but to plead out  ( or else lose custody of my little girl).  I have been invited to earn my Bachelors degree in Jacksonville at University of North Florida.  I am currently waiting for an acceptance letter. I will be 43yrs young next month in October.
     Governor, the one thing I am requesting from you is to help me do SOMETHING about my record.  I was told no matter how many degrees I earn in University I may NEVER get to be in Counseling because I can not be hired anywhere...I can NOT pass a background check...yet I have a 3.6 GPA, 2 degrees from the Community College, and going on to earn my Bachelors either in Psychology or Social Work....PLEASE HELP! Subject:	FSDB and Chris Wagner

Dear Honorable Mr. Bush,

      As an alumni and a former employee of Florida School for the Deaf 
and the Blind(FSDB), I want to tell you that I am so pleased to know 
that you  have selected a fine deaf man named Chris Wagner as a member 
of Board of Trustees at FSDB.

      Even though I have never met Mr. Wagner, I am truly impressed with 
his dedication as an exemplary advocator for deaf people.  Without a 
doubt, Deaf alumni, employees and citizens are so thrilled to have him 
as a member of the Board.

      Despite being a victim of social injustice during Dawson 
Administration while I was an employee, I have to admit that the school 
is one of the finest schools for the deaf in the world in terms of 
facilities, government-support finance, outreach programs, size of 
student population, sports programs, publicity and parents involvement.  
If I live in Fla -I live in NC- and my children are deaf, it is 
undeniable that I will send my kids to that school.

      Thank God for having you as an open-minded person as well as a 
politician who believes that Deaf people with lack of spoken language 
are capable of reasoning.  I want to share you a brief story from an 
alumnus named John Burns of Tallahassee who proudly told me that while 
he was walking at near your state-owned house, you saw him.  Then you 
made a gesture as you warmly greeted and invited him to enter your 
state-owned home several years ago.  That story really amazed me.  I 
believe he told that story a hundred times to his acquaintances.

      Again, many thanks for your faith in Chris Wagner as a Deaf citizen 
who will contribute his wisdom to the deaf children at my alma mater.

Truly yours,
Tom Krohn

PS.  I am a teacher at NCSD.

That is just unconstitutional!  Most people in todayâ€™s busy world do not have the time or energy to read every little legal notice in the paper or even subscribe.  It is very heartbreaking for us to be 4 years down the road and unable to fight an air quality permit that was approved in 2001 that we were not aware of since we did not subscribe to any local news papers.  Please do something to help the residents and businesses of Florida by protecting them and invoke better communication with notices in the future.  Please increase the requirements of all businesses or individuals placing notices to also send regular mail and place large signage on the property with the notice information on the land being affected.  The small classified ads just do not work anymore.  We are living proof!

From:	Etienne, Geraldine E <geraldine_etienne@cable.comcast.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 8, 2006 4:35 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Comcast Cares Day 2006
Attachments:	Proclamation letter- Governor Jeb Bush.doc; CCD 2006 Miami Release FINAL.doc


Greetings Michelle, 

Comcast will be hosting our Annual Comcast Cares Day event on October 7, 2006. Comcast Cares Day is Comcast’s annual company-wide day of service in which tens of thousands of Comcast employees, along with their families and friends, volunteer in their local communities.  2006 marks the sixth year for Comcast Cares Day. Last year, more than 30,000 volunteers working on 300 projects with community organizations. 

This year, Comcast Miami-Dade will be partnering with His House Children's Home located at 20000 NW 47th Avenue, Opa Locka, FL 33055. His House is a children’s home which houses abused and neglected kids. The organization provides services ranging from residential services, case-management, an in-house counseling center, The His House Academy, after-school tutoring, weekly athletic, art and dance programs, in addition to foster and adoption placement. All programs are specifically designed and targeted to meet the needs of the whole child.


I have attached some information regarding the event for your review. I am requesting to set a meeting with Jeanie Hernandez Director of Community Relations to meet with Governor Jeb Bush to discuss Comcast's community outreach initiative at his earliest convenience. In addition to this, we are also extending an invitation for the Governor to attend the event on October 7th as well as requesting a Proclamation.

Please feel free to contact Jeanie Hernandez at 305.770.5316 or myself at 305.770.5337 with any questions or concerns. 

<<Proclamation letter- Governor Jeb Bush.doc>>    <<CCD 2006 Miami Release FINAL.doc>>

From:	Marvin Cook <rmc@wildernessgraphics.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 8, 2006 3:32 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Regarding Wakulla Commissioner Howard Kessler, MD

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing in support of Wakulla County Commissioner Howard  
Kessler. In my experience, I have observed Dr. Kessler to be a  
courageous and principled advocate for his constituents, the Florida  
environment, and transparent, representative democracy. This has  
often put him at odds with his fellow Commissioners who have  
disagreed  with his positions as well as some constituents whose  
interests are affected by his votes. None-the-less, few could  
honestly argue that Dr. Kessler has not firmly stood on his beliefs,  
with integrity and civility, in the face of overwhelming and constant  
adversity from the Wakulla Commission.

I understand Dr. Kessler is so dedicated to performing his  
responsibilities that he has even undertaken special training in  
being a Commissioner.  It is ironic that he has been alleged to have  
not fulfilled his responsibilities in failing to vote [without a  
declared conflict of interest] when his fast held conviction was in  
fact concerning the very illegitimacy of the meeting.  Well, we all  
make errors, and a trial jury might possibly sort out whether the  
State Prosecutor Willie Meggs'  findings could be proven. But, to  
what end would this serve? Prove that a good man, with exemplary  
record and commitment to public service, came to an incorrect  
conclusion in good conscience? Or perhaps, this could be used as an  
example to drive away committed and qualified people from public  
service to demonstrate low tolerance for dissent.

Governor Bush, Wakulla County is facing a lot of growth challenges as  
Monroe County experienced in the past. It is at the threshold of  
cultural, geographic, and political changes which has led to much  
turmoil. You may recall that a few years ago Monroe needed the  
intervention of DCA to straighten things out and restore public  
interests and Wakulla needed your intervention on tax assessments.  I  
know you believe in mentoring for youth. It may be time for Wakulla  
to get a little more help from the State to mentor our small county  
through the pains of growing up.

I urge you to not give a de-facto endorsement of the tactics being  
employed to eliminate a conscientious and principled, duly elected  
official from office on an alleged (and unproven) technical violation  
of a statute that does not specify a penalty.  The voters will have  
the opportunity to speak within the next few months on Dr. Kessler's  
continued service.

Thank you for your consideration.

Marvin Cook
Shell Point
850.926.3905

69 Walker Creek Drive
Shell Point, FL 32327

Judge Adams granted the injunction even though I was served at 5:30 pm on Nov. 21 to appear at 9:00 am Nov. 22. I had no chance to obtain legal representation nor was I advised of my right to venue. My attorney has been somewhat useless and like a boat, I'm throwing what money I have into a hole in the water.
I be live that he granted the injunction simply to get rid of the petitioner who had been before him at least 7 times regarding injunctions relating to her ex-husband. The idea of "repeat violence" is absurd and a travesty of justice as there had never been any sort of threat and I had not been within 30 miles of the petitioner for some 6 years.
The court granted me all of my firearms rights, but has suspended my Fl. CCW. The result is that I cannot practice my day trade of training high-level principal  protection personnel, and I am also a cert. master gunsmith. I wish to retire soon and because of this, I cannot receive my FFL or gunsmithing lic. so I can open the shop I have been planning & dreaming of for years for my retirement. I am suffering great financial hardship and my planned retirement is ruined.
I beg of you, Mr. Bush for your intercession in this matter. If your office cannot help, please, please guide me in the right direction. My livelyhood depends upon it.
 
God Bless You,
 
Adrian J. Canton

DEAR TONI JENNINGS,
 
WE NEW YORKERS ARE BEING TAXES OUT OF FLORIDA. MANY OF US SNOW BIRDS AND THINKING SERIOUSLY THAT WE SHOULD SELL OUR CONDOS IN FLORIDA BECAUSE THE TAXES ARE GETTING TO HIGH.
 
I WONDER HOW FLORIDA WILL SURVIVE IF US NEW YORKERS AND THOSE FROM BOSTON, MAINE, NEW JERSEY, ETC. ALL SOLD THEIR PLACES IN FLORIDA???
WE SIMPLY CANNOT PAY THESE HIGH TAXES WHERE WE LIVE AND THEN HAVE TO PAY HIGH TAXES IN FLORIDA FOR A PLACE THAT WE USE FOR A FEW MONTHS.
 
I THOUGHT THAT I WOULD TAKE TIME TO SEND YOU THIS NOTE BECAUSE THIS IS WHAT WE ARE ALL THINKING THESE DAYS. I KNOW THAT YOU ARE HAVING MEETINGS ON THE TAX ISSUES, BUT I AM NOT SURE IF YOU ARE DISCUSSING THE SNOW BIRD'S TAXES. SOME OF US CANNOT BECOME FLORIDA RESIDENTS TO PAY LOWER TAXES AND WE ARE REALLY GETTING HIT HARD WITH FLORIDA TAXES AND OUR HOME TOWN TAXES. PEOPLE ARE MOVING TO NORTH CAROLINA NOW BECAUSE OF THE LOW PRICED HOMES AND LOW TAXES. AND I MEAN LOTS OF PEOPLE FROM HERE AND EVERYWHERE.
 
WE HAVE BEEN TRYING TO SELL ONE CONDO FOR OVER A YEAR AND WHEN PEOPLE HEAR HOW HIGH THE TAXES ARE, THEY WALK AWAY.  I HAVE TWO CONDOS AND EACH IS OVER $5000.00 IN TAXES. WHO WANTS, OR WHO CAN PAY THESE TAXES. THE TAXES ARE NOT ONLY HIGH FOR NEW RESIDENTS BUT ARE VERY HIGH FOR  NON RESIDENTS WHO HAVE TO ALSO PAY TAXES WHERE THEY LIVE.  THERE IS NO WAY THAT WE CAN PAY HIGH TAXES IN NEW YORK AND ALSO IN FLORIDA.
 
JUST WANTED TO YELL OUT...HOPE SOMEONE HEARS ME BEFORE IT'S TOO LATE..
 
SINCERLY,
 
FLORA CAMARDELLA
WEST PALM BEACH

From: L8D8Agin@aol.com [mailto:L8D8Agin@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, August 27, 2006 2:11 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Fwd: Transcription Bids (Second Note)

Governor Bush,

 

I mailed the below note to you on the 25th so I'm sure you haven't had a chance to read it yet.  I did feel it was important for me to also point out the following information.

 

I was registered under the commodity/group number for "transcription, all types."  While researching why I was not given the purchase order to continue transcribing for the DOC Inspector General's Office, I spoke to Mr. Larry Daugherty.  He advised that I should register as a "court reporter" so that I could be advised of any transcription bids going out since court reporters also perform transcription.  Although I disagreed on whether or not I should have registered as such, being that I'm NOT a court reporter, I have done so at Mr. Daugherty's direction.  

 

Many of the people who are registered under the commodity/group number for "transcription, all types" are simply parents who need to stay home with their children but also need to work in order to provide for their families.  By awarding the contracts without soliciting bids to those who registered under what we were advised was our correct commodity/group numbers means that there are many self-employed people who no longer have the option of being self-employed.  Those people must now make other choices regarding employment and/or whether they want to do business with the State of Florida.  

 

I know you and your office are extremely busy.  However, I felt it was important to advise you that the State is spending money needlessly while not allowing those who have registered under the MyFlorida commodity groups to be able to bid on work.  If this is the way bids are normally handled by the State, it appears the MyFlorida process would rather deal with larger companies, has no interest in saving money and/or does not know how to bid out the work.  To advise transcriptionists to register under a commodity group that the State then ignores results in those people not receiving any bid solicitations.

 

Thank you again,

 

Valita Widdop

From: Carnegie, Claudius A.
Sent: Sun 9/3/2006 10:56 AM
To: commissioner@fldoe.org; cooperjo@nova.edu
Cc: NOVA Details (claudius@nova.edu); Carnegie, Claudius A.;
carnegie@fiu.edu
Subject: Higher Educational Issues in the State of Florida, NOVA
EDD-8007 Course assignment.


Good Morning Commissioner Winn: As part of an assignment for one of my
Ed.D.degree course (EDD-8007, Dynamics of Managing Institutions of
Higher Education: Policies and Practices) at Nova Southeastern
University, I am writing to you on two important matters, to seek your
intervention and assistance.
 
1. Having read your website, I note your recent announcement of the
"SUCCEED Florida!" grants press conference and the opportunities that
will be offered and made available for students in various critical
workforce areas. However, the workforce areas targeted by this
initiative, did not include a critical workforce area in the aviation
industry, that is, in the airframe and powerplant (A&P) mechanics
workforce area. The current average age of A&P mechanics is in the late
50s---based on my personal observations! Therefore, in about another 10
to 15 years time, unless this State or this Nation can encourage and
attract many students to this workforce area, our aviation industry will
be in critical need of qualified and competent A&P mechanics to service
and maintain our increasing high technology fleet of airplanes. This
shortage of A&P mechanics will therefore threaten the safety and
economic viability of the aviation industry and our Nation's ability to
compete in the International market place. I would strongly encourage
your Administration to seriously consider this matter and appropriately
intervene in a timely manner, to preserve our Nation's competitive
advantages in the International marketplace. Please be advised that I am
also currently teaching aeronautical and aerospace engineering courses
at FIU and I also sit on the Miami-Dade County CTAC Board (Aviation
sub-committee chairperson) and I am therefore very much aware of this
disturbing trend and issue, in the aviation industry.
 
2. As part of my Ed.D. degree program completion, I am doing my Applied
Dissertation on "Strategies for reducing mathematics driven attrition in
a university's declared engineering majors." Subject to all necessary
and appropriate IRB approvals, I will be quantitatively analyzing
de-identified SUS longitudinal data and collecting additional
qualitative survey data of incumbent students, to draw inferences,
conclusions, make recommendations and formulating strategies, pursuant
to completing this work. Your assistance and support in this endeavor,
is hereby respectfully requested. As you can appreciate, we all need to
find a way to increase degree completion of our enrolled university
students, in order to be cost-effective with our educational
dollars---but more importantly, to adequately prepare our students to be
successful in our future largely populated, highly technological and
highly scientific world.
 
Please feel free to call me with related questions and/or concerns.
Thanks very much and best regards.
 
Claudius A. Carnegie, 
Director II, Regulatory Compliance, 
Miami-Dade County Public Schools, 
12525 NW 28th Avenue, 
Miami, Florida, 33167, 
V: 305-995-7993, 
F: 305-995-7966, 
C: 786-229-1355, 
E: ccarnegie@dadeschools.net 
 
"giving our students the world"
From:	Stiles CIV Randall M <randall.m.stiles@usmc.mil>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 6, 2006 5:54 PM
To:	TSA-ContactCenter@dhs.gov; Registered.Traveler@dhs.gov; RegisteredTraveler@clearcorporate.com; ric.keller@mail.house.gov; tom.feeney@mail.house.gov; john.mica@mail.house.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; comments@whitehouse.gov


I am writing to urge that the Registered Traveler program be rolled out across the country ASAP, as TSA has promised.

Registered Traveler is one of the few best deals around for this country's air travelers. It's voluntary. It costs the government and airports nothing. It gives travelers a predictably, convenient, speedy and SECURE experience getting through the airport's checkpoint. Also, biometric IDs represent a means for increasing our national security beyond this particular program. TSA's resources can be more focused on those who have not been pre-screened. It ensures that the non-Registered Traveler lines move faster, too. Registered Traveler is cutting-edge technology and old-fashioned common sense.

I'm told that TSA is in the final stages of completing the paperwork for the national rollout. Please do all you can so that TSA proceeds now with no further delay. Millions of "road warriors" across the country want to join the 27,000 Registered Travelers in Orlando  and all of us want to be able to use Registered Traveler wherever we fly.

Thank you for your consideration. 
Sincerely, 

Randall Stiles 
Orlando, FL

From:	Pastor Tom Bingol <tbingol@stmarkbythesea.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 6, 2006 1:00 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Invitation to the 3rd Annual Operation Cookie Lift

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
September 6, 2006
 
 
Dear Gov. Bush,
 
Please be our honored guest for the Third Annual “Operation Cookie Lift” on Sunday, September 24, 2006 at St. Mark By The Sea Lutheran Church in Palm Coast, Florida.  Please find a PSA attached.
I thank you for your consideration in advance.
 
Rev. Tom Bingol, Pastor
 
###

OPERATION: COOKIE LIFT 2006

Sunday, September 24 – 8:45 a.m.

 


Palm Coast, FL – Everyone associates Girl Scouts with the annual sale of cookies, but for the past three years, St. Mark By The Sea Lutheran Church Girl Scout Troop #1116 in Palm Coast, have been selling cookies that are delivered half-way around the world.  It’s called “Operation: Cookie Lift” and the cookies are sent to our service men and women who are currently serving in Iraq and Afghanistan.


 


The concept began three years ago with Troop Leaders Dominic & Janice DeZego, and Mark & Linda Klayman approached Rev. Tom Bingol with the idea.  “Our congregation is very committed to our service men and women as well as the Veterans in Flagler County.  We have held the Annual Four Chaplain’s Service and Armed Forces Recognition Sunday each year for the last eight years.  What made this project even more personal was the fact that some of our scouts had parents or relatives serving in Iraq,” says Dominic DeZego.  That first year, the Troop was able to send 198 boxes of Girl Scout cookies, and a special relationship was established between the church and the 506th Agile Expeditionary Group (AEG) Chapel in Kirkuk, Iraq. The Chapel runs a respite area for soldiers coming out of the field called the “Oasis” that welcomed the cookies as “A taste of home in the desert.”

 
Last year, the Troop increased its shipment to 315 boxes and partnered with local Veteran Support organizations, members of the Marine Corp League, American Legion and VFW and their respective Auxiliary units.  The girls wrote notes of encouragement on the boxes, and the cookies were boxed up for Iraq.  The troop also increased the number of troops it was connecting with by expanding distribution; maintaining its partnership with the 506th Agile Expeditionary Group Chapel in Kirkuk, but adding Chaplains at the US Embassy in Baghdad, the Wing Chaplain of the 376th AEW in Kyrgyzstan, and the 407th AEG in Tallil, Iraq. The Troop was also recognized in 2005 as the recipients of Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary Youth Activity Award. 
 
On Sunday, September 24, 2006, the St. Mark By The Sea Girl Scout Troop #1116 will be recognized for the Third Annual Operation Cookie Lift, at the 8:45 Worship Service.  The girls have more than doubled the number of cookies to 640 boxes, and two other troops are joining their efforts, one local and another in Volusia County.  
 
If you would like to be a part of “Operation Cookie Lift 2006” mark your calendar for Sunday, September 24 and join us at the 8:45 AM service.  If you would like to donate funds to offset shipping costs, you can make checks payable to “Girl Scouts” and place Operation Cookie Lift in the memo section.  We’re located at 303 Palm Coast Pkwy., N.E. in Palm Coast, next to the Sun Trust Bank.  Contact us for more information at 386/445-3420, or visit our website at www.stmarkbythesea.org.
 
# # #

-----Original Message-----
From: Cherie Reid [mailto:cheriereidusa@yahoo.com]
Sent: Monday, September 04, 2006 5:32 PM
To: Governor.Rell@po.state.ct.us; Governor Jeb Bush; gov@hawaii.gov
Subject: National Veteran's appreciation website

 

 

 

     A few months ago I contacted your office about a new program called “Kids Thank a Veteran” at www.kidsthankavet.com. I would like to update you on the progress of the site and hope that your state can join the 10 states that are now participating. The primary purpose of this site is to have children say “Thank you for serving” when they see a veteran.  They can then register their first name and state on our national database.  We already have children from 20 states registered and this is only the beginning. The secondary purpose is to educate children on the many topics relating to our veterans.

 

      Within a couple of months we: 

*         Have ten state education associations join in to support the site in their schools (AZ, CN, MO, NV, NJ, OR, PA, SC, VA, WY) 

*         Have veteran’s organizations throughout the country spreading the word by including the site in their written material 

*         Are linked up to national veteran’s websites, such as the New Jersey Department of Military and Veteran’s Affairs and the Oregon Department of Veteran Affairs, to name just two.     

*         Are included in town websites, pediatric websites, etc.  

*         Received letters from eight Governors applauding the site for its merit. (Al, KY, LA, MD, MA, T, VA, WY) 

*         Were written up in three newspapers and featured on New Jersey Channel 12 News 

*         Received 100% positive feedback from veterans, educators and the public 

*         Will be featured on Veterans Radio, a national radio program

 

     The site is unique in that it does not sell anything and does not advertise – it just supports out veterans and teaches our children. During the next few months we are hoping to increase the number of state education associations that include the site in their curriculum, spread the word to more state organizations and sponsor a national or local poster contest.

 

     Please visit www.kidsthankavet.com.  I think you will agree that it is a worthwhile endeavor.  We are looking forward to having your state join in.

                                                             Thank you,

 

 

                                                             Cherie Reid

From:	Audrey Gay <Audrey@willtrust.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 5, 2006 9:36 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Referral for Allyson Hughes

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I am writing this letter to you to strongly encourage you to select Allyson Hughes for the Sixth Circuit Judicial position for the judicial seat formerly occupied by Judge John Renke.  

 

I am a young lawyer in New Port Richey, Florida, and I practice primarily in the field of Elder Law.  However, when I initially came to New Port Richey, I was interested in practicing Family Law.  I was introduced to Ms. Hughes as a leader in the Family Law community here in the Bay Area.  Despite her impressive reputation, I found Ms. Hughes easy to converse with and willing to offer instruction.  I was immediately impressed with her capacity as a compassionate and extremely knowledgeable mentor.  In addition to allowing me to shadow her in the courtroom, she freely invited me into her office to learn office practices and procedures.  I believe her ability to provide instructions together with her command of the courtroom are valuable assets for a judge to possess. 

 

Shortly thereafter, I joined the Family Law Section of the West Pasco Bar Association and the first meeting was held at Ms. Hughes’ office.  I continued to be impressed by the level of knowledge and understanding with which she introduced the topics for discussion that day.  She also freely encouraged discussion and debate of new and existing laws and listened intently to everyone’s point of view, no matter how new a person, such as myself, was to the field of family law.  I believe Ms. Hughes’ ability to listen to her peers and apply the rules of law to specific circumstances will also be a valuable asset to the Sixth Circuit Judicial bench. 

 

Since my first year in practice, as my practice has evolved, I have continued to have contact with Ms. Hughes in both my practice and through the West Pasco Bar Association functions and meetings.  Ms. Hughes continues to consistently be well spoken and educated in the counsel she provides to her fellow attorneys which I have most recently observed in currently serving with her on the Professionalism Committee for the West Pasco Bar Association.

 

I truly believe that Ms. Hughes would make an amazing judge and would provide a great service to our community.

 

Very truly,

Audrey Gay Ehrhardt, Esquire 

 

Audrey Gay Ehrhardt, Esquire

The Law Offices of Gay & Ehrhardt, P.A.

5318 Balsam Street

New Port Richey, Florida 34652

Telephone: (727) 849 - 1122

Fax: (727) 848 - 4466
