Dear Mr. Jeb Bush
 
I am writing on behalf of myself, Shelia Coretta Washington. On the day of April 26, 1998 I was sentenced to be incarcerated for four years and 1 year probation following my release. During my sentence I obtained my General Education Degree and enrolled in P.C. support services (Business Software Application), which I too completed.
 
            I completed probation with no violations and have been a productive citizen since my re-entering society. It has been 3 years now since my release on March 6, 2003. Though I’ve done all that was asked of me, I am at a barrier. Because of this felony, charge, many of the jobs I am qualified for are overlooking me because the felony weighs heavier than my qualifications.
 
            My inner being longs for development to reach higher. I want so badly to follow the steps of my mother in the nursing field. Even my schooling is limited with choices because there are certain fields I am not able to enter into due to the mistakes I have made in my past.
 
            So I ask of you to take into consideration my age and the fact that I was a first time offender. I was sentenced as an adult-though I was a minor-therefore, the charge will always appear on my record.
 
            I can say the consequences have made me knowledgeable, I now truly understand. I have opened my eyes now-realizing and appreciating-who I am and where I want to go. At this point of my adulthood, I understand the importance of voting and having my rights which this felony has also stripped of me. I ask you to review my case so that you may take into consideration pardoning my felony charge from my records.
 
 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
Shelia Coretta Washington

Allyson has volunteered many hours to our local bar education efforts also.  I recall that she organized a computer fair more than 10 years ago when attorneys in our area were just beginning to enter the computer age in their office practice.  The purpose of the fair was to educate practicioners as to the advantages of using computers in their law offices.  This was a very unselfish endeavor.
Allyson is very highly regarded by  her peers and is considered impeccable in manner and deed.  She will serve the community and the legal profession with dignity and judicial excellence.  Upon first meeting Allyson, one may percieve her to be aloof, but she is merely reserved.  This will be to her advantage as a Judge. From:	Curt & Linda Kirkland <kirkland24@cox.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 5, 2006 5:33 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Eglin's 46TW's Proposed move to Edwards CA

Linda Kirkland 

146 Old South Drive

Crestview FL  32536 

22 July 2006 

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush 
Office of the Governor 
The Capitol 
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

 

As a resident of North West Florida, I am very concerned about the latest talks of moving all or part of the 46 Test Wing (TW) to Edwards AFB, CA.  As I’m sure you already know, Eglin’s and the 46 TW’s missions have been studied, scrutinized and validated in both Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) 1995 and BRAC 2005.  This latest proposed move to somehow circumvent the latest BRAC recommendations comes as a complete surprise and has many Eglin AFB employees and Florida residents very upset and concerned. 

 

Serving as the focal point for all Air Force conventional Weapon and Armament (W&A), Eglin AFB is responsible for the Research, Development, Acquisition, and Test & Evaluation (RDAT&E) of all air-delivered weapons. This is possible for three main reasons: The first being the synergies realized from the co-location of the Air Force Research Lab’s Munitions Directorate (Research), Air-to-Air and Air-to-Ground Weapon Systems Wings (Development/Acquisition), 46 TW (Development Test), and 53rd Wing (Operational Test) at Eglin AFB; the second being the irreplaceable, contiguous, and highly instrumented 724 sq miles of highly vegetated land ranges and over 120,000 sq miles of water ranges; and the third being state-of-the-art test facilities such as McKinley Climatic Laboratory, Guided Weapons Evaluation Facility, and the Preflight Integration of Munitions and Electronic Systems.

 

Several BRAC 2005 recommendations have other geographically located W&A facilities realigning to Eglin AFB to further complement and strengthen Eglin as a full spectrum W&A RDAT&E Center. The impact of these BRAC recommendations will: increase W&A life cycle and mission related synergies/integration; increase efficiency; reduce operational costs; retain the required diversity of test environments; and facilitate multiple uses of equipment, facilities, ranges, and people.

 

As a resident of Florida and a taxpayer, it makes absolutely no sense to move all or part of the 46 TW to Edwards AFB. Even a partial move of only the flight test operations would greatly limit the ability of DoD to test weapons in the most challenging operational environments - vegetative/tropical environments. Also, it would have a significant impact on the synergies that currently exist at Eglin AFB starting with the elimination of the 53rd Wing’s ability to conduct Operational Testing and maintain its aircraft (shared w/46 TW).  If the truth be known it will cost the taxpayer a significant amount of money to establish only a subset of the capabilities that currently exist within the 46 TW at Eglin AFB with zero chance of every realizing a cost savings. Why is the Air Force trying to conduct its own mini-BRAC on Eglin AFB – It needs to stop now!

 

As governor of this state, I am asking for your help to ensure the entire 46 TW remains at Eglin AFB, FL to safeguard world class RDAT&E for future Air Armament Weapons, the livelihood of thousands of Florida residents, and the economy of Northwest Florida.

 

Sincerely,

 

/s/

 

Linda Kirkland

 Business trip between 17-09 and 10-10-06.

				
Dear Sirs, (a)  Jeb Bush:	
				
The Cámara Andina de Desarrollo (CAMANDES) is in charge of a decentralization program for peace and democracy which includes  Peru  and  the border  regions of Ecuador ,  Colombia ,  the State of Acre  (Brazil), Bolivia  and Chile. This  program is  coordinated  through activities  and  agreements with local  authorities, NGO’s and private business as well as several national and international Institutions. By now, this program includes agricultural and agro industrial investments organized in 25 development poles and 17 territories linked between each other by exchanges axes. See for consultation. www.camaraandina.org/camandes/promocion

Mr. Henry O’Neill, Chairman of CAMANDES, will be spending three weeks in North America and Europe from September 17th till October 10th  aproximately.  He is interested in contacting people, insitutitons and business so as to organize platforms for exchanges and joint-ventures, according to the invitation you will find herewith in Spanish at http://www.camaraandina.org/camandes/promocion.

If interested personnally or knowing people or institutions who may be,  as well as any related institution or Research Centers for Territorial Development whom you let us get in touch with,  please  communicate with us as soon as possible so as to prepare a possible meeting and precise beforehand products and services. In case of associations or alike, group presentations are possible too.

From:	Jeff Haines <tropjeff@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 5, 2006 4:41 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Insurance costs and other concerns

Dear Governor,

    I’m sure you are inundated with similar correspondence but here it goes. I just recently received my new insurance quote for next year from State Farm Insurance Company. I was shocked to see that it has increased by a little over $800 for the year. I live in East Fort Myers in a small, older CBS home and I am not in a flood zone. I also have never submitted a claim.  I now of several families who have seen increases into the thousands of dollars per year. They are currently trying to sell and move out of Florida. I fortunately under-bought my house so I am able to absorb the blow of higher insurance and tax costs. However, many of the people in this area, and I’m sure many other areas, will not be able to handle the increased costs. With most of the insurance carriers gone from the state there is very little options for homeowners. As you well know, a lack of competition is not good for consumers. I also received my property tax estimate and because my wife and I bought our house here in Dec. of ’05 we paid a good amount over what the previous owners had and our taxes have more than tripled. I fear our fair State is headed for a real crisis. I know in this area there is a shortage of teachers, policemen, and firefighters. They simply cannot afford to live here with the combined cost of housing, insurance, property taxes, etc. 

     I know the State has experienced 8 hurricanes in the last two years but many of the insurance companies that pulled out of the state reaped profits for years, if not decades here in Florida during the lull years of few named storms. When thing were good they were here and when the times got tough they fled leaving many of the home owners in Florida in the lurch. We need people in the state government that is going to stand up for Florida residents. I don’t know who to vote for in the primaries or who I will vote for in the Governor’s election – the candidate choices are poor. There ads are more aimed at telling the public what the other candidates’ shortcomings and mistakes are than telling me and the other voters what they stand for and what they are going to do for the State and it’s people.

     I’m sad to say that our local government isn’t any better. The leaders in this area have left urban sprawl get way out of hand. I’m all for growth but lets have managed growth with a plan. Many of our roads here are overwhelmed. Citizens in Cape Coral had their wells run dry in the spring. Not to mention the water and sewer fiasco they are currently enduring. How can it cost $22,000 to run water and sewer pipes across 120’ of a persons property? This fee doesn’t include the $4,000 to $6,000 a plumber will charge to run and connect pipes from the house to the systems. If this doesn’t demonstrate a complete lack of governmental oversight I don’t know what does! Many people in Cape Coral are trying to sell their property and leave. How does an average family afford to do this? 

    I would welcome a personal reply but I know you will never personally read this or respond to it. I would also be willing to meet and discuss these matters and others if your schedule permits. I’m sure many citizens in this area would like to meet and discuss these matters with you. 

    I would like to thank you for your time and consideration.

 

Sincerely,

 

Jeffrey A. Haines

Subject:	Election / Thanks

As a fairly new resident to Florida (2+ years), I have
been very happy with Jeb Bush as governor.  He should
be the leader of FEMA!  Or better yet...president.  I
would vote for any person he would endorse for
governor.  

Is it possible to get a hint on who I should vote
for??  I am very confused by the commercials.  They
have been rather negative.  When I see a Crist
commercial I am sure to vote for him.  When I see a
Gallagher commercial, I want to vote for him.  

At this point, I will probably vote for Crist just
because he explains his side of the issues more
thoroughly!

Thank you for being the best governor I have ever had!
(Coming from Illinois, then Michigan)

Best wishes for your future.  Most likely I will vote
for anything you run for in the future!

Shirley Schultz
Resident of Marco Island, Florida

From:	Cristinamosqueda@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, September 4, 2006 6:27 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Illegal Immigrants

September 4, 2006

 

 

President George W. Bush

White House

1600 Pennsylvania Ave.

Washington D.C.

 

Dear Mr. President,

 

Five years ago, I bought my first home in what was predominately a neighborhood of retired, former New Yorkers.  Last October, we were devastated by Hurricane Wilma, and many of our now older neighbors, decided it was time to leave.  To date, we still have approximately 30 homes, out of 274 that are in a major state of disrepair.  Many of the older residents sold their houses at below market, simply wanting to get out before another Hurricane season.

 

We have noticed that since then, there have been an unusual number of illegal immigrants moving into the neighborhood.  How do we know they are illegal, you may wonder?  They are proud of the fact that they are able to break the law and no one cares.  They have said that they feel safe here, as no one is going to look for them amongst our retirees. Yes, I am tired of the fact that they choose to not follow some basic rules and regulations on maintaining the standards of the neighborhood, but that is not why I am writing.  I am writing, because for the first time in my life, I am starting to feel ashamed of whom I am.  

 

I have always been proud to be an American, my Mother’s family migrated to this country many, many years ago, but on my Father’s side, I am a first generation American.  My father came to the United States, and made this country his home.  He insisted that we be proud to be Americans, teaching us American history and making sure that we climbed up to the top of the Statue of Liberty, crossed the Golden Gate Bridge, gazed at the wonders of the Great Lakes, Grand Canyon, and Gateway Arch of St. Louis, and paid our respects as we toured National Battle Grounds, viewed the USS Arizona, and the memorials in our nations capital.   He also managed to make sure that we learned Spanish, knew Cuban history, literature, culture, and were proud to be Cubans, as well.  

 

Prior to this new phenomenon in immigration, when new immigrants came to American, they sought to become part of America, while still retaining their immigrant identity.  They did not seek to re-write our National Anthem, in Spanish, they were proud to learn it in English.  Our neighborhood is changing, but not for the better.  I am tired of people insulting my country and choosing not to obey her laws.  I have struggled with making my feelings public, and calling for action.  My parents were ministers, and at one time pastored a church in Delano, California, where much of their congregation was made up of illegal immigrants, who worked in agriculture.  But I have to say, those people were at least trying to enter our melting pot, which is not what I see now.  

 

We called the Homeland Security department that deals with illegal immigrants,-1-866-347-2423, to report what was happening in our neighborhood.  The agent seemed to be irritated that we had so many names and addresses to report.  He questioned how we knew what we were saying, and that was the end of it – that was about a month ago, and nothing has happened.  Recently, in South Florida, there have been statements made, in the press, that the priority of the INS is dealing with criminals and terrorist.  Is not the act of entering this country illegally a crime?  Where does this stop?  What do we do?  

 

I am certain, that if the Immigration service investigated our neighborhood, they would be shocked at what they would find.  

 

There are several homes which we suspect, based on their association with other known illegal aliens, that they too are illegal, but we have not heard anything directly about them, but on the list we gave the INS, we feel certain there are illegal people in the house.  Some have told us themselves, or told us how they bought the house – when they first come on Visa, they get an international tax payer identification number, and then use this to set up what they need.  The laws being broken here are numerous.  People driving without a license, because you need to have proof of legal residency to get a drivers license, more than one family living in a single family home (this is city of Tamarac Code), people harboring other criminals, bringing senior citizens up to set up social security benefits, fraudulent marriages, fake social security cards (people have been sent letters from the social security office saying their names does not match the number), and oh so much more.    

 

Where does it stop?  Which laws are we going to enforce, and who decides?  These people are criminals, they have no regard for the law, and we as a people, as a government are telling them that it is okay to break our laws and not respect our nation.  We need help, at the very least, why not investigate for yourselves and see if there might be a problem here?  

 

Below is a list that we gave to the INS:  During the weekends or holidays there are always many more cars present.

 

Miranda, Maritza 

6500 NW 72 Ave

Tamarac, Fl 33321

 

(Columbia, supposed to be one family – mom, dad, one child – seems to be three families in the one house.)

 

 

 

BOSCARINO,LEANDRO 

7203 NW 67 ST

TAMARAC FL 33321 

(Columbians and Argentines)

 

GUZMAN, LUIS

7300 NW 68 ST 

TAMARAC FL 33321-5525

(Supposed to have their own maid service.)

 

 

HERNANDEZ, MARIA S

6321 NW 74 AVE 

TAMARAC FL 33321-5510

(Also, says they have their own business clearing houses.  Multiple families as well.)

 

GOMES, LUZ MARINA & JARAMILLO, ENRIQUE ETAL  

Mailing Address:  16410 MIAMI DR #209 NORTH MIAMI BEACH FL 33162

 

 

This group owns two homes in our neighborhood, that I know of, one of the men, Victor, who lives there, told me he had no papers, and that what he is buying is a piece of the house.  The group gets together and each get a portion of the house.  The woman he lives with, is getting ready to cash out in another year and go back to Columbia.  

 

7109 NW 68 St.

Tamarac, FL 33321  

 

7111 NW 66 St.

Tamarac, FL 33321

 

 

Owned by an American: MOLINA-JULIO, ZUREIDA

7105 NW 68 St.

Tamarac, FL 33321

  

 (But living there is her partner, Silvia Arroyo Blanco, the two women have been together for over twenty years, though they are third cousins.  Silvia married a gay man, to get her papers, does not and has not lived with him.  When she applied for papers originally she was seeking political asylum.  As her hearing approached was told things had changed too much in Columbia and would not get papers, so married, complete with wedding and album.  Has bragged that some looser Immigration agent, drunk in a bar, fixed her papers.  I have never understood this part of the story.)

 

 

 

PONCE, GUSTAVO E & CARMEN Mercedes

7203 NW 68 ST 

TAMARAC FL 33321-5522

 

(Sons: Gustavo Jr., and Javier Both working at Burger King in Coral Springs Mall, along with an assistant manager, also from Peru who has illegal marriage for green card  Gustavo Sr. works for a house painting company and Carmen works as a maid.)

 

 

 

I live in this neighborhood and do not want my house fire bombed.  If the government is not going to act, then I would appreciate my name not being released to these people, if they are going to act, then I would be happy to help in any way I can.  I am writing this letter, but I assure you I do not stand alone, there are many people frustrated and afraid to act.

 

Sincerely,

 

Cristina Jill Mosqueda

6410 NW 72 Ave.

Tamarac FL 33321

cristinamosqueda@aol.com 

 

c. Governor Jeb Bush 

    Senator Mel Martinez

    Senator Bill Nelson

    Congressman Alcee L. Hastings

    Mayor Beth Flansbaum-Talabisco    

 

 

 

 

 

From:	Cherie Reid <cheriereidusa@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Monday, September 4, 2006 5:32 PM
To:	Governor.Rell@po.state.ct.us; Governor Jeb Bush; gov@hawaii.gov
Subject:	National Veteran's appreciation website

 
 
 
     A few months ago I contacted your office about a new program called “Kids Thank a Veteran” at www.kidsthankavet.com. I would like to update you on the progress of the site and hope that your state can join the 10 states that are now participating. The primary purpose of this site is to have children say “Thank you for serving” when they see a veteran.  They can then register their first name and state on our national database.  We already have children from 20 states registered and this is only the beginning. The secondary purpose is to educate children on the many topics relating to our veterans.
 
      Within a couple of months we: 

*	Have ten state education associations join in to support the site in their schools (AZ, CN, MO, NV, NJ, OR, PA, SC, VA, WY)
*	Have veteran’s organizations throughout the country spreading the word by including the site in their written material
*	Are linked up to national veteran’s websites, such as the New Jersey Department of Military and Veteran’s Affairs and the Oregon Department of Veteran Affairs, to name just two.     
*	Are included in town websites, pediatric websites, etc.  
*	Received letters from eight Governors applauding the site for its merit. (Al, KY, LA, MD, MA, T, VA, WY)
*	Were written up in three newspapers and featured on New Jersey Channel 12 News
*	Received 100% positive feedback from veterans, educators and the public 
*	Will be featured on Veterans Radio, a national radio program

 
     The site is unique in that it does not sell anything and does not advertise – it just supports out veterans and teaches our children. During the next few months we are hoping to increase the number of state education associations that include the site in their curriculum, spread the word to more state organizations and sponsor a national or local poster contest.
 
     Please visit www.kidsthankavet.com.  I think you will agree that it is a worthwhile endeavor.  We are looking forward to having your state join in.
                                                             Thank you,
 
 
                                                             Cherie Reid

From: Sherman Alexander [mailto:budalxandr@earthlink.net] 
Sent: Sunday, September 03, 2006 4:39 PM
To: Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com
Subject: Republican Image

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

Let me start by congratulating you for your service to the citizens of Florida while serving as Governor.

 

Having said that, I must admit that I am perplexed about how you can sit on the sidelines of the U.S. Senate race and not state a preference for one of the candidates.  If all goes according to the polls, the Republican Party in Florida will be represented by an undistinguished, weak, certain-to-lose candidate, for the November election -- Katherine Harris -- and the Democrat candidate will retain his seat in the Senate with effectively no opposition.  This situation will reflect poorly on your position as the leader of our party; and your commitment to give the citizens of Florida the kind of leadership they deserve in the Federal government.  I'm sure this has not escaped your consideration and I'm positive you have made an obvious decision to stay out of primary politics -- but why?  Florida Republicans need -- must have -- your leadership.  It is unfair and unlike you to remain on the sidelines while serving as the elected leader of our state.  You have a responsibility to make a choice, just like all the voters of Florida.

 

I have made a choice.  LeRoy Collins, Jr. is an obvious choice for Republicans but he faces an uphill battle against Harris,  a  candidate who you have said "can't win".  He has the experience and integrity that we need in the Senate.  I'm sure you have evaluated the other candidates, as I have.  Will McBride has no experience in business or the military and only scant experience in his chosen profession.  I sincerely doubt that he could stand up to Nelson in a debate.  No doubt McBride has potential but he is just too young and too inexperienced to be a viable candidate for the U.S. Senate.  The other candidate, Peter Monroe, completely lacks any attraction for voters as shown by his standing in the polls.  That brings me back to LeRoy Collins.  He needs your endorsement.  He has the experience and ability to take on Nelson.  And, as I'm sure you are aware, he has been endorsed by six leading Florida newspapers.  He has an unblemished record and a legacy from his father that he has followed throughout his service to Florida and the nation.  His pledge of one term in office would provide time for grooming the next Republican for the office and set the stage for Republican control for years to come.  He is Senatorial and he can win for the Republicans.  

 

Please don't make the mistake of remaining mute on the Senate race.  You are the Republican leader.  You have a responsibility to speak out and make your choice known.  I trust that would be LeRoy Collins, Jr.

 

Sincerely,

Sherman G. Alexander

Capt. USN (Ret.)

626 Saxony Blvd.

St. Petersburg, FL 33716

From: mills_t@bellsouth.net [mailto:mills_t@bellsouth.net] 
Sent: Saturday, July 22, 2006 12:20 PM 
To: Mills Kathy - LRMC 
Subject: State offering $250 million to help homeowners prepare for 
hurricanes 

This story was sent to you by: Mills 

-------------------- 
State offering $250 million to help homeowners prepare for hurricanes 
-------------------- 

By Michael Peltier 
The Stuart News 

July 5, 2006 

TALLAHASSEE * Florida homeowners seeking to make their homes more 
hurricane proof soon will be allowed to tap into a $250 million pool of 
state money to assist their efforts. 

But the relief won't come overnight, and property owners must be willing 
to back up their requests with cold, hard cash. 

State officials plan to begin processing applications in August for a 
matching grant program that could put up to $5,000 in state money into 
the hands of qualified homeowners in the next five months. 

"It would be fair to say, given how the first phase works, our goal will 
be to have money in the hands of thousands of homeowners and contractors 
to begin making improvements before this hurricane season is over," said 
Tami Torres, spokeswoman for the Florida Department of Financial 
Services, which is overseeing the program. 

In May, Gov. Jeb Bush signed a bill that provides dollar-for-dollar 
matching grants of up to $5,000 in state funds for qualified property 
owners who want to strengthen their home's chances of surviving a storm. 
The program is part of a sweeping hurricane-assistance package that also 
provides aid to governments, mobile home owners and others. 

"As I've traveled around the region, I see a lot of people don't even 
know this is going on," said Rep. Ralph Poppell, R-Vero Beach. "There 
have been some people calling us about it, but not as many as we would 
have hoped. That will probably change." 

The state is in the process of instituting the $250 million program. The 
law requires state officials to set up a process that will require 
inspectors to pass drug screening and criminal background checks. 

Approved inspectors also must have some type of hurricane training or 
experience, Torres said. 

The program is limited to owners of single-family homes worth $500,000 
or less. The property must be a primary residence. Applications will be 
evaluated on a series of factors, including hurricane threat, what can 
be done to improve a structure's survivability and the 
cost-effectiveness of the improvements. 

"We're not talking about mobile homes or condos," Torres said. "This is 
really a single structure program." 

Applicants must first undergo an inspection to determine what, if any, 
improvements can fortify their homes. The state money must be used for 
hurricane-proofing endeavors including shutter installation, roof 
improvements and other work described in the law. 

Torres said homeowners living in hurricane-prone areas of the state 
would be given priority. 

"The statute was very clear that this is not an entitlement program or 
an income-based program," Torres said. "It is a program aimed at 
reducing hurricane damage in the state of Florida." 


-------------------- 
Key program points 

* Provides dollar-for-dollar match for hurricane improvements. Maximum 
grant is $5,000. 

* State legislators have set aside $250 million for program. 

* Application processing expected to begin in August. 

* Almost 2,000 applications filed since Web site went online two weeks 
ago. 

Want to know more? 

Interested homeowners can get information, qualifying criteria and forms 
at www.mysafefloridahome.com. Homeowners also can call the Division of 
Financial Services hotline at 800-342-2762 for forms and additional 
information. 

Copyright (c) 2006, South Florida Sun-Sentinel 

Visit Sun-Sentinel.com 

From:	Edison Vasquez <efvasque@eagle.fgcu.edu>
Sent:	Sunday, September 3, 2006 6:40 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Florida Gulf Coast University: Spanish Club


Dear Governor Bush:

I'm the President of the Spanish Club at Florida Gulf Coast University in 
Fort Myers. Every year, we have a dance to celebrate the Hispanic Heritage 
Month and to raise funds for our service learning project to the Dominican 
Republic. We have had great speakers in the past and the event has been a 
great success every year. This year, we are having our annual celebration at 
the University on October 13th starting at 7:00PM. We expect an attendance 
of about 200 people. The celebration will focus on the impact that the 
Hispanic Community has in Florida. 

We would like to ask you to be our keynote speaker for this celebration. We 
are well acquainted with your excellent work as a Governor and your great 
support to the Hispanic population in Florida. Your remarks as keynoter 
would set the tone perfectly for our celebration. 

Although our limited treasury does not permit payment of fees or expenses 
for speakers, we are hoping that your interest in the Hispanic community 
will be a sufficient incentive for you to be with us.

I look forward to a favorable reply, and just as soon as I receive it, I 
will send you complete details. Our celebration would take place at the 
Student Union Ballroom, at the University. Thank you. 
Sincerely,

Edison Vasquez
Spanish Club President
efvasque@eagle.fgcu.edu

From:	David Johnston <masterson_2500@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Sunday, September 3, 2006 4:44 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	lethal injection

Dear Governor Bush:

Florida's death penalty is in jeopardy and only you can fix it at this 
point. Right now, Clarence Hill's execution date is set for September 20th, 
2006, and with the 11th circuit just remanding the case back to the district 
court a couple days ago, it is highly unlikely Mr.Hill's execution will be 
carried out on this date. To my knowledge, the case on Hill's lethal 
injection claims can be expedited, but it's unlikely. If you reset Clarence 
Hill's execution date to around November, it will provide much more time for 
both the District Court and 11th Circuit to rule on Mr.Hill's lethal 
injection claims.

I fully support capital punishment in Florida. I would like to see Mr.Hill's 
execution carried out as soon as possible, but with a Sept. 20th execution 
date and his case having permission to challenge lethal injection....it's 
either postpone the execution another 2 months and give the courts time to 
settle the issue and expedite it and Hill's execution can be carried out.... 
or Mr.Hill will get a stay of execution permanently and Florida won't have 
any executions for quite possibly the next 2 years. I will be absolutely 
livid to see Florida's death penalty put on hold for 2 years. It's wrong. If 
you do the right thing and postpone Mr.Hill's execution 2 months, his case 
can be expedited through the courts and his execution will be carried out. 
Right now he's almost guaranteed a stay of execution because there's not 
enough time to expedite the challenge in 19 days to lethal injection in both 
district court and the 11th circuit.

Thank you

Mr. Bush:
 
I was born at Warren A.F.B., Cheyenne,Wy.  My father is 83 and a retired Air Force Colonel.  We moved across this country every 3 years and I have been in every state in the union.  When I was in junior high school I saw a film where Kruschev stated the United States would fall from within.
This prophecy has come to pass. 
 
Why should I learn to speak Spanish?  Why should I support - feed, cloth, and educate people who are in this country illegally and who are not even interested in learning to speak our language. I want this mass exodus into our country stopped.  All the veterans did not serve in the military to see a Mexican flag flying on U.S. soil.
 
Do whatever it takes - send them back to Mexico and let them begin the legal process of entering this country.  They are violating the laws and constitution of this country.
 
Lynda Love.

From:	Firemom1522@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, September 1, 2006 11:06 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thank you

I must apologize for taking so very long to write & tell you thank you from the bottom of my and my family's heart.  You see when Hurricane Ivan wiped everything my family had and my husband & I were living in a tent in our front yard - our daughter had to be moved in with friends - you made a telephone call to FEMA and a travel trailor appeared in our yard so that we could move in and bring our daughter home after many many weeks of being separated. I was transferred by mistake by the main switchboard operator and landed up talking with your secretary.  She was my guardian angel that day and took time from her busy schedule to talk to me, to cry with me - she just listened - then I can only imagine that it was her that told you about our telephone conversation. 
 
Ivan was only the beginning let's not forget the visit we received from Dennis & Katrina that brought water back into our home and made us to have to start all over again.  My Dad use to tell me that we were not to question why things happen just to remember that there is a reason for everything - granted I have often wondered what it was but I will say that we are better for the experience.  My husband & I are state certified Firefighters I - we volunteer in our local fire department - we teach CPR & 1st Aid and also volunteer with our county's Search & Rescue organization.  We feel our children learn by example and we try to show that everyone needs to put back into the society not just drain it dry.  
 
While Ivan was filling up our home my husband was trapped inside with our 12 year old foster son, I was volunteering at Emergency Management listening to my fire department trying to get to them not being able to complete that task - I will never forget walking into the 911 call center and listening to this event unravel.  I must say I will never be the same as I was prior to that moment.
 
People in today's society are fast to talk and say ugly things about others but few are there to tell the good things and to our family that is you.  It took us almost 21 months to get our home back together - well not counting just new sheet rock not finished in the laundry room - but close enough - we are 100% in our home - my home day care is back up and running - granted not where I was before Ivan but up nevertheless.
 
People often ask if there was one person in the world that you could meet who would it be - my answer is always the same - it is Governor Bush because you are my hero.  I thank God every day in my prayers for you and all that you have done for my family and so many others.  I wish that it was possible that you could see our home now that we have it completed but I understand that some things just can't be - that is with your busy work schedule and all the decisions that you have to make daily.  But the invitation to our home is always open for you.
 
I feel very honored to have you as my Governor and also very honored to have your brother as my President.  I truly believe that we are better people for having your family take the leading edge and guide us in the right way.  It is always so easy to be negative about what someone else is doing but not wanting to be bothered and help out.
 
I must admit that I learned many things along my way since Ivan, that "NO"  word that so many were fast to say - the lack of support from those people we thought were our friends that treated us like we had a disease and never stopped by or called to check on us - the insurance company cussing me and laughing at me and finally the attorney that I had to hired to take control and just give me a break - yes it is bad that I had to give him 33% but at some point in time I would have given him 100% just to prove that I was not going to give up.  Now that insurance company is not renewing us and no insurance company wants to write us a policy because my house was built in the 1950's and anything before 1977 is not insurable by most.  Well, let me say we have found one company that will but it is $2,700 a year to be made in one payment by the beginning of December - well I guess I have crossed many tall blockages during all of this what is one more.
 
I am sorry I have taken enough of your time but please know that we will always be eternally grateful to you, a busy Governor that took precious moments of his time to help us when no one else would and we so appreciate it - we are thankful for you.  God bless you in all that you every do.  Please tell your family thank you for sharing such a wonderful man with us.
 
Sincerely,
Denise Lowery
4738 Ward Basin Road
Milton, FL  32583
850) 626-9191 / 554-5351

Subject:	[*] Housing Factory

Dear Gov. Bush,

 Greetings from the great State of Louisiana! My name is Bob Titus. I am an independent consultant in South Louisiana. I was recently contacted by a client who was seeking funding to construct a factory to manufacture panelized housing using a patented steel /concrete/insulation panel. 
 This method allows a builder to construct a home in half of the time required to construct a conventional wooden frame home. The finished product is designed to withstand hurricane-force winds; it is resistant to termites, fire, mold, mildew, and many other items that plague wooden houses! The panels are also capable of creating huge energy savings for the homeowner and subsiquently for the power grid! 
 This client is interested in raising $10 million dollars to fund this project. The factory would create new jobs and produce a premium product that would greatly assist in the rapid recovery of the destroyed homes left in the wake of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, as well as, future development projects in both residential and commercial areas.
 The client would welcome a loan, partnership, or a combination of both!

From:	Jim Rucquoi <rucquoi@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Thursday, August 31, 2006 10:10 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Walk for Peace: 9/16/06 in Sanford

Dear Governor Bush,


I imagine there are very few of us on the planet today not deeply concerned with the violence happening all around us, in all parts of the world including on our very own streets. You know the feeling of powerlessness in the air; it seems no matter what we do, things are just getting worse. When can we ever imagine our America in this state?

I do, however, feel a significant shift underfoot. Take this idea Congressman Dennis Kucinich came to us with not long ago about a cabinet level U.S. Department of Peace. Although a new Secretary of Peace may be years from the naming, the fire has been lit, an alternative to this bleak present is imaginable. I can sense  the deep impact of such an eminently sensible, perfectly concrete message.


Existing programs, communication skills, mediation and conflict resolution are already being practiced and refined. Just think of how a federal Department of Peace, formally charged, might validate and expedite the process for nonviolent solutions to domestic and international conflict. The proposal even includes establishing a fourth service academy on a level with West Point, Annapolis, and the Air Force Academy. Training young leaders for peace instead of war. Imagine!


Are you aware that two bills are presently before each house of Congress to establish such a Department? I feel very strongly that if our fellow citizens knew, they wouldn't lose any time  joining us to urge our representatives to sign on.


I AM ASKING YOU TODAY TO JOIN US ON SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 2006 FOR A WALK FOR PEACE.
This walk is being held both in honor of Gandhi's first walk for peace 100 years ago in South Africa and to support the Department of Peace campaign. There are currently over 80 cities in 32 states hosting walks in this nationwide endeavor. You can get the full picture at http://www.thepeacealliance.org/content/view/178/147/

We will be meeting at 9 AM on the 16th next month in downtown Sanford at the Visitor's Center on the corner of Palmetto & FIrst. We'll walk down First and up Park past City Hall and Seminole Courthouse to Veterans Memorial Park on the lake. After a short address at the park, we'll continue eastward along Riverwalk and circle up Mellonville to First past the Seminole County offices, then back to the municipal parking lot. It's just over a mile and should take under three hours including our time at the park. As it's still summer, we are urging all participants to bring a bottle of water with them and a hat. Toilets are available at Mellon Park along the RIverwalk. 


This walk is not envisioned as a protest, an anti-war march or rally. We are for peace and the Department of Peace, specifically; on that day we will not be against anything. This is an opportunity to model peace in all we do  --to truly be that momentous change we're so hungry for. As such, we will have T-shirts, signs, banners, etc. promoting only Peace. In this way, we will be walking for positive change, for healing, and for those things that genuinely unite us all and promote mutual understanding.


I am attaching our information sheet. For more info, contact me at 407 323-9809 or email me here. It would be great to share these few hours together for this one vital issue that so touches all our lives.  

If you are not available on the 16th, I'd greatly appreciate your sponsoring me as I walk; your donation will be your own way of being included in this local movement towards peace. Make your check out to The Peace Alliance. You can send it to me at: 715 South Myrtle Avenue, Sanford, FL 32771. Your support will make a difference.


Thanks so much for taking the time to walk with me here. One more thing: can you think of five friends who should know too, and who might want to join us? They don't have to be from Sanford: ours is the only walk for peace taking place in these parts. Would you please take another moment now to pass this invite on to them?


Peace,
Jim Rucquoi

SANFORD WALK FOR PEACE
Saturday, September 16, 2006
9:00am at the Visitors Center
http://www.thepeacealliance.org

From:	willieharriett@bellsouth.net
Sent:	Thursday, August 31, 2006 9:15 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Son Case

Dear Governor Bush,

My name is Willie A. Wood. We have one main thing in common, we both love our children. Thus, the reason I am writing you today.

Recently, my son received a life sentence in prison for Sexual Battery Under 12 Years of Age. I am writing you, because he did not commit this crime. He was wrongly accused by my son's ex-girlfriend, a mother , who had a serious frug addiction. Naturally, I am standing behind the viewpoint that my son is innocent.

After three hours of court, the judge just gave me son a life sentence, without any concrete evidence, just that person testimony, which was questionable.

My attorney has written a brief to argue my son 's case. I am quite certain that we will have a new trial coming in the near future, but that could take as much as four years.

My son has a son, who is seven years old. This is where we have the main thing in common.I don't want my son to spend the next four year in prison for something he didn't't do. My grandson, should not have to grow up without his father-especially, since his father is innocent.

May I please have the priviledge of an appointment with you, or your representative, to discuss the matter. Would you please fax a response to this request to 386-345-2776 or E-mail me back to willieharriett@bellsouth.net.

We both love our children and want only  what is just for them. I am sure you can understand where I stand on this.

Thank you for your corporation.



Willie A. Wood
Father and Grandfather

From:	hibiscus <hibiscus@sunline.net>

August 30, 2006

Dear Governor Bush,

Our family unanimously recommends Don Coppola to fill the vacant District 5
commissioner seat in Charlotte County.

Susan and Charles first met Don Coppola at his place of business in 1983.
From the first, they saw he had a remarkable understanding of county issues
and solutions. They remember when your father was running for president,
there were photos of your mother’s trip to Charlotte County in his shop. Don
Coppola was and is proud to be a Republican and has promoted the Republican
party at his place of business.

We would give him an A for responsibility, knowledge, and compassion for the
residents of Charlotte County.

As for responsibility, he served 8 years in the US Navy. Some of these years
were during wartime. He has been successful in his personal and business
endeavors. Besides his successful business, and investments in Charlotte
County, he showed fiscal responsibility as a Charlotte County Commissioner
from 1996 to 2000.

As for knowledge. Don Coppola knows Charlotte County backwards and forwards.
This is partially because he has lived here since the 1970s and because he
cares about Charlotte County. He knows what he is talking about and shares
his information with others.

Don Coppola’s rapport with people sometimes is overshadowed by his knowledge
and sense of responsibility. However one great sign of his rapport with
voters, is reflected in the fact that during his office there was a better
ratio of Republicans to Democrats in District 5 than there is now.

Don Coppola has the responsibility, knowledge, and compassion to make a
great commissioner for District 5 and the county, as he has in the past. We
hope you take this information into consideration when you are making your
choice.

We would be glad to answer any other questions you might have. Please call
us at (941) 286-1183 for further information. Thank you.

Sincerely,

Susan and Charles Kovacs
Holly Kovacs
and Anne Pawson
(Anne, Susan, and Holly are three generations of registered Republicans in
Charlotte County)

From:	BRONXQUEEN64@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, August 30, 2006 11:36 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	CHILD SUPPORT

Dear Governor Bush,    I have a divorce order that includes child support in Florida. After the divorce my ex-husband moved to Texas. After much difficulty in receiving child support from him, I opened a case with Child Support Enforcement here in Florida in 2002. I filled out the appropriate paperwork, and the child support office forwarded this paperwork to the state of Texas for enforcement. Sometime later I requested that FL contact TX to request enforcement as it had been quite some time since I had received support. FL contacted TX for me and was told that they never received the paperwork. FL immed resent the paperwork to TX. As I have always received my support sporadically, I do not know if TX ever contacted my ex-husband. Some months later, I again requested FL contact TX for enforcement. Again, FL was told that TX did not have the paperwork on my case. FL then faxed AND mailed the paperwork to TX. Texas did nothing to enforce. As of this Friday, Sept. 1, it will have been 9 months since I have seen any support payments.  A month ago I emailed the Office of the Attorney General in Texas. I did not receive a response. Two weeks ago I emailed the Office of the Governor of Texas. I received a copy of the email I sent and a copy of the notice that was sent to the Office of the Attorney General. So far, no action. I contacted my local child support office today (Aug. 30). They had contacted Texas yesterday to request enforcement. Fl CSE was then told by the TX child Support office that they had closed my case in May 06 as they did not receive the paperwork they requested in March. This is when the paperwork was faxed and mailed to them for the second time. The worker in FL was talking with the Texas call center. The worker looked up the case and found in the notes that they had indeed received the paperwork in March. Needless  to say I am very distressed over this! The FL CSE has done their job and I have done mine. Texas is terribly lacking. I have always taken care of my child to be sure he did not do without do to a deadbeat dad. I am married at this point in time and am very lucky to have a husband who helps take care of my child as if he was his own; but during the years I was a single mother I never took any thing from the state as I was fully capable of working and did in fact work two jobs for quite some time to take care of my child as it was my responsibility, not the State of Florida's. I again emailed the Governor of Texas this evening and hopefully will get some satisfaction soon. This said, I hope that your office will contact the office of the Governor in Texas to inquire for me what is happening. In the meantime, the Child Support office here  is resending the paperwork in hopes that Texas may do something this time. I thank you for your time and help in this matter. Sincerely,  Theresa M. Foreman

Fred B. Currid
2011 Rymal Road

646 Beethoven Circle

From:  "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Reply-To:  jeb.bush@myflorida.com
To:  "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Subject:  Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 18, 2006
Date:  Sun, 20 Aug 2006 07:47:35 -0400
>For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
>Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
>http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
>The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
>FLORIDA STUDENTS INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN FOURTH ANNUAL HISPANIC HERITAGE
>MONTH ESSAY CONTEST
>
>On Tuesday, First Lady Columba Bush and I invited Florida students in
>kindergarten through twelfth grades to participate in the fourth annual
>Florida Hispanic Heritage Month essay contest. The essay contest is the
>first in a month-long schedule of events planned to commemorate Florida's
>Hispanic heritage. The theme of the essay contest is, 'Why is learning about
>Florida's Diverse Hispanic Heritage and Culture Important?'
>
>Columba and I are proud of the Spanish and Latin-American influences that
>contribute to Florida's rich culture and history and play a dynamic role in
>shaping our history and future.  Hispanic Heritage month gives us the
>opportunity to educate Florida's students on the tremendous contributions
>Hispanic individuals make to our state.  We are asking students to pay
>special tribute to the Florida's diverse Hispanic population and their
>contributions to the state's culture, economy and education. The theme for
>Florida's 2006 Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration is 'La Florida: Honoring
>Our State's Spanish and Latin American Influences'.  Those interested in
>participating in the essay contest or obtaining more information on
>additional Hispanic Heritage Month events should visit
>www.floridahispanicheritage.com or contact Nadia Hagberg in the Governor's
>office at (850) 488-5000 for more information.
>
>
>RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDA HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES TOOK THE ACT
>
>On Wednesday, Education Commissioner John L. Winn and I announced a record
>number of Florida's high school graduates took the American College Test
>(ACT).  This year 66,299 of Florida's 2006 high school graduates took the
>ACT, up from 58,302 in 2005. Of all high school graduates, 44 percent took
>the ACT in Florida compared to 40 percent nationally. The ACT is one of two
>college entrance tests Florida students can choose to take. Last year, more
>than 93,500 of Florida's 2005 high school graduates took the SAT,
>representing 65 percent of the total number of high school graduates.
>
>Florida has been extremely successful at increasing the number of students
>taking college entrance exams.  We must continue to encourage all of our
>high school students to take these exams and prepare for the rigor of
>college and the workforce.  Minority students represent 47 percent of the
>2006 test takers, compared to 30 percent nationally.  During 2006, African
>Americans represented 21 percent of the Florida test takers, compared to
>only 13 percent nationwide.  Hispanic students comprised 17 percent of
>Florida test takers, compared to only eight percent nationally.  To learn
>more about the ACT visit www.fldoe.org.  To learn more about FACTS.org or to
>complete an ePEP, visit www.FACTS.org.
>
>
>POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO JERMAINE PHILLIPS
>
>I recognized Jermaine Phillips, a starting safety for the Tampa Bay
>Buccaneers, as this week's Points of Light Award recipient.  Jermaine's
>efforts are making a positive difference in the lives of those he visits at
>Central Florida hospitals, retirement homes and juvenile justice programs.
>Jermaine's commitment to Florida's youth has proven that he is a champion
>both on and off the field.  Through his volunteerism and philanthropy, many
>young Floridians have a brighter future.  For more information, or to
>nominate, go to www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.
>
>Congratulations!
>
>To read more about this week's winners, please click here:
>http://www.flgov.com/release/8082
>
>
>GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES
>
>Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
>

>Volume 8, Issue 33
>Copyright(c) 2006 State of Florida
>

>http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html
>
>
>Thank you.
>
>

From:	Mike Lozano <mlozano1@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 30, 2006 10:46 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Virtual Hearing - Security Plus Citizenship

Mike Lozano
4824 Longwater Way
Tampa, FL 33615-4216


August 30, 2006

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of Florida
The Capitol, 400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


 Governor Bush:

As part of Congress.org's virtual hearing on immigration reform, I wanted 
to offer my own views. I support border security plus a path to earned 
citizenship. We need to take the same approach to immigration as was done 
in response to the flooding in New Orleans last year. Namely, reinforce 
the border first to prevent unauthorized individuals from entering the 
country, and then remove those unauthorized individuals who have committed 
ANY transgression of federal, state, or local laws. There are plenty of 
hard working, law-abiding individuals who would be welcome members of our 
society. Once the acute emergency is dealt with, we can have a discussion 
in our country on how to integrate the remaining folks into our society. 

Sincerely,


Mike Lozano
813 818-0003

From:	Donnie Kennedy <dgk_kennedy@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 30, 2006 5:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	To the office of Gov. J. Bush

Gov. Bush

My name is Donald Kennedy Jr., and I have a warrant out for my arrest for 
violation of probation in the State of Florida. I have been considered a 
fugitive since 2003, and I want to clear this matter up and so I can move on 
with my life and not have to worry about being separated from my wife and 
children again.

I was living in Florida when I failed to return a rental vehicle. I know it 
was a dumb thing to do and I wish that I had not made that kind of decision. 
I went to court for my offence, and agreed to be placed on probation for 24 
months and pay restitution. I went to every meeting and made every payment 
for about 17 or 18 months and then I lost my job. Within a few weeks my life 
became a nightmare.

My wife tried to commit suicide, and my son back in Arkansas was calling me 
everyday crying for me to come home. I got my wife out of the mental help 
facility in Stuart FL, and after we talked about it, I made the decision to 
leave.  I know it was a bad choice to make, but I chose to take what little 
bit of cash I had left and my wife and I caught a bus back to Arkansas. At 
the time I was thinking about saving my family instead of considering my own 
legal situation.

I had discussed transferring my probation to Arkansas with my probation 
officer before all of this happened, but she had told me that I would have 
to have a job first. I tried to get a job over the phone, but it didn’t work 
out too good for me. Without being able to actually show up for interviews, 
I couldn’t find a job, so there was no hope for me to leave Florida legally.

I have contacted a couple of lawyers to try and get some help, but they want 
far more money to take the case than I can afford, and they said that I 
would have to turn myself in before they could help me out. My family can 
not afford to be without me, and if I were to turn myself in it would leave 
my wife and our two kids without anywhere to live, and destroy our family. I 
cry every night about this whole situation, and I have no idea how to handle 
my problem without any money, and without anyone to help me out. Other than 
this thing, I have never had any serious trouble with the law, and if I 
could, I would fix this mess. My family and I live life on a day to basis, 
and coming up with enough money to resolve this issue is just not possible.

I have pretty much lost any hope that I will ever be able to live a normal 
life, and I know that one day I will be picked up by the law and sent to 
Florida to face a jail sentence. This letter is written as a last resort, 
and I’m hopeful that there is a way I can get a pardon from the State of 
Florida. If you can help me at all please contact me.

Sincerely
Donald Kennedy Jr.
dgk_kennedy@hotmail.com

Dear Govenor Bush,                                                    Re:Robert E.Smith Doc #994615
                                                                                       
 
           I am writing to you on behalf of my brother,Robert E.Smith, Doc# 994615. He is an inmate at the Sumpter County Forestry camp.  We are asking for your help in commuting
the rest of his sentence to probation.  My brother is remorseful for his crime, a crime whose only victim was himself and his families. Due to a momentary lack of judgement fueled by alcohol intoxication he mistakenly thought vigilantism was his only recourse in regaining his stolen property.  He realizes what a stupid mistake that was but at the time he was more worried about his ability to run his business and provide for his family.  He helped someone out by giving them a job and a place to live and they repaid him by stealing all his computers he needs to run his sign business.  
       Our family has suffered many tradgedies and injustices.  Robert has missed his sister's funeral, the birth of his first grandchild and countless other family occasions due to one serious lapse in judgement.  We have lost of mother, father and sister due to long debilitating diseases.  The biggest injustice of all is that our oldest brother was murdered in 1974.  He left behind two small children and a devastated family.  The two men who brutally murdered my brother and his girlfriend only served a two year sentence due to a plea bargain.  Yet Robert sits in prison for 10 years for a victimless crime because a judge decided to sentence him way above the guidelines of his conviction.  Where was this judge when  the child molesters 
whom roam our streets were sentenced?  
           Robert is a well respected man in the sign business world with 35 years of experience and would serve the community better as an actively employed member of society. He was never a threat to society and never will be.  He has the support of his family and friends. He has renewed his faith in God and the Catholic Church. He says the rosary everday as our mother did everyday of her life. We are pleading with you to please right this wrong and restore our faith in the justice system. We are asking to provide clemency and commuting his sentence to probation in which he has applied for with your office. Please reunite the little family that we have left.  
                                                                                    Sincerely,
                        
                                                                                     Eileen M. Price
                                                                                      407-275-5662  
From:	Elizabeth Dunklee <edunklee@frallc.com>

Subject:	INVITATION TO SPEAK:  Price Transparency in Healthcare Conference
Attachments:	Transparency Past Attendees.xls

Dear Governor Bush,

 

On behalf of Financial Research Associates, I’d like to invite you to speak at our upcoming conference on Price Transparency in Healthcare, scheduled to take place on January 24-25, 2007 at the Paris Casino in Las Vegas, NV, dedicated to facilitating the goal of achieving price transparency for health insurers and care providers.  With President Bush’s Executive Order 13410 on transparency going into affect on January 1, 2007, price transparency is sure to be on everyone’s mind in the healthcare field come the turn of the year, with particular anxieties as to what will be most successful and effective.  By educating these individuals, we hope to calm anxieties and benefit the consumers around the nation who have been affected by the order.  I would like you to serve as a keynote speaker in this conference, referencing your experiences and successes with price transparency in Florida.

 

Financial Research Associates offers numerous high-level events in the healthcare arena; I’ve attached a list of attendees of our healthcare events of 2006.  For a current listing of events, and for more information on the company, please visit our website: www.frallc.com.

 

Could you please let me know as soon as possible if you can participate?

 

Thank you and I look forward to working with you on this.

 

Elizabeth Dunklee, Conference Producer

Financial Research Associates, LLC

From:	Mark S. Hankins <flacorps@gate.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 30, 2006 1:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Investigate the Tampa-Hillsborough Expressway Authority

Dear Governor Bush,

Today the Tampa Tribune called for your office to begin an investigation of the Tampa-Hillsborough Expressway Authority. 

I agree.  Please help the Suncoast as a whole by eliminating the improprieties that seem to be creeping in.

We need transit solutions, not more ill-conceived toll roads designed 
more to enrich insiders than to serve the public.

Thank you,

Mark S. Hankins
From:	Robert Mitchell <robert.mitchell@sfcc.edu>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 30, 2006 11:19 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Interim Sheriff for Alachua County, Florida

August 30, 2006

RE: Joseph M. "Buddy" Crevasse III

Dear Govenor Bush:

It is my understanding that an "interim sheriff" will be needed to take the helm of the Alachua County Sheriffs's office upon the effective date of the resignation of Sheriff Oelrich until the installment of the new elected sheriff after the election is completed. I am a resident of Alachua County and have been so since 1964. I am retired from the Gainesville Police Department with 33 years of service and currently am an Associate Professor of Criminal Justice at Santa Fe Community College. 

I have known Joseph M. "Buddy" Crevasse III for some 35 years of his 37 years with the Alachua County Sheriff's Office and I ask that you consider appointing him as the leader of that organization for the interim period. It is important to stabilize the organization with someone who knows how to immediately take the helm and a person with the integrity to do the right thing for the benefit of those employed and the citizens of the county, as a whole. Buddy Crevasse has worked in the community for many years both inside the sheriff's office in numerous command positions and in community outreach, whether serving on the board of the Salvation Army or cooking for the Rotary Foundation Fryers. I have been associated with Buddy both on the job and in the community and you will not find a finer human being anywhere. 

Buddy started with ACSO in February of 1967, as a marine patrol deputy and over the years,worked and commanded communications, warrants, baliff, civil section, uniform patrol, civil/court security, and technical services bureau.
During the mid 1980's he completed his BA degree from the University of Florida while working, raising a family and progressing though the ranks to the satisfaction of all.  I met Buddy in 1969 when I began with the Gainesville Police Department and have never had occasion to regret eith our friendship nor anyy activity we have worked on over the years. 

I am proud to ask that you consider placing Buddy as the Sheriff for Alachua County. I appreciate your consideration and I remain available for further inquiry if additional questions need answered or if I can assist you in any way.

Sincerely,


Robert S. Mitchell II
10116 N.W. 6th Place
Gainesville, Fl 32607
352.331.5823
robert.mitchell@sfcc.edu

Since the terrorist attacks 5 years ago it seems that the one day a year we have to get his face out on TV. has been taken but you will not let that stop you from doing whatever it takes to help all the families in their time of need. A lot has changed since Zach has disappeared, two of his cousins have children, two have babies on the way three have gotten married one was in a bad accident last year at Universal Studios while he was working and died twice, but I’m glad to say the Lord was with my family on that day he is alive and doing very well, and last eight of his cousins have graduated High School. He has missed so much and been missed so much. My daughter will be 5 in January and knows a stranger took him and knows him only by pictures. I guess all I would like to say is thank you for what you have done for our children since you have been in office, I hope your work will continue after the new election takes place, but I do wish you could stay in office. Please try not to let our next Governor and the one after that and all the other’s after that forget these children. Children are our priceless future and should be treated in such a way- priceless. And always remember they are lost but never forgotten. Your time in office has meant so much to Zach’s entire family and for that may god bless you and yours, and keep you safe from harm.

 

All my heart,

Amandia Sharbono (Flanagan)

I am one who was recently married June 4, 2006

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I have been watching Florida’s efforts to protect it citizens through a culture of preparedness.  During this effort the government has appropriated $250,000,000 in state funds to protect homes under $500,000 in appraised value.  At the same time, the insurance industry is giving the Floridians the two step. One by increasing the premiums on wind insurance and Two dropping the people that need the insurance most of all, leaving the States Insurance safety net holding the bag.

 

My company StormBlok has an answer to how to protect these peoples homes and contents as well as to get insurance companies to step to the plate and fulfill their responsibilities in regard to offering insurance to the lowest common denomination, Mobile home owners and single story home owners. We have patented and validated a new thinking product that offers total home protection, not just the windows and doors but the entire structure.  The product reduces the wind load on the structure by a minimum of 60% (University of Massachusetts), creates an impact barrier that surpasses Project Impact standards and is affordable.

 

The Company has recently moved its status as a New York based Company to a Florida based Company. 

 

Along with my Board of Directors, I will be in Florida September 6th through the 10th and would like the honor of educating you on this revolutionary new thinking product and also to see how we might work with Florida Universities, the Economic Development Council and the States Insurance Council to help Florida not only have a culture of Preparedness but actually be totally prepared.

 

We will alter our schedule in any way to accommodate your availability.   I can be reached at (585) 749-8943 or by e-mail at either of the following addresses.  Pwiegel@rochester.rr.ocm or pwiegel@extradev.com.

 

Thank you for your consideration in this matter and I am sure that once you see how StormBlok approached this significant problem you will feel that the 30 minutes you spent with us is time very well spent.

 

Sincerely,

 

Parr Wiegel

Dear Gov. Bush,

 

I am contacting you because of my frustrations with your office. Recently in Miami there is a commercial showing you  standing and supporting  a political candidate named Frank Bolanos. Are you aware of the personal agenda and irresponsibility of this individual? In Miami we have a large Cuban population. They may be many in number but they are still part of the American system. There is a book in our community libraries  titled “Vamos A Cuba”. Well Frank Bolanos and the community Cubans feel it does not portray Cuba as it should and have voted to remove it off the shelves of our schools. There are a lot of books that leave room for discussion but they are not removed off of the American shelves. Frank Boalnos, acting on pressure from the Cuban community, voted to remove this book, and when a Judge ruled the vote was illegal, he then voted to take $250,000 of our school money to fight this action. He states he is protecting our children. WHAT ARE WE BEING PROTECTED FROM ??? Our schools are in need of physical repair, we do not have enough schools for our children, our teachers are underpaid, there are gangs and not enough supplies and he wants to spend $250,000 of our precious money to fight a Cuban children’s book cause. Can you please explain this to me and can you please explain why you are supporting this individual? Yes he is Cuban and yes he is a Republican but your responsibility is to see that our school system is well funded and our American way is protected from censorship. My advice to you is to pull you name off of this individua’ls campaign otherwise you have tarnished your reputation of education support.

 

Also I beg you to help us with insurance reform. My homeowner/windstorm insurance has increased from $465 to $4,000. We soon will not be able to live in the State of Florida. There are blue tarps on a majority of the homes in our area because we can not get our roofs repaired, and there is a hurricane moving in our direction.  Where is our government and how are you helping us? 

 

Our politicians were voted to support the people who elected them, not support special interest groups or causes. 

 

Thank you,

Lynda Scheuermann

Dear Governor Bush, 

 

I am writing on behalf of Josephine Gagliardi, a finalist for appointment as a Lee County Court judge. As private tutor and family friend, I have known Josie for several years and can vouch for her tireless work ethic, honesty, integrity, tenacity, and belief in fairness. 

As an educator, I wish that more parents were like Josie in the wise guidance she gives to her twin sons in teaching them to be accountable for their personal actions. In truth, I think she’s had to act as a caring judge for the 14 years she’s been a mother. One of Josie’s sons, Dennis, has multiple disabilities, and I have seen Josie be not only his tireless advocate and devout mother, but also his personal instructor on self-discipline and accountability. 

If Josie presides over a case, I know that she will deal with each party in a fair manner. I am confident in saying this because, despite her sons’ vast difference in abilities, Josie shows them both the individual affection, attention, and supportive love they each need. 

As a voter, a teacher, and as a citizen, I ask you to please appoint Josephine Gagliardi to the bench. I am certain that she will serve Lee County well, with every attention to detail and fairness. 

 

Sincerely,

Shannon Migut, M. Ed.

Dear Governor Bush, 
The School District of Hillsborough County in conjunction with Hillsborough Education Foundation  will be awarding  the 16th Annual Business Partnership Awards at a breakfast on Tuesday, October 31, 2006 at the Hyatt Regency in Tampa. The awards program recognizes and honors all the businesses who have supported public schools in Hillsborough County in the past school year. Typically, this popular event attracts between 700 and 800 leaders in business, community and education as well as the media. 

We would be honored if you would consider joining us to serve as keynote speaker for this special event to help recognize those who have helped promote public education. The teachers, administrators and community along with our board of directors would be thrilled if you would participate in the awards program and help recognize the importance of business and community working together to support students and teachers in the third largest school district in the state.
 
Some of last  year's winners include Suncoast Schools Federal Credit Union, TECO Energy, Inc, Washington Mutual, as well as smaller businesses and organizations  like Sparky's Oil Company and The Tampa Downtown Partnership.

Dear Governor Bush:

Mr. Robert Guidara has sent numerous e-mails to your office during the last two weeks to apprise you of the serious situation faced by your constituents here on the Gulf Coast who are unable to obtain flood insurance. He then spoke to one of your aides who directed Mr. Guidara to request a telephone conference with you. Shortly thereafter he received a form letter from Tara Wainwright, your Director of Scheduling, which said you did not have lime to meet with Mr. Guidara. Of course, the fact is that Mr. Guidara never requested a meeting with you. He requested a telephone call — as was suggested by one of your aides. Your refusal to even talk with Mr. Guidara indicates a disheartening indifference to the problem facing the (mostly Republican) constituents of this area.

I have voted a straight Republican ticket ever since I voted for Barry Goldwater. I have voted for you, for your brother, and for your father. I voted Republican because I believed the Republican Party had more compassion and concern for the American people than did the opposition party. Your indifference to the flood insurance problem faced by the people on the Gulf Coast gives me reason to question the wisdom of what I have done.

I am writing to request you have a representative attend the meeting.

Yours truly,

James D. Brodie

Subject:	Disappointed

Dear Governor Bush:

I sent numerous emails to your office these past two weeks in attempt to apprise you of the very serious situation faced by many of your constituents here on the gulf coast. I spoke with one of your aides at length, and she directed me to request a telephone conference with you. I did that via email as instructed. A few days later, someone from your office called my home and asked my wife for our address as she was told that it was a scheduling procedure requirement.

Today, to my dismay, I received a form letter in the mail from Tara Wainwright, your Director of Scheduling, which said that you did not have time to meet with me. I did not ask for a face-to-face meeting. I asked for a telephone call conversation. All I wanted was 10 minutes of your time to discuss options and ideas relating to our inability to purchase flood insurance this year. There are thousands of homeowners here in the CBRA zone-restricted Destin area who have suddenly become totally vulnerable -- and virtually stranded -- due to an unfortunate series of unforeseen circumstances, and unanticipated regulatory consequences.

A citizen's group has been formed recently in our community. We have our second meeting scheduled on September 13th at 11 a.m. at the Destin Chamber of Commerce. We have been told that representatives from both Senator Nelson's and Congressman Boyd's offices will be present to discuss possible remedies and to help facilitate a scheduled conference call with congressman Boyd's Washington DC office, who as you may know, has proposed federal legislation relative to this issue. Our local newspaper will also have a reporter attending the meeting. Perhaps someone from your office could be present as well. While we may not represent a large voting block, we are counting assistance and the show of concern from all our elected officials.

Please let me know as soon as possible if it would be if a representative from your administration will be able to attend our upcoming meeting. If not, I would ask you again to please reserve a few minutes for a brief telephone conversation with me sometime before September 13th. 

Thank you, in advance, for your personal attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Robert Guidara
Destin, FL
(850) 837-9939

Dear Governor Jeb Bush:

Florida loves you as Governor. There is no doubt in my mind that if you 
weren't prohibited from seeking another term, you would be re-elected. You
