fellow Floridians on your side.

One issue that comes to mind as it regards your status as Governor is you 
have proven yourself to be a tough on crime Governor who doesn't put up with 
no crap. You have shown support for the states use of the death penalty, 
which is good, and you continue to fight to protect the safety of our 
citizens.

With all do respect though, there is one issue that has been bothering me, 
and thats the failure to sign death warrants and announce execution dates 
for certain inmates. You should start by signing Norman Parker's death 
warrant. This man is a three time convicted killer. He is a convicted 
cop-killer as well. he was sentenced to Life in prison for the murder of a 
law enforcement officer in 1967. Mr.Parker escaped from the Florida Dept of 
Corrections in 1978 and murdered Julio Chavez during an illegal drug 
transaction. Just one month later Norman Parker commited another murder in 
Washington D.C in August of 1978. Mr.Bush, this man is extremely dangerous. 
He has escaped custody before, and he is on death row because he committed 
several murders. He's a three time convicted killer. I'm asking you to sign 
this man's death warrant in particular because all of his LEGAL APPEALS are 
now exhausted. You are probably well aware of Florida's appeals system which 
allow inmates to file successive postconviction motions. Right now, Parker 
has an appeal of denial (by the trial court) for DNA testing. Granting DNA 
testing isn't gonna prove a thing to Mr.Parker. There is overwhelming 
evidence of his guilt, and even if this murder would to be out of the 
picture, Parker was convicted of two separate murders, one of which was a 
police officer.

Stop letting justice be delayed Mr.Bush. Sign Mr.Parker's death warrant 
before you leave office.

From:	Chailai Brune <rallaw@verizon.net>
Sent:	Monday, August 28, 2006 2:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re:        Nomination of Judge of Compensation Claims District M-South

I am writing in regard to the position of the Judge of Compensation Claims in District M-South (Fort Myers) which is being vacated by the Honorable Daniel F. Turnbull.  I have practiced in this area for more than 20 years and am concerned with the apparent consideration being given to Kathy Sturgis for this position.  I have been familiar with Ms. Sturgis in the position of Mediator in District M-South since she assumed the position and do not believe that she represents the best candidate for this position.

 

Without going into substantial detail, I have found Ms. Sturgis to be only marginally effective as a mediator.  I know from extensive conversation with most of the bar practicing in District M that Ms. Sturgis is not held in any particular regard, but few active practitioners are willing to vocalize this out of concern for retribution in the event Ms. Sturgis ultimately assume the position of JCC.

 

Although I have number of lesser concerns regarding Ms. Sturgis’ qualifications for this position, my primary hesitation involves her lack of experience as a Workers' Compensation practitioner.  Participating in mandatory State Mediations involving Workers' Compensation claims lends virtually no transferrable skills into the position of Judge.  I am aware that there are number of experienced practitioners who are interested in the position of the Judge of Compensation Claims and I feel would be more than qualified to assume this role than Ms. Sturgis.  I would respectfully recommend that these other candidates be given greater consideration due to their documented dedication to this area of practice.  I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss this further with you at your convenience.  

 

Sincerely,

LOVESKY & CLEMENTS, P.A.

 

 Richard A. Lovesky, Esq.

 

RAL/cb

 

From:	Gilbert Perez <Gilbert.Perez@henlaw.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 28, 2006 1:11 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Magistrate Josephine Gagliardi

Dear Governor Bush:
 
Presently you are considering an appointment to the Lee County Court bench to replace Judge Ed Volz who you elevated to the Circuit Court.  I was a prosecutor assigned to Judge Volz's court room from January to December 2002.  I think it will be a challenge to succeed Judge Volz in this position; however, you have an excellent candidate in Magistrate Gagliardi.
 
Over the past year until her appointment as a Magistrate, I litigated opposite Magistrate Gagliardi in a very contested juvenile dependency case.  Despite our clients' extremely opposing positions, Magistrate Gagliardi was always very fair, professional, and treated my clients and I with courtesy and respect.  Although she was a very zealous advocate for her client, Magistrate Gagliardi always maintained excellent temperament and demeanor.
 
Since her appointment, I've appeared before Magistrate Gagliardi in a juvenile court proceeding.  She was extremely prepared for the hearing and very poised.  She treated everyone in the hearing room with dignity.  Magistrate Gagliardi was very careful to ensure all the procedural and statutory requirements were followed and the integrity of the system maintained.
 
I am familiar with Magistrate Gagliardi's work history and her commitment to public service, both the legal community and community at large.  I believe her experience and dedication exemplify her qualifications for this position.
 
In addition to being qualified for County Court Judge, your appointment of Magistrate Gagliardi will contribute to your legacy of ensuring that the bench mirrors the community that it serves.  I appreciate your taking all of these factors into consideration, including public comment when making these very important appointments.
 
Sincerely,



Gilbert Perez
Attorney at Law

Dear Mr. Governor,

 

I just wanted to send a quick introduction.  My name is Chad Pupillo, and I am the Chief Executive Officer for US Biometry Incorporated.  We are a newly formed company that is in the early stages of development.  We formed to develop solutions to the ever increasing issues of personal identification and authentication, security of information that passes between machine and networks, and secure access to, as well as storage of, critical data.  As technology rapidly becomes more advanced, particularly in the areas of wireless machine to network, the threat to a person or company’s most prized possession – information – becomes a critical concern.

 

Our long-term focus is to use this technology as the foundation for development of more advanced offerings, specific to how people interact universally to all technology that surrounds them.  For example, a user that possesses a core universal identification and security solution could streamline their interactions between mobile smartphones, intelligent display systems, and advanced information networks, in a safe and effective manner.

 

I wanted to express my thanks to you for the hard work that you have invested in the Florida economy.  When my colleagues and I were in the selection phase for the location of our corporate headquarters, we began to realize that the Tampa area would be a great fit.  Technologically, it has a robust support structure with both the Tampa Bay Technology Forum as well as the Technology Corridor.  We are delighted with our progress, particularly due to the assistance of various Florida-based organizations.

 

In closing, I would be very interested in any advice you may be able to provide to us regarding venture capital relationships we may be able to leverage.  I am building as fast as possible a list of candidates that I would like to partner with, and in particular, Florida-based relationships willing to reinvest in the continued development of its economy.  I thank you in advance for any assistance that you may be able to provide to us, and for your support.

From:	Dianne Mentzer <mentzermd@swfla.rr.com>
Sent:	Sunday, August 27, 2006 3:25 PM
To:	AskDOJ@usdoj.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; tampa.division@ic.fbi.gov
Subject:	USDOJ Comments

To Whom It May Concern -
 It is my understanding that the FBI and the Justice Department are 
aware of certain practices by the City Council of Cape Coral, Florida 
concerning the Utilities Expansion and the City's audit.  We recently 
received  a Notice of Availablility with yet more charges that we, as 
homeowners, are to pay to the City of Cape Coral for  the Capital 
Expansion Fees. 
It states that just for us to have sewer connection, the fee is 
$1738.00, a security deposit with varying rates for $100.00, water meter 
installation for $310.00, septic abandonment (county inspection fees) 
for $40.00, a lien fee per lien if Capital Expansion Fees are financed - 
$10.000 PLUS obtaining permits for : Sewer Connection, Water Connection, 
Septic Abandonment and Irrigation connection.
Now, on top of the $11,000.00+ that we have to pay for the sewer(with 
part of the monies going for road repairs(thought that was in our 
taxes), we have these fees which will probably be $3,000.00 more.  Of 
course the City offered, just for this latest bunch of charges, a 6 year 
loan, after a down payment of 15%, with an interest rate equal to Prime 
Rate plus 2%.  If we, as homeowners, finance, the the property owner is 
*_required _*to sign a  _*voluntary  *_lien form, being again charged 
for  recording the lien and paying to have it notarized. Since when is 
"*_required"  _*a _*voluntary *_action?
After all  of this is done and we have followed every step correctly, 
had all of the necessary inspections paid and done, we, as homeowners, 
have to contact the Lee County Health Department concerning the septic 
tank abandonment .  The septic tank has to be crushed or collapsed and 
then we have to fill this crushed or collapsed tank with clean material, 
grade and stake the area and call for another inspection.  Answer me 
this, - how do you fill a crushed septic tank with clean material when 
it is CRUSHED???????????
I certainly pray that the Justice Department and FBI are investigating 
this matter thoroughly because the City of Cape Coral is causing a 
tremendous amount of uproar and discontent among it's citizens.  There 
are a lot of people moving out of Cape Coral because they can no longer 
afford to live here.  There are families here that have lived here for 
40 years plus and are sickened by the corruption and illegal practices .

Sincerely,

Martha D. Mentzer
130 SE 2nd Place
Cape Coral, FL  33990

if we continue to make the changes forced on us by the peoples from other countries that came to live in America because this is the

I celebrate Christmas, but because 
it isn't celebrated by everyone

"Merry Christmas."

..... It's Winter Break. 
Isn't it amazing how 
this winter break ALWAYS occurs 
over the Christmas holiday?

bent over backwards to not offend 
that now I am being offended.

This says it all! 
 
This is an editorial 
written by an American citizen, published in a Tampa newspaper. 
 
He did quite a job; didn't he? 
Read on, please!

IMMIGRANTS, NOT AMERICANS, 
MUST ADAPT.
 
I am tired of this nation worrying
about whether we are offending 
some individuals or their culture. 
 
Since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, we have experienced 
a surge in patriotism 
by the majority of Americans. 
 
However, the dust from the attacks had barely settled 
when the "politically correct" 
crowd began complaining
about the possibility that our patriotism was offending others.

I am not against immigration, 
nor do I hold a grudge against anyone who is seeking a better life 
by coming to America. 
 
Our population is almost entirely made up of descendants of immigrants. 
 
However, there are a few things that those who have recently come to our country, and apparently some born here, need to understand. 
 
This idea of America being a multi cultural community 
has served only to dilute our sovereignty and our national identity. 
 
As Americans, we have 
our own culture, 
our own society, 
our own language 
and our own lifestyle. 
 
This culture has been developed over centuries of struggles, trials,
and victories 
by millions of men and women 
who have sought freedom.

We speak ENGLISH ..... 
not Spanish, Portuguese, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese,
Russian, or any other language. 
 
Therefore, if you wish 
to become part of our society, 
then learn the language!

"In God We Trust" 
is our national motto. 
This is not just some Christian,
Right wing, political slogan. 
 
We adopted this motto because Christian men and women
..... on Christian principles ..... 
Founded this nation ..... 
And this is clearly documented. 
It is certainly appropriate to display it on the walls of our schools. 
 
If God offends you, then I suggest you consider another part of the world 
as your new home .....
because God is part of our culture.

If Stars and Stripes offend you, 
or you don't like Uncle Sam, 
then you should seriously consider a move to another part of this planet. 
 
We are happy with our culture 
and have no desire to change, 
and we really don't care how you did things where you came from. 
This is OUR COUNTRY, 
our land, and our lifestyle. 
 
Our First Amendment gives every citizen the right to express his opinion and we will allow you every opportunity to do so! 
 
But once you are done Complaining, Whining, and Griping 
About our flag...... 
Our pledge ..... 
Our national motto ....
or our way of life .
 
I highly encourage you 
to take advantage of one other 
Great American Freedom .....

THE RIGHT TO LEAVE.

It is Time for America to Speak up 
 
If you agree -- pass this along; 
 
if you don't agree -- delete it!

Good evening Governor Bush.
Samuel Wickham Ferguson was born at Healthpark Hospital in Fort Myers on

Since then I have found myself learning an immense amount. A nursing

SW FL PODS Angels for support & guidance. I have become an advocate for
Downs Syndrome for my son Samuel.

have attached a file on our walk & sponsorship. I am hoping perhaps you can
join my family as well as so many others' on the morning of October 14,

I have the priviledge of knowing him as a person.  A man of honor and integrity beyond question.   A devoted family man who has always been there for them and has always been a very involved leader in his church and community.  Some may know him only as Assistant State Attorney and any one who does can tell you that he is fully committed to that job as well.  His track record and knowledge of the law speaks for itself and his tenacity and puposeful attitude prove that he knows how to get the job done.  His job as you know is to prosecute those who have broken the law.  I don't have to tell you that when you are surrounded by that element of society day in and day out, you are bound to loose some of the joy of life.  It doesn't mean that you become unreasonable and hardheaded,  it means that you take your decision making very seriously.  This is what he does.
Please let him show the people of Florida that a determined lifelong Florida resident can dream and live the dream.
 
My best wishes to you
and thank you for you time.
Thomas Bowers

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Governor Jeb Bush 
Sent: Saturday, August 26, 2006 2:35 PM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 25, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


BURNHAM INSTITUTE WELCOMED TO FLORIDA

On Wednesday, officials from the Burnham Institute for Medical Research of
La Jolla, California, members of the Florida Legislature and representatives
from Florida's state universities joined me to announce Florida's selection
as the site for its East Coast expansion.  Burnham specializes in pure
scientific research, translating discoveries into innovative treatments and
therapies.  In its startup phase, the Burnham Institute will operate a
campus-style research park in the City of Orlando and plans to create 300
jobs. Burnham and its state of the art research facilities will have a
significant impact on the local economy, and the state's overall life
sciences sector.  For more information on our economic development
initiatives, please visit www.myflorida.com.


$33.4 MILLION IN SUCCEED, FLORIDA! GRANTS AWARDED

Also on Wednesday, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings and Education Commissioner
John L. Winn announced the recipients of $33.4 million in 2006-2007 SUCCEED,
Florida! Career Education Grants.  Through this funding provided by the
Florida Legislature, the Florida Department of Education (DOE) will award 87
new competitive grants to support new and expanding programs in areas
designated by Enterprise Florida and Workforce Florida as targeted sectors
for statewide economic development.  The funding will also support the
addition of 102 career academies. For more information on the grants, please
visit http://www.firn.edu/doe/workforce/pdf/succeed_summary.pdf.


"FORTIFY FLORIDA!" BRINGS PREPAREDNESS HOME TO TAMPA BAY

On Thursday, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings, Chief Financial Officer Tom
Gallagher, Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty and St. Petersburg Mayor
Rick Baker announced Fortify Florida: Tampa Bay Prepares!, the first in a
series of town fairs around the state to provide homeowners with a
one-stop-shop of information about hardening their homes against hurricanes
and reducing their insurance premium.  For information on creating a Family
Disaster Preparedness Plan, please visit www.floridadisaster.org. 


MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS ATTEMPT TO BREAK WORLD RECORD

On Friday, I announced more than 214,600 middle school students in Florida
will attempt to break the Guinness World Record(TM) in reading for the "Most
People Reading Aloud Simultaneously in Multiple Locations".  According to
Guinness World Records(TM), the record is 155,528.  On Thursday, September
28, between 11 & 11:30 a.m. EST, middle school students will attempt to
break that record via a live public broadcast and Webcast from Disney-MGM
Studios.  During the program, I will lead a statewide read aloud using an
excerpt from the book "Peter and the Starcatchers" written by Dave Barry and
Ridley Pearson who both joined me on Friday to announce the event.  To learn
more about the Breaking a World Record: Read Aloud! or register for it,
visit www.JustReadFlorida.com. 


HIGH PERFORMING SCHOOLS REWARDED WITH $157.6 MILLION

Also on Friday, I announced $157.6 million in funding to 1,799 Florida
schools in recognition of academic achievement and improvement during the
2005-2006 school year - more than five times the number of schools and
funding first rewarded in 1999.  Since 1999, Florida has awarded more
than$852.7 million in school recognition funding.  I marked the announcement
by presenting checks to Webb Middle School in Tampa and Sadler Elementary in
Orlando.  Both schools received recognition funds for academic success.  To
view a list of schools receiving recognition funding and amounts visit
www.firn.edu/doe/evaluation/schrmain.htm. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO THOMAS COONEY

I recognized Thomas Cooney of Palm Harbor as this week's Points of Light
Award recipient. As a volunteer at Osceola Middle School, Thomas teaches
sign language to students in the school chorus. He has shared his passion
for sign language and music with more than 2,000 students during his 16
years as a volunteer.  For more information, or to nominate, go to
www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8128


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
       
____________________________________________________________________
Volume 8, Issue 34
Copyright(c) 2006 State of Florida
 
If you would like to change your subscription or unsubscribe, please go to:
http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html


Thank you.

August 26, 2006

 

Larry Kellogg of Tew Cardenas writes The Bar the following, while complaining of Jack Thompson’s hurtful words:  

“With the possible exception of Ray Reiser, I would wager that most every lawyer who has encountered Jack Thompson has considered filing a Bar Complaint or defamation action against him….If all Florida lawyers begin acting like Thompson – with the Bar’s tacit blessing – then our profession is in serious trouble.” 

 

Ms. Sheila Tuma

The Florida Bar
1200 Edgewater Dr.
Orlando, Florida 32804-6314 Via Fax to 407-841-5403, e-mail, and US Mail 

 

Re:  Further Response to Larry Kellogg’s August 11, 2006, Filing with The Bar Re 2006-71,140 

 

Dear Ms. Tuma:

 

This week I was in trial in the Miami-Dade Courthouse.  I was able to concentrate on the task at hand because a) I was not engaged in an adulterous affair with a client, unlike some lawyers, b) I was not contacting law enforcement officials to get them to drop investigations of me and my firm, unlike some other lawyers, and c) I was not busily facilitating the distribution of pornography to children, unlike some other lawyers.

 

In light of Mr. Kellogg’s above words to The Florida Bar about what “most every lawyer” thinks of me, which are found in a letter in which he claims my words are spiteful, I thought I would share with him but more importantly with you and others, the following emailed comments from the folks I represented in Court this week:

 

----- Original Message ----- 

From: Gregg Lu… 

To: 'Jack Thompson' 

Cc: J.C. Lu… 

Sent: Wednesday, August 23, 2006 10:06 PM

Subject: Thanks

 

Jack:

Words can not express how much we appreciate all you did for us.  Thank You!  You always had the right thing to say at the right time.  Your guiding advice will long be remembered and always thought of as genuine, sincere and caring.  Thank you my friend.

May God continue to watch over you and your family, now and always.

Gregg

 

----- Original Message ----- 

 

From: J.C. Lu… 

To: 'Jack Thompson' ; 'Gregg Lu… 

Sent: Thursday, August 24, 2006 11:34 AM

Subject: RE: Thanks

 

Jack, 

 

I also wanted to express my gratitude to you as well.  As I briefly stated in the car on the way home from the courthouse, I wish I would have been more myself this week.  I am afraid I did not make a very good first impression with all of this on my mind.  I was distracted to say the least.  You however, made a wonderful impression not only on me, but on my family as well.  We were grateful that you were there in so many different ways.  Thank you for everything that you did.  Although Im sure that you would say you didn’t do anything, you did more that you think, and we all appreciate it.  Hopefully our paths will cross in the again in the future.  

 

Thanks again, 

 

JC

 

In 1992, the American Civil Liberties Union named me and my client, Lt. Col. Oliver North, its two “Censors of the Year.”   This is an organization that officially holds that the possession of child pornography is protected by the First Amendment.  The ACLU would appreciate Beasley Broadcast Group’s and its lawyers’ view that pornography should be distributed to children as well.

 

Mr. Kellogg is right—there are certain lawyers who do not care for me, in addition to the scofflawyers at Tew Cardenas who are in a state of panic now because of me.  These opponents tend to be moral midgets when it comes to protecting children, and I understand where they are coming from.  I also know where they are going.

 

On the other hand, I have clients, as indicated by the above, who appreciate me as a lawyer.  I also got a standing ovation at Miami-Dade Community College fairly recently when I was introduced as “the local attorney who got Howard Stern off the air.”  The class was filled with African American women.  They get it.  Lawyers at Tew Cardenas, Blank Rome, and Leventhal, Senter & Lerman don’t get what is offensive about the following aired comment, that was aired by Stern on Beasley’s station in Ft. Myers:

 

“Ever bang any famous nigger chicks?  What do they smell like?  Watermelons?”

 

Here’s a suggestion for Mr. Kellogg:  Tell your wife and your children about the above quotation and ask them if they think that it should be aired on the public airwaves to children.  Then ask them what they think of someone who got that hurtful garbage off the air.  My guess is that they would think that person did a good thing.  If not, then your kids have a future at Tew Cardenas. 

 

Mr. Kellogg, I may have a number of lawyers who don’t care for me, and I’m proud of that, because, Mr. Kellogg, you’re one of them, and your campaign to destroy me tells me I’ve been on the right track for quite sometime.

 

I count your and your unethical firm’s and the ACLU’s hate for me a badge of honor.

 

With enemies like you, I can sleep at night.  The friends I have, who are more than you know, are more than sufficient for me until I get to go home and meet Him for eternity.

 

In Christ, Jack Thompson

Dear Gov. Bush:

This letter is to reiterate our need for support in
carrying out this noble venture. The Karma Korner
(karmakorner.com) has agreed to allow us to use their
venue. Perhaps some sponsorship could be sent their
way. We also seek sponsorship in the following areas:
an all-inclusive travel package for our largely
nationally based audience.  This includes housing/
hotels, ground transportation, catering and also other
intrepid sponsors. 

Dear Governor, this will be an event of national and
international coverage. 

The theme brings to focus the contemporary strife of
our Prisoner of War and those Missing in Action. We
also have international acts from The UK headlining.
Wouldn't it be grand for our President and Mr Blair of
Britain to know that the 18-40 year old American
demographic understands current political issues?

From:	mboening@tds.net
Sent:	Friday, August 25, 2006 5:58 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	"Medical Research" facility

August 25, 2006

Dear Governor Bush,
This letter is in regard to Burnham Institute for Medical Research building “research” and “treatment centers” in Orlando.  I am hoping that you did your homework to ensure that this “medical research” company does not test on animals.  Animal experimentation is an inherently violent and unethical practice that I do not feel anyone’s tax dollars should support.  Funding for research into health and ecological effects should be redirected into the use of epidemiological, clinical, in vitro and computer modeling studies instead of laboratory experiments on animals.  
Not only is using animals for research an inhumane practice, but studies have also shown that research carried out for “medical purposes” tends to be irrelevant to human health.  In addition, diseases that are induced in laboratory animals are NEVER identical to those that occur naturally in human beings.  Finally, the fact that the species most often used in laboratory experiments are chosen largely for non-scientific reasons, such as cost and ease of handling, casts further doubt on the validity of this research.  
Every creature, great and small, has a right to a peaceful life.
Sincerely,
Michelle Boening

From:	Jose Morin <morinjo@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Friday, August 25, 2006 4:07 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Insurance Crisis

Dear Governor Bush:
 
         The time has come to act on solutions to the currrent insurance crisis in the state. If it takes to call a special session of the Legislature, please do it now. Every day that goes by the insurance industry is getting away with astronomical increases in the premiums, or simply allowed to stop underwriting homeowners or commercial policies for windstorm damage while allowing to continue to to do business in more lucrative type of policies. It is cherry picking and it is not right !
 
           I have been a resident and homeowner in the South Florida area for the last 40 some years, and recently retired  from the military after a tour of duty in Iraq, and many years of proud service as one of your subordinates in the Florida National Guard.  The rate increases over the last two years have more than double my payments and I have already been informed by my current carrier (Balboa Insurance from California) that my policy will not be renewed as of next year. 
 
        As a senior citizen , with a fixed income and still having to make mortgage payments it is coming to the point that I will have to decide whether I can put food in the table , or try to sell the house and move out of Florida, or find a job so I can pay for the outrageous rates. 
 
        Please, do something now ! Call the Legislature to session and keep them there until they come out with a logical and equitable solution to this crisis.
 
Respectfully,
 
Jose O. Morin
4250 SW 134th Avenue
Miami, FL. 33175

Sent:	Friday, August 25, 2006 10:50 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Interview request for magazine Florida Gun News

Dear Gov. Bush:
 
Please allow me to introduce myself, my name is Daniel Gemal and I am the Managing Editor of Florida Gun News. We are a rapidly growing magazine with distribution throughout Central and Northern Florida. We have a monthly distribution of 10,000 copies distributed through gun dealers, shooting ranges, gun shows, pawn shops, sporting goods stores and other gun friendly businesses. We write reviews of products, comment on the current political issues that are gun related and publish other general information of interest to shooters in Florida. Our mission statement is as follows: Florida Gun News is published to support, promote and educate on responsible and ethical gun ownership, whether it be for defensive, competition or hunting purposes. 
 
For our September issue (available to readers on August 15th) I conducted an interview with Wayne LaPierre, the Executive Vice President of the NRA and I have already received numerous comments from our readers about how they would like to see more interviews with the people who are instrumental in preserving our Second Amendment rights.
 
For our November Issue (available in our distribution outlets October 15th), we are doing an election special. We have sent surveys to each of the candidates standing for seats in the upcoming elections asking their stance on gun related issues. The results of those surveys will be published in that issue. It would also be an honor to include an interview with you to discuss the way that you have worked tirelessly (and continue to work) to preserve our Second Amendment rights and our rich hunting heritage during your tenure as Governor of Florida.
 
I would make myself available at your convenience to conduct the interview and would send an advance copy of my questions to your office.
 
Thank you for your time reading this email. I look forward to hearing from you soon to schedule a date and time for the interview.
 
 
Daniel Gemal
Managing Editor
Florida Gun News

Cell: 727-366-7529

We would like invite you to “Talas and Rasas” dance performance by the Navarasa group to be held at 6:30 PM on September 23rd, 2006 at Freedom High School in New Tampa. From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Thursday, August 24, 2006 2:32 PM
To: Executive_Office
Subject: FW: Defense Infrastructure Grant (DIG) Program

 

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Wadel, Jmichael CIV NAS Jacksonville [mailto:jmichael.wadel@navy.mil]
Sent: Thursday, August 24, 2006 2:27 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Kaylee LaRocque; Travis Zwenger; Gartland, Kevin CIV NAS Jacksonville 064
Subject: Defense Infrastructure Grant (DIG) Program

Governor-- 

My organization recently applied for the 2006-2007 DIG Program in order to obtain design funds for our proposed wastewater reuse facility (WWRF).  Using these funds will allow us to design a project that will result in "zero discharge" from our wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) to the Lower St. Johns River (LSJR).

Right now our WWTP discharges 1.2 MGD to the LSJR.  Just think, John Ellis, that would equate to 29,201 pounds of nitrogen removed from the LSJR  Basin per year, a giant step in meeting the nutrient Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) recently established by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP), the St. Johns River Water Management District (SJRWMD), and the EPA.

Jeb, we want to uphold our end and be a part of Jacksonville Mayor John Peyton's new plan, "The River Accord: A Partnership for the St. Johns River"; but to do that we need that money.  It will be a great day for the St. Johns River when on a calm day, not a single part of the river's surface offers the boiling proof of why the river turns green.  Now, doesn't just thinking about that bring tears to your eyes?

I am hoping you will announce our award at your earliest convenience. 

Sincerely, 

J. Michael Wadel, P.E. 
NAS Jax Water Program Manager 
904-542-4220

From:	Lynn Stoeckel <Write4u2@mchsi.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 23, 2006 10:19 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Invitation from Dean Cannon and Bill Sublette

 
 
 
Florida House of Representatives
Representative Dean Cannon
District 35
 
 
Dear Lieutenant Governor Jennings:
 
Bill and I invite you to again join us and Host Ed Timberlake, President – Central Florida, Bank of America, in the tradition of hosting Frontline Outreach’s 12th Annual Benefit Luncheon for Children: The Power of Friendship.
 
As in the past, there are no tickets to sell. But by lending your name to the luncheon, and with just 60 minutes of your time on Friday, October 6, 2006, at 3000 C.R. Smith Street, we can once again impact significantly the urban kids of our community. Your arrival at 11:30 is requested for the noon meal.
 
Each year, the luncheon receives strong attendance by fellow legislators who serve the one-hour meal in 30 minute shifts. Last year we served nearly 400 community leaders. The result was $183,000 raised for Frontline scholarships and facility renovations. This is 20 percent of Frontline’s annual budget.
 
For over four decades, Frontline has been serving our city’s kids with unparalleled performance. Their educational, leadership, character and family development programs are changing lives in urban Orlando. We commend them in their mission to prepare tomorrow’s leaders with a vision for success and service.
 
Each year, Frontline’s partners enable the faith-based organization to serve almost 1,000 children and their families. Their results have earned them Bank of America’s 2005 Neighborhood Builder Award and the 2004 Walt Disney World DisneyHand Helping Children to Shine Award. Frontline has also been designated a “Point of Light” by the first President George Bush and a 2005 Governor’s Point of Light.
 
We look forward to seeing you on October 6 as we support our city’s children and our city’s future. Register NOW at www.fl-o.org (look for the Legislator’s Link). Or call 407-293-3000, ext 202, or reply by email at giving@fl-o.org.
 
 
Respectfully,
 
      Dean                                                                                                             Bill
Dean Cannon/Event Chair                                                                                                                                           Bill Sublette/Founding Chair

From:	EmilyRubot@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, August 23, 2006 8:12 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Don Rubottom's 50th Birthday

Dear Governor Bush,
 
Greetings!  My name is Emily Rubottom and I am the daughter of Don Rubottom, who works for the Florida House of Representatives.  My father is turning 50 on Thursday, September 7.  It is very difficult to buy gifts for my dad, because he is so very content with what he has.  He is not caught up with worldly possessions and his biggest hobby is spending time with us, his family.  When I asked my dad what he wanted for his 50th birthday, he said (very seriously), "I want the President of the United States to call me and wish me a happy birthday."  Well, I know from the White House web page that the White House doesn't send birthday greetings except for 80th-plus birthdays, but his comment gave me another idea.
 
May I be so bold, sir, as to ask you to call my dad and wish him a happy 50th birthday?  Dad has a great deal of respect for you, and our family has felt incredibly blessed to live in Florida for the past 9 1/2 years.  We are already grieving for what we feel will be a great loss when you leave office.
 
So, Mr. Governor, I know my dad would be extremely honored to receive birthday wishes from a man he respects so very much.  If you are able to do this, his office phone number at the Capitol is (850) 922-7076.
 
Thank you very much,
Emily Rubottom

From:	Philip Amorgianos <pamorgianos@gatewaycommunity.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 23, 2006 6:30 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Donna Mellion
Subject:	Please help us!!!

The Honorable Jeb Bush 

Governor, the State of Florida

August 23, 2006

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

We need your help!!!

Jacksonville, Florida has a problem. As you know, addiction touches all of us. Jacksonville is no exception.  Of high profile felony crimes in our city, nearly half are accounted for as drug crimes. In fact, not only does drug crime top the list in both number of charges filed and number of inmates admitted to our jail, drug-related crimes outnumber the next top three categories of criminal offenses combined. This year alone, 2,884 of the 4,593 those jailed on high-profile felony charges were charged with one or more drug related crimes.

 

We are Gateway Community Services, the largest not-for-profit substance addiction prevention and treatment agency on Florida’s First Coast. On Tuesday November 14, 2006 we will present our annual Community Champions’ Awards to community leaders who have supported our efforts and those of others who strive to build a better community. 

 

In addition to other local business leaders, this year’s recipients include Delores Barr-Weaver. Mrs. Weaver is a prominent in our community for two reasons. First, she and her husband Wayne own the NFL Jacksonville Jaguars and have the public’s recognition. Second, because she is a community leader who, in addition to supporting several other worthy causes in the community, has donated generously to champion our mission over the years through both the Jaguar foundation and the Weaver Family Foundation.

 

This event is our major fundraiser with proceeds going to build more residential facilities so we can help more people. We would be honored if you would join us as our keynote speaker and help us present our awards.

 

Our Awards Banquet will be:                                      The schedule of events will be:

 

Tuesday November 14, 2006

At Alltel Stadium

One Stadium Place

Jacksonville, Florida 32202

Socializing: 5:30 p.m. -- 6:30 p.m.

Dinner: 6:30 p.m. -- 7:15 p.m.

Program: 715: p.m. – 8:10 p.m.

Auction 8:10 p.m. – 8:50 p.m.  

 

Please let us know as soon as possible if you can make it. We would be happy to help your team set up media interviews, etc.

 

Sincerely,

 

Donna Mellion

Director, Corporate Communications

Gateway Community Services, Inc.

904-387-4661 ext 152

Dear Jan Bergemann,
 
      A big round of applause to Jan Bergemann! All of the CCFJ members should be very proud of the effort by Jan Bergemann. Mr. Bergemann has delivered on his promise to bring the DBPR directly to the condominium owners. Throughout the past couple of months the DBPR has scheduled meetings throughout the state of Florida to keep condo owners aware of legislation that impacts you as a condominium owner. The DBPR has also answered many questions from condo owners during these meetings. If you missed a previous meeting you should definitely not miss a future one.
     Thank you Jerry Melvin for our input during the August 22, 2006 meeting that was held in Destin Florida. Mr. Melvin is a former State Representative that continues to serve Floridians in their quest for balance and fair play between condo owners and condominium boards. His work is deeply appreciated!

From:	GiGiOf6@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, August 23, 2006 9:41 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please respond

Was researching my choices in this latest election and came across this about Judge Greer.  I'm wondering why nothing was done?
 
Simmons had told a group who met with him in late March that he would consider starting an impeachment investigation concerning Greer.

In her letter of April 20, Hennessy said that "In his adjudication of the guardianship case of Terri Schiavo (File 90-2908), Judge Greer has entered what I believe to be illegal orders, which, if proven, would be grounds to conclude he has committed a "misdemeanor in office," as that term is used in Article III, Section 17 of Florida's Constitution.

"As a result of his rulings, Ms. Schiavo is now deceased and irreversible damage has been caused by his disregard of Florida's Statutes as they relate to the rights of incapacitated persons and abuse, neglect and exploitation of vulnerable adults."

Hennessey itemized what she says are only two of the many violations of law in which Greer engaged.

"On March 8, 2005, Judge Greer entered an order stating that Terri Schiavo could not receive food and water by mouth after her gastronomy feeding tube had been removed. This order cannot be reconciled with Florida Statute 825.102 (Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of Elderly Persons and Disabled Adults), which defines the prohibited conduct:

(b) An intentional act that could reasonably be expected to result in physical or psychological injury to an elderly person or disabled adult; or

(c) Active encouragement of any person to commit an act that results or could reasonably be expected to result in physical or psychological injury to an elderly person or disabled adult.

"A caregiver's failure or omission to provide an elderly person or disabled adult with the care, supervision, and services necessary to maintain the elderly person's or disabled adult's physical and mental health, including, but not limited to, food, nutrition, clothing, shelter, supervision, medicine, and medical services that a prudent person would consider essential for the well-being of the elderly person or disabled adult; . . ."

"Judge Greer's order requires the commission of a felony - the withholding of oral sustenance and hydration from a disabled adult - something for which no judge at any level has jurisdiction to order and in complete disregard for his sworn duty to uphold the laws of the State of Florida", Hennessy says. "This feature of his ruling should be distinguished from his tube-removal order, an act over which he did have jurisdiction."

"The international scorn already heaped upon and to be heaped upon the United States in general and Florida in particular is directly traceable to this unnecessarily cruel and unlawful order.

"On March 23, 2005, Greer entered an Emergency Order Enforcing Mandate in which he ordered that the Department of Children and Families was restrained from carrying out a protective investigation into allegations of abuse, neglect and exploitation of Terri Schiavo, pursuant to their statutorily mandated duties under Florida Statute Section 415.1051 (Adult Protective Services) which states, in part:

(b) Emergency removal from premises.--If it appears that the vulnerable adult lacks the capacity to consent to emergency protective services and that the vulnerable adult, from the personal observations of the representative of the department and specified medical personnel or law enforcement officers, is likely to incur a risk of death or serious physical injury if such person is not immediately removed from the premises, then the representative of the department shall transport or arrange for the transportation of the vulnerable adult to an appropriate medical or protective services facility in order to provide emergency protective services. Law enforcement personnel have a duty to transport when medical transportation is not available or needed and the vulnerable adult presents a threat of injury to self or others. If the vulnerable adult's caregiver or guardian is present, the protective investigator must seek the caregiver's or guardian's consent pursuant to subsection (4) before the vulnerable adult may be removed from the premises, unless the protective investigator suspects that the vulnerable adult's caregiver or guardian has caused the abuse, neglect, or exploitation.

(c) Emergency medical treatment.--If, upon admission to a medical facility, it is the opinion of the medical staff that immediate medical treatment is necessary to prevent serious physical injury or death, and that such treatment does not violate a known health care advance directive prepared by the vulnerable adult, the medical facility may proceed with treatment to the vulnerable adult."

"Judge Greer's injunction of DCF from performing its statutorily-mandated duties vividly demonstrates his lack of understanding of the separation of powers between the three branches of government. Instead of accommodating DCF's decision to exercise its authority under the above-cited statute, Judge Greer determined that decision to be offensive to him personally and to the judicial function in general."

"On March 23, 2005, in the order cited above, Judge Greer also ordered that "each and every singular Sheriff of the State of Florida are hereby directed to take such actions or action as is necessary to enforce the provisions hereof."

"In this order, Judge Greer overstepped his own authority under Florida's Constitution and usurped the power of the Executive Branch and Florida's Governor who is Florida's Chief Law Enforcement Officer. Article 4, Section 1 of Florida's Constitution states, in part:

(a) The supreme executive power shall be vested in a governor, who shall be commander-in-chief of all military forces of the state not in active service of the United States. The governor shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed, commission all officers of the state and counties, and transact all necessary business with the officers of government.

"Judge George Greer has disregarded Florida's laws and the other branches of government in his rulings in the Schiavo case. I realize there may be some political distaste in pursuing this matter, but unless this judge is reined in, you will see this conduct occur again and again. The instances cited above are so flagrant as to require the House's serious consideration of articles of impeachment."

"I have numerous other records, orders and petitions from the Schiavo guardianship case and will happily get them to you in any form you require. It is imperative that you set to work on this immediately. Not only are Judge Greer's rulings not in keeping with the intent of your laws, they are flagrantly unlawful", Hennessy told Bense and the other officials.

At the time Simmons met with constituents in late March about an impeachment investigation of Greer, he told them he had received numerous emails and letters asking for an investigation of the judge. An Internet petition calling for Greer's impeachment has over 41,000 electronic signatures.

Article 3, Section 17 of the Florida Constitution says circuit court judges "shall be liable to impeachment for misdemeanor in office. Impeachment requires a two-thirds vote by the House and then a two-thirds vote by the Florida Senate to convict him, with the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court presiding over the Senate trial.

Simmons, said "we will look at it and analyze it" but said he wasn't committing to do anything other than review what any constituent tells me as a representative and as chairman of the Judiciary Committee to look at".

There are two ways for a Florida public officer, including a circuit court judge, to be removed from office----impeachment or executive order of Gov. Bush. Florida Constitution, Article III, Section 17 provides for the impeachment of judges among other public officers, for misdemeanor in office, misdemeanor being defined as a misdeed or offense less than a felony.

With public record supporting the allegation that Greer has not legally qualified for judicial office and allegedly violated election laws resulting in him vacating the office pursuant to Section 114.01, Gov. Bush is required pursuant to Section 114.01(2) to file an executive order with the Secretary of State setting forth the facts which give rise to the vacancy, setting forth the facts which give rise to the vacancy, and he must include in the order the title of the office, the name of the incumbent officer or person who held the office, and the date on which the vacancy in office occurred.

In the case of Greer, pursuant to the laws of the state he is supposed to be upholding, following the rule of law, by failing to qualify for office, he legally failed to obtain access to the ballot and was not legally elected, therefore never acquired legal title to the office. The vacancy would have initially occurred in January, 1998, and would have allegedly prohibited him for seeking "reelection" to a post he had not legally held initially.

Pursuant to Section 114.01, the office shall be considered vacant as of the date specified in the executive order, or in absence of such a date, as of the date the executive order is filed with the Secretary of State. jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Persons wishing to ask Gov. Bush why he has not issued an Executive Order removing Greer from the bench or why minimally he hasn't launched an investigation into Greer's filings for the ballot and alleged misconduct involving his political commercials may contact the Governor at jeb.bush@myflorida.com or his general counsel, Rachel Rodriguez at rachael.rodriguez@myflorida.com. June Maxam 1-16-06 

© 2005 North Country Gazette

Pat G., Naples, FL

RE: HAROLD S. ESKIN’S NOMINATION FOR COUNTY JUDGE

 

DEAR GOVERNOR BUSH:

 

It is with great pleasure that I have the opportunity to write on behalf of Harold S. Eskin who has been selected by the 20th Judicial Circuit Judicial Nomination Committee to fill the recently vacated Lee County Judgeship.

 

I am a physician and, in addition to a busy clinical orthopaedic practice, I serve on several committees and boards of several state and national surgical specialty organizations

 

I have known Mr. Eskin for eight years and have had the opportunity to get to know Mr. Eskin in both his personal and/or professional capacity.  Professionally I have found Mr. Eskin to be honest, sincere, and of the highest ethical standards.

 

Personally, I have observed Mr. Eskin in various circumstances and found that he is a dedicated family man and a genuine person who is nice to be around. Additionally he has been involved in various civic and charitable activities, including being active in our synagogue, Temple Beth El.

 

What has struck me about Mr. Eskin is his ability to be fair-minded and seek knowledge. This was quite apparent when his wife recently required surgery and I observed, firsthand, how Hal gathers and processes information. I understand that this is his rigorous and customary manner in all of his professional, legal, and community activities. It is this quality, among others, that I feel would make him an outstanding judge.

 

For the foregoing reasons, I enthusiastically support Mr. Eskin’s selection for the bench. If you would like any further information, please do not hesitate to contact me directly.

From:	Robin Heath <robinmheath@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 22, 2006 6:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Illegal Aliens

Dear Governor Bush:

I live in the small town of Trenton, Florida but I was born and raised in 
Orlando, Florida.  My mother’s family had a relative we were able to trace 
back to one of the 3 ships that landed at Plymouth, Mass.  My father’s 
parents came here from Scotland in the early 1900’s and my father was a 
first generation American.  As you can see, my families from both sides were 
immigrants.  They were LEGAL immigrants and worked hard to support their 
families and better their ways of life.  They paid taxes and owned land and 
built homes and contributed to the betterment of the U.S. with their blood, 
sweat, tears and even their lives. My father even once said to me that he 
didn’t mind paying taxes to live in our free country.  He was a true 
patriot, having been in the second wave on Normandy on D-day.

As you may guess, I am writing about the mess our country is in with illegal 
immigrants.  They break the law as they take the first step onto our soil. 
Then they continue to do so as they stay on our soil. Yes, they perform work 
that many others will not do. Farm labor is backbreaking and thankless work. 
However, they should not be rewarded for breaking the law to earn dollars 
that are not taxed and much of which is sent to foreign soil to support 
their relatives and their foreign economy.

Children of illegal immigrants who are born here purely by calculation 
should not automatically be granted legal status as American citizens.  
Children who are born to an illegal mother should also be illegal and, 
therefore, not entitled to the Welfare and any other benefits this country 
freely offers. And since there are millions of illegals in this country, 
there are at least millions of “legal” children of illegals.  Those children 
have been afforded the rights of American citizens simply by accident of the 
location of their birth.  Those children will grow up to be voters and will 
eventually turn this country to their way of thinking.  That being that 
there should be no consequences to breaking the law. That we, soft-hearted 
and complacent Americans, should simply ignore their criminality and not 
only overlook their crimes, but also bestow on them all the benefits of 
being American.

You saw the crowds in the streets when the Mexicans and any other group of 
illegals or their legal children freely demonstrated en masse.  Did you also 
see them flying the flags of their countries? Did you also see their 
disrespect of the American flag? They truly feel that this country owes them 
something.  They feel downtrodden as their “legal” children attend and 
overburden our school systems.  They make our schools teach in both English 
and Spanish, further burdening the schools. They fill our hospitals because 
the hospitals will not turn them away when they have no insurance. They form 
gangs.  They steal identities. No, not all.

However, this is an issue that will eventually pervade every state in the 
union, except Alaska and Hawaii.  These people pay no taxes, yet they 
collect benefits from the taxes we Americans pay.  And we pay too much to 
begin with.  The tax rates in the country are ridiculous and much of that 
money is wastefully spent.  This is another issue, but I am also in favor of 
the Fair Tax.

Please...listen to all the voices of those who are too complacent to write 
to you.  There are many millions of us, more than there are of the illegals, 
who are all against amnesty.  Though it seems to be an impossible task, we 
must stop the flow of illegals daily into our state and country and deport 
all of those who can be deported. Please do not back down on this issue.  
Please think of your heritage and your children.  Please think of my 
children and grand-children.

Respectfully,
Robin Heath
Trenton, FL

I will follow up with copies sent via certified US Postal mail to your office. I am again publically calling for intervention and oversight by  your office and the Governor.

I understand that the Commission is limited to the financial disclosure and conflict of interest laws contained in Part III, Chapter 112, Florida Statues, and Article II, Section 8, Florida Constitution, as they apply to individual public officers and employees but, my intention is to create an accountability trail until the constant state agency run around I am getting stops and some one with the proper authority is reached and takes ownership of the situation.

It seems that Bill Eddins, Florida State Attorney / District 1 answers to no one and can apparently do whatever he pleases. Does your office and the Governor himself have no power to become actively involved when the legal rights of a citizen of the State of Florida are so carelessly trampled? 

I would like to hear from you the answer to that question and a clarification on just what the chain of accountability is in state government.

Please carefully review the attached documents, visit the website I have been forced to put up www.billcagle.com read and understand the situation and please direct me to the proper authorities if you are not the authority.

Dear Gov. Bush:
 
You may remember me as a St. Petersburg Times columnist who wrote a piece about you that you thought was too kind-- about speaking Spanish to the public during hurricane preparations in 2004. 
 
Well, I'm back again, now as a freelancer, and trying, like journalists from here to the moon, to write about Katherine Harris. I am not, however, interested in the foot race -- who's up, who's down -- in the polls.
 
I am interested in writing about Harris in a more personal way: it's been suggested to me that she is unable to do the wise thing and drop out...or was unable, because it is certainly too late now -- because she never recovered from the very personal trashing she endured during the 2000 recount. It's as though she has to prove everybody wrong and that if she wins, she will gain back some dignity that she feels she lost.
 
This may strike you as armchair psychology....but I'd love to hear your observations. And if you know of any of Harris' friends who I might talk to, could you pass on the names?
 
I know that given my reputation (which has not faded over the two years I've been gone) as a "liberal" columnist you may have little interest in replying, but I figured, what the heck, and decided to try anyway. 
 
Thank you.

From:	Connie Harris <yellowmoon2@verizon.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 22, 2006 11:16 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Commendation

Dear Sir,

Below is a commendation on two of Florida's police officers.
You can be proud.


To: Governor Jeb Bush 
August 22, 2006





                                                            Commendation



                                                    Re: Deputy Jeff Cuttitta 
and Officer Andrew Gillespie



Last Wednesday night I placed a call to the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office 
to report my 89 year old father missing.  He had been gone since 8:30 AM 
that morning and the search my brother and I did produced nothing.



Deputy Jeff Cuttitta met me at my father's house.  He immediately put out a 
BOLO. After hearing all of the particulars about my father's recent mental 
state and age he made the decision to place a missing/endangered person 
report.

I felt he made a critical decision to place that report and showed 
exceptionally good judgment.  He probably saved my father's life.



Within 10 minutes of the notice going out, I got a call from Orlando City 
police officer, Andrew Gillespie, saying he found my father in the most 
dangerous area of the city, sitting at a stop sign. My father did not know 
how he got there from his home in Palm Harbor.  Once again the quick 
thinking of a police officer kept my father out of harm's way.



Officer Andrew Gillespie took my father to a nearby fire station and got him 
something to eat.  It was now 10:00PM. He stayed with my father, rather than 
abandon him at the police station and ensured he was safe until I could get 
there. I had to drive two hours from Palm Harbor, Fl.



When I arrived at the fire station, my Dad was in remarkably good spirits, 
smiling and talking to Officer Gillespie. Words couldn't describe my relief 
or my gratitude.



These two police men exemplify the motto, "To Protect and Serve."



I am so impressed with their professionalism I wanted to personally let you 
know.



Connie Harris

Palm Harbor, Fl





CC: Pinellas County Sheriff

       Orlando Police Chief

My name is Abby Hunter and i am organizing a HOBY CLEW. HOBY stands for Hugh O'Brian Youth Leadership, and if you like old westerns, Hugh O'Brian played Wyatt Earp in the old western series Wyatt Earp. A CLEW is a Community Leadership Education Workshop which is a one day version of the HOBY weekend that is held in Tallahassee, FL during a weekend in June. 
 
What I am interested in is if you would not mind coming and speaking at the Government panel held at 9 AM on Saturday October 21, 2006. I understand that you are really busy with your position and I understand if you cannot make it. If you are preoccupied on that date, I would really appreciate it if you could give me the information of someone in state government who might be able to attend. 
 
The government panel consists of 3 to 4 local and state government officials who give a 3 to 5 minute speech about their position and what their occupation requires. Once all the panelists have had a chance to speak, there will be an open time for the students to ask questions to the panelists. 
 
If you are interested in this program, please visit www.hoby.org or www.northfloridahoby.org. If you have any further questions for me, you can reach me at 1-850-974-1311 or 1-850-859-2366. I anticipate your response.

From:	Nick Jeffries <jeffries_7500@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 21, 2006 11:43 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Injustice in Florida

Governor Bush
 
 The constant delays in death penalty appeals has got to be put to an immediate stop.Right now, the state of Florida has 376 inmate's on death row, 19 less then Texas's death row population of 395 (TDCJ website says 396 but an inmate was put to death in TX last week). Texas averages about 20 executions per year. Florida, on the other hand, averages 1 to 2 executions a year. I find this absolutely ridiculous. It make's me sick to think that inmate's on death row since the 70's and 80's are still appealing their sentences. The only difference between inmates who have been on death row since the 70's and 80's in Texas (which are very few by the way), is that those inmates were all resentenced. Almost 90 % of the inmates on Texas death row who sit their appealing their sentences from the 70's and 80's have all had their convictions and/or sentences overturned.
 
 I would like to ask that you please stop stalling and please start moving forth with carrying out the punishment handed down by Florida juries. These death row inmate's have had their chances to appeal. The standard three tier appeals process in every death penalty state is as follows:
 
1.)Direct Appeal
2.)State Postconviction Review/State habeas corpus petition
3.)Federal Habeas (Federal District Court/11th Circuit Court of Appeals)
 
 The bottom line is that Florida is letting inmate's stall their executions with meritless successive postconviction motions. The Florida Supreme Court has been too lenient in allowing inmates to file these motions, so it is your duty to see to it that these executions are carried out and death warrants signed whether there is or is not a successive postconviction motion filed. I respect you greatly as our Governor Mr.Bush. I admire you greatly. It is also my understanding that you hold strong support for the death penalty. The only problem is that I don't see you signing death warrants. I ask, on behalf of all Floridians waiting for justice, that you proceed with signing these death warrants for inmates who have lost there final 'LEGAL' appeals in the 11th circuit. After a death row inmate loses an appeal in the 11th circuit, this is supposed to be their last avenue of relief. Here in Florida, I find it pretty disgusting that executions are being held up on useless successive postconviction motions when the inmate knows its going to be denied. It's only to stall executions. It has to stop Governor.
 
 Please, see Justice is Served.
 
N.J

  _____

-------Original Message-------
 
From: Governor Jeb Bush
Date: 08/20/06 07:49:09
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 18, 2006
 
For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
 
http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
 
The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
 
 
FLORIDA STUDENTS INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN FOURTH ANNUAL HISPANIC HERITAGE
MONTH ESSAY CONTEST
 
On Tuesday, First Lady Columba Bush and I invited Florida students in
kindergarten through twelfth grades to participate in the fourth annual
Florida Hispanic Heritage Month essay contest. The essay contest is the
first in a month-long schedule of events planned to commemorate Florida's
Hispanic heritage. The theme of the essay contest is, 'Why is learning about
Florida's Diverse Hispanic Heritage and Culture Important?'
 
Columba and I are proud of the Spanish and Latin-American influences that
contribute to Florida's rich culture and history and play a dynamic role in
shaping our history and future.  Hispanic Heritage month gives us the
opportunity to educate Florida's students on the tremendous contributions
Hispanic individuals make to our state.  We are asking students to pay
special tribute to the Florida's diverse Hispanic population and their
contributions to the state's culture, economy and education. The theme for
Florida's 2006 Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration is 'La Florida: Honoring
Our State's Spanish and Latin American Influences'.  Those interested in
participating in the essay contest or obtaining more information on
additional Hispanic Heritage Month events should visit
www.floridahispanicheritage.com or contact Nadia Hagberg in the Governor's
office at (850) 488-5000 for more information.
 
 
RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDA HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES TOOK THE ACT
 
On Wednesday, Education Commissioner John L. Winn and I announced a record
number of Florida's high school graduates took the American College Test
(ACT).  This year 66,299 of Florida's 2006 high school graduates took the
ACT, up from 58,302 in 2005. Of all high school graduates, 44 percent took
the ACT in Florida compared to 40 percent nationally. The ACT is one of two
college entrance tests Florida students can choose to take. Last year, more
than 93,500 of Florida's 2005 high school graduates took the SAT,
representing 65 percent of the total number of high school graduates.
 
Florida has been extremely successful at increasing the number of students
taking college entrance exams.  We must continue to encourage all of our
high school students to take these exams and prepare for the rigor of
college and the workforce.  Minority students represent 47 percent of the
2006 test takers, compared to 30 percent nationally.  During 2006, African
Americans represented 21 percent of the Florida test takers, compared to
only 13 percent nationwide.  Hispanic students comprised 17 percent of
Florida test takers, compared to only eight percent nationally.  To learn
more about the ACT visit www.fldoe.org.  To learn more about FACTS.org or to
complete an ePEP, visit www.FACTS.org.
 
 
POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO JERMAINE PHILLIPS
 
I recognized Jermaine Phillips, a starting safety for the Tampa Bay
Buccaneers, as this week's Points of Light Award recipient.  Jermaine's
efforts are making a positive difference in the lives of those he visits at
Central Florida hospitals, retirement homes and juvenile justice programs.
Jermaine's commitment to Florida's youth has proven that he is a champion
both on and off the field.  Through his volunteerism and philanthropy, many
young Floridians have a brighter future.  For more information, or to
nominate, go to www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.
 
Congratulations!
 
To read more about this week's winners, please click here:
http://www.flgov.com/release/8082
 
 
GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES
 
Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

From:	Dr. Clifford G. Fleetwood, Ph.D. <drcliffordgfleetwoodphd@lawyer.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 21, 2006 4:55 PM
To:	ask_the_sheriff@sheriff.org; Governor Jeb Bush; campaign@charleycrist.com
Cc:	riograndepublishing@usa.com; archives@scientist.com
Subject:	NOTICE OF LITIGATION TO FILED AGAINST YOU

Good Day Mr. Jeb Bush, and Mr. Charles Crist, etal:
    This notice is to inform you that you will be added to the list of defendants in 
United States District Court case # 05-CIV-61398 ref: Fleetwood Vs. Jenne, etal.
    The plaintiff's will move the court for a civil trial, damages, court costs, and legal
fees. The U.S. Marshal will serve the defendants with the summons to appear, the federal civil
complaint, and the related court documents filed in the office of the clerk of the U.S. District
Court. You must appear on the date that the summons, and the court has ordered.
    You may have your attorney(s) contact my office should you have any questions and upon the
commencement of this litigation. The plaintiff's have sustained irreparable damage, and will seek
damages in the amount of one-hundred million dollars, and any other relief the court would deem
just and proper. The plaintiff's will also move the court to file a order to compell the office
of the United States Attorney to pursue a criminal complaint in which the defendants used
child pronagraphy which the plaintiff was visulized in, and such being disseminated in order to extort money from the plaintiff by using the guise of a non-existant child support debt. The plaintiff's were denied due process, and equal protection of state, and federal law(s). The plaintiff has also been racially, and criminally profiled by using the local Fort Lauderdale media with the attempt to gain money or other assets to include copyrights, and/or other assets owned by the plaintiff's.
    The case will be refiled purusant to the order that was filed in the office of the clerk of
the United States District Court. The city, county nor the state of Florida is a party to this action.
The clerk of the United States District Court may assign alternative docket number to this case.
                  "THIS IS A NOTICE OF SUIT AND LITIGATION TO BE FILED AGAINST YOU"
Thank you,
Dr. Clifford G. Fleetwood, Ph.D., JD.R., J.S.D.R.

Dear Governor,

I'm writing to you regarding Clarence Hill who is scheduled to be executed 
on September 20th. As a member of amnesty international I'm deeply concerned

regarding the fact that Hill has an execution date even though the U.S.
Supreme 
Court ruled 9-0 that Clarence Hill can appeal his case to a federal court. 
The appeal is pending.

Governor Bush, an execution would be in violation of the right to life as
proclaimed 
in the UN Declaration of Human Rights and would perpetuate the cycle of
violence. 
So I urge you to stop the execution and to commute his death sentence.

Thank you for your time and attention in this very serious matter.

Joachim Kuebler

From:	leebreyer@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, August 20, 2006 10:21 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Mr. Clarence Hill

Dear Governor Bush:
 
What is the rush to execution for Clarence Hill when the US Supreme Court, by a 9-0 decision, has allowed an appeal to be considered?  It is not as though Mr. Hill is going to go somewhere he can't be found should the appeal go against him.  But if there is some merit to the civil rights claim, and you've executed him in the meantime, the whole consideration -- at least for him -- is moot.  And that is not a just process...regardless of the outcome and future action based on it.
 
I am asking you, Governor Bush, to reconsider your decision in this matter.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Lee Breyer
Ellenton, FL  34222

Dear Governor:

 

It is my long service to the Brevard County community that moves me to write this letter of reference to you on behalf of Michael L. Bowen’s nomination for the position of County Court Judge in Brevard County.

 

Having served as a Cocoa Beach Police Officer for over twenty-seven years with almost ten years as its Chief of Police, I have been professionally associated with Mr. Bowen for at least half of my tour of duty. From:	Miamicubausa1@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, August 20, 2006 8:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	invite, Launching -  Miami-Cuba USA & Hispanic Florida Tours
Attachments:	001_MCUPressLAUNCHRelease_4.doc; flyer miami cuba usa 7.pdf; MCU06-005Flyer_SpanishVer_HR.pdf

 

August 18, 2006

 

Honorable Governor Jeb Bush

Tallahassee, FL 

Via e mail

 

Honorable Governor Bush:

 

It is with excitement and enthusiasm that we introduce you to a new cultural experience, the Miami-Cuba, USA, and Hispanic Florida tours. It is people like you, and your songs that have made our great city of Miami known as the world’s Hispanic Mecca of today.  

 

I take this opportunity to invite you to this historic event and request the honor of your presence for the ribbon cutting ceremony of the first “Azúcar” trolley celebrating the successes of the Cuban and Hispanic experience in Little Havana, USA.  The launch will take place on September 7th on the eve of the Lady of Charity celebration at Domino Plaza, on S.W. 15th ave. and calle ocho at  6:00pm.  The “Azucar” trolley will then commence with weekly 2 ½ hour tours from Domino Plaza every Friday and Saturday from then on.

 

This new project includes an array of day and night tours that highlight the hot spots of Miami’s Cuban-American and Hispanic community. Tourists from around the globe will board the “Azúcar” trolley, that will depict paintings of local artist and Cuban masters on the outside and will vibrate with tropical music and cafecito being served by the tour guides in authentic “Guajiro” and other themed attire on the inside. Tourist will sway and sing along to popular songs while enriching themselves with the narrated presentations from their guides.

 

The memorable experience will  stop at sights that will bring in the aromas and sounds of such important locations as: Calle Ocho, Domino Park, Freedom Tower, Bay of Pigs Memorial, Our Lady of Charity Shrine,  and several other tourist and historical places highlighting the unique and fascinating Cuban culture. There will also be special tours showcasing other Hispanic cultures. During these tours, the “Azúcar” trolley will stop at key locations such as Little Managua, Doral, the bust of Simón Bolívar at Bayside and Hispanic restaurants and night shows. Miami-Cuba, USA & Hispanic Florida Tours bridges a gap in the community, Miami is a living museum of the immigrant experience, everything has a story, now that story will finally come to life.  

 

The VIP Party at Domino Plaza will feature a guest list that will include a ribbon cutting ceremony from public officials, VIPs, media representatives, Neri Torres IFE- ILI group will dance a conga, Americas dancers, strolling guitarist will be playing typical songs, Rumberas and Guajiros will be on the beat, tobacco rollers will be adding to the aroma, as well as el Caballero de Paris, and other popular Cuban and Hispanic icons will be welcoming in the first City tour of El Exilio.  In addition café Bustelo/Pilon will be serving cafecito and Bacardi their famous Mojitos.

 

Please feel free to call me at 305 491 5884 or Carolina Toledo from Diaz & Cooper Advertising at 305-670-2004. For more information, please visit www.miamicubausa.com.

 

We hope to see you there,



Bettina Rodriguez Aguilera

                          President

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Sponsorship Levels

Miami-Cuba, USA, and Hispanic Florida Tours is a tour like no other. The “Azúcar” trolley will light up Miami strolling down the streets with scenic paintings on its sides depicting the Cuban and Hispanic culture; while the tourists sway to the rhythms of the hot mambo, cha-cha, Guaguancó, rumba and other Latin beats, they will also enjoy a “cafecito cubano” served by the “Caballero de Paris,” a “Rumbera,” “Guajiro” or other Hispanic icons.

Miami-Cuba, USA, and Hispanic Florida Tours has received an outstanding welcome from the community and will attract over 5,000 visitors to Miami in its first six months. It will also serve as a bridge to unite our local community and create the synergy through music, culture and fun to bring tourists from all over the world and our back yard. It will also our sponsors with the opportunity to showcase their products and services to the world, while at the same time participating in a vibrating and stimulating aspect of our history.

 

Our launch includes an integrated marketing communications campaign that encompasses public relations and advertising at the local, national and international level. The advertising campaign includes local radio, print and television, a full page 4 color ad in the GMCVB in-room hotel hard cover book, full Page 4 color ad in Visitor's Guide, full page 4 color ad in Super Bowl special Collector's Edition autographed by Romero Britto, video on touch screens that will be placed in 45 key hotels in Miami, Distribution of the Miami-Cuba, USA, and Hispanic Florida Tours through the CTM network brochure placement website presence in the GMCVB’s website, Visit Florida’s website and other tourism and chamber of commerce related websites as well as local media.

 

We invite you to be part of the launch of the Miami-Cuba, USA, and Hispanic Florida Tours by becoming a sponsor. Below is a description of the three levels of sponsorship opportunities:

 

GOLD LEVEL

$7000 (6 month), 10,000 (One Year)

Website banner and link to business

Your business listed with logo and website on all brochures (placement in over 5000 tourist spots)

Bus benches (logo)

Full ad in the tour Passport

Placement in all public events

Include your company in the tour stops (if feasible) 

Seven tickets for the day-tours
