Her mother raised the money for Bayfront Park in Miami...and they moved to Miami from Key West where she was born...when she was 10.  She has donated the Challenger Memorial located in Bayfront Park in front of the Intercontinental Hotel to The City of Miami and placed money in perpetuity to maintain it.   Additionally, there is a middle school named for her in Dade County, The Lamar Louise Curry Middle School, in recognition of the fact that she taught so many "leaders" of  Florida including Bob Graham and Bob Traurig, and of her donations to education.

-----Original Message-----
From:	"owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com" <owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com> on behalf of	"Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Sunday, August 20, 2006 11:47 AM
To:	"Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Subject:	Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 18, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


FLORIDA STUDENTS INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN FOURTH ANNUAL HISPANIC HERITAGE
MONTH ESSAY CONTEST

On Tuesday, First Lady Columba Bush and I invited Florida students in
kindergarten through twelfth grades to participate in the fourth annual
Florida Hispanic Heritage Month essay contest. The essay contest is the
first in a month-long schedule of events planned to commemorate Florida's
Hispanic heritage. The theme of the essay contest is, 'Why is learning about
Florida's Diverse Hispanic Heritage and Culture Important?'
 
Columba and I are proud of the Spanish and Latin-American influences that
contribute to Florida's rich culture and history and play a dynamic role in
shaping our history and future.  Hispanic Heritage month gives us the
opportunity to educate Florida's students on the tremendous contributions
Hispanic individuals make to our state.  We are asking students to pay
special tribute to the Florida's diverse Hispanic population and their
contributions to the state's culture, economy and education. The theme for
Florida's 2006 Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration is 'La Florida: Honoring
Our State's Spanish and Latin American Influences'.  Those interested in
participating in the essay contest or obtaining more information on
additional Hispanic Heritage Month events should visit
www.floridahispanicheritage.com or contact Nadia Hagberg in the Governor's
office at (850) 488-5000 for more information.


RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDA HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES TOOK THE ACT
      
On Wednesday, Education Commissioner John L. Winn and I announced a record
number of Florida's high school graduates took the American College Test
(ACT).  This year 66,299 of Florida's 2006 high school graduates took the
ACT, up from 58,302 in 2005. Of all high school graduates, 44 percent took
the ACT in Florida compared to 40 percent nationally. The ACT is one of two
college entrance tests Florida students can choose to take. Last year, more
than 93,500 of Florida's 2005 high school graduates took the SAT,
representing 65 percent of the total number of high school graduates.

Florida has been extremely successful at increasing the number of students
taking college entrance exams.  We must continue to encourage all of our
high school students to take these exams and prepare for the rigor of
college and the workforce.  Minority students represent 47 percent of the
2006 test takers, compared to 30 percent nationally.  During 2006, African
Americans represented 21 percent of the Florida test takers, compared to
only 13 percent nationwide.  Hispanic students comprised 17 percent of
Florida test takers, compared to only eight percent nationally.  To learn
more about the ACT visit www.fldoe.org.  To learn more about FACTS.org or to
complete an ePEP, visit www.FACTS.org. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO JERMAINE PHILLIPS

I recognized Jermaine Phillips, a starting safety for the Tampa Bay
Buccaneers, as this week's Points of Light Award recipient.  Jermaine's
efforts are making a positive difference in the lives of those he visits at
Central Florida hospitals, retirement homes and juvenile justice programs.
Jermaine's commitment to Florida's youth has proven that he is a champion
both on and off the field.  Through his volunteerism and philanthropy, many
young Floridians have a brighter future.  For more information, or to
nominate, go to www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8082


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

From:	Stacie Davis <stacieftl@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Sunday, August 20, 2006 2:56 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please take the time to read!!!

August 20, 2006
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
            I am currently an Honor Student and Junior at Florida Atlantic University, as well as a single mother, studying to be a doctor.  I am writing this letter to find out how I may be granted clemency. Unfortunately, I do not feel that having my record sealed or expunged is an option due to my future occupation.  Part of my career path requires me to volunteer in the community as well as to gain experience in the field of medicine, shadowing and working closely with health care professionals and their patients.  From my research, I have learned that this particular field has access to certain records that most employers do not.  I have been honest with the institution I currently attend about my past; however, I feel that my criminal record has the potential to damage my future career in medicine. In the following paragraph, I explained my situation and only wish now to put my past behind me.  Other than this, I have never been in any trouble with the law.  I would like to explore my options on how I can have this removed from my record and would also like information on reinstating my voting rights.  I have overcome many obstacles in my life and admit that I finally need help with this situation.  Being a full time student and single-mother, I do not have the financial means to hire an attorney to assist me with this.   Any help you could give me would be greatly appreciated. 
On July 28, 2000, I was arrested at Sears and charged with Grand Theft in the third degree.  The authorities claimed that I knowingly used two gift cards that were purchased with stolen credit cards.  I admit that most of the facts contained in the police report are correct except for a few minor mistakes.  The report claimed that I gave the authorities a false name, which is untrue.  I did give the store clerk a false name, as I do at all stores who ask for personal information when making a purchase, because I believed it was intended for telemarketing purposes.  When detained by the authorities, I willingly gave them my correct information, which they believed to be untrue.  I searched frantically for my license and could not find it in my purse, and it was later found in my pants pocket with the exact information I had supplied them with.  They asked me to furnish the name of the person from whom I had purchased the cards and I refused as it was a member of my family.  
Prior to this incident, I had no knowledge that I was in any way committing a crime.  I was offered pre-trial intervention, in which I would have had to write a letter admitting my guilt, yet I declined the prosecutor’s offer as I refused to tell a lie about my involvement.  I opted instead to take the issue to trial, under the advice of counsel who due to my economic circumstances was a public defender.  When the day of my trial arrived the judge made a comment insinuating that he was not going to be lenient if I were convicted and would give me jail time.  This being my first and only infraction, I believed him and decided that although I was innocent, it was in my best interest to enter a plea of no contest with adjudication withheld and serve eighteen months probation.  I did not feel that I would be convicted; however, I could not take the risk of my child going to my abusive, substance-abusing ex-husband.  
            There was no way that I could have known that the cards that I was using were illegally purchased, although I would not allow myself to be put in a situation like that again.  The person who sold me the cards has since served time in prison for other similar offenses, and I sincerely hope that this person has learned their lesson.  
This infraction taught me an important life lesson about being naïve, and I have since learned from it.  I feel that every experience in life teaches you something and if you can overcome all obstacles, you will become a stronger and more resilient person.  
I sincerely hope that you can appreciate my honesty and not hold this incident against me.  I have worked very hard to achieve what I have, and would hate to lose it all now, so close to fulfilling my dream of becoming a doctor.  Like I mentioned before, this is my only altercation with the law.  I have not ever been charged or even suspected of any scholastic misconduct.  I hold education in the highest regard and I hope my academic record speaks for itself.  Thank you for taking the time to review my situation and I genuinely hope that you can in some way assist me with this unfortunate impediment that stands in the way of my career in medicine.  
 
Sincerely,
Stacie Davis

THE NUMBERS ON THE HISPANIC INVASION

That's right.  The invasion is still underway.  

Here's an interesting website for you.  It's called immigrationCounters.com  the #1 Site for Real-Time Immigration Statistics.  I can't vouch for the accuracy of the information on this site, but it sure does get your attention.

*	Illegal Immigrants in Country    20,426,887 
*	Money wired to Mexico    $23,575,296,302 
*	Cost of Social Services for Illegal Immigrants        $397,469,111,828 
*	Illegals Enrolled in Government Schools K-12        3,749,373 
*	Cost of Illegal Immigrants Enrolled in K-12        $14,489,987,299 
*	Illegal Immigrants Incarcerated        315,460 
*	Cost for Incarcerations of Illegal Immigrants    $1,446,245,595 
*	Illegal Immigrant Fugitives        623,761 

Here's a statistic from elsewhere, one that I did check out.  Out of all of the outstanding warrants for murder in Los Angeles, 95% of them are for illegal aliens.

One more thing:  The House immigration bill called for the borders to be controlled and contained no guest worker program; the Senate had a bill calling for amnesty and only a token attempt to control the borders.  Nothing got done.  The Senate bill was written by Harry Reid and Ted Kennedy.  It contained a provision for about 370 miles of fencing along the Mexican-U.S. Border.  But, here's the catch.  That fence can only be built after consulting Mexico as to its location.  Well isn't that special!  Mexico gets to decide where we put our border fences!

August 18, 20206
 
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
Please allow Mr. Clarence Hill the opportunity to use the right which The Supreme Court of the United States has offered him.  He has been granted the time, by The Supreme Court to appeal the method of execution which the State of Florida uses to end his life; allow him to make use of this right.
 
I am sure that you are aware that all organized religious groups in the world have issued a statement declaring that if the citizens of a country can be protected from a person by keeping them in prison without parole we do not have the right to end this persons life.  We are responsible for offering him the opportunity to find forgiveness from his God and to have some form of religious and spiritual rehabilitation.  We do not have the right to murder him to prove that murdering is an improper act.
 
The Supreme Court has given you the opportunity to make use of their decision, please allow Mr. Hill to file his appeals and claims.  So very many citizens have changed their minds about the death penalty due to human failings and errors in our death penalty system.  At this time, or any time I don't believe that the people of the State of Florida need to see another death.  I would be wonderful to see that we have a government which still cares about an individual and allows him the right to follow through with the rights which our judicial system has offered him.
 
Thank you for your time and consideration.
 
Sincerely,
 
Marsha A. Lyons

Subject:	Inter-Governmental Relations

Dear Flordia Governor Jeb Bush:
 
I recently returned from working in Washington, D.C. as an intern at the U.S. Conference of Mayors through the Hinckley Institute of Politics at the University of Utah. As part of my internship experience, I am required to write a research paper. I have chosen to discuss inter-governmental relations and the influence of mayors and governors on Federal policy.
 
Mayors and Governors from across the United States have been an increasingly loud voice in the office halls of the nation's capital. At the Conference of Mayors, I head about mayoral appearances before Congressional hearings and have been paying attention to the recent gathering of Governors at the National Governors Association Meeting.
 
To understand more about city and state leader's influence over Federal policy, I hope you will indulge me by answering my inquiries.
 
How active have you been in voicing your concerns to Congress and the Presidential Cabinet Members?
 
If mayors and governors are to effectively change U.S. policy to benefit local communities, how should they go about doing so? Is "pork" or earmarking effective? Or are there other methods mayors/governors and members of Congress can work together toward to better the country's cities and towns?
 
Thank you for taking the time to read this. I understand that as I am not a constituent of yours, my inquiry is not high priority, but as your reply will be of use for my research, a comment would be a welcome addition to my work. Thank you again, and I look forward to receiving any reply from you by E-mail or the address below.
 
Sincerely,
Robert Costa
929 Heritage Center
Salt Lake City, UT 84112

From:	Egner, Diane <DEgner@wusf.org>
Sent:	Friday, August 18, 2006 3:59 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	An invitation to have fun with NPR's national audience

Dear Gov. Bush,

My colleagues and I at WUSF Public Broadcasting would be honored to have you as our station’s celebrity guest on the “Not My Job’’ segment for the popular National Public Radio news quiz show “Wait, Wait, Don’t Tell Me!’’ when it visits Sarasota on Nov. 2.

The “Not My Job’’ segment, as you may know, invites well-known personalities to answer questions about topics way outside their accustomed areas of expertise. The “Not My Job’’ contestants play on behalf of a listener selected from the station’s listening area. If the contestant – you, in this case --- can come up with at least two of three correct answers, Carl Kasell will record the outgoing message on the listener’s home answering machine.

Past celebrity guests have included John McCain, Elliot Gould, Patrick Stewart, Cokie Roberts and Chris Matthews. All have had lots of fun doing the show and everyone enjoys lots of laughs in the process. Here are links to the “Wait, Wait’’ show and to a couple examples of the “Not My Job’’ segment:
 
The show’s site -- http://www.npr.org/programs/waitwait/ 


Tom Hanks -- http://www.npr.org/templates/rundowns/rundown.php?prgId=35&prgDate=05-13-2006&view=storyview 

Brian Williams -- http://www.npr.org/templates/rundowns/rundown.php?prgId=35&prgDate=06-24-2006&view=storyview 


The program will be recorded in front of a live audience at 8 p.m. on Thursday, Nov. 2, at Van Wezel Performing Arts Hall in Sarasota, starring regular hosts Peter Sagal and Carl Kasell and familiar celebrity panelists answering questions and sharing tales about the top news of the week. Tickets to the 1,700-seat Van Wezel Hall are expected to sell out shortly after they go on sale starting tomorrow (Aug. 19).

We believe that your well-honed sense of humor, keen appreciation of news and politics, and prominent public stature as the governor of the nation’s fourth-largest state add up to make you an ideal participant in a program that is always entertaining as well as educational for its 2 million regular listeners nationwide. 

We would be honored to have you there connecting on-air with WUSF’s listening audience in West Central Florida.

Please let me know by Aug. 22 whether you would be willing to spend the evening having fun with “Wait, Wait,’’ WUSF and the National Public Radio audience so that we can begin promoting it on air. 

Thanks very much for your consideration. I look forward to hearing from you.

Diane

Subject:	"Hill v. McDonough"

Sir,

 

Are you aware that The U.S. Supreme Court had ruled unanimously in the Florida case "Hill v. McDonough (05-8794)," that death row inmate, Clarence Hill can challenge the lethal injection method of execution as a civil rights claim.  The court accepted Hill's appeal as he lay bound on a cross-shaped gurney for almost 2 hours with needles inserted.

 

With an appeal pending and so many unanswered questions about Florida's method of execution, why are you now re-instating the death warrant for this case?  Are you trying to prevent this man from proceeding with his claim?  

 

I would think you would be more interested in justice than in assuring that one individual gets executed.

 

Mair E. Buddug

Registered Florida Voter

From:	Muslima Lewis <MLewis@aclufl.org>
Sent:	Friday, August 18, 2006 2:36 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Rodriguez, Raquel
Subject:	Letter Supporting Appointment of Marie Jo Toussaint to Miami-Dade County Court

August 18, 2006

 

Via Electronic and First Class Mail

 

Governor Jeb Bush

Executive Office of the Governor

400 South Monroe Street

The Capitol

Tallahassee, Florida  32399-0001

                      Re:      Appointment of Marie Jo Toussaint to Miami-Dade County Court

Dear Governor Bush:

Wilkie D. Ferguson, Jr. Bar Association gives its unqualified and highest support for the appointment of Marie Jo Toussaint to the County Court in the Eleventh Judicial Circuit in and for Miami-Dade County.  The Wilkie D. Ferguson, Jr. Bar Association ("WDFJBA"), formerly the Black Lawyers Association of Dade County, is a voluntary bar association serving Miami-Dade County's lawyers, law students and communities of African descent.  As you know, WDFJBA previously urged you to appoint Ms. Toussaint to a circuit court seat.  While we are disappointed that Ms. Toussaint did not receive your appointment at that time, we are encouraged that she has once again submitted her name for your consideration, and we see this county court appointment as another opportunity for you to appoint a highly qualified candidate to the Miami-Dade courts.

As you undoubtedly know, Ms. Toussaint is highly qualified for the position of county court judge.  During her work in the Office of the State Attorney she gained extensive experience trying cases.  Not only does she possess vast experience and a keen intellect, but Ms. Toussaint has a demonstrated commitment to public service, as evidenced by her dedicated leadership in the community.  Finally, Ms. Toussaint has a demeanor that is perfectly suited for a member of the judiciary and she is highly regarded and respected by her peers.  

Diversifying the Florida judiciary is one of the Wilkie D. Ferguson, Jr. Bar Association's highest priority.  I understand that you share this goal. Appointing Ms. Toussaint, a Haitian-American, will be an important step in addressing the woeful under-representation of Haitian-Americans (and persons of African descent) serving on Florida's courts.




 

It is without reservation that the Wilkie D. Ferguson, Jr. Bar Association urges the appointment of Marie Jo Toussaint to the Miami-Dade County Court.  Thank you for your thoughtful consideration of this matter.

Very truly yours,

s/Roderick Vereen

President

inappropriate with respect to their effects on inmates, their families, 
and others who care about them.  I have made my judgments from the 
perspective of a former administrator in the department of corrections 
in another state.

In the months the James McDonough has been Secretary of Corrections, he 
has made a large number of decisions which have positively affected 
inmates, inmate families, and others who care about inmates.  The staff 
changes he has made has have a great effect ultimately on the 
responsiveness of the department and in careful attention to matters 
which truly merit genuine concern.  His actions with regard to the 
canteen contract and the inmate telephone service have already had a 
significant impact of inmates, and those who love them, and he is to be 
commended.

Far too many state departments of correction fail miserably to remember 
that inmates, although they have broken the law, are human beings and 
are precious in the eyes of Almighty God.

I know of only two really professional heads of departments of 
correlation  in the US and one of them is James McDonough and the other 
is James Donald here in Georgia!  It is interesting to note according to 
my understanding, they both have military backgrounds.

May I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your selection of Mr. 
McDonough and also suggest you should certainly congratulate him for 
doing such a splendid job!

Sincerely yours,

With government budgets being so tight, I was intrigued to recently learn that taxpayers and local governments across the country spend hundreds of millions of dollars per year to collect and dispose of all the bulk mail citizens typically didn’t want to receive in the first place.

That's why I was encouraged to learn about Junk Mail Awareness Week, a public education week October 1-7 that will call attention to both the numerous existing steps citizens can currently take to reduce unwanted ad mail as well as new steps that marketers and legislators could take to make opting out easier for citizens.

If we don't stop concentrating on being hyphenated Americans, we will never think of ourselves as just Americans, and our country will continue to have problems.

I have been more than patient and fair as I have had my rights totally trampled upon,
lost everything I own and am now in mortgage foreclosure due to the over reaching and 
prosecutorial misconduct in the District 1 office.

Briefly, I was wrongly arrested based on lies (proven in court and on video tape) in a
vicious divorce action where my wife lied about having a domestic violence injunction against
me to local law enforcememt and had me jailed when I called deputies to check on our
daugther after her mother had taken her without authorization twice before.

The charge "aggravated cyberstalking after an injunction" - again, NO INJUNCTION and not stalking.

That is when the ordeal started.

Although the prosecutor for the state told my criminal defense attorrney that she believed that the 
case was really a civil matter and that my wife had "impure motives" she HAD TO PROSECUTE me. Why? Who
knows. Perhap's because of the politicl promises of Bill Eddins and Sheriff Ron McNesby to be tough on
domestic violence offenders.

The State NEVER investigated, gathered evidence on their own or even looking into the background of the accusor.
To date she has 906 documented perscriptions over a 6 1/2 year period and our divorce Judge allowed into the record
the prescription and payment records for 654 over a 4 1/2 year period. The drugs included 4 different anti-depressents PER DAY - all completely documented and a matter of the court records now.

So the State doggedly chased these thin charges even after Judge Skievaski (our divorce Judge) stated on the record that the charges were thin at best, that I probably should never had been arrested in the first place and then he told my criminal defense attorney (who was present at one of the divore hearings) that it was a "slam dunk" for him based on the thin interpertatijn of the Statues and the lack of any evidence.

The State continued and the bottom line is that I have evidence of colusion between my wife, the prosecutor, and the Department of Children and Families to force me into PTI to get riud of me.

My wife emailed the prosecutor stating "I have the Sheriff and DCF at my house no please call me ASAP.". This was a couple of days before I was to appear against the State and deliver a "Motion to Dismiss".

Within no time the prosecutor emailed my attorney and stated "I'm thinking about revoking your clients bond and having him arrested based on a conversatino overheard by a DCF investigator." Although a report from DCF is cited in her email, and mentioned her motion to revoke bond (and stated it was attached to the motion)it was NOT ATTACHED or ever produced to anyone since it never actually existed! The only report to come from DCF was several weeks after the incidents and the incident was "no findings" - essentially stating nothing improper occured. 

The next day the Judge who was obviously showing favortism to the prosecutor stated she would not entertain or review the Motion because "the State says it is improperly formed" - this effectively removed my legal options and forced me to take PTI under threat of jail time. I entered into the program and immediately set out to clear my name.

The prosecutor is guilty of hiding evidence, obscuring facts and trampling on my rights by attempting to revoke my bond and have me arrested on a non-existent report to force me to enter PTI and hid her abuses.

The State continues to refuse to give me their copies of emails between the parties first stating they had no records of any emails (althoug I have many) then claiming they were deleted because they were transitory in nature.

Because of these glaring abuses and the trampling of my rights I have been forced to put up a website (www.billcagle.com), have made a formal complaint to the Florida Commission on Ethics, have filed a complaint against the prosecutor with the Florida Bar and contacted the Florida and National offices of the ACLU. In addition I have sent information to several media outlets and requested coverage.

My purpose is to make the people responsible for these abuses be held accountable for their actions and their arrogant actions be made public.

My hopes is that the glaring light of public eyes on these abuses will somehow spark external intervention and oversight of investigations by office like yours.

I am now officially requesting contact and assistance from your office.

I look forawrd to hearing from your soon. I can be reached at 850-324-3107.

From:	ForeFathersPen@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, August 18, 2006 9:59 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Lawson, Alfred
Subject:	Discrimination and the Sunshine Law in Wakulla Co.

Governor Bush and Senator Lawson,
 
    My name is Daniel Thompson and I have Multiple Sclerosis and live in Sopchoppy.  On July 17, 2006, the Wakulla County Board of Commissioners voted 3-2 to restrict the broadcast of the "Citizens to be Heard" portion of the commission meeting on Comcast C-Span channel, restraining public sentiment.
    This directly affects the disabled and elderly citizens of this county.  It is the intention of the BOCC to further restrict the ability of the citizen to be placed on the agenda of the BOCC meetings.  A workshop will be held on Aug. 21 to discuss these further restrictions.  It is advertised and titled agenda, not indicating the seriousness of the workshop.
   
    I have had 3 min. for a redress of my grievances concerning this issue of broadcast. Two commissioners spoke briefly with me on this subject, one spoke with me on another issue and said we would talk about broadcast later, two have not responded to my attempts to contact them.  I have also written a letter (attached to this email) to them referencing the Sunshine State Law, The Disabilities Act of 1990, and historical literature on the importance and foundation of local government, only one commissioner has responded.  
 
    Of the two that voted against the restriction of broadcast, one commissioner released the very next day, an e-mail statement praising the decision of the board and listed the ability of the citizen to get on the meeting agenda as a disadvantage.  One would wonder for whom is this a disadvantage and why would you praise a decision you voted against.  I know,  his voting record may be in question when running for higher office in two years and a vote to restrain public sentiment would reflect negatively on his campaign.
 
    I contend this decision to restrict broadcast is a violation of the Sunshine State Law, Florida State Constitution and negatively affects the disabled, elderly, and all the citizens of Wakulla. My intentions are to have a true "open government".   The State Attorney Willie Meggs is investigating a possible violation of the Sunshine Law by a board member, and I would like him to also determine if restriction of broadcast is a violation.
 
    I been approached and  encouraged by many citizens(over 60 now and counting) and only three agreed with the decision of the board.  Only after trying to take this matter up with the board over the last five weeks and nearly being ignored,  I bring this issue to the state level.
 
    Please contact me, I would appreciate your insight on this issue.
 
                                                            Thank you, Daniel Thompson

From:	Jerry Kanghua Chang <sales@fibsusa.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 16, 2006 8:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	BOT business

Dear Mr. Bush:

 

I am happy to have the chance to send this information to you for your attention. Florida is developing very quickly in the recent 10 years, especially in the period under your excellent leadership.

We thank you and your brother very much for all you have done for this country.

 

My personal business friends in Shanghai just told me that they want to find some business opportunities in Florida. The business is called BOT (Build Own Transfer).

They want to find some construction projects here in Florida that they can join. They will provide the necessary capital to support big projects in Florida and they do not wish to be shareholders.

 

Simply speaking, the nature and conditions of the business are as the following:

 

1)       The project investment target normally needs to be larger than 100 million U.S. dollars

2)       30% to 35% of the investment needs to be purchasing orders to companies in China (either material or labor)

3)       The project must be secured by Federal Government or a credible bank to guarantee the payment back

4)       The interest rate is about 5.0% plus some managerial cost, and the total rate is usually between 7 to 9%.

5)       The pay back period / term is negotiable.

 

If you know any construction development projects (Like highway, bridges, ports, big warehouses, social benefit residential buildings, water systems, etc.) in Florida that can use this BOT paradigm and really benefit Floridians, please let me know. I can discuss the matter with you or your assistant anytime.

 

Best regards!

 

 

Jerry K Chang

Florida International Business Service

Tel: 727-455-7558

Fax: 727-536-5915

Email: sales@fibsusa.com

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I have contacted your office numerous times to be considered for an appointment to the Florida Board of Medicine. I believe our medical profession is in need of some leadership in order to preserve the trust of the people we serve, I am committed to using educational tools to modify and improve physician behavior and competence. I have exceptional qualifications and experience. I am a Clinical (Voluntary) Professor of Medicine at the University of Miami School of Medicine. I am bilingual and speak and understand Spanish. I also believe physicians need to think out of the box when it comes to assisting in disaster relief. The impact that one physician can have will benefit our citizens. Moreover, I know from several of my friends that the Board needs help and probable cause panel is inundated with cases. I have been in practice for over 30 years and have had an excellent track record as a physician in my field as noted. I would appreciate it very much if you would consider me for an appointment to the Board of Medicine. I would like an opportunity to serve the Board and be able to contribute in some small way to the improvement of our health care system for our citizens. I am in favor adding reference to §766.115(3)(2)(e)(2), F.S. regarding volunteer service guidelines. I am also in favor of providing Board Authority to Require Provider Competency (Ortiz Opinion) The Board proposes language to correct the unsafe situation created by the Ortiz decision. That decision would prevent the Board from taking action on physicians who delegate medical care to persons who are not competent to perform them or are services which the physician is not competent to supervise the performance of. 

 

 

Please call me at (305) 778-7243 or my offices at (305) 956-9062 ask for Lori she is my office manager. 
 
Howard B. Reinfeld, M.D.

From:	Ryan Dumas <RDumas@ucpcdc.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 16, 2006 11:12 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Letter of acknowledgement

Gov. Bush,

 

The word “hero” is defined as a “person of courage and accomplishment” in Webster’s Dictionary.  For United Cerebral Palsy of Central Florida, twenty-one-year-old Krista Pohorenec is our definition of hero.

 

On Saturday, September 30, Krista will swim from Alcatraz Island to San Francisco Aquatic Park to help raise awareness for early intervention services for children with special needs.

 

Diagnosed with Down syndrome at birth, she is also using her love for swimming as a tool to help raise funds for UCP of Central Florida, an organization she holds near and dear to her heart.

 

Krista sees the Alcatraz swim as an opportunity to make a difference and educate parents on the importance of seeking early intervention services for their children. But for Krista, the Alcatraz swim is just the beginning.

 

She is an extraordinary individual who works hard to give back to those who are in need as she once was. One day a week, she volunteers as a teacher’s aid at one of UCP of Central Florida’s Child Development Centers.  And she wants to become a motivational speaker to help create a better world for all people, with and without disabilities.

 

“Krista is a remarkable young lady who has already succeeded in living a purposeful and goal-oriented life,” says Ilene Wilkins CEO/President of UCP of Central Florida.  “She has a positive impact on everyone she meets, inspiring us all to realize our own untapped potential.”

 

We realize your schedule is very tight and a personal visit to wish her luck may not be possible. However, would you be able to send a personal letter to Krista acknowledging her desire to help children with special needs and congratulating her on her accomplishments?

 
Please address the letter to Krista Pohorenec and mail it to my attention at:

 

UCP of Central Florida

3305 S. Orange Ave.

Orlando, FL 32806

 

We will be happy to have UCP’s CEO or even a local representative present the letter to her on your behalf if you desire.  If you are able to meet with Krista as she departs for her journey to swim Alcatraz, she would be more than honored. Please contact me at 407-852-3305 or 407-721-5490 and I will be happy to help make this happen.

 

Again, Krista is a very passionate and personable individual and I appreciate your time and assistance in helping show Krista how much she means to UCP.

 

Sincerely,

 

Ryan Dumas

Corporate & Community Relations Manager

UCP of Central Florida, Inc.

3305 S. Orange Avenue

Orlando, FL 32806

407-852-3305 - Business

407-852-3301 - Fax

www.ucpcdc.org

 

"Where Hope begins and Miracles Happen”

From:	Robert Neely <bneely@fla-alarms.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 16, 2006 10:39 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Appointment of Tim Quigley to ECLB

THank you for your consideration 
  _____  


 

 

 

 

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush – Governor

PL 05 The Capitol

400 South Monroe Street

Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001                                                          August 16, 2006

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

As President of the Alarm Association of Florida I am pleased to recommend the appointment of Tim Quigley to the Electrical Contractors’ Licensing Board for the State of Florida.

From:	Nick Jeffries <jeffries_7500@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 16, 2006 2:02 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] death penalty

Dear Governor Bush:
 
 This is absolutely ridiculous. I find it a complete outrage that inmate's who have been on death row for the past 3 damn decades without a new trial or new sentencing hearing are still languishing on death row filing these meaningless appeals. You are by far the best Governor Florida has ever had, and I commend you on all your great accomplishment's. One of those was by signing into law the death penalty reform act of 2000. The Florida Supreme Court quashed the new law to speed up death penalty appeals, and I find that utterly repulsive. The idea of an innocent person getting executed keeps coming up. I am so tired of hearing that. It is the legislatures duty to amend the laws. In this case, the legislature actually did the right thing, a bill passed that would have reduced the number of years an inmate has spent on death row from 14 to 5. Florida needs to start taking after Virginia in carrying out it's executions if you ask me. I understand you only have to January in office. Right now I would ask that you respectfully sign the death warrants, for which your assosciates have not rightfully provided you with. A couple months ago during Clarence Hill's pending execution, where it was later stayed you were quoted as saying "I don't think any are ripe anyway" in referring to the signing of death warrants as it relates to certain cases. Unfortunately, there are dozens on death row who have long been through with their appeals before Clarence Hill and Arthur Rutherford. I will name them later. Right now, I'de like to talk about the future of Florida. You are leaving office in January and I find it urgent that someone like you does something as it regards the appeals limited to death row inmates. Where do these low-class human beings get off suing the state for amending our laws to shorten the time to their execution. It's punishment for their crime. There should be NO LAWSUITS, no challenges. Sometimes you just have to take what you get, and these inmates come off threatening to sue the state because we cut off their appeals. This has to stop. The Victims and their families have been on the receiving end of this trauma to long Governor Bush. I respectfully ask you to act NOW on this issue before it is to late. 
 
As far as death warrants go, executions are proceeding in other states. The U.S Supreme Court specifically made it clear in their ruling that not all executions would be stayed just due to legal challenges to lethal injection. Clarence Hill won a stay of execution, fortunately for him and Rutherford, and Hill won. Hill has the right to pursue a civil lawsuit challenging lethal injection. The high court stated their must be clear proof for a challenge to lethal injection to be granted. I therefore respectfully ask you sign the death warrants for which your person who handles death penalty appeals has not told you about...
 
Jeffrey Atwater, McArthur Breedlove (on death row since 1979 and has lost all appeals),Jim Chandler,Angel Diaz,Charles Foster,Guy Gamble (pending disposition of certiorari petition to U.S Supreme Court),Norman Parker,William Kelley,Cary Lambrix,Ian Lightbourne,John Marek, John Marquard,Domibnick Occhicone (pending disposition of certiorari petition),Sonny Oats,Kenneth Quince,Danny Rolling,Mark Schwab,Paul Scott,Wayne Tompkins,Manuel Valle (pending disposition of certiorari petition),William Van Poyck, Peter Ventura,Johnny Williamson,Edward Zakrzewski, and lastly William Zeigler (on death row since 1976). Each and every one of the names I have just provided you have LOST their appeals in the 11th circuit, which is every states last major avenue of relief as it concerns the death penalty appeals. Right now most of the above inmate's have meritless postconviction motions pending which are undoubtedly going to be denied. One inmate has an appeal pending saying that Roper V Simmons should apply to him even though he was 18 years and 8 months old. Another one of those inmate's has filed an appeal on how Roper should apply to him even though he was 23 when he commited the crime, he has the mental age of a juvenile, or 10 year old. These are unworthy appeals up for review, and no relief is going to come out of filing such unworthy, useless appeals. The Florida Supreme Court has gone to far with this issue. The above inmate's need their death warrant's signed. I have studied the death penalty for years, and in any other state, those inmates would have been executed decades ago after the court of appeals ruled on their issues. I respectfully ask that you reverse your decision in not signing any death warrants (as I'm sure these executions would be carried out), and sign the name's above up for execution in a timely manner. The person who handles the death penalty appeals for you has not been keeping track of these very well if he/she sees Arthur Rutherford or Clarence Hill up for execution before the other names on that list. Most of those inmates have filed at least 5 Postconviction successive motions which were all denied and have been on death row since the 70's, and still continue to file those meritless appeals..
 
Please see to it something get's done expeditously. Thank you
 
-- If Governor Bush does not actually read his e-mail's, I would ask that you please see to it that he is fully aware of the name's I have provided. Those ARE inmate's whose date with the executioner can very well be carried out if a death warrant is signed.

From:	Peggy Fisher <pegsterinfl@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 15, 2006 9:09 PM
To:	Patrick Fisher; Lisa Schweiger; Lloyd Marcus; George; Jerry Fisher; Jim Fisher; John Fisher; Carolyn Fisher; Carolyn Martin
Subject:	Illegal Immigrants

(This story puts an interesting perspective on the illegal immigration
issue!!)

A lady wrote the best letter in the Editorials in ages!! It explains
things better than all the balderdash you hear on TV.


Recently large demonstrations have taken place across the country
protesting the fact that Congress is finally addressing the issue of
illegal immigration. Certain people are angry that the US might protect
its own borders, might make it harder to sneak into this country and,
once here, to stay indefinitely. Let me see if I correctly understand
the thinking behind these protests.

Let's say I break into your house. Let's say that when you discover me
in your house, you insist that I leave. But I say, "I've made all the
beds and washed the dishes and did the laundry and swept the floors;
I've done all the things you don't like to do. I'm hard-working and
honest (except for when I broke into your house).

According to the protesters, not only must you let me stay, you must add
me to your family's insurance plan, educate my kids, and provide other
benefits to me and to my family (my husband will do your yard work
because he too is hard-working and honest, except for that breaking in
part. 

If you try to call the police or force me out, I will call my friends
who will picket your house carrying signs that proclaim my right to be
there. It's only fair, after all, because you have a nicer house than
I do, and I'm just trying to better myself. I'm hard-working and honest,
um, except for well, you know. 

And what a deal it is for me!! I live in your house, contributing only a
fraction of the cost of my keep, and there is nothing you can do about
it without being accused of selfishness, prejudice and being
anti-housebreaker. 

Oh yeah, and I want you to learn my language so you can communicate with
me

Why can't people see how ridiculous this is?! 

Only in America....if you agree, pass it on (in English).

From:	Peyton, John <JPeyton@coj.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 15, 2006 5:46 PM
To:	Peyton, John
Subject:	Article about crime from the Orlando Sentinel

I thought the attached article from the Orlando Sentinel from last Saturday would be of interest.

Best,

John Peyton

Mayor

Is crime crackdown the answer? 

Jacksonville's fight against its murder wave may be a model for Orlando.

Jim Leusner

Sentinel Staff Writer

August 13, 2006

JACKSONVILLE -- It started with the Jan. 3 death of Donte Chapman, a 20-year-old man found shot, burned and dumped in a field -- one of 14 murder victims in the first month of the year.

Consoling the boy's mother, pastor Mark Griffin knew things had to change in his city -- which for years has been dubbed "Florida's murder capital." So Griffin and others in the AME Ministerial Alliance partnered with police and then started walking neighborhoods on their own, talking about crime in the community and even offering cash for guns.

As the city of Orlando faces its deadliest year in history -- with 37 murders to date -- it might look to Jacksonville, where city, law-enforcement, business, faith and community leaders have rallied to attack the rising body count.

In May, 13-year-old honor student Shenice Holmes was killed by a stray bullet while reading in her bedroom. The outrage in the black community was palpable. Jacksonville Sheriff John Rutherford announced Operation Safe Streets, a multiagency task force aimed at guns, drugs and violent offenders.

The community's breaking point, it seems, came July 26, when 8-year-old DreShawna Davis was killed -- again by a stray bullet -- while playing a video game in her grandmother's home.

"DreShawna Davis was our flash point," Jacksonville Mayor John Peyton said. "The community said enough is enough. Her life was snuffed out for no reason."

To date, the city of 840,000 has tallied 79 murders -- 31 more than this time last year. For all of 2005, the city had 91 slayings.

Ways to fight back

Jacksonville is throwing everything it has into the battle against urban violence. And it's not just politicians' promises and prayer groups:

The mayor and City Council have pledged $5 million in police overtime to add 70 officers in the city's most dangerous neighborhoods.

Peyton appealed to Gov. Jeb Bush, who sent $32,000 to fund Operation Road Block North, which brings troopers to the city on weekends this month.

The mayor has reached out to 550 faith organizations to help promote "Walking Wednesdays," where he, police and residents tour neighborhoods to help improve relations.

Members of the Jacksonville Chamber of Commerce are pledging $200,000 to help the Sheriff's Office pay rewards up to $1,000 to citizens who report criminals armed with guns.

If Jacksonville's business community -- the city is a regional banking and insurance center pushing to attract more high-tech companies -- doesn't address violence and murder, and do something to help, "it could have a chilling effect on business and people wanting to come to Jacksonville," said Steve Halverson, a construction-company executive leading the chamber fundraising effort. "It's intolerable from a businessman's perspective. . . . And sometimes, you need a crisis to wake people up."

Orlando's Regional Chamber of Commerce doesn't see its role that way, its president said.

"That's not our mission at all," said Jacob Stuart, chamber president. "Our mission is to lead a regional visioning exercise." The chamber once had a crime-prevention committee. But that, he said, is "ancient history."

On Friday, Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer said he will launch a task force designed to find new ways to combat the city's crime wave. It will be asked to develop a plan using police, volunteer and community resources to reduce crime.

"We're solving the crimes after they occur. The issue is, how can we be effective at preventing the crime?" Dyer said. " . . . It's going to take more than the Orlando Police Department to solve the crime problem."

Turning tide in community

Jacksonville's sheriff thinks his city needs a community backlash against criminals to succeed in its anti-crime response. Violent crimes overall are down in Jacksonville during the past 15 years, and law-enforcement members are confounded by the jump in murders this year. They want residents to report criminal activity and identify people with guns.

"That collective intolerance is the only thing that can stop this violence," Rutherford said. "If you act like a thug, the community is going to come after you -- and the police are coming with them."

From:	Hernandez, Yaniel (MDPD) <yhernandez@mdpd.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 15, 2006 3:18 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Rodriguez, Raquel
Subject:	Cristina Miranda

Importance:	High

 

 

 

 

 

August 15, 2006 

 

Governor Jeb Bush;

 

I am writing this letter on behalf of Judicial Candidate Cristina Miranda. It is my understanding that Cristina is being considered for appointment by you for a position as a county court Judge in the Eleventh Judicial Circuit of Florida. Even though you may consider my opinion biased, I think Ms. Miranda's strong ethical, moral, and honest beliefs would make an outstanding judge.

  

I have been a Miami-Dade Police Officer for thirteen years. For the past two years, I have been assigned to the Strategic and Specialized Investigations Bureau, Organized Crime Section, Vice Squad.  During this period I have dealt nearly exclusively with Cristina for the preparation and the prosecution of the cases I investigate.  My responsibilities as an investigator includes;  Organized Prostitution, Organized Gambling, Human Trafficking, Juvenile Prostitution, Murder-for-Hire, Murder Conspiracy, Extortion, Racketeering, and RICO.  I'm also assigned to the South Florida Human Trafficking Task Force. Throughout my tenure in the Organized Crime Section I have always requested Cristina's legal guidance for the successful prosecution of my cases.  Cristina can always be counted on 24/7.  Cristina always makes effective decisions based on her strong ethical, moral, and honest beliefs. Her dedication to her job is second-to-none; as I have had to, on very frequent occasions, call upon her late nights and weekends, for advice, and at times, response to scenes. Cristina is a fearless prosecutor whose career speaks for itself.   Having the opportunity to work with Cristina when dealing both with subjects and victims, has truly been a learning experience. I have known very few people who can show the maximum compassion, whether it is to a victim or offender, when making decisions which adversely or positively affect the rest of that person's life.

 

It has and continues to be one of the greatest privileges of my career to work with and learn from Cristina. She is an individual who would make an outstanding judge.  If I can be of any assistance to you in this matter, or any other, please feel free to contact me. 

 

Respectfully,

 

Detective Yaniel Hernandez

Miami-Dade Police Department

Strategic & Specialized Investigations Bureau

Organized Crime Section

(305) 471-2697 - Office

(305) 471-2307 - Fax

 yhernandez@mdpd.com

"Delivering Excellence Every Day

 

 

From:	Nancy_Ballard@doh.state.fl.us
Sent:	Tuesday, August 15, 2006 3:40 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	baskerr@ocps.k12.fl.us; Michael_Dey@doh.state.fl.us
Subject:	"Mentoring Success"

Dear Governor Bush,

 

Please allow me to introduce myself.  My name is Nancy Ballard.  I am a Human Service Counselor III with the State of Florida Department of Health located at the Orange County Health Department in Orlando.  It is widely known that your administration has placed great emphasis on improving the educational standards for the children of Florida.

 

During the 2005-2006 school year,  the employees at my office were encouraged by our health unit director, Dr. Kevin Sherin, to volunteer as mentors at one of our local elementary schools.  This particular school, Ivey Lane Elementary School, had just received a second “F” rating.  Through the encouragement of Dr. Sherin and that school’s principal, Dr. Ruth Baskerville, 55 of our employees signed on as mentors.  This included personnel from the highest level of administration to entry level clerical positions.  They undertook this challenge with the goal of bringing Ivey Lane out of the “F” category.  Ivey Lane students adopted as their motto, “From Ivey Lane to Ivey League”. At the end of the school year, not only did Ivey Lane come out of the “F” category, they improved TWO letter grades to a “C”.  Most of these children come from low income families, many below poverty level.  Their parents were included in the process and were motivated just as the children.  They became an integral part of the solution.

 

This particular school has been blessed with a dynamic, highly motivated, selfless principal.  She has the ability to inspire the desire for success in all that she meets.  She challenges all to come on board and to become a part of the solution.  Dr. Baskerville, in turn, has been blessed with a very talented, compassionate staff who has taken to heart improving the educational status and the lives of these very special children.  These individuals have given of their personal time (evenings and weekends), resources, and hearts to help these kids.  The children have in turn responded with improved grades, and ultimately, the chance for brighter and more successful futures.

 

I would like to ask if there is a chance that you could acknowledge their hard work by awarding them a U.S. or a Florida flag that has flown over the State Capitol in Tallahassee that they could take pride in flying over their school as a daily symbol of their successful efforts?  I know that it would mean the world to them.  It would be immensely meaningful if you or Lt. Governor Jennings could present it to them in person during one of your scheduled visits to the Orlando area.  

 

These children and this dedicated staff of educators will strive to go forward in their quest to be the best that they can be.  I respectfully ask for your help in motivating them to reach for the stars in their educational journey.

 

Most sincerely,

Nancy Ballard

Human Service Counselor III

Orange County Public Health Unit

Orlando, Florida  32805

From:	Malcom Campbell <backroads@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 14, 2006 10:11 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	ILLEGAL Immigrants

 

“Attorney General Alberto Gonzales today has made a mockery of the millions  who have stood patiently in line waiting our turn, and endured the burdensome legal process to become a citizen. He is saying  today that all  who honored the rule of law are chumps, fools, losers—for faithfully showing their respect for America’s ordered liberty, and the rights and responsibilities of citizenship. 

“While the Attorney General is today advocating preferential amnesty to excuse millions of serious felonies committed by non-citizens, he is also ignoring gross violations of the law by the very agency he would entrust to police that amnesty. Attorney General Gonzales remains utterly neglectful of addressing the rampant corruption exposed by the United States Government Accountability Office (GAO) in its devastating report released March 14th of this year. The GAO charges the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)—the agency of the Department of Homeland Security that would oversee any guest worker amnesty program—with failed organizational infrastructure, and massive mismanagement and corruption. Yet the Attorney General wants to expand the duties and responsibilities of this organization to process millions more illegal intruders through the system. 

“This GAO report was commissioned by the U.S. Congress and it was part of an investigation that started immediately following the 9/11 terrorist attack. 

“Among the GAO's most alarming findings were that 33 percent of “religious worker” visas were issued fraudulently. The GAO documents evidence that radical Islamists, with ties to terrorist organizations, have used the religious worker visa category to gain admission to the United States. 

“The Copley News Service reported on March 7th, 2006, that ‘Michael Maxwell stepped down last month as Director of the Office of Security at U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, and sought protection under the federal whistle-blower protection law. He claims that senior agency officials had been retaliating against him for telling Congress about what he described as serious national security vulnerabilities that persisted despite his warnings to those running the agency.’ 

“In addition, Maxwell claims that the agency lacks the resources to handle some 500 allegations of criminal misconduct against agency employees, including allegations of espionage and acceptance of bribes. 

“The GAO report documents that immigration benefit fraud was pervasive and significant and the approach to controlling it was fragmented. In one of the largest labor—that means guest worker—certification fraud schemes ever uncovered by the GAO, federal investigators found evidence that a single prominent immigration attorney in the Washington, D.C., area submitted at least 1,436 and perhaps as many as 2,700 fraudulent employment applications between 1998 and 2002. 

“The GAO found that the USCIS is completely unprepared to handle their present 7.5 million case work load with their 3,000 employees. Few if any of the present 500 allegations of criminal misconduct against agency employees will ever be prosecuted. 

“And the GAO also conclusively found that the agency as it stands will be unable to handle the proposed guest worker amnesty proposals bandied about by the Bush administration, the Senate and now the nation’s premiere law enforcement officer. 

“Attorney General Gonzales would be well advised to focus his attention on his own back yard—clean up the rampant fraud and corruption in the USCIS—and prosecute those who have broken our laws in the immigration system before crossing the country with a charm offensive to promote mass amnesty. Amnesty places millions ahead of the REAL citizenship queue—the one that waits years and years OUTSIDE of the promised land of America. It is patently inequitable and unjust to reward those illegally jumping that line with “sweetheart citizenship” papers that lets them cut ahead of the law-abiding in becoming Americans. 

“These illegal migrants have not only broken laws including document fraud, identity theft and income tax evasion, but they have enjoyed the benefits of being in America years ahead of law-abiding applicants waiting for visas and earning citizenship as my wife and I did. The Attorney General has no moral ground to stand on to talk to me and millions more like me about American immigrant values, hard work, and fairness. Whatever happened to equity under the law?” 

[See Full GAO Report here: http://judiciary.house.gov/media/pdfs/gaoimmbenefits31006.pdf] 

STATEMENT OF AL GARZA ON ALBERTO GONZALES AMNESTY SPEECH 

SANTA CLARA, CA (July 21, 2006)—Al Garza, National Executive Director of the Minuteman Civil Defense Corps (“MCDC”), released the following statement at a press conference on Attorney General Alberto Gonzales’s pro-amnesty speech today in Santa Clara, California: 

“As this nation’s highest-ranking law enforcement officer, it is inexcusable that Attorney General Alberto Gonzales would promote a blanket amnesty for people who have committed such felonies as document fraud, identity theft and income tax evasion, and all based solely upon some special status that their illegal entrance into this country and their national origin has somehow allegedly conferred. Their very first act on American soil was to break federal law by entering this country illegally. 

“This selective amnesty being proposed by Attorney General Gonzales to excuse millions of NON-CITIZENS from their commission of serious felonies, while American CITIZENS continue to be held accountable under applicable statutes, is unconstitutional. Mr. Gonzales’ familiarity with 14th Amendment’s Equal Protection clause means he understands that point of law. There is no amnesty being offered to those American citizens who have committed document fraud, identity theft or income tax evasion—apparently only illegal border crossers. But Lady Justice is represented wearing a blindfold for a reason, and that reason is the equality of all persons before the law. 

“Furthermore, any proposal for amnesty in the guise of ‘guest worker permit path to citizenship’ is a national security risk that is already causing a human tsunami across our unsecured borders for those seeking to ‘get in under the wire.’ In some of the areas the Minuteman Civil Defense Corps has stood watch, the numbers of people crossing the borders illegally have increased tenfold since the talk of amnesty began last year. This wave of illegal migrants is exploiting the black market document underground in anticipation of new amnesty programs—and conceals in its sea of humanity all sorts of criminal and even terrorist elements. I am sure in these days of Middle Eastern violence, our wide-open borders are a fact that has not escaped the notice of Hezbollah, Lebanon, Syria and Iran. 

“The critical need is to secure this nation's borders with federal troops immediately. There is no conflict in doing so with the Posse Comitatus Act, as the war zone that is America’s southern frontier and the wide-open northern border do not represent a law enforcement matter—but a clear matter of national security. 

“Mexico’s government has created a majestic disconnect between the wealthy and the peasant by deliberate design. Their failure to organize, demand and promote fair and balanced economic and social opportunities has led to Mexican citizens fleeing their homeland for America by the millions. 

“With already overburdened public services, medical facilities, welfare programs, criminal incarcerations and public education systems, Attorney General Gonzales demands his fellow Americans ignore his direct assault on the rule of law and our national security, become complicit in Mexico’s degradation, and subsidize an unending flow of slave-wage labor into this country. Caesar Chavez had it right when he fought so hard to stop this exploitation. 

“We are a compassionate nation and believe in fairness, and in that fairness American citizens are first demanding enforcement of our laws. Illegal migrants should not be given preferential rights and liberties after knowingly committing felonies. Special treatment, in such a case, is simply unacceptable, with laws that apply only to some and not to others because they share an ethnicity with our Attorney General. 

“Neither should the poorest of the poor be enticed to come here illegally or legally to be exploited like pack-mules. We are a nation founded on human equality, not indentured servitude. The current ‘guest-worker’ proposals are an affront to American principles of social justice and the rights and duties of citizenship. 

“We have had promises of border security tied to amnesty after amnesty after amnesty. The American people no longer trust our government to secure the borders. Congress and the Bush administration first need to prove that they have competently secured our borders against foreign incursion and are protecting America’s security and sovereignty. Only then we will deliberate about what to do with those millions already here illegally.” 

 

Malcom & Judy Campbell

4196 Loury Drive

Zephyrhills, FL 33543

backroads@tampabay.rr.com

Sent:	Monday, August 14, 2006 10:08 PM
To:	Scott Aaronson (scott_aaronson@billnelson.senate.gov); Tracy Nagelbush (Davis); Adam Schmidt (young ld); Amie Woeber (ginnie brown-waite); Arthur Estopinan (Roslehtinen); Brittany Mcmaster (Ric Keller); Bryan Malenius (Keller); christy stefadouros (bilirakis); Craig Stevens (Allen Boyd); Dan McFaul (Miller); Dana Gartzke (Weldon); david goldenberg (hastings); Elby Godwin (j miller); Eric Johnson (Wexler); francis gibbs (mack LD); Fred Turner (Hastigs); Gary Burns (john mica); Gerald McSwiggan; Harry Glenn (Young); hector arguello (lincoln diaz-balart); ian rayder (wasserman-shultz); J Roe (Feeney); J.J. Subject:	DOT Office of Inspector General Update--Laptop Theft
Attachments:	Aug14064a.pdf

We wanted to provide you with an update (please see the attached word document) on the status of our investigation and follow-up activities regarding the recent theft in Miami of an Office of Inspector General (OIG) laptop computer that contained personally identifiable information (PII).    

We also wanted to give you a heads-up on something else we are doing.  Tonight we talked to reporters from the Miami Herald and the Washington Post about a second laptop that was stolen in April, 2006 at our 4th biennial fraud prevention conference in Orlando, Florida.  We told the reporters that we have broadened our investigation of the facts and circumstances surrounding the Miami loss to include this earlier theft of a laptop from another Miami-based OIG agent.  

That agent, who heads up our Miami office and was organizing this conference, reported that the laptop was stolen from a locked meeting room.  At the time, we understood that this laptop, which was password protected, contained conference-related power-point presentations and materials, all which were publicly releasable.  This occurred before the Department of Veterans Affairs incident raised awareness of the PII issue and, at the time, we treated this as a theft of property.  Notifications were made to local law enforcement and within OIG.  This was the first laptop ever reported stolen or missing from an OIG investigator.  (Note: Several years ago, one of our audit staff reported that a laptop was stolen from a hotel room.) 

In response to the loss of the Miami laptop and its PII, we decided to revisit this earlier theft.  We are in the process of more precisely determining what information was on the laptop stolen in Orlando.  We identified a back up of this laptop's hard drive and are currently performing an examination to determine what was on the laptop.  This analysis is ongoing and we will keep you informed and make any notifications, as appropriate, should we determine that the stolen laptop contained PII material.    

<<Aug14064a.pdf>> 

       CONGRESSIONAL UPDATE

August 14, 2006



Dear Members and staff of the Florida Delegation, other interested congressional committees, and Governor Bush: 

We are providing the following update on the Department of Transportation's Office of Inspector General activities regarding the reported theft of a laptop computer belonging to an OIG special agent in Miami, FL on July 27, 2006.


Response to Florida Members of Congress 
Letter to Acting Inspector General 

On August 11, 2006, 16 Members of the Florida congressional delegation sent a letter to the Acting Inspector General, expressing their concerns about the loss of personally identifiable information of Florida residents, especially in light of other recent data thefts at other Federal Agencies.  The Members requested a "detailed description of current procedures and protocol in handling this type of information and what steps and specific protocols are being implemented to ensure a massive breach does not occur again".

In response, the OIG is drafting a letter that will assure the Members that we will report to them the results of (1) our investigation of the incident, (2) our review of the adequacy of policies compared to existing requirements and whether our policies were appropriately followed, and (3) actions taken to strengthen our policies and controls to ensure that no similar incident can occur in the future.  We plan to enlist the help of an outside contractor with expertise in computer security and privacy requirements to assist in the review of our policies and the development of new policies, as appropriate.  We will also provide periodic progress updates to the Department and interested congressional staff.

Our current efforts are focused on: 

Recovery Efforts 

*       We have a team of approximately 15 investigators on the ground in Miami.  They are working with the Miami/Dade County police and other law enforcement agencies, which have provided important assistance in efforts to recover the stolen laptop. 

*       OIG investigators and local police have conducted more than 500 field interviews. 
*       We have handed out over 600 fliers announcing the reward for and providing a description of the laptop (including its serial number) to police stations, pawnshops, and used computer stores in the Miami area.

*       OIG investigators and local police have visited more than 350 pawnshops in the Dade County area. 
*       OIG investigators and local police visited 12 flea markets on Saturday, August 12th. 
*       We reviewed the stolen/recovered property inventories for 8 local police agencies in the area and the Florida Highway Patrol.

*       Via our website, we have directed victims to call our hotline to receive tips and advice on how to check their credit.  As of Monday morning, we had received a total of 311 calls.  Several calls provided tips which we have actively followed up on.  

*       We have offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the laptop's recovery and posted this on our website along with a description of the laptop and contact information.  


Public Outreach 

*       OIG has posted open letters on our website for Florida residents who had certain PII information contained on the laptop.  The letters are written in both English and Spanish.

*       We are mailing out personal letters to individuals beginning August 15th to notify them of this situation and provide information on actions that they can take to prevent identity theft.     

*       We have recommended that affected individuals: contact one of the three major credit reporting bureaus to request that an initial fraud alert be placed on their credit record (which entitles them to one free credit report form each company); monitor bank and credit card statements and contact financial institutions to check for any suspicious activity on their accounts; be vigilant to any phone calls, e-mails, and other communications from individuals purporting to be government officials and "phishing" for or asking to verify personal information.   

*       We are encouraging anyone who suspects they may be the victim of identify theft to contact our hotline (1-800-424-9071), 24 hours a day.

*       We are working with the General Services Administration and Department of Veterans Affairs to obtain information on credit monitoring services. 


OIG Actions 

*       Once we obtained confirmation that the stolen Miami laptop contained PII information, we began to undertake our own investigation to determine the facts and circumstances surrounding the loss of this laptop as well as what follow-up actions were taken.  We have two agents assigned full-time to this investigation.    

*       On August 3, OIG investigators agents were instructed not to leave government laptops unattended in their vehicles, even if the vehicle is locked. All electronic storage media must be kept out of site. Any loss of computers or electronic storage media must immediately be reported to OIG HQ management and information security staff.

*       On August 7, all OIG employees were instructed to remove all PII data from laptops and to ensure that all sensitive data is stored in encrypted folders. OIG managers are being directed to review the content of their employees' laptops and obtain a certification from each employee that their laptop does not contain PII.

*       On August 14, the Acting IG held an all employee web cast to reinforce these safeguards.  
*       All OIG employees must also re-certify that they have read and understand Departmental and OIG guidance on computer security.

*       Additional training for employees on Privacy Act requirements and computer security is being required for all OIG employees.  

*       Specific policies on PII are being established consistent with new DOT policies being issued in response to OMB's July 12, 2006 memorandum (M-06-19) directing Chief Information Officers to strengthen controls over PII data.



         

Brian A. Dettelbach 

Assistant Inspector General for

  Legal, Legislative and External Affairs 

Office of Inspector General 

U.S. Department of Transportation 

Phone:  (202) 366-8751 

Fax:      (202) 366-1975    

Email:  Brian.A.Dettelbach@oig.dot.gov

From: 	Lisa Shaw [mailto:lisashaw@myrapidsys.com] 
Sent:	Monday, August 14, 2006 8:43 PM
To:	Lisa Shaw CTM
Subject:	Help Stop The Problem - Two Colorado Sanctuaries Closing

Hi,
As you know the cats and other animals at Big Cat Rescue have become a very large and important part of my life.  As we know all too well, not every animal can be saved.  Unfortunately for the animals, there are sanctuaries that do try to say "yes" to every animal that is brought to their doors.  Unfortunately even more is that they cannot always continue to support themselves.  The attachments are about the two of the three sanctuaries that we have heard about that have to close for financial reasons.  These two sanctuaries (www.wildlife-sanctuary.org and www.deafpagan.org/pwar.html) that are closing represent 200 animals that face a very uncertain, probably dim, future.  Euthanasia may be the only answer as most sanctuaries such as Big Cat Rescue are full.

There is another sanctuary in Colorado (www.bigcatsofserenitysprings.org) that faces closing because it's founder, 47 year old Karen Sculac, died suddenly of pneumonia that developed from a strep throat.  Her sanctuary houses 105 big cats.  This brings the total of these three sanctuaries to over 300 animals in limbo.

These developments are heart wrenching and heart breaking and completely avoidable and can be rectified.  Many of these organizations are on very fragile ground.  With over 10,000 privately owned tigers alone owned in the United States the problem must be stopped at the source.

I don't expect you to try and help any of these places with funds.  What I would hope you would do is write your local representatives in both your state houses and at a federal level that the ban of exotic animal ownership must be put into place and soon.  These 300 animals did not ask to be born into captivity to be sold as disposable pets and certainly did not ask for the bleak fate that faces them.  Help us put an end to private ownership, backyard and basement breeders of these magnificent animals.

I would ask that you pass this message along to other animal lovers that you know.  A single voice can make a difference.

Thank you for the animals.
Lisa
