From:	Rovarose@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, August 14, 2006 5:16 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Breakthrough in early grade education

Dear Governor Bush,

I read your excellent article "How to Help our Kids" on line at the Washington Post website.

I would like to share with you the draft of an unpublishable meta-analysis we did on the Internet a few years ago.  It is the first time in a century the Maria Montessori's contention about the magical effects of giving children adequate practice in writing alphabet letters BEFORE they are old enough to enter first-grade.

The draft of our controlled study is appended.  I hope you will be able to find the time to glance over it, because it contains the secret of real educational reform.

Robert V. Rose, M.D. (retired)
Jasper, GA
Tele: 770-737-2503
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Here is an reedited copy of the article I submitted to the Harvard Educational Review.  

THE WRITING/READING CONNECTION
Submitted March 15, 2004

Abstract

The possible relationship between practice printing alphabet letters and learning to read in the earliest grades has not been adequately explored.  The present article describes preliminary evidence that this relationship may be important, and that reading difficulties may relate directly to inadequate printing practice in kindergarten and first-grade

Historically, many authorities on the subject of literacy instruction have stressed the importance of adequate practice in printing alphabet letters.  The first century Roman scholar Marcus Fabius Quintilianus (ca A.D. 35-98?) has been quoted as writing, "the art of writing well and quickly is not unimportant for our purpose, though it is generally disregarded by persons of quality.  Writing is of the utmost importance in the study which we have under consideration and by its means alone can true and deeply rooted proficiency be obtained." He also wrote, ",,,a sluggish pen delays our thoughts".
                 The full text of the Quintilianus essy, "The Ideal Education", book one, is  accessible at the website:            http://www.molloy.edu/academic/philosophy/sophia/quintilian/education.htm, The Sophia Project, Sophia Study Editions -- Quintilian, Institutes of Oratory, Translated by H.E. Butler (1920) "The Ideal Education, Book One, Chapter 1/sophia/quintilian/education.htm
             In 1912, Maria Montessori wrote, in effect, that teaching young children to print letters is easy, that it is easy to teach children to read after they have practiced printing alphabet letters, but that it is difficult to teach children to read if they have not practiced writing them. 1 
Marilyn Jager Adams noted that prior to the onset of the twentieth century the "spelling drill" was the principal means of inducing literacy for several millennia. 2 
More recently, several published authors have called attention to the dearth of research on the possible link between printing practice and the acquisition of literacy in young children, but objective studies of the relationship are still lacking.3, 4
This author has made the assumption that emphasis on practicing printing alphabet letters increases the fluency with which children can print them.   It was therefore decided to examine the relationship between fluency at printing the alphabet in preliterate children, and their subsequent success in learning to read well.
This method suffers the disadvantage of requiring children to be able to recite the alphabet in order to print the different letters both legibly and at a rate sufficient to demonstrate that they have practiced enough to have become "printing fluent."  However, it was considered superior to other methods of assessing fluency in printing alphabet letters in young children.
Such children have limited attention spans.   It was therefore decided to measure the number of alphabet letters children write during a timed twenty-second interval, and multiply that number by three in order to obtain a "letters-per-minute," or "LPM," value for each child.
During the early months of 2002, five first-grade teachers were enlisted from teacher-related internet listservs, to do a cooperative study of the relationship between fluency in writing the alphabet, and concomitant reading skill.
The printing rate of each child was listed by teachers submitting classroom data, and each was matched by the subjective teacher assessment of the child's relative reading skill.  The assessments were A, B, C, D and E, to designate "excellent", "above average", "average", "below average" and "possible reading problem", respectively.
A total of 94 children in five first-grade classrooms were studied.  When the letter grades were converted to numbers (4, 3, 2, 1, 0), "average relative reading ability" could be determined for subgroups of students, defined as printing at different rates.
Among the sixteen children who printed faster than 40 LPM, the average reading score was 3.6.  Among the 33 children who printed from 30 to 39 LPM, the average was 2.9.  For the 26 children writing at 20-29 LPM, it was 2.3.  For the 21 children who wrote more slowly than 20 LPM, it was 1.6.
During this current school year, a number of kindergarten teachers have submitted series of similar studies on their classrooms to the k1writing listserv, accessible at www.yahoogroups.com.  By the end of February, 2004, a total of five teachers had submitted serial data on a total of 106 kindergarten students, including data for the month of February.
The relative reading skills of the kindergartners were ranked according to a three-level system:  "reading better than grade level", "doing well at grade level" and "lagging behind expectations".  In the opinions of their teachers, six children were already reading at second-grade level or above.
Statistical analysis of the correlation again yielded similar results.  Among the eighteen children who printed the alphabet faster than 40 LPM, 72% were "above grade level," and only one was "lagging."  Among the eighteen children who wrote more slowly than 20 LPM, none was above grade level in reading skill, and half of them were "lagging" in this regard.
A tabulation of these findings is revealing.  It is informative to look down the column of LPM figures for these 106 children, and observe the correlations.  These data are presented in Table One.
The correlation between reading skill and fluency at printing alphabet letters in kindergarten and first-grade is readily apparent.  This correlation was known to each of the experienced [kindergarten] teachers participating in this study even before the study was done.  The experiment, then, was designed to answer the question as to whether this correlation is one of causation, or merely coincident with some other unidentified factor.
The kindergarten teachers involved have each been able to achieve a level of printing fluency that is considerably above what is generally achieved by American kindergarten students.  The printing rates of their kindergarten children are comparable to the rates of the first-grade students in the original study, whose teachers had NOT been previously monitoring printing rate.  If the cause of the correlation were in the opposite direction, and it is having learned to read which drives printing fluency, then one would expect the correlation to weaken in classrooms where printing fluency has been intentionally contrived.  However, we here see the correlation has persisted intact.
This year, each of the kindergarten teachers has been making a dedicated effort to induce objectively measurable printing fluency in the students as the school year progresses.  Each of the five kindergarten teachers has emphatically proclaimed that this practice is found to be immensely helpful in turning young children into readers.
A number of the classrooms have high percentages of poverty and minority children, and none of the children could read at the beginning of the kindergarten school year.  It was found that printing fluency, which we arbitrarily defined as 40 LPM or faster, is achieved at different times by different children, and that such fluency is an excellent indicator of when children will learn to read, as well as indicating which children have become successful at reading at any particular point in time.
It was also observed that printing fluency gradually improves in almost all cases with continued practice writing the alphabet letters.  Failure to cooperate during the time allocated by teachers for dedicated printing practice seems to be the main limiting factor in the development of printing skill.
None-the-less, our data suggest that fluency in writing the letters of the alphabet is a reasonable goal for all normal children by the end of first-grade.
But it appears that printing fluency does not at all correlate with reading ability much beyond the first-grade level.  One teacher submitted data on 54 fourth-graders, demonstrating no difference at all in the median alphabet-printing rates between children who had been formally identified as reading below grade level, and the other students.5
It is also apparent that printing skill is by no means a necessary prerequisite for literacy.  Many children learn to read before they are fluent at printing alphabet letters.  On the other hand, virtually all children who lag in reading skill in K-1 are dysfluent printers.  That this lack of skill is remediable through continued dedicated practice, extended over time, appears to be of fundamental importance.
If the attainment of fluent ability to print alphabet letters in the earliest grades generally assures early success in reading, this fact challenges some current theoretical conceptions regarding the nature of reading disabilities.  
     Our evidence suggests both that printing fluency confers the ability to name random letters more rapidly than 40 per minute6, and that the ability to phonetically write words fluently, possible only after the attainment of fluency in printing letters, confers phonemic awareness.
Adams wrote, "It has been shown that the act of writing newly learned words results in a significant strengthening of their perceptual integrity in recognition.  This is surely a factor underlying the documented advantages of programs that emphasize writing and spelling activities."7
Montessori also considered practice writing alphabet letters to be crucial, and wrote, "We shall soon see that the child, on hearing the word, or on thinking of a word he already knows, will see, in his mind's eye, all the letters, necessary to compose the word, arrange themselves.  He will reproduce this vision with a facility most surprising to us."8
While such rhetorical explanations of the value of writing practice have been seen as nebulous in the past, converging advances in the fields of pattern recognition by artificial intelligence and of the cerebral physiology involved in visual pattern recognition and categorization may render them more plausible.
It is emphasized that these studies are limited and preliminary, but their results underscore the pressing need to either confirm or disaffirm their apparent implications.
The author wishes to acknowledge the participation of the classroom teachers who did and submitted these comparison studies on their students.  They are Libby Rhoden, Pasadena, Texas;  Sue Fisher, Kailua Kona, Hawaii;  Ann Vasconcellos, Homewood, Illinois;  Helen Wilder, Middlesboro, Kentucky;  Nancy Creech, Eastpointe, Michigan;  Ruby Clayton, Indianapolis, Indiana;  Alice A. Pickel, Phoenix, Arizona;  Lori Jackson, Mission, South Dakota;  Lalia Kerr, Nova Scotia;  Jennifer Runkle, Ohio.

Dear Governor Bush,

6250 Sunset Drive, Suite 204    Miami, FL 33143

PH 786-662-5210   FX 786-662-5211

Email: info@melissainstitute.org

Websites:  www.melissainstitute.org     www.teachsafeschools.org 

 

SILENCE THE VIOLENCE

 

The Melissa Institute for Violence Prevention and Treatment requests your participation in an invitation-only symposium to address issues related to violence in our community.

 

Since April 5, 2006, the local media has clearly documented an outbreak of violence that has included more than a dozen homicides of children under the age of 17. When the statistics for Broward and Palm Beach County are added, it reflects the concern that exists in south Florida about the problem of violence in the community and how it might be addressed.

 

The symposium presenters and participants will examine the causes of violence. They will describe existing programs currently being offered in the community, and they will attempt to identify some "best practices" for reducing violence. The participants will then develop an advocacy agenda that is a listing of actions that can and should be taken to reduce violence in Miami.  That list will subsequently be shared with such agencies as local government, the school district, The Children’s Trust, health care providers, the judicial system and law enforcement agencies.

 

As a key stakeholder in the community we value your participation in this event.  Please note that there is no cost associated with this event.  Lunch will be provided courtesy of our local sponsors.  The keynote speaker will be Leonard Pitts, who will participate courtesy of the Miami Herald.

 

Silence the Violence

Community Advocacy Symposium

 

September 22, 2006

8:30 a.m.-3:00 p.m.

Baptist Children’s Hospital

(Auditorium-Third Floor)

8900 North Kendall Drive

Miami, FL  33176

 

Please RSVP your participation via return email or telephone (786-662-5210) by August 25, 2006.

Governor sir, 
 
    I am a 36 year old man that has had some problems with alcohol.  I had two DUI's before I was 18.  I had an accident on my 25th birthday where I hurt myself only and then went into the supervision program to get my license back 7 years later.  I cleaned up my act and I moved from  Panama City Beach while in the program to find a better life in Orlando, Florida.  I adhered to all policies for almost 3 years until one day after all of the money, time off work, and meetings I had done seemed to be for naught when I was told to go to yet another meeting every week because of the truthful answers I gave to my supervisors.  Things I said that about my life and jobs that were known for the whole 3 years and now I was subject to another group session once a week 20 miles through hectic Orlando traffic, which was scary in itself.  
    I was told to go to three AA meetings a week, once-a-month meeting at the Florida Safety Council and now while my life was balanced and moving along positively I was told to go to yet another meeting every Friday morning at a relapse treatment in Longwood.  It had the opposite effect.  They teach in AA that hunger and anger are two most dangerous feelings for relapse.  I feel the Florida Safety Council banked on this fact and tested me with the worse feeling I could get.  The feeling of the rug being yanked out from under me.  While I understand the need for governing the ungovernable I felt that I was set up for failure.  I did everything I was supposed to do and yes I felt the last straw, I was caught at a time where I had a wisdom tooth and no sleep and a past of alcohol abuse.  I had no fight left in me. I was told to show up at yet another meeting that would cost me 100 dollars a month in addition to the 55 to the supervision program and I had not given any reason for this, except I was nearing my termination of the program and I believe it was in their best interest to make one more hurdle for me to jump and yet fail.  
    I led a quiet life and I am an upbeat person all of the time. I try not to let anything get me down.  Of course I felt cheated and forced into a worsened state by the Florida Safety Council because of the time I needed off of work for all of the programs requirements and the money it costs. It is true I was arrested for DUI again, but had it not been for the excess of power over people that have none I do not believe this would have happened.  I have a nice life, a great relationship, and a great job with Disney.  I now have to look to other ways to work where there is no bus stop and while I hope not to end up on the streets, I feel that without a Drivers License that is where I will be, or in the Florida jails.   I was hoping not to have to abandon my home state, but maybe I should or have to.  My father worked for the City of Tallahassee where I was born, my uncle worked for the police of the Capitol of Florida, all of my family works in Tallahassee and I can not go see them unless I get a bus ticket.  This is my last effort to have a life in Florida to ask for a pardon to get my drivers license back.  While I am pretty sure you will not read this or get the gravity of the situation, it is my last effort to stay in Florida, my home, my families home, where I like to call home. 
 
Thank you for listening, 
 
Travis Donnell

Orlando, Florida 32821

Dear Govenor Bush:
 
I have been wanting to send this off to you for quite sometime, and now find that time is running short.  I just wanted to express my personal feelings toward you and your administration....I remember when I was 20 years old, and if our firstborn child was a girl, I was going to name her Regan after my hero, President Ronald Reagan.  The reason for this was that as a woman and mother I felt safe, at least as safe as one could feel in the 70's with the cold war.  President Regan was at the helm of our government, and the USA was in safe hands.  I knew no one would pull one off on Ronnie, at least if he knew about it.  He would keep his eye keen and would go toe-to-toe with opposition against right.
 
With you as Governor of Florida I have felt many similar feelings of stability knowing you were on watch for the State of Flolrida.  You calm, quiet leadership has brought our state back to its feet during hurricanes, I always felt you would do the "necessary" thing.  I greatly appreciated your visibility during crisis - always moving forward in a plan of defense or recovery.   In government, I always felt you would do the "right" thing.  I watched many difficult issues cross your desk and your gentle-giant presence was there to be firm and take action on issues of conscience.  As I watched you raise up against opposition in making our public schools better, I knew you would do the "smart" thing and raise the bar.  The number of students receiving high school degrees has increased and quality education has leaped.  You have challenged our teachers to meet the challenges of our day.  As many heart-wrenching events of children exploitation and murder have come to your attention you have done the "sympathetic" thing for the families and stengthened the hand of justice in determent and prosecution.  As a 49 year old gradmother, all the above mean more to me know than when I was a new mother of one.  Our President is right, there is much evil in this world.  We must not run from it, but we must do what is in our power to thwart it.  
 
Dear Governor Bush, I will miss your leadership for our state.  I thank you, your wife, and your children for the GREAT sacrifice in serving the people.  I know that I do not comprehend what public service really means, I only benefit from others unselfishness.  May God lead you and give your clarity of thought and direction during your transition and future.
 
With great appreciation,
 
Mrs. Laura L. Benigni

>From: Amy Sellers <amycsellers@yahoo.com>

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing on behalf of Tara Pascotto Paluck for Lee County Judge.  I have know Tara for nearly 20 years, having lived with her during our college years at the University of Notre Dame.  Tara is one of the hardest working people I know.  Her work ethic and enthusiasm are contagious.  Tara has always been involved in the service of others having served as class president of her high school, as student government representative in college and as a prosecutor.  Additionally, Tara is an individual of the highest moral character.  
 
Tara would serve the people of Lee County with sincere dedication and the highest moral integrity.  Thank you for your consideration of Tara Pascotto Paluck for Lee County Judge.
 
Sincerely,
Christine Stanford

Re: Clemency
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing today as his cousin to ask for clemency for James Steven Keller, DC # 114579.  He currently is incarcerated at Sumter Correctional Institute in Bushnell.  He is currently serving 20 years for vehicular homicide.  
 
I am the eldest and James is the youngest of 16 cousins.  He was born when I was 18.  This gives James and me a special bond.  I used to take care of him when he was a baby.  We all grew up in Bradenton.  There were always big family gatherings.  James was very close to our grandmother.  She died when he was very young.  The unfortunate thing is that when she died the big family gatherings went by the wayside and James was not able to cope well. 
 
I have been visiting James in the county jail before the trial and later in prison.  We have discussed the accident and all the ramifications.  James did not start out on 12/21/2000 to commit a violent act.  He made wrong choices in judgment that night that led to MR. Chris Kleuh being killed.  I have seen true changes in James since the accident.  He now understands he can never have alcohol or drugs again.  
 
I would appreciate your reviewing his case for consideration of clemency.  He has an exemplary deportment and work record since he has been in prison.  He currently works in the print shop, tool-room supervisory position.  
 
I thank you Governor Bush for your time and attention to this matter.
 
Sincerely:
Maureen Donohue

From:	David Boyd <ds.boyd@verizon.net>
Sent:	Sunday, August 13, 2006 10:07 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Hurricane Panels    Fire Danger

 
Dear Gov. Bush,
 
I have recently put hurricane panels on all openings of my home.  It gives me great concern that if during the short duration of having these panels on my home, in the event of a fire there is only one way out of the building.  This concern has forced me to devise a storm panel track that can be removed in seconds from the inside of the house, making the entire panel assembly to fall free from the outside wall and allowing the window to become a fire exit.
 
We are currently making a proto-type of this "Fire Trax" assembly, but as you can imagine the expence is quite high.  I feel that there are hundreds of thousands of Florida residents who currently have storm panels installed on their homes and many more who will be installing them in the near future.  I feel it is important to make this assembly available as soon as possible.
 
My question is to your knowledge is there any kind of grant money available for this type of program.  With a small amount of grant money I feel quite comfortable that this could be made available to the residents of Florida (and many other states) within several months.  Without any kind of help it could take us several years as at this time we are having to use very limited funds on this project.
 
Respectfully
 
David S. Boyd
6828 Ketona Road
North Port, Florida  34287
Home  941-423-7937
Cell  941-374-4136


 	
	
From:	M1TANK@aol.com

Subject:	state review required

maybe your office needs more on this, Cape Coral can't seem too
State audit findings on Cape utilities expansion
Originally posted on August 13, 2006

Stormsafe Shutters Web Bug from http://gcirm.news-press.com/RealMedia/ads/adstream_lx.ads/news.news-press.com/news/cape/index.html/[REDACTED]/300x250_1/OasDefault/002996/0000098582.gif/34303063373430623434646632396130?_RM_EMPTY_	

Here is a summary of the findings of the state1s operational audit of Cape
Coral's water, sewer and stormwater services between Oct. 1, 2000 and March
31, 2005:

§ Finding No. 1: The City had not maintained its accounting records on a
current basis, or periodically reviewed them for completeness and accuracy.
§Finding No. 2: Written policies and procedures necessary to assure the
efficient and consistent conduct of accounting and business-related functions were not established in all
cases. 

§Finding No. 3: The City had not provided for an adequate separation of
duties in certain areas of
operation, and had not provided for the proper safeguarding of blank checks.

§Finding No. 4: The City did not consider all available net assets from
prior fiscal years in adopting its
2003-04 or 2004-05 fiscal year budgets for the funds combined and reported
as Water and Sewer and
Stormwater Utility, contrary to Section 166.241(2), Florida Statutes.

§Finding No. 5: The City reported budget overexpenditures totaling
approximately $39 million in 7 of the
27 funds reported as Water and Sewer and Stormwater Utility, contrary to
Section 166.241(2), Florida
Statutes. Furthermore, budget-to-actual comparisons were provided to the
City Council only through
the 3rd quarter of the 2004 fiscal year.

§Finding No. 6: Bank reconciliations were not always performed timely, were
not adequately reviewed,
and contained errors.

§Finding No. 7: The City failed to timely report and remit unclaimed
property to the Florida Department
of Financial Services, contrary to Chapter 717, Florida Statutes.

§Finding No. 8: The City did not prepare a financial analysis, including a
calculation of the economic
gain or loss, prior to issuing refunding debt totaling $53 million.

§Finding No. 9: The City did not timely refund special assessments in
excess of project costs for three
completed utility expansion areas.

§Finding No. 10: The City's methodology for determining contributions in
aid of construction (CIAC)
fees may not appropriately match fees charged to actual costs incurred and,
as a result, may be subject
to challenge by property owners.

§Finding No. 11: The City does not have adequate controls in place to
ensure that CIAC fees are timely
collected. 

§Finding No. 12: City Council approved, via vote of City Council members
rather than enactment of an
ordinance, a change in CIAC fees established by ordinance, contrary to
Section 166.041, Florida Statutes.

Further, City staff's actions regarding CIAC and capital expansion fees
charged regarding the North
Loop CIAC project may have been contrary to the City Council1s intentions.

§Finding No. 13: Capital expansion fees and CIAC fees were not always
expended in accordance with the
City's Code of Ordinances and applicable case law.

§Finding No. 14: The City did not always charge utility users appropriate
fees or timely bill for services
rendered. 

§Finding No. 15: Costs for shared administrative expenses from departments
other than utilities were not
always allocated to the Water and Sewer Fund and Stormwater Fund in a
systematic and rational
manner. In addition, some costs directly charged from other departments
were not supported by
documentation to evidence the basis for the direct charge.

§Finding No. 16: Expenditures totaling $131,859 were not supported by
documentation demonstrating
the public purpose served.

§Finding No. 17: The City did not select its bond counsel through a
competitive selection process.

§Finding No. 18: The City did not have written agreements with several bond
professionals. 

Additionally, City practice and its procurement policies and procedures are
contrary to Section 2-148 of
the City's Code of Ordinances regarding required signatures on contracts.
§Finding No. 19: The City did not properly monitor contracts for services
to ensure contractors
performed in accordance with terms of the contract.

§Finding No. 20: The City did not fully comply with provisions of Section
287.055, Florida Statutes, in
procurement of its contract for its utility expansion program.

Additionally, invoices submitted for
payment by the contractor were not adequately supported. Finally, the
City's consultant hired to audit
selected work authorizations relating to its utility expansion program
included several findings and
made several recommendations.

§Finding No. 21: Although the City has taken some actions to reduce water
loss, unaccounted for water
remains in excess of 10 percent. Additionally, preliminary data from a
water audit obtained by the City
indicated several factors, including excessive service leaks, meter testing
and replacement, and
inconsistencies in meter size, that contributed to the City's unaccounted
for water. 

§Finding No. 22: Some of the City1s staff may have inappropriate access to
information technology
system resources. We also noted another deficiency in controls over the
City1s information systems.

§Finding No. 23: The City has not prepared and executed a lease agreement
for its charter school and
the frequency and timing of billings to the charter school for services
provided by the City were not
addressed in Ordinance 41-04.

§Finding No. 24: The City conducted discussions regarding the calculation
of the charter school lease
payments through a liaison rather than in a publicly noticed meeting.
Source: State Auditor General's office

From: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
To: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Sent: Saturday, August 12, 2006 11:55 AM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 11, 2006


> For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
> Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
> http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
> The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
> PROPERTY AND CASUALTY INSURANCE REFORM COMMITTEE HOLDS INAUGURAL MEETING
>
> On Tuesday, the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee held its
> first meeting in Tallahassee.  I recently created the committee to study
> proposals addressing the critical insurance challenges affecting Florida
> residents and businesses. Chaired by Lt. Governor Toni Jennings, the
> Committee will make recommendations to the President of the Senate,
Speaker
> of the House of Representatives and me to bolster the private insurance
> market in Florida.
>
>
> GOVERNOR BUSH ATTENDS A BRIEFING ON FLORIDA'S ELECTRONIC MEDICAL RECORDS
> INITIATIVE
>
> On Friday, I was joined by Agency for Healthcare Administration Secretary
> Christa Calamas and the Governor's Health Information Infrastructure
> Advisory Board for a briefing on Florida's Electronic Medical Records
> Initiative.  The advisory board incorporates the needs of patients and
> providers by leading the development of the Florida Health Information
> Network. The Network utilizes information technology to allow health care
> providers to share electronic medical records and other important
> information statewide to better care for Floridians.
>
> To date, three Regional Health Information Organizations in our state, the
> Big Bend, Tampa Bay and West Palm Beach, have received grants to fund
> development of regional information sharing systems.
>
>
> GOVERNOR BUSH PRESENTS POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD TO MARIE EGGERT
>
> Congratulations!
>
> To read more about this week's winner, please click here:
> http://www.flgov.com/release/8048
>
>
> GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES
>
> Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
>
> ____________________________________________________________________
> Volume 8, Issue 32
> Copyright(c) 2006 State of Florida
>
> If you would like to change your subscription or unsubscribe, please go
to:
> http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html
>
>
> Thank you.

From:	Michael Troutner <mj.troutner@verizon.net>
Sent:	Saturday, August 12, 2006 10:53 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Bad Rap for Florida
Attachments:	"AVG certification"




Dear Governor,

We are writing you over the onslaught of negative publicity for Florida as provided by the St. Pete Times and Tampa Bay television stations.  I know that other stations/newspapers are doing the same thing.

We are registered Republican voters.  We are upset over the way the media, on a daily basis, is pointing out to the world that Florida is not a good place to live.  For instance, today's St. Pete Times headline reads "Sunshine Won't Pay the Bills", referring to the high cost of living in Florida.  The article goes on to describe people leaving the state because they can't afford to live here.  Another article in the paper refers to the high cost for closing costs when buying a home as compares to other states, then there is another article about the high cost of insurance and the anticipated increases.  You add this to the media frenzy about hurricanes and no one wants to buy a home in Florida.  This is a HUGE economic problem!  When we were visiting friends in N.C. in June we saw a program on TV showing Clearwater Beach and hyping up the terrible hurricane season we are going to have.  Don't you have a marketing department that could work to overcome this negative publicity?


We have had our condo on the market to sell since last November.  Three other neighbors have had their units for sale longer than us.  It is not just our building....all of Clearwater Beach and Island Estates are having the same problem.  I am told by realtors that all of Tampa Bay is experiencing the same problem.


Please help us!
Mike and Jean Troutner

Dear Governor Bush:

As a member of the Emerald Coast Association of REALTORS and a resident of Northwest Florida, I am extremely concerned about the Air Force's proposed realignment of the 46th Test Wing and it's potentially devastating impact on our area.  Not only would we be dismantling a world class weapons and armament test capability, but the economic impact of losing over 1500 high tech jobs would have an extremely adverse impact on our local economy.  As a concerned citizen, I urge you to do everything in your power to influence the Air Force and Department of Defense officials to reconsider and ultimately not carry out this proposed realignment.

Rai Desgranges

Subject:	[*] 

 
GOVERNOR BUSH,
 
 
      A GREAT MISCARRIAGE OF JUSTICE IS TAKING PLACE, RIGHT UNDER YOUR NOSE. AS YOU KNOW, I'VE APPLIED AS CHAIR/MEMBER OF THE NEWLY FORMED FLORIDA COMMISSION FOR TRANSPORTATION DISADVANTAGED. HAVING SERVED ALMOST EIGHT YEARS ON THAT BOARD (W/2 TERMS AS VICE CHAIR). I THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A NATURAL TRANSITION. NOW GOING BACK TO THE FACT THAT THE COMMISSION IS BEING REFORMED (BY A BILL FROM SENATOR CONSTANTINE-ORLANDO, AND REPRESENTATIVE ROBAINA). INCIDENTALLY, I WAS TOLD I HAD THE SUPPORT OF BOTH GENTLEMEN (AS WELL AS MANY OTHER LEGISLATORS AND OTHERS) IN MY RE-APPOINTMENT. THEN LAST WEEK, WHEN I SPOKE TO YOU ON THE PHONE, WITH MY OPINION ON HOW SOME INDIVIDUALS SHOULD NOT BE CONSIDERED FOR MEMBERSHIP (AKA J.R. HARDING), BECAUSE HE WORKS FOR AN ORGANIZATION-DEPT. OF VOC. REHAB/EDUCATION, WHICH PURCHASES TRANSPORTATION. AT THAT TIME YOU INSTRUCTED ME TO SPEAK WITH APPOINTMENT HEAD CELESTE LEWIS, AFTER TRYING TO REACH HER A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO, I GOT A CALL FROM HER THURSDAY, SHE SAID THAT I HAD BEEN DISQUALIFIED FOR MEMBERSHIP BECAUSE I HAD BELONGED TO A TRANSPORTATION COMMITTEE LESS THAN 5-YEARS AGO, I WAS ON METRO PLAN-ORLANDO'S LOCAL COORDINATING BOARD (LCB), WHICH I LEFT 2 1/2 YEARS AGO. NOW WHEN THE BILL WAS BEING WRITTEN I SPECIFICALLY ASKED SENATOR CONSTANTINE ABOUT THIS LCB MEMBERSHIP DEAL, HE BASICALLY TOLD ME IT WOULD NOT PERTAIN TO ME BECAUSE I WAS A DISABLED PERSON W/NO FINANCIAL INTEREST IN TRANSPORTATION. THEN FRIDAY MS. LEWIS WROTE ME AN EMAIL SAYING I COULD NOT BE ON THE COMMISSION BECAUSE OF THE LCB-MEMBERSHIP THING. IN ALL MY 30-YEARS IN COMMUNITY SERVICE/DISABILITY AWARENESS, AND 25 YEARS INVOLVEMENT IN JOURNALISM I NEVER HEARD OF SUCH A DOUBLE STANDARD. I GUESS THE BIG QUESTION IS WHY AM I DISQUALIFIED FROM MEMBERSHIP, AND MR. HARDING IS NOT, PLEASE LET ME KNOW WHAT'S GOING ON, AND THANKS YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR TIME. 
 
SINCERELY,
TONY TIZZIO-407-461-7649

From:	Kim Durrell <kim@eaglelaw.com>
Sent:	Friday, August 11, 2006 1:55 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	State of Florida vs. David Allen Gore

Dear Mr. Bush,

 

            I am writing in regards to David Allen Gore who is currently on death row.  Mr. Gore was convicted of several murders 25 years ago in Vero Beach, Indian River County, Florida.  He has gone through several Appeals and has lost those appeals.  How much longer will it take before he gets what he deserves and what he was sentenced to?  THE DEATH PENALTY!  Not life in prison which is what he has been doing for the last 25 years by the expense of the Florida citizens.  His victims, didn’t get to live their lives, he ended those after hours and hours of torture.  His youngest victim, Lyn Elliott was a teenager.  He tortured these women, dismembered their bodies or buried them in drums in the middle of a citrus grove.  Miss Elliott, the young teen actually was tied up in his attic and got free.  Only to be caught running for freedom down his driveway and was shot in the back.   Mr. Gore was a reserve Law Enforcement officer for the Indian River County Sheriffs Department.  He used this capacity to lure women.  In other situations, he just kidnapped, raped, tortured and then killed them.  Dumping their bodies where ever he felt.  Why are the citizens of the State of Florida, including you, still paying for this evil devil?  I think as Governor its time for you to put your foot down and enforce the sentence imposed on this man.  

            I truly hope as Governor of the State of Florida, who has done an excellent job for several years would consider fulfilling this task prior to the end of your tenure.  

 

Thank you for your time and consideration in this case,

 

 

Kim Durrell

For Immediate Release                                                 Contact: June Minto
Wednesday, August 9, 2006                                         (954) 739-6618                                                                                               
 
 
COMMUNITY LEADERS UNITE FOR VOTER EDUCATION AND REGISTRATION DRIVE
 
(FT. LAUDERDALE) Local Caribbean radio station Mystik 1400, The Caribbean National Weekly and Café Calypso are hosting a Community Voters Education and Registration Drive Saturday, August 19th 1:00m-3:00pm at Café Calypso located at 6190 W. Oakland Park Blvd in the Inverrama Plaza. 
 
Broward County is home to a large and diverse population. Republican and Democratic leaders are uniting together to appeal to this growing community to participate during this current election season. 
 
The 2 hour live broadcast is hosted by author/radio host Andre Eggelletion, and Mystik’s on air personality Ron Burke. Confirmed to participate are Supervisor of Elections, Dr. Brenda Snipes, Broward County, Vice Mayor, Joe Eggelletion, Commissioners Levoyd Williams, Margaret Bates, Hazelle Rogers, Barrington Russell, Attorneys, Levy Williams, and Marlon Hill, Businessmen, Dr. Dorsey Miller, Art Kennedy, and Glenn Joseph, among others.
 
The Broward County Supervisor of Elections representatives will be on hand to register the public for the fall election.
 
For additional information contact June Minto (954) 739-6618.

From:	Sherry Popham <sherry@marathonboatyard.com>
Sent:	Friday, August 11, 2006 9:19 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; Senator Bill Nelson; Senator Mel Martinez; Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen
Cc:	Lundstrom-Tamara; David Rice
Subject:	[*] FL Keys Airport Initiative/Time Sensitive Request for Assistance

Importance:	High

FAX & Email 

 

 TO:                    Edmund “Kip” Hawley, Asst. Secretary


              Director, Transportation Security Administration


 FROM:               Florida Keys Airport Initiative, Inc. 

  RE:                   TSA Denial of Service for Marathon Airport, FL Keys

 

The Florida Keys Airport Initiative, Inc. is a Citizen’s group formed to raise financial and community support for bringing commercial air service back to the Middle Keys. Our organization, working cooperatively with County Government and our Community, actively participated in the successful process to obtain Federal funds to support this endeavor via the Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. In concert with this effort, we were able to raise more than $300,000 in donations and pledges from individuals and companies that recognized the tremendous economic impact of returning airline service to the community.  (The study conducted identified the potential for $43 Million  in revenue to the Middle Keys). Subsequently, we were able to secure commitments from two airlines willing to work with us to make this dream a reality.

 

It is our understanding that County staff has been dealing with TSA for many months now, receiving advice and instructions on facility requirements necessary to prepare for TSA’s provision of service at our facility. To our knowledge there has never been a mention that this would be an issue. Therefore, we are puzzled as to this late hour decision and further perplexed as to how and why one arm of the Federal Government would soundly support this project by way of the commitment of tax dollars while another, the TSA, would seemingly thwart the effort via this denial of service.  

 

We are urgently appealing to you to please do all that is in your power to reconsider and reverse this decision as soon as possible. Our window of opportunity is rapidly closing as the airlines have placed us on notice of their intent to withdraw unless this issue is promptly resolved. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.

 

In closing, in the letter from the TSA, a non-specific “lack of resources” was cited as the reason for this denial of service. We are pleading for the TSA to reverse this decision however, in the unfortunate event TSA chooses not to do so, we respectfully request a written explanation explicitly identifying the actual issues and any steps, as taxpayers, we may take to address them.  Though we are focused on our own dilemma at this time, the answer to this question has broad reaching implications for our and for many other communities who are seeking or have obtained Small Community Air Service Grants from the Federal Government. 

 

Thank you for your time and attention to this important matter.
 
Sherry Popham
Secretary, FKAI, Inc.
305.743.6341 Office
305.393.0657 Cell

From:	AliceSPrice@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, August 10, 2006 3:21 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	(no subject)

8/10/2006


Governor Jeb Bush
State of Florida
The Capitol, #LL08
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001
Fx: 850 487-0801
Email: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).

For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000. Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide sustained economic stability.

Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063. His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.

Name: Alice Price
Address: 108 Bimini Dr
City: Duck Key
Zip: 33050
State: FL

From:	stanngalloway@bellsouth.net
Sent:	Thursday, August 10, 2006 2:35 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Rural Employment
Attachments:	stann galloway.doc

Hello,

My name is Stann Galloway,  I am a life long Washington County Florida resident, tax Payer, and registered voter.  Recently my employer of 18+ years decided to move it's operations from Marianna. Florida to Ripon WI.  It goes without saying,  I had much rather remain in my home state.  My concern as well as others I'm sure, is the very long commute some us have to make outside of our home counties in order to obtain gainful employment. I try to spend as much of my money in my home county as possible but let's face it, you tend to spend money in the area you work.  This has to hurt the county's economy.   I fully understand that Washington county is a rural county and that the top jobs are in larger areas.  It appears to me and several others that our county leaders should and could do more to lure more jobs to our area.  the major problem is that, our county leaders are many times business owners themselves.  Making them afraid to bring business into the area.

I currently commute over 50 miles one way and 3 counties away just to earn a modest living.  I am too aware that mine is not an isolated case.  My request to you and our government officials is to please do everything possible to lure employers to these small counties.  There must be something we can do.  I am more than willing to do my part.

I have attached my resume in hopes that you are who ever reads your e-mails may know of a position in Washington County that may help.

Thank you very much for your time,

Stann Galloway
PO Box 743
Vernon, Fl 32462

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency.   The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).

 

For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.  Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide sustained economic stability. 

 

Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.

 

                                                            Respectfully,

From:	Anita <richnels@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, August 10, 2006 1:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Against recent TSA decision to not supply baggage checkers to Marathon, FL airport

Hon. Governor Bush:
 
We are very distressed at the recent decision by the Transportation Security Administration to not provide security screeners (baggage checkers) for the Marathon, Florida Keys, airport. 
 
After several years of not having major commercial airline service into our airport, the community and Federal agencies have been collaborating to get service started, including mandated improvements to the airport to meet Homeland Security's - and the TSA's - requirements. $300,000 in local pledges were secured to guarantee the airlines' financial viability, which was to be matched by Federal grants. About $3 million+ in additional money was obtained for the project. Delta/Continental and Gulfstream Airlines agreed to initiate the routes, and were to begin service in the fall. The service to our city would complement the only other viable airport in the Keys (Monroe County), that in Key West, which is under reconstruction but has effectively reached capacity. It is estimated that enhanced commercial service to our airport would equate to tens of millions of dollars in revenue to our county. 
 
Then, a few days ago, after having consulted with the county and city for some time - and being well aware of the airport project - the TSA stated that baggage checkers could not be provided. The airlines immediately moved to cancel their contracts.
 
The TSA's contention that airlines could direct travelers to "unsecure" sections of Atlanta's - and other - airports, is, according to the airlines, not feasible. (Understandable, since travelers trying to make connections would not be inclined to go and get their bags, exit the "unsecure" area, and go through security again to check their bags.)
 
We can only conclude that there has been a "disconnect," where one branch (or in this case, department) of a government agency does not know what another has been trying to accomplish. If it is in your power to effect a reversal of this decision, middle Florida Keys residents will be eternally grateful.
 
Thank you for listening.
 
Sincerely,
 
Richard and Anita Nelson
Marathon, Florida Keys

This team addresses and advises on issues pertaining to HUD Housing related issues. Attached you will also find a "who we are and what we do" document that generally explains our agency services and programs. Please have your daughter submit an intake online or contact me directly at 1-800-342-0823 ext 336 to see if we can assist in this regard.
Paul J. Finch,BSW,CIRS

From: MBelleRN@aol.com [mailto:MBelleRN@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, July 26, 2006 2:56 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: HUD -regulated apartments



Can you tell me why my daughter, who is recognized as handicapped by the state must pay more for a first floor apartment in a HUD -regulated complex? She has applied for an apartment at Nantucket Cove, in Hernando county and was accepted, but they told her she would have to take a second-floor apartment unless she could prove $400 more income per month somehow. This makes absolutely no sense to me. I am hoping she can get into a first floor  place, as going up and down 15 stairs would be a great hardship for her. Of course there is no elevator.
 
Thank you for your attention to this most urgent matter. No one with physical handicaps should be put in this position. I am a registered nurse and realize full well how difficult being on the second floor would make her life.
 
                                                        Sincerely, Marybelle C. De Wandler

Subject:	Lee County Judge- Tara Paluck

Dear Governor Bush,
 
This email is to express my support for nominee Tara Paluck for Lee County Judge.
 
I have known Ms Paluck since she began practicing law here in 1994.  We have had many cases in which she represented one party and I represented either the adversary or a co-defendant.  I have also had the opportunity to observe her interact with her clients when I have mediated cases in which she has been involved.
 
Her knowledge of the law and case preparation has always been excellent.  She also displays a nice balance between advocacy and respect for her opposition.
 
I think Tara's mix of a solid work ethic and respect for the legal system would make her an excellent appointment to the bench.  
 
Please give Tara Paluck serious consideration for County Court.  Lee County would be well served to have Tara on the bench.
 
Steven Gautier Koeppel

Email:  jeb.bush@myflorida.com 

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency.   The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).

 

For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.  Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide sustained economic stability. 

 

Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.

 

                                                            Respectfully,

 

                                                            Gail Cortelyou

    `                                                       Glenda Keach
                                                            PO Box 510612
                                                            Key Colony Beach, FL 33051-0612

                                                            Phone/Fax 305-289-1295

Louise Chapman

Dear Governor Bush:

 

On September 10, 2006 Boca Raton Community Church will be conducting a “Celebration of Dedication” service to dedicate a significant renovation and expansion of the church’s facilities here in downtown Boca Raton.  We would like to invite you to attend and be a part of this significant moment in our Church’s life.  

 

If your schedule doesn’t allow, we would certainly understand and would ask that you consider sending a congratulatory letter that we would read as part of our ceremony.   We have taken the liberty of drafting the enclosed letter for your consideration.  Should you wish to send a similar but differently worded letter, please feel free.  The attached draft is provided to try and save your staff from crafting such a letter from scratch!  

 

The 50 year old Boca Raton Community Church with a membership of nearly 2,000 is not only historically significant but is also a present and growing part of the Boca Raton community.   We have historically been a winter bible conference location, where Billy Graham and many other renowned evangelists have spoken, and large portions of the modern New International Version or “NIV” Bible were translated.  Today we believe we are being called to expand our reach by replicating our church in locations throughout the world.   

 

Again, we would love to have you attend and participate in our dedication service.  If however you cannot, we would hope that you could provide the attached or similar letter on your office stationary before the event so we might be able to include it in our “Program of Dedication”.  We thank you for your consideration, and wish you all the best in the remainder of your term and in all of your future endeavors.  

 

God bless you,

 

Dr. John R. Strubhar

Executive Pastor

Boca Raton Community Church

470 NW 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL  33432

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency.   The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).
 
For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.  Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide sustained economic stability. 
 
Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.
 
     Respectfully,
     Peter F. & Sharon E. Johnson

Hi, I would like to know why Sheriff Mascara of St. Lucie County is allowed to get away with things that seem shady. One of these is his dealings with Aramark. He allowed this corp. to take over the kitchen (Meals) and canteen of the jail in Sept of 2004. I was incarcerated at the time and a group of us sued him and Aramark around April of 2005. A contract was not signed between them until April of 2005!!!  Allowing them free rein for around 6 months, and they only signed a contract AFTER we sued them. NOW, guess who was a big contributor to his golf tournament, you guessed it, ARAMARK!!!
 
He is also allowing ARAMARK to take out the subsistence fees from inmate’s canteen accounts. According to Florida law, this has to be given back to inmates that are found not guilty as I was. It is also supposed to go through the Clerk of Court according to the documentation I have read. They are NOT doing this and go out of their way to keep from giving this money back. I believe that Sheriff Mascara and ARAMARKS dealings should be investigated fully. I intend to keep sending this to every governmental agency including Congress, Senate, House of Representatives, County Commissioners, ETC until I get an answer as to why this has not been looked into by Someone. I hope you are able to check this atrocity out and if there is in fact wrongdoing, Take action as they did with the head of DOC.

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency.   The Transportation 
Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not 
going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida 
Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).

For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working 
extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study 
was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small 
Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The 
local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. 
The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying 
the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development 
Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide 
advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of 
Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.  
Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last 
and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle 
and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study 
completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon 
Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. 
These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide 
sustained economic stability.

Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince 
the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is

292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is:

From:	Farnell Cole <fcole01@alltel.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 9, 2006 7:06 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Special Appointed, Interim Sheriff for Alachua County

Dear Governor Bush,

I first must say thank you to you, your brother and your father, for serving us all so well, during what has proven to be some of America's most trying hours. I can only hope that we as a country can stay the course in the future, find others like you who will stand firm and do the right thing, so as not to loose any of the hard fought progress that the shed blood of Americans helped pay for.

I know you don't know me from Adam, but I have had the great honor voting for you twice, and of actually shaking your hand several years ago at a Police Memorial Service there at the Capital. And I proudly helped provide security for President George Bush while he campaigned in Gainesville, just before his victory during the last presidential election. I feel I know what you stand for, making this request much easier to ask, of such an important man as yourself, so here goes.

As I said before, you don't know me, but I am a career Law Enforcement Officer who was born and raised in North Central Florida. My father proudly served as a Law Enforcement Officer before me, starting from the time of his return from World War Two, and lasting until his retirement in 1978. I myself have now served more than thirty years, with 28 of those having been as a Deputy Sheriff at the Alachua County Sheriff's Office in Gainesville. I will be retiring in June of 2007, and so I know what pride, commitment and a life of public service really means. I am writing you today with a very special request, a request that when an appointment is made for the interim Sheriff for Alachua County, that retired Sheriff's Captain J.M. "Buddy" Crevasse be the one you choose to place in that position. Knowing that this appointment will only be for the brief period between the departure of Sheriff Steve Oelrich, and the election of a new Sheriff in November. My request is even more special than had it been for a longer term of office, as some people would believe that it really matters little who you appoint, I firmly disagree with that sentiment, for the reasons I write below. 

Buddy Crevasse, like myself had a great role model, both of which made tremendous sacrifices over the years, often going in harms way to protect the  citizens of Alachua County. Buddy, is the son of Retired Sheriff J. M. "Joe" Crevasse and was practically raised up at the Sheriff's Office in Gainesville. While being exposed to both the good and the bad elements of society by that experience and having so many heroes around him at such an early age, Buddy followed in his dad's foot steps, to become a Deputy Sheriff himself, progressing to the rank of Captain within the Alachua County Sheriff's Office before his retirement. 

My request is all about pride and honor, not self satisfaction or political gain. Over the years I have worked along side of Buddy, and I have grown to know him as a close friend. In talking to him, I know what a proud day it would be to become Sheriff and fulfill a lifelong dream to follow his dad into that office. I know from talking to him that even more than self-satisfaction, he would give anything to be able to honor his dad, by standing beside him, while being sworn in as a Sheriff. I'm sure the pride your Father, President Bush felt as your brother followed him into that esteemed office was much the same that father and son, if given the opportunity, would experience here as well.

My father had the great pleasure of working for both Sheriff Joe Crevasse  as well as with "Buddy", and he always spoke highly of their integrity and their caring ways, before his death. I was never fortunate enough to work directly for Sheriff Crevasse, but I did work for Buddy for many years, and can only echo what my father had told me of his virtues.  He worked his way up from an impressionable kid that hung around the old jail, to a highly respected professional who always tried to honor his father's legacy by doing the right thing as a Deputy Sheriff.

Governor Bush, I know you to are a very busy man, but I also know you are a just and honorable man who owes a great deal to your dad and one who holds him in very high esteem, just as both Buddy and I do our fathers. So please consider this request as it was intended, a chance to achieve something few others will ever be allowed to do. Buddy has already proven himself as a great Lawman, so why not reward him with this position as the crowning moment in his stellar career? He is more than adequately qualified, and very deserving, so I hope you will agree with me, and that you will grant my request.

 

Thank you sir, for your time and consideration,

 your humble servant,

Deputy Farnell Cole

 

 

From:	Chris Hahn <rchahn@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 9, 2006 6:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Cecil Commmerce Center

The Honorable Jeb Bush,

 

I saw today that the City of Jacksonville has filed suit to block the placing on the ballot of the Cecil Field return to flight initiative. I have some thoughts that I’d like to share.

 

The voters of Duval County worked very hard to get enough signatures to place this on the ballot. It seems to me that  this would have a major impact on the surrounding counties as well as the entire state. The State of Florida should step in and see this issue remains on the ballot. The financial gain to the state could be enormous. If Cecil Field were to reopen as a military facility: 1. There would be immediate incentive to make Mayport nuclear capable… the majority of a carrier’s squadrons could be locally based therefore saving more money. 2. NADEP Jacksonville would be an even more attractive site for repairs… closer to the squadrons it serves. For that matter… Cecil would be an even better place to build a modern depot maintenance facility… right where they are based. 3. We can’t forget that the decommissioning of the S-3 squadrons and then the P-3 squadrons at NAS Jacksonville are coming and then what are we left with? If push comes to shove why can’t an offer for the exchange be made for the prime riverfront property of NAS Jacksonville for Cecil Commerce Center? It was a major mistake to let Cecil go in the first place… we can’t afford to make that mistake again. Florida… not just Duval County needs Cecil Field re-opened. The bottom line… Florida needs Cecil and the good things it would bring.

 

Sincerely,

 

R. C. Hahn

Orange Park

Subject:	TSA/Marathon, FL airport

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has recently refused  
funding the necessary security for opening the Marathon, FL airport  
for commercial travel. This follows years of planning and a grant of  
$1.5 million from the FAA to ready the airport. Don't these two  
government agencies communicate?

We were eagerly planning to use the Marathon airport as a new  
departure point for a trip in November. Just as we were ready to make  
the reservations, we read of the TSA refusal. This small amount of  
money requested from the TSA/ Homeland Security budget is  
insignificant in comparison to the money squandered illegally by FEMA  
in New Orleans.

Flights in and out of Key West are limited and often are not  
available.  Commercial flights at Marathon would alleviate  
reservation difficulties for Keys residents and visitors.

Please reconsider and provide the TSA funding for security measures  
at the Marathon, FL airport.   Thank you.

Theresa Raven and Daniel Fitch
Big Pine Key, FL

Dear Governor Bush

My name is Juan M. Ortiz and I live in Pinecrest, Florida 33156.  I am

to double given the hurricanes we have experienced in the last two
years.  I was not prepared to get an invoice equal to 4.3 times my
2005/2006 premium with less than 60 days notice.

My recent invoice from HomeWise Insurance, which assumed my policy
from Citizens Property Insurance in January 2006, is charging me
$12,432 for windstorm coverage for the policy year 2006/2007.  My
premium for 2005/2006 under the Citizens policy was approximately
$2,900.   Given the lack of insurers underwriting risk in Florida I
have little choice but to stay with HomeWise.

This is a travesty that I hope you will address through a special
session as soon as possible.  I cannot believe that the Florida
Legislature had this result in mind when it came up with solutions to
the Citizens dilemma.

I look forward to hearing from you.

Juan M. Ortiz

From:	Audrey Moir, Executive Director <execdir@floridakeysmarathon.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 9, 2006 1:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Marathon Florida Airport

 
 
 
 
August 7, 2006
 
 
Governor Jeb Bush
State of Florida
The Capitol, #LL08
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001
Fx:  850 487-0801
Email:  jeb.bush@myflorida.com 
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency.   The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has notified Monroe County that they are not going to support the County’s effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).
 
For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. Monroe County applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.  Our region was very severely impacted by four hurricanes last year. The last and most catastrophic was Wilma in October of 2005 that flooded the middle and lower keys with six feet of storm surge. Our economic impact study completed last year, states that air service into the Florida Keys Marathon Airport will provide $43.7 million in annual revenue to the Florida Keys. These funds are now desperately needed to hasten our recovery and provide sustained economic stability. 
 
Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. If further information is needed, please contact our Director of Airports, Mr. Peter Horton at (305) 292-3518 or on his cell phone (305) 304-0063.  His email address is: horton-peter@monroecounty-fl.gov.
 
                                                            Respectfully,
 
 
 
                                                            Audrey Moir,
                                                                  Executive Director
                                                            Greater Marathon Chamber of Commerce

Subject:	URGENT: FROM DOT OIG-NOTICE of LAPTOP STOLEN CONTANING PERSONAL INFORMATION- PHONE BRIEFING AT 2:30
Attachments:	TZAug906FINAL.pdf; TZGovBushAug906.pdf

Importance:	High

We are writing to the Florida congressional delegation, our other oversight committee chairs and ranking members, and Governor Bush to inform them of a laptop stolen from an employee's GOV car in Miami, FL that contains multiple databases of personally-identifiable information (PII) of certain Florida residents.  We have notified the FBI and are working with the Miami-Dade Police Department in an intensive effort to recover the laptop.  We are still reviewing a backup of the computer's hard drive to determine what other information may be contained on the laptop. We will be notifying the affected individuals, maintaining a 24/7 hour hotline, and offering a reward for information leading to the recovery of the laptop. 

In order to inform everyone at the same time, we are establishing a conference call briefing with Todd Zinser, Acting IG, at 2:30 p.m. TODAY, August 9th.  In order to access the briefing, please call 888-566-5791 shortly before that time.  The passcode is 5873283 (followed by the # sign).  If you have technical difficulties, please call (202) 366-1959.  Thank you.

Dear Governor Bush:

My name is Constance White-Davis, and I am the Principal of Alta Vista Elementary School in Sarasota, Florida.  

In 1999, our school received a school grade of "D."  For the past three years, we have maintained our school grade of "A," and this past year for the first time, Alta Vista Elementary has met the federal guidelines of No Child Left Behind and achieved Adequate Yearly Progress.  I also wish to inform you that we are a Reading First School and have made remarkable progress.  For the second year in a row, Alta Vista has made the most reading gains (77%) with our lowest 25th percentile.

I had the opportunity to hear you speak at the Just Read Florida Conference this past July in Orlando.  My Reading Coach and I were also presenters at the conference whereby we had the opportunity to share our story of the challenges and success of moving from a "D" to an "A" and making "AYP." From:	Glenn Bond <gabond@comcast.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 8, 2006 7:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Charlotte County Commissioner Seat

  

Dear Governor Bush:

 

 

I respectfully request to be considered for the now vacant Charlotte County District 5 commission seat.  I have been a resident of Florida for thirty two years and have served my communities as an employee of the Public Works Department in Manatee County for thirteen years and here in Charlotte County for eight years.  I am a stable man not given to moving around on a whim and love the area I live in.  I am residing within the boundaries of Charlotte County Commission District 5.   

 

Being involved in County Government for the past years I have an understanding of the County Government System and how the County Works.  I have been recently applauded for my foresight in recognizing this opportunity and coordination with the Department of Transportation to help the expansion of the County’s fiber optic communications infrastructure at a considerable cost savings to the County.   I have exemplary performance reviews and consider myself to be a valuable member of the team that is Charlotte County Government.  I have the ability to understand complex concepts and communicate them to the audience I have in front of me.  I have experience in public speaking, having been given the task on many occasions to address groups of citizens, co workers and my contemporaries in other government positions.  I have first hand experience at disaster response, managing the contractors and my staff through the difficult times following Hurricane Charley. 

 

While I have dealt with local business men, community leaders, Florida Department of Transportation officials and developers, my ties are to the working people in Charlotte County, and it those citizens I seek to serve.  I am considered to be honest, forthright and not given to extremes.  I am an avid fisherman and consider myself a steward of the environment but not at the expense of common sense.  

 

In short, while I don’t have the political experience of some of the other candidates you may be considering, that alone could be an asset; I am not tied to any organizations or corporations and consider myself to be a person of principle.  Please consider my request, 

 

 

I remain at your service:

 

Glenn A. Bond

1293 Mohawk Drive 

Port Charlotte, Florida 33952
