From: jeb.bush@myflorida.com [mailto:jeb.bush@myflorida.com]
Sent: Fri 5/12/2006 9:42 AM
To: Carlson, Susan L; Scarborough, Truman G
Subject: The Need for Better Disposal of "e-waste"



http://newstandardnews.net/content/index.cfm/items/3154

A number of toxic substances are used in of electronics, from the liquid
crystal displays on cell phones to the circuit boards inside computers. The
lead, used in glass panels of computer monitors, in soldering of printed
circuit boards and in cell phones, can leach from landfills and contaminate
drinking water. In addition to negatively affecting brain development in
children, the toxin can cause nervous- and blood-system damage as well as
kidney problems. Lead constitutes more than half of the 70 percent of
consumer electronics contribution of heavy-metal waste in US landfills.

Cadmium, another toxin that damages the kidneys, is used in computer-chip
resistors, semiconductors and cell phones'circuitry, batteries and liquid
crystal displays. Mercury, used in circuit boards, medical equipment and cell
phones, can accumulate in people, animals and plants, leading to brain
damage. And brominated flame retardants (BFRs), used in the plastic casings
of computers, televisions and cell phones, increase risk of cancer.

Chad Raphael, professor at Santa Clara University and chair of the Silicon
Valley Toxics Coalition (SVTC), said "We have to stop sweeping our toxic
trash under other people's rugs."

Westervelt said that with municipalities scrambling to keep the
electronic-waste stream out of landfills, local officials are concerned that
if they charge to recycle toxic electronics, consumers will illegally dump
the materials or continue to store them in their homes and businesses.
"I talk with hundreds of recyclers around this country and they all say the
same thing -which is you cannot responsibly process this waste stream without
charging or without having some sort of revenue coming in," said Westervelt,
adding that it costs between $10 to $30 to properly recycle each computer or
TV.

In the absence of federal leadership on e-waste, states are passing their own
laws, which discourages recyclers from creating a national electronic
recycling system.

However, local store outlets of national chains can be required to set up
"drop off" points for the manufacturers of the equipment they sell, to be
returned in bulk to the manufacturer for safe disassembly, recycling, and
disposal.

From:	Chris Bull <bullc@ci.marathon.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 8, 2006 12:32 PM
To:	jeb@jeb.org; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	06Aug05Letter to get TSA in our airports
Attachments:	TSA July 2006.pdf; DELTA LETTER REF TSA MTH.pdf

 City of Marathon, Florida

Office of Mayor Chris Bull

10045-55 Overseas Highway, Marathon, Florida  33050

(305) 731-3082  Fax (305) 743-3388  bullc@ci.marathon.fl.us

 

 

 

August 5, 2006

 

Dear Governor Jeb Bush:

 

I am writing you today on a matter of extreme urgency. Attached is a letter from the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) informing us that they are not going to support our effort to bring air service to the Florida Keys Marathon Airport (MTH).

 

For more than a year, the citizens of Monroe County have been working extremely hard to return air service to the Middle Keys. A feasibility study was conducted. We applied for and received a $750,000 Small Community Air Service Grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation. The local community raised more than $300,000 in matching funds for the grant. The City of Marathon has donated $200,000 of in kind services by supplying the Airport Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF) function. The Tourist Development Council has pledged $600,000 over the course of three years to provide advertising of the new air service. And the Florida Department of Transportation will supplement airport security with a grant for $550,000.

 

We have negotiated and signed contracts with Delta Airlines and Gulfstream International (The Continental Connection). However as you can see from the attached letter from Delta, all of our efforts will be wasted unless TSA is there to provide screening of passengers and baggage.

 

Gulfstream has also told us verbally with a letter soon to follow, that operating out of MTH without TSA screening is not feasible. The urgency of this appeal is that air service is set to begin on October 29, 2006. Flights to and from MTH have already been scheduled and booked. Mr. David Hackett, the President of Gulfstream International has told us that unless the TSA’s decision is reversed by August 13th, he will be forced to cancel all bookings for MTH and reassign the aircraft to other locations.

 

Please do all that is in your power to intervene on our behalf to convince the TSA to reverse their disastrous decision. Commercial airline service is vital to our economy here and there is tremendous public outcry to make this happen.  Your help is greatly appreciated.

 

Sincerely,

 

Chris Bull

Mayor, City of Marathon

From:	Joe Carroll <Decalman@valp.net>
Sent:	Monday, August 7, 2006 9:10 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Personnel cuts at Eglin AFB

Sir;

 

Today, most if not all workers on Eglin AFB received an e-mail from Eglin's commanding general.  This e-mail stated that 340 positions both military and civilian would be eliminated by 31 Dec 2006.  This action is authorized by PBD-720 according to the general.  He also states that this has nothing to do with the previous attempt to gut the 46th Test Wing.  It would appear to most workers that there is an on-going attempt to draw down Eglin's ability to provide the testing facilities and personnel necessary to test the new generation of smart weapons.  Senators Martinez and Nelson, and others, sponsored/wrote legislation for a through investigation on costs and effects prior to any restructuring or personnel cuts at military bases.  Is this proposal in defiance of that legislation?   If this type of action is so necessary why wasn't it included in the BRAC 2005 committee's findings?  

 

I am a 20 plus year retired U.S. Air Force veteran.  I have been retired 15 plus years and worked for the Operations and Maintenance (O & M) contractor for that entire time.  As a retired USAF E-6, my retired pay dictates that I must work a second career.  If Eglin AFB and 46th Test Wing are reduced to the point that the O & M contract is no longer required, where will the support personnel find employment that is comparable to the current salaries.  There aren't any in the local area that compare.  

 

This is my opinion and my opinion only, that the Air Force has plans to gut, cut and downsize Eglin to the point where it should be closed.  That is just my opinion.  Most of our workers have worked for the O & M contractor for many many years, some as long as 45 years plus.  There doesn't seem to be any concern that this is our lively hood.  We do not have the comfort of that 15th and 1st of the month check being there as do the military members.  Nor do we have the placement options that most civil servants will have.  We most certainly will be paying our own way if we have to move to another location, the military members do not have this worry of moving to another job.  I've been there as a military member (PCSing) and the movers took care of most of everything.  It does not work that way when a contractor loses his/hers job and has to relocate.  

 

We have all types of problems that our current leaders are working on.  Iraq, Lebanon, Israel, North Korea, Afghanistan and Iran, just to name a few.  Budget cuts are inevitable with the on-going war on terrorism, but it is time to bring our troops home from Iraq.   Let's use the money this war is costing to protect our borders, our people, correct the immigration problems and protect our jobs here at home.   

 

Please have your team investigate the proposed cuts to Eglin AFB's workforce.  Our future, and our future weapons, depends on Eglin AFB and the 46th Test Wing staying strong and open.

 

Joe Carroll

Valparaiso, Florida

850-729-3994

850-865-3691

From:	Angelica Steinker <Angelica@CourteousCanine.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 7, 2006 8:40 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	small business crushed by zoning laws

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am writing to you to request an appointment to discuss the fact that zoning and code county regulations are crushing small business in Hillsborough County, FL and statewide.  

 

I have operated a dog school in Lutz, Florida for ten years.  After moving to our most recent new location, address below, I learned that zoning laws had changed. I was asked to provide a map to the county drawn by a certified Florida engineer and eventually was told that I would have to pave a driveway.  Being a small business I have no money for a map priced at 14 thousand dollars.  When I pressed the county they said I could draw my own map but insisted that I would have to add a paved driveway.  I can’t afford the money for a paved driveway.  So I opted to put my gorgeous new top notch 2300 square foot dog school up for sale as a residence.  My dog school previously was not forced to have a paved driveway, it isn’t environmental to pave a driveway but suddenly it is being forced on my small business. 

 

It seems to me that county officials and civic associations are greatly impeding small business.  Myself and others being unable to comply with the ever increasing county regulations and fees are forced to move or close our businesses. 

 

This trend appears to be statewide and dog trainers are being forced to operate “under the radar” of their counties or being forced out.  Petsmart and Petco are already putting tremendous pressures on us small business dog trainers probably soon the majority of small business dog trainers will be forced to close.  Just like other industries it will be another one run be an oligopoly.  Considering that the United States is at its core small business this seems inappropriate.  Since government will step in at some point to break up oligopolies, why not proactively prevent them from occurring by empowering small business at the county level?

 

My recommendations are:  1. Empower land owners –if you buy the land you get to decide what you want to do without the requirement of special use permits or high county fees.  Simply every county provides a list of what is allowed and not allowed in each type of zoning.  2. Apply zoning laws to the date of the purchase of the land rather then the date of the permit.  Land owners have no control over delays prior to permitting (in my case this would have saved my biz) my land was stuck in the county for over a year rendering us unable to even pull a permit for building.  

 

Since I have shared my story with my 8 thousand plus clients I have heard many other stories of the county forcing regulations – which in several cases were not even accurate – on the citizens of Hillsborough County.  Hillsborough County can’t be sued so even when they provided my attorney with false information there were no consequences for the county.  This sets citizens up to be bullied by their counties.  

 

Incidentally, it seems that code enforcement is predominately a tool for mud slinging since I was turned into the county by a competitor who is starting her own dog school across the street.  By simplifying code zoning regulations and making them less stringent on small business this dynamic would be curbed. 

 

Thank you for your time. 

 

Cordially,

Angelica Steinker, registered and voting republican and small business fan!

 

Angelica Steinker, M.Ed., C.D.B.C., CAP2, PHI MAR TECH, NADOI endorsed 1013E, APDT #2419P exp. 4/07

Courteous Canine, Inc. Dog School

No Force, Just Fun!

3414 Melissa Country Way, Lutz, FL 33559

Phone:  813-949-1465  Fax:  813-949-0534

www.CourteousCanine.com

www.DogTrainersJournal.com

www.CynologyCollege.com

Governor Bush,
 
As you may know, the state of Florida is #1 in the country for boating accidents. I love boating and I wanted to use my passion to help improve boating education and safety in the state.

We have a nationally known production company retained to film the weekly episode at locations throughout Palm Beach County.  We have negotiated and secured airtime 2x weekly FOX Sports Net throughout Florida, and 2x weekly on the Travel Channel from Vero Beach to the Keyes.  
 
Each episode offers three segments:
1)  USCG Boating Education
2)  Boat Handling
3)  Water Sports
 
Our first taping is scheduled for August 19th and 20th.  We are getting tons of support from the media and the boating community, all who feel education is the key to helping with safety.  
 
As a new show we need HELP.  We believe this is such an important issue right now that we do not have time to wait.  It will take us time to get our advertising base to the point where we are completely self supportive.  We are asking at this point for emergency help getting this important show off the ground for 4th quarter 06.  
 
We have many of the expences covered by advertisers but we are still in need of $8,500 per episode for the first 13 weeks.  Is there anything the state can do to help us with the launch of this program that will help the entire state.  
 
Boating is one of our greatest revenue sources for the state.  We want boaters to be safe and have put the work in on our end to make this happen.  We need your help to make this happen.    
 
Review our website for more information - www.captainhollis.tv
 
Thank you for your consideration,
 
Captain Hollis

From:	Alex Malaguti <Alex@newportintl.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 7, 2006 3:15 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	A Success Story from Newport International :: Preserving Florida's History while Enabling Business Growth

Mr. Jeb Bush, 
 
My name is Alexandre Malaguti, Marketing Coordinator for Newport International in St. Petersburg, FL USA. Late last year (2005), the company I work for started to hunt for a new headquarter location in the Tampa Bay area. This project took Jack McGeough, CEO and Owner, on a wild race all over town. After many unsuccessful buy attempts, Mr. McGeough and his wife, Jeanne, were given a tip about an old abandoned funeral home in downtown St. Petersburg. Just the word "funeral" was enough to turn both of them off, nonetheless after some creative selling from their realtor's part, Mr. and Mrs. McGeough agreed on seeing the property. 
 
The place was literally a decrepit wood frame with walls. the place resembled a "Crack-house" (sorry for the word) more than a 1920s upscale funeral home. Nonetheless, Mrs. Jeanne's creative spark lit up after seeing the place, and with that she was able entice our company's owner and husband, Jack, to seriously consider the building as a viable option. 
 
After some research and deliberation over viability of the project, Mr. and Mrs. McGeough took it upon themselves to restore that "Funeral Crack-home," if you can call it that, into the corporate headquarters of our 50 million dollar a year company. 
 
What was thought to take months, ended up taking like a year, but finally in June 2006 our new stunning HQ was ready for business. The project was kept in line with all historic regulations, the outside now looks exactly like the original 1920s design, and the interior houses an immense elegant office space for 20 employees. The beauty of the building and its multifunctional design puts it on a league of its own.
 
After reading about the historic safeguarding efforts of our first lady through Preserve America, those of History Channel with "Save Our History" and those of other national and state entities, I have come to realize how relevant our company's initiative, and that of the owners, is. Such bold move of restoring a ran-down funeral home into a modern, yet historic, corporate office space exemplifies the spirit of the great works been carried nationwide. 
 
Please accept my invitation to our official Ribbon Cutting Celebration in Downtown St. Petersburg Florida, August 30th 2006.  Mr. Rick Baker, Mayor of St. Petersburg, will be in attendance a long with The Tampa Tribune, St. Petersburg Times and other local news agencies. 
 
Lets make the dream of preserving America a reality in our education, businesses and personal lifes.
 
For more information, or to confirm your attendance, please call 727-866-1188 ext 209, or email me at alex@newportintl.com
 
Alexandre Malaguti
Marketing and MIS Coordinator
alex@newportintl.com
 
Newport International
"Home of Jack's Catch"
155 Eighth Street North
St Petersburg, FL 33701
727.894.1188
727.894.1185
www.newportintl.com

Dear Governor Bush:

I read that you have recently appointed a 15 member committee to make  
recommendations on possible real property tax reforms.

I am a thirty-five year Hawaii resident who is a non-resident Florida  
homeowner. My wife and I own an Englewood home that was built by my  
grandfather in 1950 and was owned by my mother until we purchased it  
from her in 2002 when she became ill with Alzheimer's Disease.

I am very interested in the work of your property property tax  
committee partly because the property tax bill on our Florida home  
has risen from $10,000 in 2002 to $33,000 in 2005, and partly because  
I served on a similar property tax reform committee on my home island  
of Kauai in 2004 - 2005.

I thought that the Florida property tax committee might be interested  
in the the property tax reform proposal from our Kauai committee.  
There are many similarities between the property tax situation in  
Florida and, on a smaller scale, ours here on Kauai.

I would appreciate it if your staff could provide me with information  
regarding how to contact the Governor's Property Tax Committee in  
order to share some information. Thank you.

Michael Dyer

From: jeb.bush@myflorida.com [mailto:jeb.bush@myflorida.com]
Sent: Fri 5/12/2006 9:42 AM
To: Carlson, Susan L; Scarborough, Truman G
Subject: The Need for Better Disposal of "e-waste"



http://newstandardnews.net/content/index.cfm/items/3154

A number of toxic substances are used in of electronics, from the liquid
crystal displays on cell phones to the circuit boards inside computers. The
lead, used in glass panels of computer monitors, in soldering of printed
circuit boards and in cell phones, can leach from landfills and contaminate
drinking water. In addition to negatively affecting brain development in
children, the toxin can cause nervous- and blood-system damage as well as
kidney problems. Lead constitutes more than half of the 70 percent of
consumer electronics contribution of heavy-metal waste in US landfills.

Cadmium, another toxin that damages the kidneys, is used in computer-chip
resistors, semiconductors and cell phones’circuitry, batteries and liquid
crystal displays. Mercury, used in circuit boards, medical equipment and cell
phones, can accumulate in people, animals and plants, leading to brain
damage. And brominated flame retardants (BFRs), used in the plastic casings
of computers, televisions and cell phones, increase risk of cancer.

Chad Raphael, professor at Santa Clara University and chair of the Silicon
Valley Toxics Coalition (SVTC), said "We have to stop sweeping our toxic
trash under other people's rugs."

Westervelt said that with municipalities scrambling to keep the
electronic-waste stream out of landfills, local officials are concerned that
if they charge to recycle toxic electronics, consumers will illegally dump
the materials or continue to store them in their homes and businesses.
"I talk with hundreds of recyclers around this country and they all say the
same thing –which is you cannot responsibly process this waste stream without
charging or without having some sort of revenue coming in," said Westervelt,
adding that it costs between $10 to $30 to properly recycle each computer or
TV.

In the absence of federal leadership on e-waste, states are passing their own
laws, which discourages recyclers from creating a national electronic
recycling system.

However, local store outlets of national chains can be required to set up
"drop off" points for the manufacturers of the equipment they sell, to be
returned in bulk to the manufacturer for safe disassembly, recycling, and
disposal.

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor 
State of Florida
 
Dear Governor Bush, 
 
As you know our daughter, Tara Pascotto Paluck, is applying for the appointed position for Lee County Court Judge previously held by Judge Volz. As parents we know Tara will be quite an effective judge. She is smart, ethical, energetic, and hard working.  Tara desires to further her commitment to her community as she and her husband, Ron, are raising their two boys in Fort Myers.  She feels that it is time to give back at the highest level that she can achieve. 

 

We have been in Fort Myers for 31 years. Tara was raised here. She graduated valedictorian from Canterbury School.  Then, she graduated from Notre Dame majoring in American Studies.  After Notre Dame, she went to Creighton University Law School where she founded the Health Law Association. For both her undergraduate and graduate studies, Tara earned Dean’s List honors.  After graduating in 1994, she returned to Fort Myers and worked at the State Attorney's Office. There, she gained an excellent reputation working in the courtroom primarily handling Domestic Violence and Narcotics/Firearm cases. Subsequently, she did insurance defense work for Allstate for 8 years. Approximately one year ago, Tara opened a general law practice doing a significant amount of family law.  In 2004, Tara was certified by the Supreme Court of Florida as a mediator in county and circuit court cases.  She has mediated cases in all areas of law. 

 

Tara has actively volunteered in many local organizations including American Cancer Society’s Relay for Life, Ronald McDonald House, Lee County’s Restitution Accountability Board for juvenile offenders, and the Notre Dame Club of Lee County as president.  She participates with the Florida Association of Women Lawyers and is a board member of the Historic Edison Park Neighborhood Association.  Recently, Tara was invited to serve on the Board of Trustees for Canterbury School.

 

Tara has seen the community grow and she knows what it takes to be a effective judge  in Lee County. Her qualifications speak for themselves. 

 

Thank you for your consideration.

 

Sincerely yours,

Joan and Robert Pascotto MD

 

PS I established the cardiac surgical program here in Fort Myers in July 1975 and like Tara we feel it is time to give back.  Please find enclosed a copy of a letter that you sent me for my work in the Dominican Republic.

From:	Jim Keller <jkeller6@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Sunday, August 6, 2006 1:12 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Clemency

James R. & Edith C. Keller
3010 42nd Street West
Bradenton, Florida 34205
 
 
 
The Honorable Jeb Bush, Governor
Tallahassee, Florida
 
August 6, 2006
 
Re: Clemency
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing to you today as the father of a son that has had a troubled life.  My son is James Steven Keller, DC# 114579.  He is presently incarcerated in Sumter Correctional Institute at Bushnell.  He was found guilty of vehicular homicide and was originally sentenced to thirty years.  Subsequently, James was granted a re-trial by the Appellate-Court.   Instead of the re-trial, he elected to take a plea bargain of twenty years, which he is currently serving.  There are many circumstances, events and history germane to this case, but in the interest of brevity I will await instructions from you as to the extent of detail required.
 
It is important for you to know that James is thirty-six years old and is and always has been a hard worker.  He has many trade-skills and can be a productive citizen.  Unfortunately, James has an addictive personality with an alcohol and drug stained past going back to his middle teens.  Almost without exception, his run-ins with the law have stemmed from substance abuse.
 
There is no excuse for what my son has done or the life that he took.  Furthermore, there is no excuse for him leaving the scene of the accident or refusing to turn himself in as we all instructed him to do.  All that can be said is that he was afraid and coupled with the alcohol and drug abuse the other side of the equation equaled cowardice.
 
James Steven Keller was sexually molested, along with an older mentally-challenged girl at Westwinds Mobile Home Park in Bradenton by David Toby. James was seven years old at the time.  We were told at the time of this molestation that James could develop social behavioral problems later in his life.  These types of problems started to manifest themselves about three years later when his step father passed away.  Immaturity and coping failures have plagued James his whole life.   However, at the end of the day, the tragic death of Chris Klueh, 12/21/2000, was an accident.  My son did not set out to kill anyone.
 
I have prayed and worried over this plea more than anything I have ever done.  I decided to ask for your help because I firmly believe that I can help my son assimilate productively back into society.  However if he serves out his current sentence the likelihood of my participation is slim.
 
Having met you on several occasions over the years, I was left with the sense that you are a genuinely compassionate man.  I ask only that you look into James’ prison record.  You will see that he has an exemplary deportment and work history.  He is assigned to a print shop, tool-room supervisory position.  This is a position of trust and responsibility normally given to prisoners with a much longer track record.
 
Several people in the penal system have noted that James is out of place.  Meaning he is not a hardened criminal.  My son is not a violent person and when he is sober he is a good man with a kind heart.
 
Please consider clemency for my son and let me help him move back into our society.  I don’t know if I am going about this petition the right way, so please forgive my ignorance and let me know if there is a specific procedure.  
 
I thank you Governor Bush for your time and kind attention.
 
Sincerely:
 
 
James Richard Keller

From:	Kirsten Noppinger <kirsten@dnalabsinternational.com>
Sent:	Saturday, August 5, 2006 4:24 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Reducing DNA backlog for FDLE - helping with Jacksonville crime

August 5, 2006

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush
The Capitol

400 South Monroe Street

Tallahassee, FL 32399

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I read with interest this morning about your authorization to send state troopers to help with Jacksonville’s Operation Road Block North to reduce the high murder rate they are experiencing this year.  We applaud your innovative approach to problem solving.

 

I am writing this letter to introduce you to DNA Labs International and to request a meeting with you or an appropriate member of your staff so that we may discuss how we can work together to help solve more crimes in Jacksonville and the rest of Florida.

 

DNA Labs International is a private, ISO 17025 Accredited Forensic Serology and DNA Identity testing laboratory located in South Florida.  Our mission is to help clients solve cases by providing timely, accurate and cost effective DNA testing results.  Our laboratory is equipped with state-of-the-art technology and we are the only private lab with ABC Board Certified Scientists.  Our Lab Director has 25 years of forensic serology and DNA experience working in state and county crime labs. 

 

As a Florida corporation we are focused on assisting all law enforcement agencies within the state.  We have been contacted by people in many law enforcement agencies around the state that are frustrated with the current turnaround times and are looking for a solution to the DNA casework backlog problem.  

 

We believe we can offer you a win-win-win-win situation…for the People of Florida, for the law enforcement agencies, for FDLE and for us.  We guarantee all of our clients a two week turnaround time for their cases.  The local law enforcement agencies set the priorities by submitting evidence in the order they want cases worked.  We work the samples and return the DNA reports and evidence back to the agencies or FDLE - whichever they decide.  FDLE reviews the case then enters the DNA profiles into the state database and into CODIS. CODIS enables federal, state, and local crime labs to exchange and compare DNA profiles electronically, thereby linking crimes to each other and to convicted offenders.  Since private labs cannot directly input data into the system, it is important to have FDLE’s cooperation for cases that have no known suspect identified.

 

This scenario greatly reduces the amount of work for FDLE as the average time it takes to review a DNA case is only about 30 minutes versus one to two weeks and more to work an entire case from start to finish.

 

I am sure you have many questions, and we would be happy to discuss with you some of our very workable ideas on how to implement this process. Your influence with local legislators and FDLE would be valuable to make this plan successful.

 

We look forward to hearing from someone on your staff in the near future.

 

Kind regards,

 

Kirsten Noppinger

President, DNA Labs International

 

 

DNA Labs International

1239 E. Newport Center Drive, Suite 111

Deerfield Beach, FL 33442

Office: 954-426-5163 ext. 10

Kirsten@DNALabsIntl.com

www.DNALabsIntl.com

 

Publisher of The DNA Informant. 

www.dnalabsinternational.com/news.html

 

Proud members of BioFLorida

From:	Jack Driggers <jackddriggers@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Saturday, August 5, 2006 12:16 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	hill.anthony.web@flsenate.gov
Subject:	Information about notary forgery
Attachments:	3486716113-markandcarla signatures.pdf; [REDACTED]-markandcarla signatures2.pdf; 3482745618-carlapegg signature1.pdf; [REDACTED]-carlapegg signature2.pdf; 4019524924-forged affidavit.pdf; [REDACTED]-forged affidavit2.pdf

Governor Jeb Bush, 
 
I recently made a trip to Jacksonville, FL to sell a boat to a prespective buyer, and while waiting at the marina, decided to have a beer in a bar called Jackie's Seafood.  As I was enjoying my beer,  a couple of women came and sat next to me.  Although I wasn't particularly listening to their conversation, I could tell they were regulars in this bar and possibly even worked there.  I asked these women if they knew where I could find a local notary to complete the sale of my boat, since it was the weekend and I was not from the area.  Crazy as it may sound, this prompted a very interesting and quite disturbing conversation that I feel impelled to tell you about.  I will try to be as brief as possible.
 
When asked about the notary, one woman did not hesitate to tell me that one of the bartenders in this bar, Bonnie Parks, was a notary.  She went on to say that Bonnie also worked as a bail bond at Bill Dye Bail Bonds and should have no problem meeting me on the weekend.  Before I could thank her for the information, the other woman spoke up and asked if Bonnie was still a notary after all that "crap with Carla and the Governor's office".  The first woman said, "oh yea, all that was dropped after Bonnie sent in our statements - remember?"   Of course I immediately saw a red flag and asked if this Bonnie person was legitimate.  The first woman said yes, and went on to tell me that several years ago, Bonnie and someone named Carla were real good friends and Carla was going through a bad divorce.  Apparently Carla was trying to sell some property that she hadn't disclosed in the divorce before the former husband found out.  As with most property, she needed the husband's signature before she could sell it and obviously could not go to him to get it.  According to these women, Carla signed her husband's name and asked Bonnie to notarize it for her.  As unethical as it may be, Bonnie did.  Unfortunately, the husband found out and filed a complaint against Bonnie with the Governor's office.  According to these 2 women, this "freaked Bonie out" and she was afraid she would be charged with a felony as well as lose her job at the bail bond.  So, Bonnie and Carla got their friends and relatives together and came up with a plan.  They decided they would say that Carla and her former husband came to Jackie's Seafood to sign the papers and therefore they could have witnesses to the signing.  They then had everyone write a notarized statement to this effect and Bonnie sent the fraudulent statements in to the Governor's office as proof of her "innocence".  Apparently it worked because the complaint was dropped.  
 
As I sat in horror at the total lack of integrity in these two women, who were obviously a part of this plan, as well as with Bonnie and Carla,  the first woman went on to tell me that Carla was now a bail bond as well and perhaps she was also a notary - she wasn't sure.  Then as luck would have it, she wrote down both women's names and place of employment so that I could contact them for my boat sale (like that was going to happen). 
 
               Bonnie Parks - Bill Dye Bail Bond
               Carla Pegg - 1st Coast Bail Bond
  
Needless to say, this scared me to death.  Not only was one notary with no ethics stilll allowed notary priveleges but now possibly two.  I'm sure things like this happen all the time, yet I could not understand why your office dropped the complaint without any further investigation, so I pursued the matter a little further and said, "well I guess Carla must have done a good job on the forgery if no one could tell that it wasn't her X-husband's".  To this they both kind of laughed and said, "that was the part that freaked Bonnie out, 'cuz the signature didn't look like his at all".  So I said, "well, then I guess Bonnie got lucky."  The first woman said, "yea, and I think she learned her lesson because she and Carla aren't really friends anymore".  Then the second woman said, "yea, and if I remember correctly the Governor's office sent Bonnie a letter saying she should hire an attorney - like she was the victim."  I laughed amusingly, thanked both women for the information and left the bar. 
 
Like I said, I was very disturbed by this story and although I think it is probably common for a friend to "help another friend", I could not let it go.  Basically in the time it took for me to drink a full beer, I had heard of several laws that had been broken...starting with this Carla Pegg woman not disclosing personal assets in a divorce and ending with fraudulent statements submitted in an investigation.  Not too mention, a sworn notary violating her ethical duties, and swearing a forged signature was legitimate then convincing her friends to also perjure themselves.  The most outrageous part; however, is the office of the Governor basically condoning this behavior and suggesting Ms. Parks was innocent.  I couldn't help but wonder how many times this has happened not only with these two women but with all notaries.  Seems funny that in this day and age, the Governor's office would not take the time to look more closely at a legitimate complaint from someone claiming their signature has been forged and notarized.  I'm sure the Governor's office has access to all this man's records including his driver's license - if there was any difference in the signatures, it should have been pursued. I realize your office is busy but how much time would that possibly take?  Isn't it better to err on the side of caution then to allow such a travesty to happen?   
 
Maybe I have too much time on my hands, but I spent a little time working as a Private Investigator and all these thoughts intriqued me to take a look myself at the public record in Duval County and see what I could find.  I found that Carla Pegg's former husband's name is Mark Pegg, and several documents containing both his signature and Carla Pegg's signature on public record.  Then I found not one but two Affidavits dated April 10,  2002 notarized by Ms. Bonnie Parks that do not match the other signatures on file for Mr. Pegg.  As a matter of fact, they bear quite a resemblence to Ms. Pegg's signature.  Mr. Pegg's official signature looks more like "Mil O Pegg" than Mark D. Pegg as it is easily read on the forged affidavits.  Obviously the public records department has had trouble reading his name because he is listed as Mark A. Pegg and Mark O. Pegg in addition to Mark D. Pegg.  After viewing this for myself, I have to believe the story I heard in Jackie's Seafood is 100% true.  
 
Therefore, all I can say is I'm appalled and completely outraged that your office has condoned breaking the law on several counts and blatently ignored a legitimate complaint by Mr. Pegg whose civil rights were violated by his former wife and her notary friend.  I am unsure of the reasons behind your office's decision to ignore this complaint but luckily for you, this wasn't my problem because I would have been a richer man today.  If I could see a difference in the signatures, surely you could too.  I have to assume that the Governor's office doesn't care about the general public in Florida and it is no wonder there is such a problem with identity theft. Apparently all the "hype" about stopping identity theft in this country is nothing but typical political bullshit.  
 
I have attached copies of the documents I retrieved from public records in Duval County for your review.  Although I'm sure you will probably not give this matter any more consideration than you did when the official complaint was made - I suggest you take a look yourself.  All I can say is thank goodness I live in Georgia and do not have to depend on you or your office for anything.  The one Bush I do have to deal with is bad enough!
 
Best Regards, 
Jack D. Driggers
 
686 Nebraska Road
Screven, GA  31560
Jackddriggers@yahoo.com

From: Mark Kole [mailto:mkole@sunletter.com]
Sent: Monday, July 31, 2006 11:48 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Desoto County Arcadia Rodeo


Governor Bush,
 
As I working with several other people to rebuild and expand (we are all volunteers) the Desoto County,  Arcadia All-Florida Rodeo arena and facility. I would like to thank your office for making the $30,000 feasibility grant money possible. Thank You. 
   
Stop and Think!
If a Hurricane, Natural disaster, Terrorist attack happened is SW Florida........The most logical emergency command center and hub would be an Equestrian show facility's with Rail Road access, which is what we are building.......WHY ?????........these Equestrian show facilities have, as part of their normal components,  which become key elements needed in a disaster recovery situation. a) several hundred acres close to town: that could be used for staging-up equipment and housing manpower (in tents), b) Multiple bath room/ shower buildings scattered across the grounds: that could be used to keep quality of life and sanitary conditions for man power and evacuees, c) Exhibit Halls: which could be used to be used as office space, cafeteria, medical offices, dry supply storage. d) Horse stalls and Dog/ cat kennels: which could be used as pet shelter, animal control offices, military and police dog housing and emergency veterinarian care. e) Main Stadium 9,000 seats plus a large arena floor space, office space w/privet bath rooms and showers, sky boxes and conference rooms: This could be used as  housing, information briefings to evacuees, supplies, communication center and accommodations for key emergency manager personnel. f) RV park area's (300 water, sewer and electric hook ups: This will allow instant housing for key personal and their families with no set up time, pull the RV or Travel trailer up and plug in. g) The Rail Road spur and station: This could be used to connect SW Florida to the rest of the country,  with the most efficient method of mass transportation known. you could move supplies or people North or South, thousands at a time and per hour.  you could even evacuate people from south Florida,  hub them in Desoto county and then bring them to any place in the country.  Consider the possibilities     
 
Our concept 
is to build a several hundred acre equestrian and rodeo facility with mostly private funds. The facility would be owned and operated sole by the 80 year old "not for profit", organization, the "All- Florida Championship rodeo" currently run by President Judge, Don T Hall of Arcadia. The completion of this faculties will preserve the agriculture industry in our area by promoting agriculture events and allowing our Florida students to show animals, participate in agriculture functions. This facility would impacts the community with job, tourism, economic development during normal weather and when a storm threatened or hit, the facility would be turned over to the Desoto County emergency management team or FEMA.to use as they see fit..... This would be one of the only PET Friendly shelters in our area and even possibly regionally. Now add the idea of an EVACUATION TRAIN, this could be a great way to become part of a net work of shelters connected by the Rail Road. 
    The Icing on the cake is that we have interest from the world famous circus "Ringling brothers" circus who has a genuine interest in making Desoto County their winter Quarters. This will promote Florida tourism across the united states and will certainly significantly impact the economy of our town which is only 2 hours from Orlando's Disney world. 
 
 
This e-mail is to ask you to please appoint one or more staff members to our board of advisors for this project. We would like the governors office to be involved in the planning of our facility. we fee this facility will become a key resource for the state during disaster recovery, on a local and regional level ...As you know we will need the support experience of every one we can to make this project work. By appointing just one person to our board of advisors.......even if they never attend one meeting in person, You could single handedly catapult this project to instant success.......
 
 
Your faithful supporter
 
Mark Kole- Acting developer for the Arcadia Rodeo Assoc.
11019 SW Cypress Bend Ave 
Arcadia, Florida 34269
863-993-1777 Home 
941-585-9632 Cell

My name is Dave Edwards and I am the Senior Vice President for Cardinal Logistics Management.  We are a logistics company with major operations in the State of Florida. Our 24 drivers at this account have collectively reached 1,000,000 miles operating in Florida without an accident.  The article below provides the details.

 

Here are my questions.

 

1)       Would you like to attend the safety celebration we are planning to honor these drivers?

2)       Could you send some type of letter to each of the drivers congratulating them on their achievement?

3)       Could you send one letter to the account that can be read at the safety celebration congratulating them on their achievement?

Hughes Supply Orlando Reaches One Million Miles Accident Free 


By Bryan Alford, Operations Manager


 



It gives me great pleasure to announce that the Hughes Supply Orlando Florida location has surpassed the One Million mile mark without a preventable accident. Many people have worked very hard to make this possible. This account is over 6 years old and this is the first time that I am aware of. The drivers here are 100% responsible for attaining this goal. They turned every mile, made every stop, did every drop and hook. All I did was keep track of it and hand out the accolades. Lewis Johnson, Dan Goodall, Brannon Morse, and John Nagle continued to preach the message every time they could until it became second nature. Florida Operations Managers Mark Hadley, Larry Ott, Cameron Hyde, and their staff provided us with quality drivers when we needed help and kept the safety ball rolling. Through their commitment to safety, teamwork, customer satisfaction, and a genuine care for each other’s performance, they have won a long overdue reward.

Many of the drivers cover more miles than the next, some run local, OTR, and regional. This was a team effort from not only the Hughes drivers, but also surrounding Orlando Metro accounts. Drivers from Georgia Pacific, Office Depot, CHEP Pallets, and Mills Pride participated in pushing us over the top. This is a testimony to those drivers and their leaders. Preaching safety is easy, sitting down with a driver and talking about safety is easy, holding them accountable is easy, and celebrating this goal will be sweet. We worked on safety one stop, mile, day, week, and month at a time. Each of them supported the other with encouragement, positive attitudes, and a common goal they all wanted to achieve. 

Each month at our safety meeting we sit down and have breakfast together. We talk about safety and operational issues, and I give each of them an opportunity to have the floor to discuss anything they see we need to improve on. We've had many suggestions from them that we've implemented and practiced. Each one of the drivers knows they can count on the other to do his/her job today to the fullest. They know that their teammates are just as concerned as they are about safety. We require them to hold us as supervisors and managers, just as accountable for safety as we hold them. We expect to be told of equipment issues and they expect us to correct it. Each Friday we have a weekly safety cookout. No accidents mean burgers, hot dogs, chicken, maybe even a steak and potato. We are most definitely on "the better we do, the better we eat" program. 

I couldn't be more proud of a group of drivers than the ones I work with today. They are truly a great bunch of people who have fun together and know that Cardinal does care about them and their families. They know that we practice what we preach, even when it's tough, and are honest and fair. We trust them and they trust us. We've reached our goal together and will continue to strive further...the tough part is figuring out how to celebrate. Maybe I'll put on a grass skirt and do the hula at a luau for them. 

Thanks for the hard work and dedication to all of the drivers that got us to this goal!

 

From:	Sandi McKamey <smckamey@belleviewfl.org>
Sent:	Friday, August 4, 2006 8:57 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Scheduling:  America Supports You Freedom Walk

The following is a letter to be sent by Mayor Tammy C. Moore, Mayor of the City of Belleview.  

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

September 11, 2006 will be the fifth anniversary of the terrorist attacks that took the lives of thousands of our fellow citizens   Last year, in Washington, DC, the Department of Defense held the first annual America Supports You Freedom Walk. The purpose of the America Supports You Freedom Walk is to establish a national tradition to reflect on the lives lost on September 11, 2001, to renew our commitment to freedom and the values of our country, and to show our gratitude for our military men and women, past and present, who commit to protecting our freedom.

 

This year, at the request of people from around the nation, the America Supports You Freedom Walk is being expanded to include the entire country.  The City of Belleview has been contacted and is organizing an America Supports You Freedom Walk to be held Monday, September 11, 2006.  The opening ceremony and program will begin at 6:00 PM, followed by the walk and an evening in the park, located next to Belleview City Hall.  

 

On behalf of the City of Belleview, I would like to invite you to speak at the opening ceremony and join us in the walk.  Your presence would mean so much to the family members in the area who have lost loved ones, not only in the terrorist attack of September 11th, but also those men and women, past and present, serving in our military.  Please give this request your utmost consideration.  I look forward to hearing from you.

 

Sincerely,

 

Tammy C. Moore

Mayor

 

(Hard copy of official letter to follow)

Sandi McKamey, MMC, CPM 
City Clerk/Administrator 
City of Belleview 
352-245-0173

From:	michael leggett <chosenbr549@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, August 3, 2006 5:02 PM

They have confessed to the crime and the gun was obtained by the students while in the football locker room on school grounds.  The school system has a zero tolerance policy for guns and have arrested a 5 year old for having a water pistol in her gym bag.  Mr. Kelly along with the football coach, who is the superintendents brother, spoke at a hearing which would decide whether the defendants would be released or remanded until the trial.  The recommendation of the Department of Juvenile Justice was that these kids should be remanded, the recommendation of the State Attorney was the same.  Mr. Kelly along with others spoke in the behalf of the defendants and the judge decided to let them go free until the trial.  Mr. Kelly did not inform any of the school board members of his plans to speak in regards to this matter and most our outraged that these violent criminals are out on our streets.  Furthermore these kids are still enrolled in our public education system and currently participating in summer workouts on public school property. Could you please talk with Mr. Kelly and ask him to stop meddling in the justice system. From:	Levesque, Patricia
Sent:	Thursday, August 3, 2006 2:01 PM

Subject:	RE: Computer-based Accommodations

Send this directly to governor, not doe.

From: Governor Jeb Bush

Cc: Levesque, Patricia

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Russell [mailto:russelmh@bc.edu]
Sent: Friday, July 28, 2006 1:35 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Thomas Hoffmann
Subject: Computer-based Accommodations


Governor Bush-
Thank you for taking the time to meet with Tom, Pat, and me yesterday.  
While on the plane back to Boston, Tom and I gave much thought to your 
questions regarding the open-ended items on the FCAT math and science 
tests, and we came up with two solutions.

Regarding how to allow students to show their work or record drawings 
on a computer, we have a simple and inexpensive hardware solution that 
will allow students to "write" on paper using a "pen" and have their 
responses recorded on the computer.  If implemented, this solution 
would enable every item found in the released tests to be administered 
on computer and would greatly decrease the cost associated with 
scanning in paper sheets that are then scored electronically.

Your second concern related to the time and cost associated with 
scoring the open-response items.  For many of the items, we have an 
inexpensive solution that will decrease the time associated with 
scoring many of theses items by 50-80%, depending on the item.  Rather 
than developing sophisticated algorithms that build on artificial 
intelligence, our idea capitalizes on existing tools and algorithms.  
While this solution would not work for items that require students to 
draw pictures, it would work for any item that requires students to 
write an explanation or record a final solution.

We are testing out these two ideas now and should be able to provide 
more information about their feasibility in about a week.

As a final note, I want to provide some additional information about 
Tom and I.  During our meeting, you mentioned some studies that the 
DOE's chief psychometrician had referenced regarding differential 
performance on computers and on paper.  Ten years ago, I began 
conducting research on this issue and I suspect she is referring to 
some of my work which has focused on computer- versus paper-based 
writing tests.  Following this initial work, I founded the Technology 
and Assessment Study Collaborative (inTASC), which works with schools 
and state organizations to explore ways that computers can be used to 
enhance testing.  As part of our research, we have partnered with a few 
states to explore ways computers can be used to provide accommodations. 
  For this work, we have had to create computer-based tests that include 
specific accommodation tools.  These and other tools we have created 
for research purposes have been received favorably by schools and state 
organizations, which have inquired about using them.  Believing that 
research is only useful if it is applied, and frustrated that the 
larger testing companies seemed to resist some of the new innovations 
we were exploring, Tom and I formed Nimble Assessment Systems in order 
to refine these tools and make them available to educational 
organizations.  While many companies conduct research regarding their 
products, Nimble's tools are direct products of formal, federally 
funded research.

Again, thank you for your time yesterday and for spurring us to think 
deeply about two important challenges faced by computer-based testing.

-Mike

Michael Russell
Associate Professor
Lynch School of Education
Boston College

Director of Research
Nimble Assessment Systems

From: Bullard, Sallie N CIV NAS CORPUS CHRISTI TX
Sent: Friday, July 21, 2006 12:07
To: 'jeb.bush@myflorida.com'
Subject: NAVY CHILD AND YOUTH PROGRAM DIRECTORS CONFERENCE

Good morning Governor Bush,

Last year Navy Child and Youth Programs’ annual CYP Professionals conference was held in Orlando, FL. and because we had such a great time, we’ve decide to visit Orlando again this year.  This year’s conference will be held November 27th through December 1st, , 2007 and there will be approximately 250 Navy Child and Youth Program Professionals attending from Navy programs world wide.  

I’m sure that you are aware of the importance of Child and Youth Programs to our military families.  Our military families rely on the kind of quality Child Development, School Age and Youth programming we provide for their children so that they can accomplish their mission as military members whether it is on board the installation or as a war fighter overseas. Knowing that their children are cared for in a safe and caring environment and are provided quality programming helps them meet their mission. Our annual conference brings Navy Child and Youth Professionals together each year for essential training seminars, networking and round table talks to keep us abreast of the latest information and innovations in the Child and Youth field and to provide us with the tools needed to continue providing the highest quality programs possible for our military families.

Because of your continuing support of our Nation’s military members and their families and your father, President George Bush was a decorated Navy pilot, we are hoping you will accept an invitation to be our Keynote speaker at this year’s conference.  The first day of the conference is November 27; however, if this date does not fit into your calendar, we would be delighted to accommodate you at anytime during the conference.

Since this is an informal request via e-mail, please let me know of any formal procedures required to request your attendance at our conference.  I am looking forward to hearing from you in the near future.

Very Respectfully,

Sallie Bullard

On behalf of 

Commander Navy Installations Command (CNIC)

Child and Youth Programs

Sallie Bullard

Navy Region South

Child/Youth Program Director

Bldg. 39 D Street

Naval Air Station

From:	Lt. Governor Toni Jennings

-----Original Message-----
From: Peggy Rutherford [mailto:peggy@peggyrutherford.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, August 02, 2006 11:48 AM
To: Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject: FEMA/Disaster


Dear Lt. Governor Jennings:

This high cost of insurance in the state of Florida and in Pasco and Hernando in particular, is causing an exodus of our residents.  Existing home sales have flooded the market and residents are unable to even sell.  Many, especially those on fixed income or with families to support, cannot effort the increase in insurance rates.  If they bought a new or resale house in the last year or two, they are also facing high property tax rates due to the high cost of real estate. Many people who will try and stay and somehow pay the high insurance increases will find ways to conserve their spending.  I am one of those people who saw my insurance premiums for my 2300 sq. ft. house go from $2300 to $4500.  I must now cancel the company that sprays my law, cancel my pool service etc. and cut back on luxury items such as restaurants and entertainment.  This trickle down effect will have disastrous consequences for small business in Florida. 
I would encourage our state politicians especially Governor Bush to call a special session so that our state legislators can address this insurance crisis and the SOH issues now, rather than later. Many people who were considering making a move in 2006 are now waiting to see what happens with the Save Our homes issue.  
The continued growth our our local and state economy is very dependent upon the resolution of these two very serious issues.  Do not wait until the spring of 2007 session.  Act now.

Sincerely,

Peggy Rutherford
13624 Dunwoody Ct
Hudson , FL 34667

From:	Fisher, Toni J. <fishert@ahca.myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, August 3, 2006 10:02 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Immigration


Dear Sir, 
As a middle income American I walk among the general population.  My lifestyle is not an outlier on the bell curve of American life.  I'm what we in the health field call "the first line".  I see what is happening in Florida, USA because of illegal immigration.  I am going to tell you how illegal immigration is affecting my life.  

        DETERIORATION OF HEALTH AND SAFETY 
                1.  Schools - cafeteria workers do not speak or understand English.  How are they going to know and follow the health and safety procedures of food preparation and sanitation if they do not bother to learn the language.  Look at the data the Environmental and Health Inspectors are collecting.  

                2.  Restaurants - tourism is the major business of Florida.  All we need is tourist getting sick ( look at Carnivale Cruises as an example on how this can impact the business) and  it will be hard to recover from bad word of mouth news. When Chicago (born and raised) is the #1 tourist destination, even though Chicago has 4 seasons, Florida cannot afford any more bad press.

        INCREASE IN CRIME 
                1.  Driving - they have no driver's license, no insurance.  If you don't understand the language how can you possibly understand the street signs.

                2.  Crime increase - nothing happens to illegals; as evidenced by the State Trooper (todays news) who pulled over a van load of Illegals and had to let them go because we have no government officials on any level with the balls to evict these people out of America.     

        DETERIORATION IN SERVICES 
                1.  It's illegal for busineses to hire illegal immigrants, but nothing is done.  Why is that if the law is being broken.

                2.  More and more small American businesses are going under because they cannot outbid companies hiring cheap illegal workers.  More of our workers are loosing their jobs to illegal immigration.

                3.  I see and hear more and more Americans complaining about shoddy work; from new construction to air condition service. 

                4.  Service industry (tourism) - they're ignorance to our language and customs has really decreased  our quality of service in Florida.

        DETERIORATION OF AMERICA 
                Illegal vaguely means against a law that society has deemed necessary for protection.  My American life is in dire need of protection.  

There is no incentive from government officials to correct a problem that is going to increasinly getting worse.  Why do we keep trying to appease illegals?  Why don't we fine businesses for hiring illegals?  There are 4 Walmarts I shop at.  I tell you like I've told my family; the next American revolution is going to start in Walmart.  Just like the slap that started WWI.  Some illegal who because they don't know our language or customs don't know  the etiquette of shopping is going to piss off some American who can't take it any longer.  There's going to be words exchanged.  The American is going to shout "You're in my f…..ing country.  Learn the language.  Take you’re a..back to your country"!  Shopping carts will crash!  More words exchanged!  A crowd gathers!  Patriotic emotions flair!  In a Walmart is where the civil revolution will take place.  That's the way I see it.  

You don't put a band aid on a festering wound.  On the other hand  surgery is not always the best choice.  We have laws against illegal immigration.  We don't need new laws.  Just enforce the ones we have, before our quality of Ameican life gets any lower.  Thank you

Sincerely, 
Toni Fisher 

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law. Most written communications to or from state officials regarding state business are public records available to the public and media upon request. Your E-mail communications may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

From:	Robert E. Gwin <Robert.Gwin@Comcast.Net>
Sent:	Thursday, August 3, 2006 7:03 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Immigration

I am not your constituent, but I am so concerned about this issue that I
want to voice my opposition to efforts to "legalize" illegal aliens living
in this country.
This goes to one of our most basic tenets of American society ... "that we
are a nation of laws, not men".  A recent federal judge's decision not to
deport known illegals because of "what MIGHT happen to the law" is an
example of why we are in trouble.

Respectfully, I would request that you and your fellow politicians would
recognize the dangers of continuing this trend.  Add your voice to those
who:

Will fully implement "secure borders, first"
Do not want to wait for "comprehensive" immigration reform, which is code
for "do nothing effective"
Want to postpone ANY talk of "pathways" to citizenship for these illegals,
who MUST go back.
Reform current entrance policies to make them efficient AND effective.
Will punish employers who have employed illegals (Big companies in
particular)
Want to promote "English immersion" for new legal immigrants, rather than
ESL programs that have proven ineffective
REMOVE ANY GOVERNMENTAL FUNDING OF ADVOCACY / INTEREST GROUPS PROVIDING
SUPPORT TO THE ILLEGALS

Thank you for your review of this request.  Please interpret the capitalized
spellings as "special emphasis" rather than shouting.  This issue evokes
very strong emotion in all of us in my social circle.  If politicians do not
become statesmen on this issue, it will become even more divisive than it is
currently with consequences I cannot even contemplate.

Respectfully submitted,


Robert E. Gwin

E-Mail:  Robert.Gwin@eGwin.com

Sent:	Thursday, August 3, 2006 1:12 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Support for the Appointment of Tara Pascotto Paluck for Lee County Judge

August 2, 2006

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor--State of Florida

 

RE: Support for the Appointment of Tara Pascotto Paluck for Lee County Judge

 

 

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

First, I trust this correspondence finds you, your family and your entire staff doing well. 

 

Second, and to get straight to the point for this correspondence, as you are aware you were recently given a short list of names from the Judicial Nominating Committee of the 20th Judicial Circuit for the purpose of selecting one nominee for the vacant position of County Judge for Lee County. Tara Pascotto Paluck was one of those chosen for the short list and this correspondence is in support of her appointment.

 

As you may recall we’ve met on several occasions both in Fort Myers and in Tallahassee as I’ve supported both you and President Bush as a member of the Republican Party at the Regents level. Knowing that you meet many people I’ve provided a brief overview of my background as reference to possibly spark your memory as well as providing meaning behind my support for Tara Pascotto Paluck.

 

In 1996, at the age of 26, I self funded a home based Internet business that ultimately became one of the largest performance marketing companies globally. Head quartered here in Florida, my company MIVA grew to represent 120,000 clients with offices throughout the United States and the European Union. I brought the company to the public market in 1999 and the company continues to trade on NASDAQ. Unlike most other Internet companies, we had tremendous growth through 2000, ’01, ’02, ’03, ’04 & ’05 growing 16,000% in a profitable manner. We were recognized repeatedly as one of the fastest growing companies in the US by entities such as Deloitte and Touche – E&Y (from a revenue and earning perspective) all while bringing many new high paying jobs to the market (several hundred in the US alone). I’ve received many awards over the years from local recognition awards to representing Florida nationally as one of Florida’s ‘Ernst and Young Entrepreneurs of the Year’. While I won at the regional level, unfortunately I did not win the national award - I believe I lost to the two founders of Google.

 

Through the years I established several other companies and made investments into yet other companies with an eye toward the future. Having stepped down as Chairman & CEO of MIVA this past April I now oversee those investments through my personal portfolio company Nexus Capital while maintaining a large share position within MIVA.

 

The point to this personal overview is throughout the past ten years I have become very aware of how local, state and national politics affected my opportunities as a business owner. Knowing that my voice could make a difference I became involved at the Regent level within the RNC as well as a Trustee within the Foundation of the Florida Chamber of Commerce. 

 

During this same period I became the father of 2 which has also influenced how I think about politics. This is the most significant point as it relates to the nomination of Lee County Judge as I firmly believe we need well rounded individuals with a proven track record of supporting the ideology you have brought to the governor’s office in every judge seat possible. By doing so we ensure that our children will not be subject to slanted interpretation of the law as they develop into productive members of our society. Fortunately the Southwest Florida area has been served well historically and with Tara Pascotto Paluck’s appointment I strongly believe that track record will continue. 

 

Tara’s back ground is diverse giving her experience in multiple areas rather than on one or two areas of expertise. This diversity gives me comfort in that I believe it would provide valuable experience regardless of the case/situation rather than having a person that has had extensive experience in limited areas which may produce volatile results. This diversity has also provided ample comfort in that there is a track record indicating how she views many different topics. 

 

In closing, I would like to thank you for your time on this matter and urge you to appoint Tara Pascotto Paluck as Lee County’s newest appointed Judge. I feel strongly that you will be satisfied with this decision as will your constituents in this area. Feel free to contact me if I can be of further assistance as you make your decision.

 

Best wishes to you, your family and your entire staff.

 

Regards,

 

Craig A. Pisaris-Henderson

From:	Brian Homan <res1qp8k@verizon.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 10:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Central Florida WW2 Museum

Dear Governor Bush, 
 
I am writing on behalf of the Central Florida World War 2 Museum.  The Central Florida WW2 Museum is planned to be the next great tribute to those who fought to preserve freedom in World War II.  In order to achieve this mission, we would like to solicit your help.  
 
The museum was incorporated in Florida as a 501(c)(3) not for profit corporation in 2005.  Currently operating in an executive office in Tampa, Florida, our short-term plan is to move to a temporary location where we can house a portion of the museum collection, meet the public, and pursue development plans full-time.  The long-term plan is to purchase a site in Central Florida between Tampa, and Orlando within proximity to Interstate 4.  Once a site is purchased, a facility housing state of the art exhibits will be constructed to teach future generations about the sacrifices made by a past generation for their benefit.  Once complete, the museum will have a constant impact on Florida, the Nation and the world community. 
 
As a not for profit corporation, we are entrusted with donations from people who understand the need for this tribute and who believe we can deliver it.  It is our responsibility to create the best team possible in order to ensure success.  We would like to extend an invitation for you to join our Board of Directors.  As the son of a World War II veteran, I am sure you can understand the significance and importance of this project.  We will require the assistance of qualified and motivated individuals, such as yourself, in order to make this vision a reality.  We believe your service to the State of Florida makes you an ideal candidate for the Central Florida WW2 Museum Board of Directors.   
 
Governor Bush, I hope you will seriously consider this opportunity.  The G.I. Generation is fading into history.  It is our duty to make sure the world remembers their noble deeds.  
 
Please contact me via email at info@cfloridaww2museum.org or phone (813) 504-3826 with regards to this offer or questions concerning this organization.  I look forward to hearing from you.  
 
Sincerely yours, 
 
Brian Homan, President
Central Florida WW2 Museum
4212 S. Manhattan Ave.
Tampa, FL  33611-1302
www.cfloirdaww2museum.org
info@cfloridaww2museum.org
PH  (813) 504-3826
FAX  (813) 839-6832

However our current Insurance problem is looking to decimate our fine State.  Those who are going to be affected the hardest, are the ones who are already having a hard enough time getting by, let alone getting ahead. I believe our state is in grave jeopardy and the situation must be addressed ASAP.  I implore you to immediately call for an Emergency Session to deal with this potentially catastrophic situation, before Florida goes from being the Sunshine State to the Doom & Gloom State.

Dear Governor Bush:

On or about January 11, 2002, a member of my companion's family was 
convicted in Circuit Court, Seventh Judicial Circuit, Volusia County, 
Division 07, upon a plea of guilty, to a charge of "Dealing in Stolen 
Property."  He was placed on probation for a period of 18 months.

Although I do not yet know with certainty whether he complied with all his 
obligations during his probation, I believe  that he did so comply.

Although I am an attorney admitted to practice law in New York and other 
jurisdictions, I am not admitted to practice in Florida.  (Some years ago 
a Florida Judge admitted me to practice pro hac vice, that is, for the 
purposes of one case.  I do not intend to seek to be admitted in Florida 
and I will not represent the individual in question.)

I wish to find out the name and the contact information for a person 
within your Administration who can supply to me information about the 
procedures the individual may follow to apply to you for clemency.

The young man is gainfully employed in New York City, but desires to seek 
new employment and is concerned that his conviction may destroy or damage 
his ability to seek a better position.

I will be most grateful to you if someone on your staff will point him in 
the proper direction.

Most respectfully and with appreciation,

From:	mediator9999@comcast.net
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 3:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Emergency Executive order for roof inspection and/or re-inspection

Rush!!  to
 
 
Dear: Governor Bush
 
The processing time for roof inspections and/re-inspections by County and City inspectors  is excessive and untimely. County and city Building Departments  in South Florida are over burden with request for roof inspection and re-inspections and now we have another pending Storm, Soon to be a Hurricane (Chris),  that appears to be headed for South Florida,  with the prospect of danger to life and property. I am writing to request that you act immediately to draft and implement an  Emergency Executive order instructing counties and cities in the path of any projected or pending Hurricane and/or storm to do the following.
 
1. Expedite  the processing time for any and all roof inspections and re-inspections.
 
2.Allow contractors to hire independent state certified  inspectors to perform roof inspection and/or re-inspection at this time.
 
3. Suspend all non-essential home inspections by cities and county's  allowing local inspectors to concentrate their efforts on those pending roof inspection and/or re-inspections. 
 
The above provision if implement may have a greater impact on saving  homes,  property and life's 
 
Thanking you in advance
 
E. Garrett
 
From:	SUSAN HORAN <SUEKEV@TAMPABAY.RR.COM>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 2:37 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	INSURANCE CRISIS SPECIAL SESSION

Dear Governor Bush:

TO ALL THOSE WHO WILL LISTEN!!!

AS YOU ALREADY KNOW PASCO COUNTY IS EXPERIENCING SEVERE PROBLEMS RE OUR HUGE INCREASES IN HOMEOWNERS INSURANCE.  I HAVE BEEN IN  CONTACT WITH SOME OF OUR LOCAL OFFICIALS WHO ASSURE ME THEY HAVE PASSED SOME LEGISLATION THAT MAY HELP THE SITUATION AFTER THE NEW YEAR.  I TOLD THEM I WILL BE OUT OF BUSINESS BY THEN - AS WILL BE MANY OTHERS IN THE REAL ESTATE OR RELATED FIELDS.

MY HUSBAND AND I OWN A LOCAL REAL ESTATE COMPANY.  WHERE WE ARE SMALL IN NUMBERS OF EMPLOYEES AND REALTORS, WE ARE ALWAYS ONE OF THE TOP THREE PRODUCING AGENTS IN THE WEST PASCO BOARD OF REALTORS.  OUR BUSINESS HAS COME TO A SCREECHING HALT IN THE LAST MONTH.  WE WILL HAVE NO INCOME TO PAY OUR OVERHEAD OR PERSONAL BILLS COME THE END OF AUGUST.  WE HAVE NOT PUT UNDER CONTRACT ONE OF OUR LISTINGS SINCE JULY 7TH.  WE NORMALLY HAVE 8-10 PER MONTH.  

WE ARE NOT EXPERIENCING A NORMAL SLOW DOWN AS ALL THE NATIONAL ECONOMISTS ARE SAYING, IT IS IF SOMEONE HAS TURNED OFF THE FAUCET!  

WE HAVE A TOTAL OF 10 EMPLOYEES AND AGENTS AT OUR OFFICE THAT DEPEND ON REAL ESTATE TO MAKE A LIVING.  I HAVE JUST LET GO MY TWO RECEPTIONISTS AND AM HOPING I DON'T  HAVE TO LET MY PERSONAL ASSISTANT GO - THAT WOULD MEAN I WOULD RUN THE OFFICE MYSELF. 

MY HUSBAND AND I HAVE BEEN SELF EMPLOYED MOST OF OUR WORKING LIFE AND ARE USED TO THE UPS AND DOWNS.  WE ARE USED TO SPENDING MONEY TO MAKE THINGS HAPPEN, BUT WITH THIS SITUATION WE FEEL COMPLETELY HELPLESS.  THEIR IS NOTHING WE CAN PERSONALLY DO TO CHANGE WHAT IS FUELING THIS CRISIS, ASIDE FROM CUTTING EXPENSES TO THE BONE, WHICH WE HAVE ALREADY DONE.  

I GUESS OUR NEXT DECISION WILL BE HOW LONG WE USE OUR SAVINGS TO PAY BILLS AND RUN OUR BUSINESS - THIS IS WHERE OUR STATE GOVERNMENT MUST STEP IN AND HELP.  SOMETHING MUST BE DONE TO CUT THE HIGH INSURANCE BILLS OUR COUNTY IS EXPERIENCING OR WE WILL BE FACING THE DECISION TO MOVE OUT OF STATE, LIKE MANY OF OUR CLIENTS HAVE DECIDED TO DO.  ALTHOUGH THEY CAN'T SELL THEIR HOUSE TO MOVE!!!

WE LOVE THE FLORIDA LIFESTYLE AND DO NOT WANT TO UPROOT OUR FAMILY BUT IF THIS DIRE SITUATION DOES NOT END SOON WE WILL BE FORCED TO TAKE OUR THREE YOUNG CHILDREN SOMEWHERE ELSE WHERE THINGS ARE MORE AFFORDABLE AND THE POSSIBILITY OF MAKING A LIVING IN REAL ESTATE IS VIABLE.

PLEASE HELP US!!!

Sincerely,

SUSAN HORAN
11336 Oyster Bay Cir
New Port Richey , FL 34654

From:	Alane Laboda <Alane.Laboda@henlaw.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 12:53 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Tara Pascotto Paluck-applicant for the Twentieth Judicial Circuit County Court Judge position

Dear Governor Bush,
 
It is my understanding that Tara Pascotto Paluck has been selected as a possible candidate for the appointed position of County Court Judge in the Twentieth Judicial Circuit.  I have been a long time friend and colleague of Tara.  I have known Tara for close to thirty years. In that time she has never done anything that would ever call her reputation into question.  She is an amazing person.  I have had the opportunity to work with Tara professionally.  She is the walking example of what other attorneys in our profession should strive to become.  She is honest, sincere, ethical and a zealous advocate for her clients rights.  She has worked hard to rise to the top of her profession.  As a result of her many years of hard work she has earned a reputation as excellent attorney.
 
Tara and I worked together at the State Attorney's Office prosecuting cases.  Tara always managed to let the law and her conscience be her guide.  After leaving the State Attorney's Office she went to work in civil litigation.  She has many years of both civil and criminal legal experience.  She has the ability to be fair and impartial despite the issue(s). It is this combination of experience and personal stability that would make her perfect to serve on the  County Court bench. 
 
Tara is also a devoted mother to her two boys and her husband, Ron.  She manages to balance the everyday challenges of being both in a high stress career and a mother/wife.  It takes a special kind of person to be able to multi-task as well as Tara can do so. 
 
If Tara is selected to serve as a Judge on the County Court Judiciary she would do a great job for both the citizens of Lee County and the State of Florida. 
 
If I can provide you any additional information please do not hesitate to contact me at the address or phone numbers below.
 
Sincerely, 



Alane Laboda
Attorney at Law
Henderson, Franklin, Starnes & Holt, P.A.
