From:	eronpalomalundy@earthlink.net
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 10:09 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	ddbrownministries@earthlink.net
Subject:	[*] Special Invitation


Good Morning Governor Bush;
 
I am a member of the Greater A. O. H. Church of God in Ocala, Florida.  The reason for this message is to invite you to a special event we will be having on Saturday, September 16, 2006.  The event will be from 9:00 am -- 7:00 pm.  It is our desire to have different political figures here on that day to talk with the voters and do some campaigning.
 
The purpose of the "Old Fashioned Feast Day" is to raise the funds needed to complete a new addition to our facility.  This facility will include a larger dining room {where we feed less fortunate individuals 2 hot meals Monday -- Friday and dinner on Saturday}, tutoring, a community library, and a Christian School.  We do not receive government funding for our services, we have fundraisers during the year and receive donations from individuals from the church and community.
 
There will be fun and activities for everyone.  We will have performances from area churches and organizations.  There will be BBQ ribs, chicken, fried "fresh" fish, collard greens, macaroni n' cheese, sweet potato pie, iced tea, and much more.
 
The address is 921 S W Dr. D. D. Brown Street (S W 3rd Street); Ocala, FL  34474.  We hope that you will find time to come visit with us.  For more information call (352) 622-4147.  Thank you for your time.

From: Muriel Gerlich [mailto:pgerlich@tampabay.rr.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, August 01, 2006 7:23 PM
To: Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject: Homeowner's insurance and our economy


Dear Lt. Governor Jennings:

We need help now. Being a Realtor and doing business right here in Pasco County, FL for 16 years I have seen some big changes in the last 10 months. Homeowners and businesses are leaving our state in droves. Most all of our company listings are of homeowners being pushed out of their homes right out to another state other than Florida. Our current sales market has dwindled to a fast stop. No one can qualify for the homeowners insurance and property taxes on top of a mortgage payment. Since everyone is trying to leave and prospective home buyers can't qualify for the insurance and taxes; we are left with pending foreclosures. According to Realty Trac we currently have 4100 pre-foreclosure homes in West Pasco county! The West side of 19 in Pasco county will soon be a ghost town. We went from 800 homes on the market in October of 2005 to over 5400 homes currently for sale in West Pasco county. 

We cannot wait until next year to resolve this issue. We need to have a special session called now so that we can address this problem and come up with solutions immediately. If this is put off it will only cost all of us more in the long run. Real estate is the heartbeat of every community. If this isn't addressed quickly there will be a huge rippling effect. Larger than what we have already witnessed. 

Thank you,
Muriel Gerlich

Sincerely,

Muriel Gerlich
11606 Eastern Star Ct
New Port Richey , FL 34654

From:	Cortez Albert NMI SGT JADOC/164 ADA <Albert.Cortez@bolling.af.mil>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 2:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Joint Air Defense Operation Center

Good Day Sir,

 

Since 9/11, Air Defense Artillery units from South Carolina, New Mexico, Florida and Mississippi have been vigilant in their mission to protect the National Capital Region and—on order— other high-value assets within the United States from air attacks.

These units are unquestionably performing the most important peacetime mission ever assigned to the National Guard. We do not know of any other job being done at the present time, which is more important to the safety and well being of our nation. It’s a job, which must be done perfectly every minute of the day and night, and every day of the year. Any failure here regardless of how slight could mean disaster.

The command and control missions are currently performed by the Guard-manned Task Force Osprey at the Joint Air Defense Operations Center, located within the National Capital Region. Commanded by Colonel Frank Laudano of the 164th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, Florida Army National Guard, Task Force Osprey is breaking new ground on how Army air and missile defense operates within the United States.

If you ever have a time, we would be honored for you to come visit your FL National Guard troops currently mobilized, Operation Noble Eagle, at the Nation’s Capital. For further information please feel free to contact 1LT Hall or SGT Cortez @ 202-767-1055. Thank you for your time.

 

 

//SIGNED//

SGT ALBERT CORTEZ 
Joint Air Defense Operations Center
J1 NCOIC, TF OSPREY
DSN: 297-1729
Comm: 202-767-1729
Fax: 202-404-8179
DSN Fax 754-8179

From:	Plym1969@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 9:19 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject:	A++ plan -- living example that it works

Dear Governor Bush:
 
My name is Pam Oakes and I am a living example that the A++ program works.
 
As a sixth grader (1976) at Caloosa Middle School (Cape Coral, Fla.), I volunteered to be a school newspaper reporter. I loved it! In eighth grade, I was promoted to editor. (Meanwhile, I was enrolled in all the advance courses and participated in regional and state science fairs.) 
 
As a high school student, I worked in the editorial department of the Cape Coral Daily Breeze (1982-1983). I typeset community news copy and did an occasional article for the evening paper. (Meanwhile, I was an advanced high school student and represented Florida as a finalist and U.S. Air Force second place winner in the International Science and Engineering Fair -- 1982 and 1983.)
 
I attended college and moved around to the Daily Breeze sister papers (to accommodate my collegiate and post educational schedule 1984-86, 1987-1989). I became the editor of a monthly, speciality publication (Senior News, 1990) and moved back to daily papers the next year (Charlotte Sun Herald, Englewood Sun Herald, Punta Gorda Herald,1991-1993). I excelled in the media, receiving four Florida Press Association awards between 1988 through 1993. I loved being a newspaper reporter/editor, but I knew that there was something more that I enjoyed -- cars. 
 
I grew up in an automotive family on the east side of Detroit. My great-grandfather, grandfather and father were technicians and I continued the tradition becoming the fourth generation mechanic. I left the newspaper industry to work with my father, Jerry Oakes, November 1993.
 
I worked for an independent shop approximately a year and a half. I knew that I could do better. So, I started my own shop, Pam's Motor City Automotive (Fort Myers, Fla.) in 1995. There was one technician -- me. I was the service writer, the advertising director and bookkeeper, as well. Today, I have 15 technicians/support personnel running the multi-million dollar auto repair and tire sales shop. 
 
I still turn wrenches.
 
Yes, I am an example that early exposure influences. Let our future generations experience the same type of "hands-on" learning that taught me work ethics, gave me the ability to do something I love and contribute to society. 
 
 
 
 
 
Sincerely,
Pamela Oakes,ASE
owner
Pam's Motor City Automotive
Fort Myers, Fl
239-278-0086

Dear Governor Bush:

I am probably one of the few local realtors that have not obtained a second job yet to try to support my failing business.

Floridians are demanding that the insurance industry be regulated. 
Please call a special session to investigate the activities of the insurance industry NOW!!! I will be out of business by next year along with most other small business owners in Florida! It's pretty ironic that the hurricanes and sinkholes aren't ruining us. Our own state is!

From:	Tish Osborne <posborne@prutropical.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 4:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	We need special session on homeowners insurance!

Dear Governor Bush:

Please get into special session and do something about this homeowners insurance crisis. It has crippled my business, sent many of my coworkers in real estate and mortgage lending out of business, and brought me real concern about my neighbors. As a Realtor, I have had many deals go by the wayside because buyers cannot afford the cost of insurance, which adds hundreds of dollars to their monthly mortgage bill. Moreover, I see many senior citizens dropping insurance entirely on their paid-for homes. If we should have a storm in these circumstances, I don't know what we will do. I've seen this crisis rob my neighbors of their sense of security in a way not even the tragedy of 9-11 did. They are assuming huge risk they would not otherwise for their own homes, against what they believe,
because they have been forced to it. Please find a remedy now. It is a terrible burden for so many.

Sincerely,

Tish Osborne
6428 Sentry Way Apt 2
New Port Richey , FL 34653

From:	Mariana Pinango <mpinango@latinamericanassoc.org>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 3:34 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Join us for LAA's 18th Annual Latin Fever Ball!

Web Bug from http://rs6.net/on.jsp?t=1101358086803.0.1011270012058.9021&ts=S0197&o=http://ui.constantcontact.com/images/p1x1.gif Saludos! 
 	



Atlanta's premier event celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month is soon approaching! We hope you will join us the evening of September 16, 2006 to celebrate the vitality of the Latino culture and the work of the Latin American Association. 

It is because of your support of this special event year after year that we are able to provide a comprehensive range of needed services to 70,000 area Latinos and their families. It is also because of your support that we are able to be responsive when emergency strikes. 

In addition to the Gala, our Silent Auction is also important in supporting LAA’s programs and services. Below is a sampling of a few items that will be available for bid during Latin Fever Ball:

Just a sampling of our Silent Auction features...

*	Domestic and International Delta tickets
*	Restaurant gift certificates
*	Hotel getaways
*	Atlanta Opera Center tickets
*	Golf tee time
*	Jewelry, art, and much more!

Don't miss out!

The Latin Fever Ball has come to mean a joyous celebration of all that is Latin to the Atlanta community. Contribute to a great cause by joining us at seven o’clock at the Ballroom of the Grand Hyatt in Buckhead for an evening that you won't soon forget! Individual tickets are selling quickly, but are still available. 

Tickets

Please call (404) 638-1815 or click here to purchase tickets.

¡Muchisimas gracias por su apoyo incondicional!

About Us
The Latin American Association is a nonprofit organization that provides comprehensive transitional services for Latinos as they strive for self-sufficiency and an enhanced quality of life. By responding to our community’s basic needs, we help its members gain knowledge and skills necessary to fully participate in the larger community.

From:	Michelle Flood <mflood@prutropical.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 3:32 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Home owners insurance

Dear Governor Bush:

Although I copied this letter I strongly agree with it's content.

Florida is losing ground daily in our economy.  We are having people relocate out of our state due to the high costs of insurance for their homes and businesses.



We can not wait until next year to resolve this issue.  We need to have a special session called now so that we can address this problem and come up with solutions immediately.



If we don't address this problem now, it will more cost more and be harder to resolve next year.  Please consider the loss in revenue the state will realize from doc stamps on mortgages and on the deed transfer.  If sales are down, so will revenue be effected in these areas and many others.  Can the state afford this loss of revenue?



Please call a special session now to get working on this situation.  To delay is costly to everyone.

Sincerely,

Michelle Flood
8034 Moonlight Ln
New Port Richey , FL 34654

All the money that's is used to help other country's  out with and there families could help me our government is so quick to help with non Americans what about us , how would the governor feel if he only brought home less than $200 a week to raise 3 children on plus pay bills plus have to buy gas to get back and forth with, on top of that your daily needs like toilet paper and soap and shampoo to bath with,soap to wash your dishes and clothes with, but he cant get daycare assistance so he can work to keep providing for his family as a single parent. It is not a fun game to play having to worry from day to day if I can afford to pay for a day care expense of $110.00 a week for just one child and pay someone to watch my other 2 children so I can work ,or if I am going to make my rent every week so I am not living on the streets with me and my 3 daughters because I cant get help from my own government let alone my own country with child care assistance. From:	Beth@eNaplesFlorida.com
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 2:15 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Excellence in Industry 2006 Invitation

	
 
Dear Jeb
	
You are cordially invited to attend the Economic Development Council of Collier County's Excellence in Industry Celebration that will be held on the evening of Thursday, September 14, 2006 beginning at 5:30 P.M. at the Naples Beach Hotel and Golf Club.
 
The Excellence in Industry Award is given to top companies in Collier County that exemplify a positive, responsible approach to economic diversification and community enhancement. The award categories are: Business Expansion Award, Newcomer Award, Entrepreneurship Award and Innovation Award this award is given to one company in the following categories: small (1-25 employees), medium (26-75) employees,  large (76 or more).  Companies receiving the awards have been automatically entered into the state level competition for consideration in the Governor's Diversification Awards.
 
Also to be announced at the event are the incoming EDC Board of Directors, as well as the "Outstanding Volunteer of the Year" which is the highest accolade bestowed by the EDC to its member volunteers.
 
Reservations are currently being accepted for the evening award celebration, tickets are $150.00 each and can be reserved by calling the EDC at 239-263-8989, formal invitations will also be mailed soon.
 
Space is limited, please register in advance, for more information please visit our web site at www.enaplesflorida.com or www.excellenceinindustry.com, sponsorship opportunities are still available. 


Look forward to celebrating business success with you! 



Beth Skotzke 
Events and Communications Manager

From:	hector millan <hectoreman@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 1, 2006 10:22 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Medical Laws in California and Florida

08/01/06
 
 
 

From:     Hector Millan
              5530 80th st n c201
              St Petersburg, Fl. 33709
              
To:         Governor Jeb Bush
 
 
 
Hello Governor Bush.  This is Hector Millan.  Sir I wanted to ask you a question regarding a recent study I was doing online regarding Prop. 215 in California and its Medical Marijuana Laws.  Sir, I was wondering, "Why hasn't Florida adapted to Prop. 215 as California has.  Below I sent you a copy of Prop. 215 from California's state laws:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Text of California’s Proposition 215 
(CA Health & Safety Code 11362.5) 
The Compassionate Use Act of 1996 
California’s ‘Medical Marijuana’ Law 
This initiative measure is submitted to the people in accordance with the provisions of Article II, Section 8 of the Constitution. 
This initiative measure adds a section to the Health and Safety Code; therefore, new provisions proposed to be added are printed in italic type to indicate that they are new. 
===================== 
THE LAW!:
--------------- 
SECTION 1. Section 11362.5 is added to the Health and Safety Code, reads: 
11362.5. (a) This section shall be known and may be cited as the Compassionate Use Act of 1996. (b)(1) The people of the State of California hereby find and declare that the purposes of the Compassionate Use Act of 1996 are as follows: (A) To ensure that seriously ill Californians have the right to obtain and use marijuana for medical purposes where that medical use is deemed appropriate and has been recommended by a physician who has determined that the person's health would benefit from the use of marijuana in the treatment of cancer, anorexia, AIDS, chronic pain, spasticity, glaucoma, arthritis, migraine, or any other illness for which marijuana provides relief. 
 
(B) To ensure that patients and their primary caregivers who obtain and use marijuana for medical purposes upon the recommendation of a physician are not subject to criminal prosecution or sanction. (C) To encourage the federal and state governments to implement a plan to provide for the safe and affordable distribution of marijuana to all patients in medical need of marijuana. (2) Nothing in this section shall be construed to supersede legislation prohibiting persons from engaging in conduct that endangers others, nor to condone the diversion of marijuana for non-medical purposes. (c) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no physician in this state shall be punished, or denied any right or privilege, for having recommended marijuana to a patient for medical purposes. (d) Section 11357, relating to the possession of marijuana, and Section 11358, relating to the cultivation of marijuana, shall not apply to a patient, or to a patient's primary caregiver, who possesses or cultivates marijuana for the personal medical purposes of the patient upon the written or oral recommendation or approval of a physician. (e) For the purposes of this section, ''primary caregiver" means the individual designated by the person exempted under this section who has consistently assumed responsibility for the housing, health, or safety of that person. 
SEC. 2. If any provision of this measure or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, that invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the measure that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this measure are severable. 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
Sir, what I want to know is, "Why hasn't Florida adapted to Prop. 215?" According to http://www.doh.state.fl.us/disease_ctrl/aids/updates/facts/usfl.html 
Florida is third behind New York, and California with more than 75,000 AIDS cases that have been reported and this is before the year 2000!
 
In California patients who are eligible to get a Medical Marijuana Prescription are required to carry a Prop. 215 Medical Marijuana Identification Card in order for the Doctors to know that they are eligible to get a prescription.  In this website http://www.rivcommic.org/downloads/DHS_9042_Application-Renewal_Form.pdf from Riverside County they have an application for the Patients Medical Marijuana Application/Renewal Program sponsored by the State of California Health and Human Services Agency and the Dept. Of Health Services.  I believe if Florida does the same and starts an application process for the patients with cancer, anorexia, AIDS, chronic pain, spasticity, glaucoma, arthritis, migraine, or any other illness for which marijuana provides relief that it would do the State of Florida better.  
 
This would benefit our state by dropping a crime rate.  It would lead to fewer arrests if they have it prescribed, fewer people growing it and selling it as well.  Our jail here in Pinellas county is already overpopulated.  It would benefit everyone if people adapted to California's State Prop. 215.
 
Sir, basically I just wanted to know, "What's the difference in us being in Florida and not being able to get the prescription as to California?"
 


Thank You,
Hector E. Millan

It is with great pleasure that I have the opportunity to write on behalf of Harold S. Eskin who has been selected by the 20th Judicial Circuit Judicial Nomination Committee to fill the recently vacated Lee County Judgeship.

 

I am a retired federal employee, having spent nearly 30 years in public service with the U.S Department of Housing and Urban Development, mostly as a manager at it’s headquarters in Washington, D.C.  As such, I was fortunate enough to work for President Bush’s administration.  

 

I moved to Florida in August of 2004 and now operate a consulting company specializing in the development and preservation of affordable housing for families and seniors.  

 

I serve on the Board of Directors of the Rotary Club of Cape Coral Gold Coast (Mr. Eskin is a Past President and member); the Board of Directors of Gulf Coast Village, a non-profit Continuum of Care Retirement Center in Cape Coral (Mr. Eskin is a Past President and current Board member and Counsel). Personally, I also have observed Mr. Eskin in various circumstances and found that his is courteous and helpful, always mindful of the needs of others, always willing to lend a helping hand.  

 

For the foregoing reasons, I enthusiastically support Mr. Eskin’s selection for the bench. 

 

Respectfully submitted, 

 

Marc A. Harris

Erin Abercrombie Surrenders

By Dana Willhoit
The Ledger





Erin and James Abercrombie 

LAKELAND -- Erin Abercrombie turned herself in Thursday night on a warrant stemming from a secret videotape she and her husband made, and she posted bail six hours later.

Her husband, James Abercrombie, who is out of town with their teenage daughter, will meet Erin in Bartow today so he can turn himself in and she can pick up their daughter, she said.

A warrant for interception of a wire communication was filed after they secretly videotaped a meeting they had with Donnie Tyler, a builder, in their home. Tyler had planned to put 29 homes on 14.77 acres near the Abercrombies' property off Gibsonia-Galloway Road.

That property was the subject of a bitter four-year court battle that the Abercrombies waged to prevent another developer from putting 33 homes on it.

The Abercrombies eventually prevailed against the Planning Commission, which had voted to increase the density allowed on the land so the developer could build the homes.

Senior Court Judge E. Randolph Bentley ultimately struck down the Planning Commission's zoning decision. The Abercrombies were reimbursed $71,000 by the county for their legal expenses.

Friday night, Erin Abercrombie said that she and her husband had no idea that secretly videotaping Tyler was illegal. "We watched `60 Minutes,' we watched `Dateline,' they all do that," she said.

They dropped the tape off at the State Attorney's Office before they went to a Polk County Planning Commission meeting last month, Abercrombie said. "Would we have done that if we thought we were doing anything illegal?"

Originally, she said, they videotaped Tyler "so we could see what he meant and what he wanted" when he was talking about this new planned development.

According to the Abercrombies, the tape shows Tyler claiming that the new development had the blessing of Merle Bishop, Polk's growth management director.

Bishop has denied telling Tyler that the development had his blessing.

The Planning Commission voted 3-2 last month to deny Tyler's proposed development.

Abercrombie said that the six hours she spent in jail Thursday night were the worst in her life. "It's dirty, it's stinky, it's cold, it's awful."

She and her husband are still $400,000 in debt because of their lawsuit against the county and can't afford a lawyer to fight these charges, she said. On Monday, they may try to find a lawyer who will represent them pro bono.

Dana Willhoit can be reached at dana.willhoit@theledger.com or 863-802-7550.

From:	Kimberly Richbourg <kimberlyrichbourg@cox.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 30, 2006 12:00 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	dealing with immigration issues

As a resident of Florida and a natural born American citizen, I feel obliged to share the news article below with  you and the rest of our legislators, senators and government officials.    We could learn a lot from their stand.  My husband has been a teacher in this state for 18 years.  It absolutely infuriates me that HE is expected to be able to communicate with Spanish speaking students in his classroom.  Then, if he fails the student (who can speak NO English and therefore can't communicate or participate in classroom activities) then HE has to justify his actions and document pages,  upon pages of information.  This creates SO much extra work for an already UNDERPAID professional.  
 
We, as Americans, could learn ALOT from Australia.  Thank you for taking the time to read this.  You really should make sure that George sees this too!!  I feel certain that your father would agree with everything that is stated below.
 
Sincerely, 
Kimberly Richbourg
Niceville, Florida
 
THREE CHEERS FOR AUSTRALIA 

I wish the leaders of our country would take a stand like Australia ...


Muslims who want to live under Islamic Sharia law were told on Wednesday to get out of Australia, as the government targeted radicals in a bid to head off potential terror attacks. 

A day after a group of mainstream Muslim leaders pledged loyalty to Australia at a special meeting with Prime Minister John Howard, he and his ministers made it clear that extremists would face a crackdown. 

Treasurer Peter Costello, seen as heir apparent to Howard, hinted that some radical clerics could be asked to leave the country if they did not accept that Australia was a secular state and its laws were made by parliament. 

"If those are not your values, if you want a country which has Sharia law or a theocratic state, then Australia is not for you," he said on national television. 

"I'd be saying to clerics who are teaching that there are two laws governing people in Australia, one the Australian law and another the Islamic law, that is false. If you can't agree with parliamentary law, independent courts, democracy, and would prefer Sharia law and have the opportunity to go to another country, which practices it, perhaps, then, that's a better option," Costello said. 

Asked whether he meant radical clerics would be forced to leave, he said those with dual citizenship could possibly be asked to move to the other country. 

Education Minister Brendan Nelson later told reporters that Muslims who did not want to accept local values should "clear off". 

"Basically, people who don't want to be Australians, and they don't want to live by Australian values and understand them, well then they can basically clear off," he said. Separately, Howard angered some Australian Muslims on Wednesday by saying he supported spy agencies monitoring the nation's mosques. 

AMERICA and Canada ..... ARE YOU LISTENING? 

Quote: 

IMMIGRANTS, NOT AUSTRALIANS, MUST ADAPT. Take It Or Leave It ! I am tired of this nation worrying about whether we are offending some individual or their culture. Since the terrorist attacks on Bali , we have experienced a surge in patriotism by the majority of Australians 

However, the dust from the attacks had barely settled when the "politically correct" crowd began complaining about the possibility that our patriotism was offending others. I am not against immigration, nor do I hold a grudge against anyone who is seeking a better life by coming to Australia . 

However, there are a few things that those who have recently come to our country, and apparently some born here, need to understand. 

This idea of Australia being a multicultural community has served only to dilute our sovereignty and our national identity. As Australians, we have our own culture, our own society, our own language and our own lifestyle. 

This culture has been developed over two centuries of struggles, trials and victories by millions of men and women who have sought freedom. We speak mainly ENGLISH, not Spanish, Lebanese, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, Russian, or any other language. Therefore, if you wish to become part of our society, then learn the language! 

Most Australians believe in God. This is not some Christian, right wing, political push but a fact because Christian men and women, on Christian principles, founded this nation, and this is clearly documented. It is certainly appropriate to display it on the walls of our schools. If God offends you, then I suggest you consider another part of the world as your new home, Because God is part of our culture. 

We will accept your beliefs and will not question why, all we ask is that you accept ours and live in harmony and peaceful enjoyment with us. 

If the Southern Cross offends you, or you don't like "A Fair Go", then you should seriously consider a move to another part of this planet. 

We are happy with our culture and have no desire to change, and we really don't care how you did things where you came from. By all means keep your culture but do not force it on others. 

This is OUR COUNTRY, OUR LAND, and OUR LIFESTYLE, and we will allow you every opportunity to enjoy all this, but once you are done complaining, whining, and griping about Our Flag, Our Pledge, Our Christian beliefs, or Our Way of Life, I highly encourage you take advantage of one other great Australian freedom, "THE RIGHT TO LEAVE." 

If you aren't happy here then LEAVE. We didn't force you to come here. You asked to be here. So accept the country YOU accepted.

From:	Jamie Flatley <lilflats07@gmail.com>
Sent:	Saturday, July 29, 2006 2:42 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 28, 2006

Gov Jeb Bush and Lt. Gov Toni Jennings also attended a TTRM Summit to recognize many astounding teenagers in his very own state of Florida...Why is that not mentioned in this?


On 7/29/06, Jeb Bush <jeb.bush@myflorida.com> wrote: 

For those eNewsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here: 

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the eNewsletter is below.


GOVERNOR BUSH AWARDS RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE FUND GRANT TO THE CITY OF ARCADIA 

On Monday, I awarded a Rural Infrastructure Fund Grant totaling $30,000 to
the City of Acadia for a Feasibility Study to determine the beneficial
impact of reconstructing and expanding the former Arcadia Rodeo facility. 
Arcadia is within DeSoto County which I re-designated in 2006 as part of a
'Rural Area of Critical Economic Concern'.  The Arcadia Rodeo is the oldest
rodeo in Florida dating back to 1929 and known throughout the southeastern 
United States.  This feasibility grant will assist the City in determining
how best to rebuild and expand a new rodeo facility which will have multiple
uses.  I am truly pleased to support their initiative through our rural 
development grants. The benefits of this study will help the community
recover from the devastating impacts of the 2004 hurricane season.
Preservation of Arcadia All-Florida Championship Rodeo is an important
component of DeSoto County's long-term recovery plan, and grants are a
significant tool to help them meet their goals.


GOVERNOR BUSH AND LT. GOVERNOR JENNINGS JOIN FLORIDIANS IN SAVING MONEY
DURING THE 2006 SALES TAX HOLIDAY 

On Monday, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings and I joined back-to-school shoppers
at Target to buy books, clothing and school supplies during this year's
sales tax holiday.  School items purchased by and Lt. Governor Jennings 
myself will be provided to our mentees.
I encourage all Floridians to take advantage of this year's tax holiday on
school supplies, as we prepare for the upcoming school year.  I also
encourage Floridians to buy extra items and donate them to those less 
fortunate.  Businesses and shoppers with questions regarding the sales tax
holiday can contact the Department of Revenue toll-free taxpayer assistance
line at 1-800-352-3671 between 8 a.m. and 7 p.m. on weekdays.  Information 
also is available through the Department of Revenue web site at
www.myflorida.com/dor or by visiting a Department of Revenue Service Center.


GOVERNOR JEB BUSH SIGNS HB 209 

On Thursday, I signed HB 209 eliminating the last part of Florida's
insidious Intangibles Tax.  I thank Senators Jeff Atwater and Charlie Clary
and Representative Fred Brummer for leading the charge in the Legislature to 
rid Floridians of this burdensome and fundamentally unfair tax. The repeal
of this tax eliminates the penalty on Floridians who take responsibility for
their own retirement by saving and investing over a lifetime. It will save 
300,000 taxpayers more than $131 million next year.  It is a bad tax.
Florida will no longer discourage its citizens from preparing for the
future. I am proud of the hard work of the Florida Legislature on behalf of 
Florida's taxpayers. Since 1999, we have worked with the Legislature to
provide our citizens and growing businesses more than $19 billion in tax
relief. Finally, I thank President Tom Lee and Speaker Allan Bense for their 
leadership and continued attention to important tax relief issues.


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO TEEN TRENDSETTER DEXTER CRAIGIE

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winner, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8040


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com .

____________________________________________________________________
Volume 8, Issue 29
Copyright(c) 2006 State of Florida

If you would like to change your subscription or unsubscribe, please go to: 
http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html


Thank you.








-- 
Jamie Flatley

Dear Govenor Bush
i have written to your office three times, last time in current to ask for a personal pardon, for a crime i didnt commit
i served honorably in vietnam and shortly after my return i was beaten by a deputy named herb grimes, which i proved
was done wrongfully. in my law suit that was handled by a dennis j plews of manatee county i had been promised that
if i would settle for a meer $10.000 that because he had lied they would decertifie him it was never done!. and i suffered
untold harrassment by his friends. my life was even threatend that if they couldnt get him back on they would kill me!.
he stayed on the bradenton police department as he worked as head of security at tropicana orange company.
after time passed he came back on the manatee county sheriffs office in a higher position than he had been disscharged from,
less than a few weeks later two friends of grimes. a deputy henderson and fieber showed up at my house at one in the morning
on a complaint that was over a supposed cb radio despute that by record was supposed to have been reported a 9pm that evening
when they attempted to enter my home threating me over what made no sense i was in mortal fear for my life and when attacked in my bedroom
by these men with no warrent and no apparent reason for being there i tryed to defend myself with a old 22 rifle my father had given me by showing it to them and asking that they leave my home. dureing the trial none of these facts were allowed to be brought out and when i tryed to
prove grimes was behind it all i was told if i brought his name up again they would lock me in the back and hold the trial without me being there.
i dont know what kinda deal my attourney at that time made with the assistant attourney but john cole my attourney couldnt even recite case historys the state attourney had to finish them for him and even the state attourney at the end of trial said it wasnt right to send someone to prison on a first offence. but the judge said he had no discretion in the matter. over the years now i have written every part of the judical system
with no resolve, its like i dont matter at all. govenor martineze's office when i sent a registered letter to, miss ottey gooding said to never send another registerd letter again she handled all the govenors corrospondence. yet a week later i read in the paper he had time to play a tv role in some james bond flick. in any case i just turned 50 this july and since my auto accident i cant do much but i worked security before my good name was tarnished and if you could find it in your heart to help me out without all the red tape maybe i could get me a little job doing security again to supplement my dissabilty so i can live like normal people. besides i used to like to go hunting with my dad who is dead now and because of whats been done i havent been able to since before he died and i really miss that as my father was a ex police officer and kept telling me it would all work out and we would go again soon!. he died and we never did.
Dear Jeb Bush i dont have the money to fight or any hope left which is why im writting you cant you find it in your heart to lift this injustice off of me so i can as a veteran have the right to serve and protect and not have to make excuses when my friends wan to go hunting and die a little each time they bring back a nice dear or boar i cant even share the hope for!.
so far the aids that you assigned in the past years have done nothing to help me so im asking you. 
PLEASE CANT YOU HELP?
sincerly James c Martin III

Subject:	FL Commission on Human Relations

TO: Brevard County State Delegation

 

FROM: Andrew Anderson, Councilmember, City of Palm Bay

 

RE: Florida Commission on Human Relations (FCHR)

 

July 28, 2006

 

 

Please read following letter I received from the Florida Commission on Human Relations (FCHR) regarding Palm Bay’s proposed ordinance regarding legal workers. 

 

I was shocked and dismayed that a State Commission sent a letter. It is very apparent that the Commission did not read the current version of the ordinance. It is a very overt attempt to affect the outcome of a local issue. I feel that the commission should be educated on the facts and refrain from making assumptions based on inaccurate information.

 

Any assistance in this matter would be appreciated. 

 

I was informed that a member (staff or commissioner) will attend the council meeting to speak against the ordinance. This may be embarrassing for the State if they do not have the facts.

 

Respectfully,

 

Andy Anderson

Councilmember

City of Palm Bay

 

 

 

 

 

July 27, 2006

 

Palm Bay City Council

Councilman Andy Anderson

120 Malabar Rd SE

Palm Bay, FL 32907

 

Dear Councilman Anderson,

 

The Florida Commission on Human Relations (FCHR) has strong concerns with the potential consequences of the proposed illegal immigration ordinance that will be considered during the August 3rd Palm Bay City Council meeting.  FCHR is the state agency charged with enforcing the Florida Civil Rights Act.  The Florida Legislature has declared that the purpose of these laws is to protect the people of Florida from discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, marital status or familial status.  

 

FCHR believes that this proposal could lead to unlawful and discriminatory activities in your community.  A city ordinance of this nature will likely create a hostile and divisive environment that could result in hate crimes, racial/ethnic profiling and unlawful, discriminatory acts against all members of many ethnic groups.  These are the types of actions that we must collectively work together to prevent.  We were pleased that the ordinance was tabled during your last meeting so that adequate time and consideration of all possible ramifications could be weighed.

 

At FCHR, it is our duty to ensure that the civil and human rights of Florida residents are protected to the fullest extent of the law.  Therefore, we will monitor the situation very closely and will respond promptly to any violation of Florida law.  As a nation based on freedom, we urge you to consider all of the consequences that could result if such a proposal is passed.  Thank you for your consideration of this critical matter.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

Derick Daniel

Executive Director 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

From:	The Gauthier's <jgjg@bellsouth.net>

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	US Flag Etiquette

Hello Jeb, I am the president of the Timber Pines Community Association, we are a gated senior community in Spring Hill (Hernando County) FL.  Our community has 3452 homes comprising some 57 individual villages, having some 6,000 residents. 
 
As we are a senior community, many of the residents are either retired military or served in the various branches of the military.  A practice that has been on going for several years has been to lower the US flag  to half staff at the entrance to the village where a service connected person has past on.
 
We recently received a letter from a retired US Air Force person complaining about the disrespect that was being displayed by lowering the flag without proper authorization. 
 
We are aware that there are specific days that this can be done, and that only the President or the Governor can authorize any exceptions.
 
Since we are a self contained community (walled with gated  access), is it possible to obtain permission from you the Governor to allow us continue lowering the flag at the death of these service related people?
 
Sincerely,
 
John Gauthier Director/President
Timber Pines Community Association
 
jgjg@bellsouth.net

 Governor Bush:

Dear Governor Bush,

I understand there was much talk last year with  a Florida Representative 
and the Southern Offshore Fishing Association (SOFA) located in  Maderia 
Beach, FL concerning the commercial fishing industry and either a Federal 
or State  buy back program for commercial longliners. There has been 
speculation and interest regarding this topic amongst many small  “bandit” 
or hook and line commercial fishing owners regarding their ability to join 
this program, who also are federally documented and individually are 
relied upon for their families’ survival.

I have searched and searched with little success to find a definitive 
answer to the ACTUAL outcome of this subject and whether there really is 
something pending for current or future consideration, or if this was just 
something that was never actually lobbied, but just spoken about.

Personally, I would like an immediate response, as the answer will help us 
determine our current pending decision making concerning our family’s 
welfare, future, and financial security. You may or may not know, there 
has been a progressive fishing decline in past years, moratoriums and 
closures, all which have financial crippled the commercial fisherman’s 
lively hood and ability to maintain an adequate financial security.  We 
are individual owners of small boats, trying to make a living the old 
fashion way, and not large fleet owners with massive miles of hook and 
line.

I look forward to hearing from you very soon, and in advance appreciate 
your office’s consideration and research into this matter. I have also 
sent this letter to both Florida Senators, several Representatives and a 
Congresswoman, and President Bush’s office.

Respectfully submitted.

Thank you for your Florida Leadership. 

Sincerely,


Laura Poe-Leyden

Subject:	Recommendation for Jim DeKleva to 18th Judicial Circuit Court Bench

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I understand that Mr. Jim DeKleva's name has been submitted to you for consideration by the Judicial Nominating Committee for the 18th Judicial Circuit open bench position. I am very pleased to write this e-mail of recommendation on his behalf.

Jim has practiced in Seminole County for many years and is very familiar with our County and its local issues. He is respected by and has an excellent reputation with attorneys practicing in our area, including myself. As our areas of legal expertise diverge, I have referred numerous clients and acquaintances to Jim and all have had nothing but positive things to say about his handling of their case and about him personally. His demeanor and "no nonsense" attitude will be a welcome addition to our bench. I have no doubt that, following his appointment, he will serve the citizens of our County extremely well.

I urge you to appoint Jim to this position as I have no doubt that he will represent the Judiciary with authority and respect.

Thank you for your consideration of this recommendation.

Respectfully,
 
VIHLEN & SILLS, P.A.
 
Paul M. Sills

1173 Spring Centre South Boulevard, Suite C
Altamonte Springs, Florida 32714
Telephone No.:  (407) 786-2200
Facsimile No.:     (407) 786-2247
law@vihlensillspa.com

From:	svea lenea <svealenea@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 27, 2006 1:59 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Urgent Need for Your Help

(athis may be a duplicate -- I tried to send it
through the "myflorida" site, and I am not sure it
went)

Dear Governor Bush,
You appoint the Early Learning Coalition Chairs and
are about to appoint the new one for St. Johns/Putnam.
Before you do, I want to take 3 minutes to give you a
perspective from my 15+ years as the participant in NE
Florida on two Coalitions --Healthy Start, and Early
Learning.

The Coalition process can be a powerful one with
communities bringing programs together for
collaboration, reduced duplication, and local control
and problem solving. The NE FL Healthy Start Coalition
is outstanding --exceedingly well organized, managed,
and accountable. This is in part due to the fact that
staff are highly qualified and housed at the Regional
Planning Offices in Jacksonville -- which gives
important structure and a long history of successful
administration.
The Early Learning Coalition (first St. Johns, and now
the merged St.Johns and Putnam) on the other hand has
greatly struggled from the beginning. This is due in
part to competition for control of the Coalition and
money, poor QI/QA processes, entities thinking they
don't have to meet the terms of contracts, and to a
great extent, very poor staff management of the
processes.  AWI is giving good feedback and
suggestions, but the local folks are really having
difficulty.  From my perspective as a participant in
both groups from the inception of each -- savy
leadership without a conflict of interest is key.  
---Ester Tibbs from Gainesville DCF is a
strong example of that kind of leadership. She holds a
special recognition called the "Silver Award" as a
certified trainer in correct procedures for meetings,
etc. She is articulate, objective, and dedicated. I
have great admiration for her skills. She
would be an excellent choice as Chair of the St.
Johns,Putnam Early Learning Coalition however, she is
not from the private sector.  She has the background
to pull us out of a very deep hole.
--- OR, would it be possible to put the Early Learning
Coalition under the guidance of the Regional Planning
Offices in Jacksonville (they already serve these two
counties in other ways)?  I spoke with Brian Teeples
-- the Director there -- about the challenges we have
faced with the Early Learning Coalition procedures and
he offered any help he could give. They helped in the
past by giving a two day trianing on QI/QA processes
and techniques.

Help can be given and received only if welcomed.
That is the challenge. There has got to be a way to
make this process better serve the needs of the
communities involved through more effective management
at the local level. You will
note that both counties have very low (among the
lowest 5 counties in the state) Pre-K summer school
enrollment. That is just a small indicator.

Sorry for the lengthy message - I know you are busy.
I just wanted to make you aware of a great need on a
local level with some possible solutions.
I wish you the best as you move beyond the duties of
Governor of Florida! My family and I are strong
supporters of you and your brother as you lead our
country and state through tough times.  Good work --
it can't be easy with so much constant negative
feedback from a variety of sources. My son serves in
Kuwait as a private sector member of the Signal
Command with the Army Central Command. He has been
there since the beginning of the war.

Sincerely,
Kathy Mankinen
Past Chair, NE Florida Healthy Start Coalition
Past Treasurer, St. County School Readiness Coalition

From: michael fitzpatrick [mailto:mikearts62029@yahoo.com]
Sent: Thursday, July 20, 2006 9:27 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: One Man Wrecking Team?


Governor Bush:
   I read where the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council has said that you must call a special session of the Legislature to try and breathe life back into Florida's collapsed home resale market. Yes, the market has already collapsed. It collapsed because of your stubborn failure to call such a session right after the scheduled session failed to pass the only viable answer to the property insurance mess.
   The State of Florida needs a State Catastrophe Property Insurance Program with a state wide single per $1,000 of insured value premium rate that will cover all forms of natural or terrorist catastrophes. Yes, the same per $1,000 of insured value premium rate throughout Florida is necessary to solve the problem. Area, or regional rates are a part of the present problem, and they fail to recognize that Florida is a long narrow state that even "inland areas" are not safe from hurricanes, or tsunamis, earthquakes, or terrorist acts.
   Some facts: Over 25% of Floridian's have dropped their homeowner's insurance protection; Foreclosures have doubled, and the exhorbitant premium rates are the fault; Home for sale listings are up about 400% while home resales have slowed to a trickle as for sale signs litter our lawns.
   If you fail to call the special session, you will be labeled "The One Man Wrecking Team", the Governor who couldn't handle the single major crisis he faced during his period in office, as Florida's economy continues on it's way into the tank with the real estate market.
   Sincerely, Michael Fitzpatrick,
                   Port Richey, Fl.

We do Not live in a fancy home in fact it was built in 1967 and is  a subdivision home. I am one of the very unlucky ones who live a few hundred feet west of US 19 and have to have the wind and hail policy in addition to homeowners. I guess I am lucky I do not live in a flood zone. I would like to know how that wind KNOWS how to stop at US 19 as if the people living just a few hundred feet across US 19 do NOT have to pay for the wind and hail policy and if their roof gets blown off their insurance WILL pay to put it back on. Something is wrong with this picture. I do not live near the water and I believe that people who can afford living on the water SHOULD pay for that but I do not believe I should pay so they can enjoy living on the water. Something is very bad wrong with the insurance in Florida and needs to be fixed NOW. 
You have ignored this problem from the beginning and NOW it is time to face the problem before you have 1000's marching on Tallahassee. "He has reviewed State Farm's filing, which the company now intends to
amend because it says the rate increase it asked for isn't high enough
to cover its reinsurance expense.

State Farm had actually asked for two rate hikes -- one, an average 58.8
percent statewide, was to cover the increased cost of reinsurance. The
company will amend this filing. The company is dropping the second
request -- 12.7 percent statewide -- which had been intended to cover
higher storm costs this year."

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathleen T Brown [mailto:khbx4@juno.com]
Sent: Thursday, July 27, 2006 9:41 AM
To: khbx4@juno.com
Subject: Fw: My Letter to Gov Bush after he endorses pro-death candidate-Please call Gov Bush 850-488-7416


 Please call Gov Bush 850-488-7416
 	
 	
Dear Friend: 

What follows is my letter to Governor Bush after Governor Bush endorsed Jim King. I pray you will read it, and send it to everyone you know. 

Hello Mr. Governor. 

As you can imagine, I, my staff, and thousands of my friends and supporters in District 8 were heartily disappointed by your endorsement of Senator Jim King in our Republican primary. I believe it was a tremendous mistake. And I believe the next few days and weeks will bear that out. 

As you (better than most) know, Senator King - even though he claims to be a Republican - has repeatedly worked against you and your Republican agenda. For example: 

- Senator King fought against you when you introduced your budget in 2004, calling it "mean-spirited"; 

- Senator King derailed your efforts at true medical malpractice reform; 

- Senator King appointed 16 Democrats to chairmanships and vice chairmanships of committees when he was Senate President; 

- Senator King tried to use state monies to build a fire department next to his vacation home in Putnam County (a bill which you vetoed, thankfully); 

- Senator King complained about your veto, and you rightly called him a "baby;" 

- Senator King took an illegal $48,000 private plane trip to Canada -- funded by a gambling casino, forcing the State Republican party to use our contributions to pay back the $48,000; you condemned the entire affair; 

- Senator King voted to give illegal immigrants college tuition with our tax money; 

- Senator King denied you your constitutional right to appoint the new 55 judges our state is going to have; those new judges would have been able to represent our conservative legal philosophy -instead, Senator King insisted that they be put to a vote by the public at large. (You strongly condemned this action in writing.) 

But worse yet - Senator King's social agenda is indistinguishable from that of a Democrat. 

- Senator King believes in slaying the innocent unborn and exploiting women by abortion - but you are pro-life; 

- Senator King supports permitting homosexual "couples" to adopt children - but you oppose homosexuals adopting children; 

- Senator King fought to starve Terri Schiavo - an innocent woman - to death, even while you advocated saving her life. (Think of how Bob and Mary Schindler will feel when they hear the news of your support of Senator King.) I will leave my effectiveness in the fight for Terri's life to the family, history, and eternity to judge. One thing is certain: Senator King fought to starve her, and now you have endorsed him. 

Mr. Governor, a man with the political history and social agenda of Senator King does not deserve the endorsement of a man of your stature and character. 

But more importantly - and I speak to you now as a fellow Christian - by embracing the ethical evils of the "culture of death," Senator King has denied certain fundamental principles of our faith. How could you ignore our faith, and the teachings of our Lord, to embrace a man who scoffs at and denigrates the very essence of that faith as it relates to life and family? Can we claim to be a friend of Faith and Family while we help those who wage a policy war against our families and our faith? 

This long list of policy positions held by Senator King should have been enough to keep you from endorsing him. Unfortunately, it did not. Your core values and faith should have kept you from endorsing him. Unfortunately, they did not rise to the occasion. 

Sadly, over the next few days and weeks some very disturbing news is about to brought to light about Senator King. As it emerges, I hope you will publicly retract your support for Mr. King. You owe it to your supporters to do so. You owe it to the loyal Republicans of this district and this state who support the Republican Party Platform, and who have voted for you in the past because they thought you supported that platform as well. By endorsing Senator King, you have called your entire belief system, priorities, and public policy statements and positions into question. 

Sincerely, 

Randall Terry 

Well Friend, there it is. I tried to be diplomatic, but honest. I hope I succeeded. I believe this letter deals with what is eating away at our party's heart and soul. If you agree, please forward it to your friends. 

And I ask you to give any contribution you possibly can towards my election. We are gathering momentum, building a great team, and getting to huge numbers of houses as we go door to door. This is why Jim King's people are terrified! 

But we still need to raise money! I hate it, but we need contributions to win! 

Please; do whatever you can. And ask your friends to do the same! Every single gift matters, no matter what the size. Go to http://www.randallterry.com to contribute on line, or you can mail a check to Randall Terry for Florida Senate, PO Box 3886, St. Aug. FL, 32085. 

God bless you, and long life to you. 

Randall Terry

From: Chris Ennist [mailto:meowhouse2002@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Monday, July 24, 2006 4:18 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: special session


regarding homeowner's insurance. I keep being told that our representatives are trying but not getting help in having a special session over the
homeowner insurance problem. I have been told they    "go home in disgust
because I can't do anything". Why is that? Why and who is preventing an honest open review of something that is effecting many homeowners and business owners? I do not comprehend why the three most powerful people in this state have done NOTHING. Speaker Bense and Senate President Lee and you have received emails from me today. I want to know why, as a citizen, a voter, and a homeowner, that I feel no one is actually representing me. That no one is actually representing any of the voters/citizens of this state. I do not see anything happening, other than a rate increase granted to State Farm. I see the public being told the OIR is displeased that we didn't come to their meetings, which we did not know about, so how can one attend? Are the meetings deliberately held without public announcement? Giving a "press release" and "leaving it to the media" to tell the people? I always took pride in casting my vote, of researching the issues the candidates put forward, how they responded to issues I was concerned about, but, it seems that once elected they only represent themselves or their interests. Insurance rate doubling or tripling in two years will destroy some of us. I think I will have to look to the Governor's Office and the State's Legislature as the reason. Enhance Citizens, restructure it as an all inclusive company, sell all types of insurance and NOT at a higher rate than the other insurance companies, and let them leave the state. It is a sad day when we see the government of Florida forsake the people they represent! Christina Ennist meowhouse2002@tampabay.rr.com

4307 Las Vegas Drive
New Port Richey, FL 34653
727-847-9838

From: Sally

Subject: YANKEETOWN FLORIDA CHANNEL 10 STORY WEDNESDAY NIGHT 

   IN MY OPINION: 
 
 I HOPE THAT YOU WILL COME BACK TO YANKEETOWN AND DO THE "REAL STORY"  NOT THE "MAYOR'S STORY" AND INTERVIEW THE MAJORITY OF CITIZENS WHO ARE FED UP WITH THE  MAYOR, FORMER MAYOR, FORMER AND PRESENT LAWYERS, FORMER ZONING OFFICERS, COUNCIL PEOPLE WHO HAVE BEEN PART OF THE MOST OUTRAGEOUS CONSPIRACY IN MY OPINION THIS STATE HAS EVER SEEN. CITIZENS ARE WAITING TO SEE IF THERE REALLY IS JUSTICE FOR CITIZENS AND A TOWN OVER TAKEN BY WHAT WE FEEL ARE CROOKED POLITICIANS AND NONTRUTHFUL LAND FLIPPERS (CALLING THEMSELVES DEVELOPERS.) 
 
GO LOOK INTO THE SAME DEAL THIS "DEVELOPER" PULLED ON 12 TO 13 BUSINESSES IN INDIAN ROCKS BEACH 2 YEARS AGO AND EVERYONE IS IN COURT. CALL THE INDIAN ROCKS BEACH CITY HALL AND ASK ABOUT JIM SHERWOOD AND WHAT HE DID TO THAT CITY. OUR MAYOR IS FROM THERE TOO AND IS 1/3 OWNER OF A GIANT REAL ESTATE FIRM EMPLOYING OVER 100 PEOPLE IN 4 DIFFERENT CITY OFFICES DOWN THERE. 
 
THE FORMER MAYOR, ZONING OFFICER AND LAWYER AND FORMER COUNCIL MEMBER WITH HER MARINA UNDER CONTRACT HID THIS MARINA PROJECT FOR MONTHS. ONE OF THE MARINA OWNERS WAS ON THE COUNCIL AND BEST FRIENDS WITH THE PRESENT MAYOR WHO WAS ON THE COUNCIL WITH HER AND NO ONE REVEALED THIS GIANT DEVELOPMENT THAT WANTS TO COME IN AND DESTROY OUR TOWN BY EVERY MEANS BUT THE RULES. WE COULD HAVE STOOD BUILDING BY THE RULES BUT THAT IS NOT PROFITABLE TO THEM. OVER TAKING THE TOWN COUNCIL WITH EITHER BRIBES OR SOMETHING TO MAKE THESE COUNCIL PEOPLE AND MAYOR DENY THE MAJORITY OF THE CITIZENS THE RIGHT TO EVEN SPEAK AT TOWN MEETINGS AND VOTING TO FAVOR EVERY REQUEST OF THESE "LAND FLIPPERS" HAS THE CITIZENS IRATE. 
 
SO FAR GOING TO THE ETHICS COMMISSION  HAS BEEN  A JOKE ALONG WITH THE SUNSHINE LAW VIOLATION BEING PUNISHABLE. WHERE HAS OUR GOVERNMENT GONE? SO FAR TO PROTECTING THE MOST OUTRAGEOUS PUBLIC OFFICE HOLDERS WHILE THEY DENY CITIZENS RIGHTS OF AN HONEST AND OPEN GOVERNMENT GOVERNED BY THE RULES. 
 
THE FDLE IS INVESTIGATING THE MAYOR AND HOPEFULLY MORE PEOPLE.  WE QUESTION THE MAYOR AND CREW CAUGHT SHREDDING TOWN PAPERS ON A SUNDAY EVENING AND PUTTING THEM IN THE RECYCLE TRAILOR, THE MAYOR TAKING ORIGINAL DOCUMENTS FROM TOWN HALL AND NOT RETURNING THEM, TOTAL DISREGARD BY HER OF THE LAWS, RUNNING TOWN HALL FROM HER HOME, HARRASSING THE TOWN EMPLOYEES TILL THEY QUIT,  AND VIOLATIONS OF CITIZENS RIGHTS IN PUBLIC MEETINGS. 
 
WE HAVE HAD RESIGNED COUNCIL PEOPLE RESEND THEIR RESIGNATION AND COME BACK AND VOTE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT. WE HAVE HAD THE LAWYER HELP HIDE THE DEVELOPMENT WHILE BILLING THE TOWN BIG DOLLARS WORKING WITH THE DEVELOPERS ON TOWN MONEY. WE HAVE HAD THE RESIGNED LAWYER PRIVATELY REPRESENT THE MAYOR UNDER RECALL SUING THE TOWN WHILE AT THE SAME TIME REPRESENTING THE TOWN CLERK BEING SUED BY THE DEVELOPERS AND HE IS RESIGNED? ASM THE TOWN ATTORNEY. WE HAVE HAD 3 OR 4 BREAK-INS IN TOWN HALL IN THE LAST 3 WEEKS THAT I BELIEVE ONLY THE MAYOR HAD ACCESS TO THE KEYS USED TO OPEN THE FILES. MANY BELIEVE THIS WAS STAGED TO COVER UP WHAT MISSING DOCUMENTS WILL TURN UP IN THE INVESTIGATION. (CALL THE LEVY COUNTY SHERIFF OFFICE 1-800-538-9767) (CALL THE FDLE 386 418-5412) THE DEVELOPERS CLAIMED FROM THE BEGINNING IN WRITING THEY WERE THE REGISTERED AGENTS FOR YANKEETOWN MARINA AND THEY WERE NOT. (THIS IS 2 OF THE ORIGINAL DOCUMENTS THE MAYOR TOOK FROM TOWN HALL MONTHS AGO AND THEY ARE NOT BACK THERE TODAY.) THE OWNER OF THE MARINA HAS REQUESTED TO SEE AND GET COPIES OF THEM THEM WELL OVER 25 TIMES SINCE THEY WERE DROPPED OFF BY THE DEVELOPERS. I WITNESSED MANY OF THESE REQUEST.  
 
 THE DEVELOPERS LIED IN THE PUBLIC MEETING ABOUT THE YANKEETOWN MARINA, PRESENTING THE PROJECT ALMOST A YEAR AFTER THE TOWN LEADERS AND LAWYER HAD WORKED WITH THEM SECRETLY. I COULD GO ON AND ON. BY THE WAY OUR TOWN CHARTER LETS THE MAYOR PICK REPLACEMENTS TO THE TOWN COUNCIL WHEN THERE IS A RESIGNATION. THE MAYOR RAN UNOPPOSED AND HER RESIGNATION FROM COUNCIL WAS NOT TILL AFTER SHE BECAME MAYOR SO HER FIRST DUTY WAS TO REPLACE HER SEAT WITH A DEVELOPER. AFTER THE COUNCIL PERSON (MAYOR'S FRIEND) WHO HAD HER MARINA UNDER CONTRACT AND NEVER REVEALED THIS MARINA PROJECT WHILE VOTING ALMOST 6 MONTHS FINALLY RESIGNED, THE MAYOR GOT TO PICK THAT REPLACEMENT. 
 
AFTER THE GOVERNOR DECLARED AN EXECUTIVE ORDER TO HELP YANKEETOWN REGAIN ORDER, THE MAYOR HELD A TOWN MEETING WITH 2 COUNCIL PEOPLE MAKING MOTIONS AND VOTING TO ACCEPT RESOLUTIONS BY THE 2 OF THEM. ONE OF THESE RESLOUTIONS WAS ACTED ON BEFORE THE 10 DAY PERIOD DECLARED BY THE GOVERNOR. AT THIS MEETING THAT WAS NOT PROPERLY ADVERTISED, THE PUBLIC AS WELL AS A HIRED LAWYER WERE DENIED INPUT OR COMMENTS AFTER THE COUNCIL STARTED THE ACTUAL MOTIONING. THE MAYOR IS OUT OF CONTROL. 
 
WE DO HAVE A TOWN OUT OF CONTROL. IT STARTED WITH A BUNCH OF LYING SO CALLED DEVELOPERS BUT IT IS THE ACTIONS OF THE TOWN GOVERNMENT HIDING, LYING, MANIPULATING, AND NOW PROMOTING THIS DEVELOPMENT IN ANYWAY POSSIBLE FOR IT TO SUCCEED THAT HAS THE MAJORITY OF THE PEOPLE FED UP. THEN GO TO THE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES FOR HELP CLAIMING VIOLATIONS OF SUNSHINE LAW, VIOLATIONS OF A PERSONS RIGHTS TO FREEDOM OF SPEECH, BREAKING OF LAWS BY ELECTED AND APPOINTED OFFICIALS WHO ARE UNDER OATH AND GET TURNED AWAY. .. 
 
FINALLY THE GOVERNOR HAS STEPPED IN .. BUT IF THIS DOES NOT GAIN BACK THE RIGHTS OF THE PEOPLE THEN SOMETHING HAS TO BE DONE. THIS TOWN GOVERNMENT IS OUT OF CONTROL, THE PEOPLE ARE FED UP AND IF THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF LAW ENFORCEMENT (FDLE) AND LEVY COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE ARE SUCCESSFUL... AND I CAN ONLY HOPE THAT YOU CHANNEL 10 WILL COME BACK TO TOWN SOON  AND ALLOW THE "REAL" STORY TO BE TOLD BY THE CITIZENS WHO HAVE ENDURED THE BIGGEST TRAVESTY EVER ON A SMALL TOWN.. 
 
 
WE WANT OUR SIDE TOLD. 
 
I CAN GIVE YOU NAMES AND NUMBERS OF PLENTY OF PEOPLE WHO ARE WILLING TO TELL YOU THAT IT IS OUR MAYOR AND COUNCIL WHO ARE THE PROBLEM. SALLY PRICE, 45 YEAR RESIDENT, RETIRED POSTMASTER AND PRESIDENT OF THE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.

From:	joe sicolo <jgsicolo@cox.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 7:19 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Eglin's 46th test wing

Governor Bush,

I write this to voice my staunch opposition to the proposed relocation of the 46th Test Wing at Eglin Air Force Base Florida, or any portion thereof, to Edwards Air Force Base California. Eglin has time and again proven itself to be an eclectic collection of dedicated individuals that outperform all engaged in the fielding of tactical weaponry. To propose such a drastic fragmentation of an undeniably synergistic unit is in my view unconscionable. Now, in a time of war, it is ill advised to diminish our capacity to develop weapon systems that might save the lives of those so valiantly serving our county worldwide. Consequently, I urge you to vigorously resist this proposed change to the testing process.

 

            Sincerely,

            Joseph G. Sicolo
From:	Colleen <kckbxr7@cox.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 5:49 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	46th Test Wing

I am retired Air Force NCO and a civilian contractor for the 46th Test Wing at Eglin AFB.  I have spent the better part of my Air Force career at Eglin and Hurlburt Field and have seen over the years how important the Test Wing is to our national defense.  I have been involved in armament testing while an Air Force Special Ops Aircrew Member and also as a civilian contractor.  The weapons that have been developed and tested here at Eglin have always performed well in wartime.  If the Test Wing was to move our nation would loose a great wealth of talent and experience in developing and testing armament.
From:	Gerald.Labruno@Certegy.Com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 5:01 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Insurance Crisis


Dear Governor Bush,

I live in Pasco County Florida, one of the hardest hit areas of Florida
with regards to Property Insurance rates.  I implore you to please call a
Special Session with Florida Law makers to deal with this problem.  We the
homeowners of this state will not be able to continue to own homes if the
insurance rates keep escalating.  When I bought my home in Land O' Lakes in
2001 my insurance premiums were about $800 per year.  Now it is $3,000 per
year,  and I was lucky to find an insurance company that would insure me
other than Citizens.  The insurance crisis in this state should be the most
important topic on the State's agenda and should be dealt with swiftly.  If
it is not, then I'm sure the voters of this state will have their say at
the next election poles.

P.S....One thing I would like to see legislated is to not allow insurance
companies to pick and choose what types of insurance the sell in our state.
If they sell property insurance in other states they should have to sell it
in Florida if they do business in Florida.

Respectfully,
Jerry LaBruno
3829 Saint Augustine Place
Land O Lakes, Fl 34639
727-227-2689
