From:	Rory Wilson <rory@exor-rd.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 3:56 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	MiscMood@aol.com
Subject:	[*] Plea of clemency and release for Joshua

To the Honorable Governor Bush,
 
I am writing you in the hope you will see it in your heart and in the best interest of fairness and justice to reduce the sentence of Joshua Earl Phillips. I myself as well as all will admit the crime he committed was a terrible tragedy and should never have happened. However in the case of this young man, he admitted his crime and has been punished for it. Their is nobody on this earth that will convince me that a terrified 14 year old could make a rational decision when they fear the wrath of there parent as much as Joshua feared his father. It is the child that has no fear or respect for authority that we should fear. Not Joshua. I have worked with young men and women and found their fear of a mentally abusive parent is far worse in the vast majority of cases than physical abuse. This is something that after reading all that I can about the case does not seem to have been dealt with fully. Much of what I have read makes me wonder if the doctor's actually looked at his mental health issue to include depression or anxiety. I have seen the effects of these diseases on others and have suffered from both myself. Until I got help I would not know for sure why I did many of the things I did as a child or even remember some had taken place afterwards. If not for the Grace of God I am sure I would have been in a tragic situation like Joshua myself. It was other adults besides my parents that pointed them in the direction for me. If they had not I am sure I would have been behind bars long ago. I seemed like a nice young man to everyone except a few and they never had a clue how I actually was inside. Confused and scared to death of my father and his reaction to anything I would do wrong. With medication, the help of my wonderful wife and my belief in the Lord I have been able to live a happy normal life. I plead with you Governor Bush to please give this young man who has proven he is and can be productive and caring a chance at a life of freedom. Please do not allow this mistake in the justice system to go on simply because it happened before the Florida laws were amended. Joshua has proven himself worthy of a second chance more than most of the young kids that have been incarcerated for as or less heinous crimes and been released. I beg you in the name of all that is good and righteous to please look into your heart and see the injustice being done to what was a child at the time of his crime. I was living in West Palm Beach when this crime took place and followed the story closely as I have three children about Joshua's same age. I was horrified by it but after I read more I saw things in my own home I had not before. I have seen fear and terror in my children's eyes when I found out they had done something and I am not a mental abuser. Yet my children still feared me enough to try to cover things up as most children will. Add to that severe mental abuse and things escalate drastically for the worse. Two of my children are daughters and I have one son. They had the chance to out grow that fear of punishment by me. Joshua never had the chance to do that because he made a very serious mistake while to young to fully understand the repercussions and has been paying dearly for it since. He has lost his childhood not to mention his freedom because of one terrible moment in his life where he let terror and fear rule him at the cost of a young life. This does not make him into a monster or butcher as the prosecutor and media played him up to be. He was an immature terrified child in fear of his father's abusive wrath. Please try to understand this Governor. I have moved away since and thought that when Florida revised their laws about juvenile offenders that Joshua would have been released and placed on parole or at least his sentence greatly reduced for the good of justice. As was Lionel Tate's in West Palm Beach. Unlike Lionel though Joshua has taken pains to better himself and his environment as well while in prison. I was shocked to find out he is still behind bars now. Please reconsider his plight Governor so a mistake done in terror and fear by a child will not continue to destroy his family. Yes the prison system is to punish criminals but is this man really a criminal or just a terrified child as I feel he was at the time of Maddie's death. Many offenders have changed and improved themselves while in prison like Joshua has to be able to come out and be a good person and contribute to society. I am sure Joshua will be one of them if given a chance. I am so sure I would be willing to offer my own home for him to stay in and get on his feet with no misgivings at all. A person is judged by his actions. Joshua was before and placed in prison as an immature child. He did not even know how to express his feelings at that time. I'm sure he didn't understand all that was going on with his body and the changes he was going through simply because of his age. I know my son did not but I was there to help him not ridicule him if something happened he did not understand. Joshua has changed as we all do with time and deserves to be judged again as a man and released for his deeds and amends now. Maddie's own mother has issues about Joshua still being incarcerated as I am sure you are aware of. Maddie's sister still thinks back about Joshua at times with fond memories as well. I have read statements in the press from both of them to that effect.
 
I pray you find it in your heart to release this young man for the sake of justice itself, sir.
 
May the Lord bless you and your family. I would like to thank you and President Bush for your continued service to our country.
 
Yours respectfully,
Reverend Rory A. Wilson
7478 Cincinnati Dayton Rd.
West Chester, Ohio 45069
513-225-4351
 
 
 

"There should be a sensitivity to the fact that a 14-year-old is not a little adult." 
~Florida Governor Jeb Bush

From:	Ben Aubin <bcaubin@msn.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 3:55 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*]

Dear Sir,

My name is Benjamin Aubin. I am 31 years old, married for 12 years and a 
father of two. I am writing you in an effort to obtain your help in a 
situation that has plagued me for over 12 years now.

In May of 1994 I was arrested for grand theft auto. I made no excuses for 
what I had done and bared full responsibility for the offense I had 
committed. Within days I was subsequently arrested and charged again for an 
additional count of grand theft auto. I must mention that this was not a 
circumstance where I had been charged and was released only to commit 
another crime but rather a situation where I was charged with the first 
offense and later charged with a second count. In any case, I served the 
sentenced imposed on me and was released early from probation with no other 
infractions. I then spent the next several years applying to the Marine 
Corps with the intent of leaving my employment in engineering to pursue a 
career in the military. Most individuals felt that this was not in my 
financial best interest, but I soon gained the respect of those around me 
when they discovered my intentions were not monetarily motivated. I have 
never directed my life towards monetary gain in fact I have always felt that 
as long as my bills were paid and my family secure I really needed nothing 
more then to pursue a dream as a Marine. For several years I pursued this 
only to be denied for what was perceived as a “dual-felony”. The ruling of 
dual-felony I understood and could sympathize with as obviously the Marine 
Corps was willing to forgive someone who had made a mistake and learned from 
it, but not willing to accept someone who was incapable of learning from 
their mistakes. I really felt as if I fell into the first part of this 
category, as this was actually one infraction, one moment in my life that I 
allowed a lapse in judgment to dictate the remainder of my life. Apparently, 
an error in the clerks of courts recording method listed the dates I was 
charged as my actual offense dates and thus it appeared as two separate 
offenses. Whether this was intentional or malicious in nature I don’t know 
and quite honestly don’t care. My time is now served and I have moved on 
with my life. Despite moving on though I have never really gotten over the 
need to serve and this was further complicated with the incident that 
occurred on September 11, 2001. Since that day I have made it a mission to 
serve in whatever capacity I could to aid those who are going off to 
protect. I have given my time to the US Army on two separate occasions to 
train troops in un-armed combat for those who are deploying to fight the war 
on terror. I have further solicited my time to any government, military or 
private security firm participating in the fight on terror free of charge. I 
can not emphasize enough the fact that I am willing to fly anywhere and do 
anything at my own expense to have the opportunity to serve. A few months 
ago it was suggested to me that I consider joining a private firm and be 
able to contribute in a more meaningful way as a security consultant and 
instructor in the middle east. Up until this time I had never really 
considered that option as I really didn’t know that much about it, but after 
doing some research I see that its not only possible but its very probable 
given me references and background. The problem lies in my prior offenses. 
As I stated above I was involved in two counts of grand theft auto and 
despite this being my one and only infraction outside of traffic related 
issues I was sentenced fairly harshly and adjudicated guilty. This 
adjudication of guilt has impeded me from having my record sealed or 
expunged allowing me to enroll in a career in one of these firms. I have 
followed all the guidelines of the clemency procedure but unfortunately have 
to sit on a waiting list for a period of another two years before my 
restoration of civil rights can be restored. My only other option is to 
apply for a full pardon. I applied for this last month and was informed that 
I was ineligible due to the fact that 10 years had not passed since I was 
released from probation in 1998. I read through the clemency procedures and 
found that this could be waived in certain cases. I am writing you to ask 
for just that. If there is anyway possible I humbly urge you to consider me 
for a full pardon and hear my case as soon as possible so that I may 
participate and due my part in this effort to combat terrorism. I can 
provide very strong character references ranging from high ranking military 
officers to police officers all of which have known me for many years and 
all of which know of my past infractions. All of my references have been 
informed of my early offenses, as I am unwilling to allow them to tarnish 
their reputations by being associated with a convicted felon. Despite this 
they are all willing to serve as character references for me. Please allow 
me to do my part and aid me in whatever way possible.

Sincerely,
Ben Aubin

July 26, 2006
 
 
Mavis Knight
Deputy Director / Governor Appointments
 
Please allow me to introduce myself.  My name is Anna Liisa Covell and I reside in Hernando County, Florida.  I am currently a member of the Henando County Planning & Zoning Commission, the Hernando County Housing Authority Board.  In addition to my volunteer projects, I am the vice president and co-owner of A.L. Covell Electric, Inc.
 
I would like to recommend Roy Martin be chosen as the interim county commission for Hernando County to fill out the rest of the term vacated by Robert Schenck.   I served with Roy on our local EAR committee for the revisions on our current comprehensive plan and found his demeanor to be calm and reserved, but firm when necessary, to make decisions on the vital issues at hand. Mr. Martin also served on a 25 member committee to review the capital improvements necessary over the long term for Hernando County. Besides these two very important committees, Roy Martin is a member of the Hernando County Port Authority Board, the president of the Wellington Republican Club, and is also very active within his own Wellington community.
 
Roy Martin will be an excellent choice to help our county through the difficult decisions facing the county commission and  an asset to our community.
 
Respectfully, 
Anna Liisa Covell

From: michael merenda [mailto:innovativecabinetsbymichael@msn.com]
Sent: Wednesday, July 26, 2006 12:32 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: [*] reason for SPECIAL session


Jeb,
   It is my idea to call a special session for insurance for the following reasons:
 
                     If insurance companies requires 50% to 100% increase for the reason of paying for damage, then they should figure into the balance NOT paying for the damage this way:    1) After two years of a relativity normal season, refunding 25% of this increased revenue.  2) Based on a normal (average) two (2) year period, a figure should be designed to calculate the "Normal" or "Average" costs that are incurred for insurance companies. This would set the standards for my idea. 
 
 
       For instance: I paid $---   last year for insurance and was increased 50% next year, nothing happened for those two years and the insurance company calculated that it would.   They would be able to KEEP 25% of that increase for future devastations, I in return would benefit from the calm season that we had. ( A two 2 year turnover might be subject to change!  , make it 3 or 4 year, but the idea is there.)
 
                   The Insurance companies still gain 25% and the general public still believes they should stay in Florida instead of moving to be able to afford the increases in this needed insurance. Once the insurance companies collects this increase that has been approved, it will never be seen again unless this is passed into law.  
 
              Anotherwords
  I will forgive where my money went over the past 15 years, but I sure want to know where it is going for the next 15 years. 
 
I have a lot more on this subject that WILL work
It is all in a win win situation

From:	Marla Ruth <mruth@dshealthcare.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 12:43 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli

7/24/06 

The Honorable John Ellis “Jeb” Bush

Re:     Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit in and for Seminole County, Florida

Dear Governor Bush: 

I am writing this letter in support of Louise Zeuli for appointment as Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench as noted above.  I have known Louise for over 30 years and in that time I have come to appreciate her endless energy and commitment to her community and profession.  

I am a Masters prepared nurse with administrative experience in hospitals and home care.  Presently, I am Director of Education for Divine Savior Healthcare in Portage, Wisconsin.  However, I lived in Florida for over 25 years and I have an undergraduate degree from Florida State University and a graduate degree from Florida Atlantic University.  I attended college with Louise and I knew, early on, that her intelligence and sense of purpose and fairness would make a difference for many.  As a nurse, Ms. Zeuli has first hand knowledge of the meaning of pain, suffering and service.  Her leadership and education skills have helped others seeking a career in nursing as well.  Her knowledge of medicine combined with her practice of law and dedication to helping others makes her a superlative candidate for the Circuit Court Bench.

Her self-less giving to the community has included: Volie Williams’ Inns of Court, Program Chairperson, then President;  Board of Directors for Seminole County Legal Aid Society, Inc; Seminole Community College’s Community Advisory Board & Lecturer to their nursing students on legal liabilities; and Rotary Club of Seminole South (Board of Directors, Chairperson of Community Service II Committee, which reviews and allocates charitable donations from our club to worthy charities in the community).  In the past she has also helped to feed the homeless. Currently, through the Rotary Club, she is helping to build a Habitat for Humanity home.

Louise Zeuli’s personal attributes include honesty with a sense of “doing what is right” even in the most difficult of situations.  Her strong sense of ethics is her guide as she listens and responds.  Louise has proven herself to me over the past 30 years and I know that she would prove to be one of your career’s best appointment decisions.  I strongly urge you to consider Louise B. Zeuli for the next Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit, for Seminole County, Florida.  I know that she will not disappoint you.

Thank you. 
Respectfully submitted, 

Marla Ruth, RN, BSN, MSN 
N8714 Starr Road 
Portage, WI  53901 

------------------------------------------------------------------- 


Marla Ruth 
Director of Education 
Divine Savior Healthcare

From: Elisa Toruno [mailto:torunome@bellsouth.net] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 25, 2006 4:10 PM
To: 'solal@miamidade.gov'; 'mayor@miamidade.gov'; 'manager@miamidade.gov'
Cc: 'kfordyce@miamiherald.com'
Subject: Disqualification of candidate

 

In the month of June we learned that Community Council 15 was being reorganized after the incorporation of Cutler Ridge and therefore vacancies were available for qualified candidates. I personally called Lourdes Avalos of Team Metro to inquire about the subarea for Nilka Gomez’ address, but after speaking with Lourdes Avalos and Com. Sorenson’s aide Lourdes, we were told that Lourdes was on vacation. The person doing Lourdes Avalos’ work was George Gomez, with whom I spoke at length and who informed me that according to that address our subarea is 154.

 

Nilka prepared her documentation to run for a seat in subarea 154 and filed it on July 17, 2006. On July 18, 2006 Elections accepted her after paying a $100 filing fee. A campaign account was opened at BankUnited, flyers, cards and other propaganda material have been ordered and paid for. A few moments ago Nilka received a phone call from Lourdes Avalos stating that there had been a complaint filed against her because she is running in the wrong subarea and that because the deadline to file as a candidate has passed, she is being disqualified.

 

We have been informed that Commissioner Moss changed the district boundaries and apparently forgot to inform the corresponding County offices. We would believe this mistake happening in a Third World country but not in the USA. I would appreciate informing us:

 

1.	The name of the person that filed the complaint against Nilka Gomez
2.	Is the County going to reimburse Ms. Gomez her expenses made relying on the misinformation from George Gomez, as well as the Elections Department that should have had the change of boundaries by Com. Moss and should not have accepted Ms. Gomez’ application if there was an error in the subarea;
3.	Constantly changing District boundaries shows incompetence on the part of our elected officials, but the lack of coordination with the County departments in charge of giving out this information to the citizens is a poor reflection on the whole County government. If our bureaucrats cannot keep their data up to date and provide inaccurate and false information to us citizens, why do citizens have to suffer the consequences of this incompetence? 

 

We await your response with interest.

 

Elisa Toruno

11347 SW 246 Terrace

Princeton, FL 33032

(305) 258-2723

From:	Thomas M Hodgson <tomhodgson2001@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 25, 2006 3:26 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; First Lady; Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Cc:	tom_hodgson2001@yahoo.com; tomhodgson2001@gmail.com; Christina_Wester
Subject:	[*] may I take a moment of your time for a personal question?
Attachments:	christina's on Presidents honor list.pdf; Christina's Awards~28 Apr 06.pdf

Dear Governor Bush, First Lady or LT. Governor Jennings,

 

I don’t mean to take up your time, and am sure you have many issues to deal with, or tend to; 

Yet I would appreciate if I might get some help or guidance on a personal subject.

 

My name is Thomas M. Hodgson; I am a veteran of our fine nation, served 6 years Active duty, and 8 Reserves. 

And have fallen in love with a woman, whom, shall let us say, has a disturbing past to most.

 

I believe everyone deserves a second chance, we all make mistakes, and my problem is that my fiancé has a criminal background.

Her name is Christina D. Wester, she once had a problem with a few miscarriages, and got depressed, got into a bad situation with an ex-husband, turned to drugs and became addicted to cocaine. Her life turned for the worst, and was arrested for prostitution, drugs, and when was about to be killed by a drug dealer, and in fear of her life, got busted with a gun.

 

Now, I know that hurts her chance to do many things in society, but I am here to ask for her forgiveness.

 

She is currently a student at Saint Petersburg College, trying to obtain a degree in Tourism and Hospitality Management, she has overcome her weakness, and went thru Operation PAR, for rehabilitation prior to school, so has been drug free for over 3 years now.

She has been blessed with Professors, and staff members who look at her as hope, she has passed 3 semesters of an Honors program that is the “pride and joy” of SPC , a 9 credit hour class, that only is offered to students that deserve such. She has made the Presidents list, and has won numerous scholarships for women that have turned there lives around. She is a member of WOW (Women on the Way), a program just for women who need help back on there feet from such a past.

 

As a single mother, a felon, and trying to better her life, she is facing many obstacles in her pursuit to bettering her, and her son’s life.

She has experience in her field, yet one look into her “criminal” record; she is denied a chance to even prove herself.

 

As a concerned fiancé I am asking you Governor Bush or staff member, to please assist me in helping her further.

Is there any chance for her to receive a pardon, clemency, or anything that we together as citizens may do to perhaps give her a little help, or clean slate?

 

I will do what I can, but I need to know what may be done, please help me, not for me though, but for her and her 5 year old son.

I know she cannot go on in life as just a server in a restaurant, and barely make means. She is thriving to become a better person, and realized her mistake, and wants to step forward, but each time she does, is pushed back to a meaningless position.

Thank you greatly;

Thomas M. Hodgson

Dear Governor Bush,

 

It was a pleasure to finally have met you at the reception you held at the Governor’s mansion a few months ago after all you have done to support the entertainment industry for so many years. The plan is to have State Film Commissioner Paul Sirmons (who will be at the event) along with The State President (myself) present you a special Award for all your contributions you have made to our industry. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject:	[*] YOUR RESPONSES

Fazeela McCabe
10388 NW 49th Court
Coral Springs, FL 33076
 
Kim Likens, Dawn E. Case and John Franco:
 
On May 31 and June 26, 2006 I received e-mails from Kim Likens and Dawn E. Case stating that the e-mails I copied the Governor Inspector General was referred to John Franco, Inspector General for the Department of Education.  To date I have not heard from Mr. Franco.
 
The last investigation that was supposedly conducted by the Office of Inspector General without my knowledge and involvement (February 26, 2002, OIG Project 01-134) was apparently initiated by Governor Bush’s office.  It inaccurately concluded the following:
1.       “…the complaint did not contain sufficient information to initiate a whistle-blower investigation”
2.       “…She also alleged that her needs and wishes were not considered when developing her Individualized Plan for Employment (IPE).
3.       “…Services, including medical, mental health, and training were provided.”
4.       “…In January 2001 Ms. McCabe was assigned to VRS Counselor Drusella Fowler.”
5.       “….the Advocacy Center for Persons With Disabilities…Ms. Fowler discontinued services without communicating with Ms. McCabe and a pharmacy bill went unpaid.”
6.       “No other instances of inappropriate behavior was identified.”
7.       “…VRS Supervisor at that time wrote a letter of apology to Ms. McCabe for Ms. Fowler’s actions and encouraged her to contact and work with the new Counselor.”
8.       “For a period of time she did, receiving mental health and training services.”
9.       “Medicaid is meeting Ms. McCabe’s medical needs, brought about by an unsuccessful attempt to commit suicide with rat poison (while in Maine).”
10.   “Although Ms. McCabe appears to be dissatisfied with the treatment Medicaid authorizes, VRS cannot provide alternative medical treatment as she requested instead of Medicaid.”
11.   “…Her demands for cash and benefits that cannot be provided by VRS have resulted in a series of complaints including the one received by the Governor.”
12.   …Mr. L.C. Fagen…ACP has investigated her complaints and a review of their file indicated that their correspondence to Ms. McCabe supports VRS’ attempts to provide the services necessary to return Ms. McCabe to employment.”
13.   “…VRS remains available to help Ms. McCabe achieve a goal of employment.”
14.   “…VRS is considering closing her case based on her unwillingness to work towards a realistic employment goal.”
15.   “…she appears to be unwilling to work towards the goal of employment identified in the IPE.”
 
In June 2002 after learning from a third party of the investigation, requesting and receiving a copy of the report to the Governor’s Chief Inspector General, I followed up by requesting a copy of the medical letters, correspondences, reports, documents from my DVR file, all documents that were received, reviewed, seen and used to come to the above 15 ruling in the 2/26/02 Report.  I was informed by Mr. Bill Geier that the information could not be made available to me and that all the IG’s office can provide is the report to the Governor’s Chief Inspector General.
 
As with CAP and OCR, I put forward the problems associated with the daily doctor’s office visits which regularly lasted several hours with some unbearable side effects.  The office visits went from approximately 3 days a MONTH, prior to November 2000, to 20 days a MONTH as of January 2002, a direct result of DVR, abruptly without written notice, discontinuing the medication goal in my mutually agreed to signed IPE and Amendment.  I was told by Mr. Geier that the IG office would not accept any corroborating documentation from me that challenges or contradicts the investigator’s statements in any way or that would attempt to change the outcome of the above statements to the Governor’s Chief Inspector General.  He also stated that the individual in the complaint is not contacted to explain, give evidence, dispute evidence provided by others to the IG investigator or in any way involved in the investigation process.
 
Again and again I've stated the reason my complaint has prolonged for so long is because investigations are completed by unknown individuals without my involvement, knowledge, input and when the report is challenged and the evidence is requested, I am denied access to it.  Had the IG’s office allowed me to be involved and challenge the investigator’s erroneous assumptions and conclusions above, I would have provided evidence to verify my claims.
 
I want to thank the Governor’s Inspector General Office for responding to my e-mails.  Of all the individuals I sent copies of my e-mails to Governor Bush, your office was the only one to care enough to respond.  However, I have not received any response or been contacted by Mr. Franco.  
 
The 2/26/02 IG Report remains factually incorrect without supporting written documented evidence to justify DVR's discontinuation of the mutually agreed to goal in my signed IPE of 10/6/99 and the Counselor's case notes on record of 10/18/99 and 11/12/99.
 
Fazeela McCabe
10388 NW 49th Court
Coral Springs, FL 33076

Memorandum for Governor Jeb Bush 

On Thursday 10 August 2006, the Tampa Chapter of the Military Officer’s Association of America (MOAA) will hold its monthly luncheon meeting at the MacDill Officer’s Club.  We extend this special invitation, and would be honored if you would be able to join us.   

 

This is a very special luncheon because our honored guest and speaker will be the Honorable Bill Young, our Representative in the US Congress. Congressman Young is the Chairman of the powerful Appropriations Committee, and has been a Member of the US House of Representatives for 18 terms.  We will also honor two Coalition Forces representatives from foreign nations at our luncheon, who are working with US Central Command in Operation Enduring Freedom. 

 

Our reception time starts at 11:20 AM, and lunch is served at 11:45.  Our speaker starts around 12:20, and we adjourn around 1:10 (approximately, depending on the speaker’s presentation and questions from the audience).  The cost of the luncheon is $12.00, payable at the door upon arrival.

Please coordinate Base clearance with a member of our Board of Directors, Major John Massey at 813 886 1938. 

 

I hope we can expect to see you at our August luncheon!

 

 

Best Regards,

From:	Jo Harrison <joharrison2@cox.net>
Sent:	Monday, July 24, 2006 11:07 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	46th Test Wing at Eglin AFB

Dear Governor Bush:
 
Please take a few moments to consider the following points concerning the possible transfer of the 46th Test Wing of Eglin A FB to Edwards AFB, and then please do all in your power to prevent the transfer:
 
Air Force project officers have stated that there is nowhere better than Eglin to test.  I have heard of project officers stating something like, “We get maybe 80% data delivered in a week to ten days out west, but we get 100% here on usually the same day - - and the quality of the data is superb.  Some have left Eglin stating “If I have a say in this, we will never test out west again.”  I wonder if anyone has taken time to survey these clients.  I question the cost saving measure of taking jobs from someone whose performance record is stronger. 
 
Eglin is unique in that it has three points of entry for testing – land, the Gulf, and the Atlantic.  No other base can offer more than two.

 

Eglin’s armament mission is unique in that a weapon can be visualized, designed, prototyped, built, tested, and deployed all at one location.  No where else in the armed forces can an item be taken from cradle-to-the field at one place.
 
I wonder if our success would have been so great and swift in our initial attack of Iraq if Edward's had been responsible for weapon's testing.
 
Thank you for your time and consideration.
 
Jo Harrison

From:	Angie Martinez <angiemartinezlaw@gmail.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 24, 2006 1:21 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Pitbull - Request to Expedite Application for Restoration of Civil Rights

Dear Governor Bush:
 
It is my pleasure to write you on behalf of Armando C. Perez (born 01/15/81) professionally known as Pitbull.
 
Pitbull is a hip hop artist of Cuban American descent heralding from Miami.  His first album M.I.A.M.I. (Money Is A Major Issue) was certified gold by the RIAA and he is gearing up to release his second album "El Mariel."  He is trying to use the exposure that he will be receiving in promoting his next album to encourage kids to register to vote and to that end, will be working with an organization called Voto Latino. 
 
The problem is that because of a felony conviction that he received while a teenager for a non violent offense, his civil rights have been revoked.  He feels like a hypocrite delivering this message while not being able to go out and vote himself. 
 
I submitted a restoration of civil rights application to the Office of Executive Clemency, but they tell me that they are a year and half away from restoring his civil rights.  They advised me that the only way to expedite this process would be via a request from your office. 
 
As such, I respectfully request that you contact the Office of Executive Clemency and request that his application processing be expedited.  As I am sure you can appreciate, the positive youth outreach garnered by such an act will be worthwhile. 
 
Please do not hesitate to contact me should you have any questions and/or concerns.
 
Very truly yours,
 
 
 


-- 
Angie Martinez, Esq.
Business & Legal Affairs

From:	Lonnie Groot <LNGroot@stenstrom.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 24, 2006 1:45 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; jeb@jeb.org
Subject:	Eighteenth Judicial Circuit Appointment

Governor Bush: 
I write to you relative to the appointment that is before you with regard to the Circuit Court vacancy in the Eighteenth Judicial Circuit which vacancy relates to a Seminole County position on the bench. 

I have written you on behalf of four judicial candidates and you have appointed each one. Each time that I have written to you I have attempted to imagine that you are in the same room with the applicants and who you would find to be a person conforming to your values and who would make you proud to have appointed to the bench.

With regard to the appointment now before you, I did not plan on contacting you, but I have come to the conclusion that there is one applicant who would clearly meet your standards and make you very proud to have appointed. The person that I refer to is Ms. Louise B. Zeuli. In addition to having her Juris Doctorate degree, Ms. Zeuli  also holds a Bachelor of Science in Nursing and a Master of Science in Nursing. 

In terms of her law practice, she is an experienced trial attorney with significant, broad experience in general civil litigation, personal injury, medical malpractice/nursing homes, insurance law, guardianship/probate law, contracts, commercial law, civil rights, and employment law, but she is also a Certified Circuit Court Mediator, a qualified arbitrator, a trainer for County Court Mediators, and an arbitrator and trial consultant. Also, upon reviewing her history, however, you will observe a career stepped in service to others in the medical field. 

Indeed, you will note that she is very active in numerous organizations and, aside from professional activities and community involvement, she is a very spiritual and patriotic person who recently co-wrote an article entitled An American Legacy of Patriotic Prayers: Blessings of Liberty which will soon be published. And, in addition to her publishing activities, she is also an active lecturer on subjects ranging from mediation to the spiritual aspects of nursing.

Ms. Zeuli has a unique set of skills to offer the public as a judge, She has a value system of the nature that you are looking for in judges. She is a person who would make you proud to have appointed and who would further your legacy of appointing the best and most qualified person to the Florida judiciary.

Please reply ANYTIME to lngroot@stenstrom.com.  Also, please feel free to contact me at either the work telephone number set forth below or on my cell phone (386-748-3685) or at home (386-789-6235) ANYTIME.

From:	gary and lina dykas <lgdykas@cox.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 23, 2006 11:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Eglin AFB, Florida

Sir,

 

I sincerely appreciate your efforts to keep the 46 Test Wing at Eglin.  As a retired Air Force E-9, I’m personally offended by General Carlson’s underhanded scheming and arrogance toward those who will suffer the most.

 

I’m writing today to implore you to reject the idea of moving flight operations and munitions testing as suggested by General Carlson while at Eglin, July 21, 2006.  The same day, an upbeat, positive headline in the Northwest Florida Daily News announced, “Potential Test Wing Cuts Not as Bad as Feared”.  This is grossly inaccurate.  It is as “bad as feared” and terrible for Eglin’s future.  Moving flight operations and munitions testing will rip the very heart from the test wing since its mission is, to test weapons for the war fighter.  There won’t be much testing when the jets go away and munitions testing moves.  And, General Carlson’s failure to include the number of contractors affected by this proposed move is dishonest.  I feel he purposely downplayed the numbers because it might shock the community to learn contractors far outnumber the 700 military and civilians referenced in the Daily News.      

 

Munitions testing is the primary mission of the test wing.  Everything else is secondary.  Flight operations means test jets, test missions, shooting missiles and dropping bombs.  If the test wing aircraft leave, how long will the 53d Wing aircraft stay?  The 46 Test Wing and 53 Wing are collocated at Eglin to provide seamless testing from weapon inception to delivery to the war fighter. 

 

If munitions testing moves, 60+ years of infrastructure and the mission will die.  Other than a few secondary missions, not much happens on the range.  Range B-70 is the primary drop point and it’s busy.  Under this latest proposal, I assume Eglin will continue developing weapons then ship the items to one of the western ranges for testing.  That’s not smart.  

 

Sir, I’m a 30-year veteran and will support changes my country needs, even if it means leaving this area.  However, I cannot accept a major decision, affecting thousands of people, from a man who appears to have a personal agenda or vendetta against Eglin.  BRAC already said no.  What’s it going to take before they understand?  The Eglin ranges are a national resource and the loyal employees (and patriots) deserve better.

 

Thank you for your time.

 

Gary Dykas, CMSgt, USAF(ret)

From:	Don Davis <davis_614@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 23, 2006 10:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	46th Test Wing Move

Mr. Bush,

 

            I am one of the 1500 contractors for the 46th test wing that stands to loose my job to a proposed cost savings cut for the Air Force.  I have worked for Eglin for 33 years and have seen the western test range try several times to close the test range on Eglin.  Talking with a number of testers that have been forced to use the facilities out west, they have reported long delays and inconsistent test results.  The infrastructure is not in place at Edwards at this time to take over the testing we currently do.  The expertise that you have on Eglin is the people employed by the contractors on Eglin which may not transfer to Edwards.  Don’t let it be overlooked that for the last 7 to 10 years there is data showing that the Eglin test range has actually shown a profit and paid the way for other resources on Eglin.  Eglin is also setup to support foreign nationals which in not allowed at other ranges.  Eglin is also the only base that has the water and land range capabilities.  Is it cost effective to move the test wing out west, only if the testing is no longer required?  It would be devastating to the local community and the Air Force stands to loose a valuable asset if the 46th Test Wing were to move and discontinue testing at Eglin.

 

Don Davis

From:	StephenLKramer@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, July 23, 2006 8:34 PM

January 23, 2006
 
Honorable Jeb Bush
Office of the Governor
The Capitol, PL05
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0001
 
Re:  The Nomination of Yvonne Colodny to the County Court of Miami-Dade County
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
    I am writing to express to you my highest recommendation for Yvonne Colodny who has been nominated to the County Court bench for Miami-Dade County.  
 
    I am a supervisor in the Miami-Dade Public Defender's office and it was in that position that I came to know Yvonne.  I first got to know Yvonne when I began supervising her several years ago.  I found her to be a tireless and zealous advocate for her clients.  Her case preparation and investigation skills are superb.  The quality of her arguments to the court and jury were unfailingly clear, insightful, and persuasive.  Over the years her legal skills have continued to grow to the point that she was promoted to the position of Training Attorney.
 
    In our office we have new lawyers entering the felony division on a regular basis.  It is crucial to their development that they be properly mentored and trained.  That is what a Training Attorney does.  Yvonne has excelled at that.  Since Yvonne trains some of the lawyers that I supervise I have seen firsthand the improvement in these lawyers after they have work closely with Yvonne.  Having once been a Training Attorney myself I know what it takes to do the job well. It requires a great deal of dedication and an equal amount of patience.  Yvonne seems to have a limitless supply of both qualities.  Those are the kind of qualities we need on the bench. Combine that with her legal acumen and demeanor, and you have the makings of a fine judge.  
 
    I have been with the Public Defender's office for the better part of 22 years and a member of the Bar for 28 years. I don't often write to governors to support judicial candidates but I felt compelled to let you know that choosing Yvonne would give the people of Miami-Dade County a terrific judge.  The people deserve no less.
 
    Thank you for considering my thoughts.
 
Very truly yours,
 
Stephen L. Kramer

From:	Kris and Sarah <krisandsarah@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 23, 2006 2:55 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	46th Test Wing/Eglin AFB

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing you in regards to Air Force Material Command’s shocking 
plan to reduce half of the 46th Test Wing’s capability and move selected 
units from Eglin AFB to Edwards AFB. As a patriotic and concerned 
citizen of the United States, and a supportive resident of Okaloosa 
county I am deeply concerned with stability of my county and moreover 
the security of the United States. I assume that you will receive many 
letters like mine and I will attempt to be concise and brief. I usually 
do not write my elected officials as I understand the pressures and time 
constraints that many in government service have levied upon them; but I 
cannot remain silent on this issue and I truly believe that this 
proposal will threaten the stability of Okaloosa county and the United 
States, cost the United States’ taxpayer more rather than save, and be 
in direct conflict with BRAC and the Office of Secretary of Defense’s 
plan to make Eglin AFB a Center of Excellence for weapons acquisition, 
testing, and sustainment.

First, Okaloosa county stands to lose the most out of this proposal. 
This county relies on the great jobs that the 46th Test Wing provides. 
Not only will the employees of Eglin suffer, but in a domino effect, 
everyone in this county will suffer. The Eglin Test and Training Complex 
provides a very unique environment to conduct developmental and 
operational test events. The resources that are available to the Joint 
test community is unmatched in the military arena. Plainly put: If you 
need to put a test weapon on a target, whether by air, sea, or land; you 
can do it at Eglin. A move to Edwards AFB will decrease realistic test 
environments therefore decrease the level of fidelity that is required 
for new and existing weapon systems. Just think of the news reports of 
collateral damage in any of our Area of Responsibilities if we failed to 
get it right during the test phase. By accepting a lower fidelity we 
weaken our nation. The only way I can think of to bring Edwards AFB up 
to speed with the present capabilities of Eglin AFB, is to commit 
millions, if not billions, of dollars to move and or construct 
facilities and purchase equipment.

The most confusing part of this proposal is that the comment was made 
that this move will save the Air Force money. I cannot begin to imagine 
the requirements that Edwards AFB will need to provide the level of 
fidelity that is required for the test and evaluation phase of the 
acquisition process. Historically Edwards AFB has been known for flight 
test, many famous and lethal aircraft have been proven in the Edwards 
AFB vicinity, however the infrastructure required for this process is 
not as large or demanding as it is for weapons testing. The Eglin range 
encompasses a land mass roughly two-thirds the size of the state of 
Rhode Island. This does not include the area of water that we have 
available for additional testing. To replicate this capability, I cannot 
envision the savings that Air Force Material Command states is in this 
proposal. In several new paper articles AFMC mentions many times that 
this will save the Ari Force millions of dollars, but they never explain 
how. This refusal from AFMC to be forthright with the information 
regarding how this plan will save money has fueled feelings from myself, 
as well as vast majority that work at Eglin AFB that AFMC is 
deliberately hiding something. All I can ask is for you to scrutinize 
the math and I would not be shocked in the least if the devil is in the 
details. I am not an expert in politics, but something is not right and 
I would highly recommend a Congressional inquiry to get the answers.

The third point I would like to make is regarding the Secretary of 
Defense’s plan to unify the Acquisition, Test and Evaluation, and 
sustainment efforts for weapons. Instead of using my own words, I will 
simply insert a document that was produced by the Office of the 
Secretary of Defense.

/OSD On Transforming T&E Capabilities/

/ /

/". . . we are requiring that a joint operational concept be fashioned 
that will then be used to test proposals from the various Services to 
see to the extent to which they can be rationalized and harmonized to 
fit within a joint operation concept."/

/ /

/The Honorable Donald Rumsfeld/

/Secretary of Defense/

/ /

/"The future T&E infrastructure should comprise a comprehensive suite of 
joint, interoperable capabilities that provide a spectrum of full and 
realistic opportunities to test new technologies, improved platforms, 
and innovative tactics and training methods."/

/ /

/The Honorable Thomas P. Christie/

/Director, Operational Test and Evaluation/

/ /

/One of the recommendations of the BRAC Commission last year was to 
agree with the DoD that it would be a great idea to create an integrated 
Air Weapons RDAT&E Center as indicated from the BRAC report quote below:/

/ /

/"CREATE AN AIR INTEGRATED WEAPONS & ARMAMENTS RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT & 
ACQUISITION, TEST & EVALUATION CENTER/

/ /

/RECOMMENDATION # 185 (TECH 18)/

/ /

/ONE-TIME COST: $2.7M/

/ /

/ANNUAL RECURRING COSTS/(SAVINGS): ($1.4M)/

/ /

/20-YEAR NET PRESENT VALUE: ($17.9M)/

/ /

/PAYBACK PERIOD: 2 YEARS/

/ /

/SECRETARY OF DEFENSE RECOMMENDATION/

/ /

/Realign Hill Air Force Base, UT, by relocating Weapons and Armaments 
In-Service Engineering Research, Development & Acquisition, and Test and 
Evaluation to Eglin Air Force Base, FL. Realign Fort Belvoir, VA, by 
relocating Defense Threat Reduction Agency National Command Region 
conventional armament Research to Eglin Air Force Base, FL./

/ /

/SECRETARY OF DEFENSE JUSTIFICATION/

/ /

/Eglin is one of three core integrated weapons and armaments RDAT&E 
centers (with China Lake, CA, and Redstone Arsenal, AL) with high MV and 
the largest concentration of integrated technical facilities across all 
three functional areas./

/ /

/Eglin AFB has a full spectrum array of Weapons & Armaments (W&A) 
Research, Development & Acquisition, and Test & Evaluation (RDAT&E) 
capabilities. Accordingly, relocation of Hill AFB and DTRA NCR W&A 
capabilities will further complement and strengthen Eglin as a full 
spectrum W&A RDAT&E Center./

/ /

/The overall impact of this recommendation will be to: increase W&A life 
cycle and mission related synergies/integration; increase efficiency; 
reduce operational costs; retain the required diversity of test 
environments; and facilitate multiple uses of equipment, facilities, 
ranges, and people. Hill AFB and DTRA NCR technical facilities 
recommended for relocation have lower quantitative MV than Eglin AFB in 
all functional areas. This recommendation includes Research, D&A, and 
T&E conventional armament capabilities in the Air Force and DTRA/

/NCR. It consolidates armament activities within the Air Force and 
promotes jointness with DTRA NCR. It also enables technical synergy, and 
positions the DoD to exploit center-of-mass scientific, technical, and 
acquisition expertise within the RDAT&E community that currently resides 
as DoD specialty locations. This recommendation directly supports the 
Department's strategy for transformation by moving and consolidating 
smaller W&A efforts into high military value integrated centers, and by 
leveraging synergy among RD&A, and T&E activities. Capacity and military 
value data established that Eglin AFB is already a full-service, 
integrated W&A RDAT&E center. Relocation of W&A D&A In-Service 
Engineering (ISE) from Hill AFB to Eglin AFB will increase life cycle 
synergy and integration. ISE encompasses those engineering activities 
that provide for an "increase in capability" of a 
system/sub-system/component after Full Operational Capability has been 
declared. ISE activities mesh directly with on-going RDAT&E at Eglin 
AFB. Relocation of DTRA NCR W&A technical capabilities will increase 
life cycle synergy and integration at Eglin AFB. Conventional armament 
capabilities possessed by DTRA NCR directly complement on-going RDAT&E 
at Eglin AFB. Cost savings from the relocation of DTRA NCR to Eglin AFB 
will accrue largely through the elimination of the need for leased 
space, and by virtue of the fact that Eglin AFB can absorb the DTRA NCR 
(and Hill AFB) functions without the need for MILCON./

/ /

/COMMUNITY CONCERNS/

/ /

/There were no formal expressions from the community./

/ /

/COMMISSION FINDINGS /

/The Commission found merit in DoD's proposal to create a full-spectrum 
capability at Eglin for Weapons and Armaments, and found no reason to 
disagree with the Secretary's recommendation. The Commission carefully 
examined the justification for the Secretary's recommendation to 
transfer in-service engineering responsibilities for research, 
development and acquisition, test and evaluation from Hill Air Force 
Base to Eglin Air Force Base, and found it would enhance long-term 
military value./

/ /

/COMMISSION RECOMMENDATIONS/

/ /

/The Commission found the Secretary's recommendation consistent with the 
final selection criteria and the Force Structure/

/ /

/Plan. Therefore, the Commission approves the recommendation of the 
Secretary."/

/ /

This beg the question, how is OSD able to conduct its plan with only 
half of the current capability in weapons testing? In my opinion, AFMC 
has completely disregarded a recommendation by OSD that was signed into 
law by members of Congress.

The direction of AFMC is extremely disturbing to me as a concerned 
citizen. I truly hope that you and other elected officials are as 
concerned about this issue as myself. I truly hope that you can make a 
difference and set the course straight. I appreciate your time.

Sincerely,

Kristoffer Payne

From:	Ali Bektas Girgin <abgirgin@gmail.com>
Sent:	Sunday, July 23, 2006 12:55 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Pontian Greek Genocide

Sir,

I am writing you from Izmir, Turkey.

My question relates to the Pontian Greek Genocide alleged to have
taken place, according to a number of Greek authors, between
1914-1922, although there are also Greek sources such as the
journalist Iakobos Pretenteris and historian Dr. Georgios Nakracas who
believe that nothing of a genocidal nature occurred. American
historian Mark Mazower also puts forth observations of a similar vein.
(http://www.lrb.co.uk/v23/n03/mazo01_.html)

I see that, in the wikipedia article on the Pontian Greek Genocide,
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontian_Greek_Genocide),
Florida is named as one of the U.S. states that have officially
recognized the historical existence of a genocide in this case.
Although, the reference shown for the recognition seems to consist of
a draft proposal by a senator.

I would like to ask if there is such recognition by the State of
Florida. The issue is sensitive through a number of viewpoints, and
would inevitably implicate, even when they are not specifically named
as in the proposal that is on the wikipedia page, the Turkish nation
as a whole. I do believe that genocide allegations are serious matters
and the presentation of this particular issue, as far as I could
judge, lacks the seriousness and the unanimity required. I could
extend my argument to cover wikipedia's coverage of the matter as
well, one "Turkish Prime Minister" named in their article, a "Safker
Pasha" has not been recorded by history, he simply never existed. The
Turkish Prime Minister in 1909 (that would be, the Ottoman Grand
Vizier) was not a Sefker Pasha. Creating fictitious prime ministers
for neighboring countries is not the best way for Greece to be taken
seriously.

Could your office please confirm me if there is a recognition by the
State of Florida or not?

Respectfully yours

Ali B. Girgin
Sakarya Cad. 32 C-12
Bornova-Izmir
TURKEY

As an employee of InDyne, with 35 years of service to the 46th Test Wing on the Eglin O&M contract, I have to say that General Carlson’s announcement on Friday only increases my concerns.  Aside from air and armament testing, our contract doesn't do much else.  

 

What concerns me is that you may breathe a sigh of relief and think we are dodging a bullet. Once things are in place at Edwards, I would fully expect them to be back in a few years to take the rest.  

 

Now is not the time to relax!  I see the fact this will go before Congress as a part of the budget process as a big plus.  However, members of Congress from California will be fighting just as hard to take our mission as I trust you will be fighting to save it.  I urge you to start to form a solid delegation of members now to join in this struggle.  BRAC praised Eglin’s test and development program.  One man should not be allowed to tear it down and move it within range of North Korean missiles at such a critical time in world events.

 

Respectfully,

 

Brannon M. Wilson

From:	jbilly@comcast.net
Sent:	Saturday, July 22, 2006 5:40 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Mayport Naval Station in Jacksonville

Dear Governor,

There has been a lot of discussion the past few years about keeping an aircraft carrier at Mayport. Somewhere along the way, the homebases of our carriers caught my attention. We have 12 functioning aircraft carriers. They are based as follows:

 

Norfolk      5

Mayport      1

San Diego    4

Hawaii       1

Japan        1

 

I must stop and wonder if anyone in charge of our military has ever read a book on America's involvement in World War II. If so, you would think that they would know that you don't base all of your ships in one port. There is no good reason and lots of bad reasons to base 5 carriers at Norfolk and 4 in San Diego. Please encourage Florida's Congressional representatives to introduce a bill in Congress to require that no more than two of our aircraft carriers can be based in the same port. We have lots of ports where we could spread out our carriers as they should be spread out. Not only will this be better for our national defense, but Mayport may end up with two carriers.

 

Sincerely,

Kyle Billy

1757 Glendale Street

Jacksonville, Florida 32205

From:	Dave de Vos <Hawaii971@cox.net>
Sent:	Saturday, July 22, 2006 11:56 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Movement of 46th TW to Edwards AFB

Sir,

    I read with great interest the words of Gen Carlton during his recent
visit to Eglin AFB.  There are several points in his speech that don’t add
up.
    First of all, if they remove the armament testing and the flight
operations and move that work to Edwards AFB, what is left of the 46th TW?
Without aircraft or the need to do armament testing the 46th then has no
mission.
    Second, his remark about “I don’t buy contractors, I buy contracts” is
cold-hearted and out of touch.  I work everyday with contractors, and they
are repeatedly told “one team, one fight”.  Am I now to understand that the
livelihood and welfare of the people who support our nation’s defense don’t
count?  I believe Gen Carlson’s comments are flawed and misleading, and that
his numbers of local jobs lost and transferred do not reflect the loss of
hundreds, if not thousands of contracted positions.
    Third, The general’s arrogance showed through on several answers to
questions during his meeting with local leaders.  His message was that it is
not the Air Force’s fault that jobs may be lost…it was because of the lack
of funding authorized by Congress.  His statement that  “our country is
waging a $318 million dollar a day war and that Congress is not providing
the supplemental funding needed to fight it” was clearly intended to take
the focus off of him and this move and divert it towards our legislators.
    I hope that you will continue to keep a close eye on any actions taken
in regards to the operation and mission at Eglin AFB.  I firmly believe that
the Air Force tried to slide this realignment under the radar, and outside
of the BRAC process.  It would not surprise me at all to see them try it
again.  MGen Riemer tried to tell everyone who was really listening that it
was his superiors that demanded secrecy and deception to try and move the
46th.
   Thank you for your continued support of our country, state, and the
people of this area.

Sincerely,


David L. de Vos

From:	gene kirkland <cgk141@isp.com>
Sent:	Saturday, July 22, 2006 9:56 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Eglin AFB's 46 TW Proposed Move to Edwards AFB CA

Carolyn Kirkland

5266 Keyser Mill Road

Baker FL 32531

July 22, 2006

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush 
Office of the Governor 
The Capitol 
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

 

As a resident of North West Florida, I am very concerned about the latest talks of moving all or part of the 46 Test Wing (TW) to Edwards AFB, CA.  As I’m sure you already know, Eglin’s and the 46 TW’s missions have been studied, scrutinized and validated in both Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) 1995 and BRAC 2005.  This latest proposed move to somehow circumvent the latest BRAC recommendations comes as a complete surprise and has many Eglin AFB employees and Florida residents very upset and concerned. 

 

Serving as the focal point for all Air Force conventional Weapon and Armament (W&A), Eglin AFB is responsible for the Research, Development, Acquisition, and Test & Evaluation (RDAT&E) of all air-delivered weapons. This is possible for three main reasons: The first being the synergies realized from the co-location of the Air Force Research Lab’s Munitions Directorate (Research), Air-to-Air and Air-to-Ground Weapon Systems Wings (Development/Acquisition), 46 TW (Development Test), and 53rd Wing (Operational Test) at Eglin AFB; the second being the irreplaceable, contiguous, and highly instrumented 724 sq miles of highly vegetated land ranges and over 120,000 sq miles of water ranges; and the third being state-of-the-art test facilities such as McKinley Climatic Laboratory, Guided Weapons Evaluation Facility, and the Preflight Integration of Munitions and Electronic Systems.

 

Several BRAC 2005 recommendations have other geographically located W&A facilities realigning to Eglin AFB to further complement and strengthen Eglin as a full spectrum W&A RDAT&E Center. The impact of these BRAC recommendations will: increase W&A life cycle and mission related synergies/integration; increase efficiency; reduce operational costs; retain the required diversity of test environments; and facilitate multiple uses of equipment, facilities, ranges, and people.

 

As a resident of Florida and a taxpayer, it makes absolutely no sense to move all or part of the 46 TW to Edwards AFB. Even a partial move of only the flight test operations would greatly limit the ability of DoD to test weapons in the most challenging operational environments - vegetative/tropical environments. Also, it would have a significant impact on the synergies that currently exist at Eglin AFB starting with the elimination of the 53rd Wing’s ability to conduct Operational Testing and maintain its aircraft (shared w/46 TW).  If the truth be known it will cost the taxpayer a significant amount of money to establish only a subset of the capabilities that currently exist within the 46 TW at Eglin AFB with zero chance of every realizing a cost savings. Why is the Air Force trying to conduct its own mini-BRAC on Eglin AFB – It needs to stop now!

 

As governor of this state, I am asking for your help to ensure the entire 46 TW remains at Eglin AFB, FL to safeguard world class RDAT&E for future Air Armament Weapons, the livelihood of thousands of Florida residents, and the economy of Northwest Florida.

 

Sincerely,

 

/s/

 

Carolyn Kirkland

Sent: Friday, July 21, 2006 11:59 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Bill Montford
Subject: Re: FW: Tallahassee



            Governor, finally, I am finishing assembly of a select group of younger generation Tallahasseeans who would be honored to meet with you, who care about the future of Tallahassee and are themselves increasingly powerful so that they can get something done.  They are ready to hear your candid assessment of Tallahassee (as both an academic and a government community); a forceful observation about why it can be substantially better for the benefit of all Floridians; and perhaps some words of encouragement.  They respect the unique perspective you bring.  It is an opportunity.  

 

            Does your schedule permit some kind of meeting anytime within the next two or three months?  

 

            We will, of course, guide around your schedule including flexibility to meet on relatively short notice and soon if that is better with your schedule.  (My wife, Karen, and I are considering hosting an informal event at our home for a maximum 25, but closer to 10, people).  Details, format and time of day, as you may desire, will be coordinated with whomever you may designate.  Thank you for your interest in this important subject).  

 

            We are not starting a new group but rather asking you to address substantial young leaders who will be able to effect change in Tallahassee.  Also, we are not providing for any kind of press release and are inviting no media but understand that your schedule is published and will conduct ourselves accordingly.

From:	Walton County Chamber of Commerce <info@waltoncountychamber.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 3:38 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Support for the 46th Test Wing

SUPPORT OF 46TH TEST WING

 

After attending a community meeting with General Bruce Carlson and Major General Jeffrey Riemer it appears there are several options under consideration to address the $1.7 billion budget reduction to the Air Force.  As a result of a recent directive the Air Force has been charged with the responsibility of proposing suggested options on how to be more efficient.  The potential move of the 46th Test Wing is just one of the options on the table.  

 

Therefore, we are encouraging our community leaders to write to their congressional delegation in support of maintaining the 46th Test Wing at Eglin Air Force Base.  Although, we recognize that change is inevitable and that the Air Force faces significant challenges it is our desire that they propose an option that does not remove the 46th Test Wing at its full capacity.  

 

Budget submissions will be presented by August 15th that will include the Air Force’s suggested reductions.  It will eventually make its way to Capital Hill for Congress to have any final decisions.  

 

Our congressman need to hear from you about the importance of retaining the Air Armament Center including the integrated capabilities of the 46th Test Wing at Eglin Air Force Base, to provide consolidated focus on weapons development and test evaluation.  

 

 

RESOLUTION

 

A Resolution in Support of the 46th Test Wing Remaining at Eglin Air Force Base

 

                WHEREAS, the 46th Test Wing is considered a World Class Center of Excellence for Weapons and Armament RDAT&E with joint capabilities; and

 

                WHEREAS,  the citizens of Okaloosa & Walton County fully support the military mission at Eglin Air Force Base and have worked together to create an atmosphere of helpful co-existence; and

 

                WHEREAS, the elimination of the 46th Test Wing would put War Fighter capability and performance at great risk today and in the future; and

 

                WHEREAS, this proposal clearly circumvents the normal Base Realignment and Closure procedures and contradicts final 2005 BRAC Commission findings that were thoroughly studied on a national scale and subsequently signed into law; and

 

                WHEREAS, the loss of the 46th Test Wing would create a huge negative local impact with the loss of jobs, award winning capability and intellectual capital; and 

                


NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the Board of Director’s of the Walton County Chamber of Commerce, that the 46th Test Wing remain at Eglin Air Force Base to ensure the continued success of its mission and its greater role in national security. And, put FY07 actions on hold pending thorough analysis of all alternatives and subsequent acceptance of final recommendations by appropriate Office of Secretary of Defense organizations and Congress.


 

                DULY PASSED AND ADOPTED this 20th day of July, 2006.

                                                                                                                

                BOARD OF DIRECTORS

                WALTON COUNTY CHAMBER OF COMMERCE

                SANTA ROSA BEACH, FLORIDA

 

For more information and updates on the Support of the 46th Test Wing, please see the chamber website at www.waltoncountychamber.com.

 

Please write letters and/or resolutions of support and send to:

 


Congressman Jeff Miller


324 Cannon House Office Building

Washington D.C. 20615

From:	Virginia Baker <hbcvrb@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 3:32 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	hbcvb@bellsouthnet
Subject:	Woodhaven Development

I understand that developers got the "go-ahead" from the Govenor's office to allow Port Orange to take a sizable chunk of New Smyrna and build thousands of homes, a mall that is larger than the Daytona Mall and widen the road that runs through our residential community to 4 lanes.  There is also a nature preserve involved in all this.  I would like to know how you could allow this to happen without any knowledge of the Turnbull Bay area.  I can only think that there is a big money pay-off to someone, or Port Orange officials lied through their teeth because of the smell of big money from tax revenues from the project.  I understand that there is a new interchange being planned off I-95.  There already is one for Port Orange and one for New Smyrna.  I have never seen people so riled up.  I also understand this was to be voted on in Sept. and now it is a hurry up deal in July.
We live in a city that wishes to remain a charming place to visit.  In fact that has been our draw for "snow-birds" and visitors.  We don't want to become a commercial venture to line someone's pockets, ESPECIALLY not even from our own community, and losing part of the land within our boundaries.
I speak for the residents of Turnbull Bay when I say we will cry for the beauty of our area if this is allowed to happen, and will fight with all our might to see that it doesn't.
Residents went to the Port Orange City Council this last Tues and were not allowed to speak.  So much for democracy in action.  I understand we were given 2 weeks to try and do something about it.  That isn't much.  I am begging you to put a hold on whatever action you took for the project until you look at our beautiful Bay and see how running a highway through it would destroy it.  Allow the people it would impact to have a say in it.  This area has some lovely homes and their value would plummet.  How would you react to a 4 lane road going in front of your home?  I had a notion that you might be an honest politician, but I'm not sure that animal exists anymore. This is all about money.  who is getting it I'm not sure.  I would like more time to get a petition going.
I'm not even sure what the politics of our boundaries are, as part  of the land is in new Smyrna not Port Orange.  At least not yet.  As far as I know we have not ceded the land  to them.
Again, I plead with you to at least put a hold on this transaction for more than 2 weeks until we can try and fend off the horrible travesty.
I thank you for your ear and anxiously await some action from your office.
 
 
Respectfully,
Virginia Baker, a Turnbull Bay resident

This year’s conference will be held November 27th through December 1st, , 2007 and there will be approximately 250 Navy Child and Youth Program Professionals attending from Navy programs world wide.  

I’m sure that you are aware of the importance of Child and Youth Programs to our military families.  Our military families rely on the kind of quality Child Development, School Age and Youth programming we provide for their children so that they can accomplish their mission as military members whether it is on board the installation or as a war fighter overseas. Knowing that their children are cared for in a safe and caring environment and are provided quality programming helps them meet their mission. Our annual conference brings Navy Child and Youth Professionals together each year for essential training seminars, networking and round table talks to keep us abreast of the latest information and innovations in the Child and Youth field and to provide us with the tools needed to continue providing the highest quality programs possible for our military families.

From:	Matt Stephenson-Smith <tomatogrower@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 12:41 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	rmcpeak2000@yahoo.com
Subject:	Troy McPeak's case/plea for Governor Bush's appointment of a special prosecutor
Attachments:	Dear Governor Bush.doc; From killers Defense ATT to D.A.doc; Richie Troy 5 months before Slaughter.jpg; Pool of blood My Baby Brother Troy.jpg; Butchered Troy.jpg

Dear Governor Bush,
 
My name is Matthew Stephenson-Smith.  Richard "Richie" McPeak and I have been friends since childhood.  Through my friendship with Richie I also became acquainted with his younger brother Troy.  You have recently learned of Troy's horrific murder 10 years ago in Tampa, Florida and the subsequent mishandling/abandonment of the cases against the 3 other participants in the slaying.  Below is an excerpt from the e-mail that Richie disseminated to friends and all government and law enforcement contacts he thought might respond to his plea for justice for Troy: 


On Monday, July 31st I will place flowers where Troy's blood once flowed and then embark on a 300 mile journey by walking from the site of my Brother's murder in Tampa to the state Capital. I will not eat or drink on the journey. Though I may suffer it pales in comparison to Troy's last twenty mintues of life. 
 
I do this not as a zealot, but with the faith that some people must be made to face justice. This walk is for Troy and every victim and family member who has lost someone whom they loved as much I did my baby Brother Troy.
 
At the end of my journey it will be August 4th, Troy's 35th birthday.

I am greatly concerned for Richie's health and safety during his planned walk.  I believe that the only thing that might persuade Richie to forgo this walk is the appointment of a special prosecutor by you.  You are the only person in the state of Florida who has this power, and I am begging you to exercise it before July 31, 2006 for Richie's sake as well as for justice for Troy and protection of all the citizens/residents of the state of Florida.
 
My initial concern is for Richie's safety when he returns to the park in Tampa where Troy was murdered to begin his walk.  If the residents of this area including family and friends of the four participants in Troy's murder learn of Richie's plan I shudder to think of how dangerous and volatile the situation would likely become.  Richie would require a police escort and possibly a media presence with cameras to assure his protection.  This area in Tampa is as "bad" as any dangerous area in any major city in the United States.  Richie's presence at the park there, although fitting, well-intentioned, and noble would be highly conspicuous and likely garner the worst kind of attention from the residents.    
 
Richie is one of the most mentally and physically tough individuals I know.  He truly believes he can will himself to complete this 236-mile walk in 5 days with no food or water.  I am the greenhouse/safety manager at an agricultural research and development facility in Immokalee, Florida.  Heat-related illness and heat stroke prevention is a major focus of my safety training program, so I am acutely aware of the physical jeopardy Richie will face while attempting to make this walk without drinking any water.  I believe absolutely that Richie has the strenght of will and committment to begin this walk, but I am afraid he will physically be unable to finish if he collapses from a heat stroke and winds-up in a hospital along his route.  I do not know what the evaluative process is in the appointment of a special prosecutor or how long the process may take, but if there is any way you can expedite your decision please do so now.  
 
It is terribly obvious to me that there has been a blatant miscarriage of justice with Troy's case.  I believe anyone with a modicum of intelligence will easily reach the same conclusion if given the opportunity to learn the details of Troy's murder.  Richie has recently acquired crime scene photos and has reviewed the police report of the initial investigation.  After 10 years Richie and his family are reliving the nightmare of Troy's murder yet again.  The propensity of evidence against the other three participants in the murder is overwhelming, and it is also clear that there are several other individuals guilty of obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and at the very least depraved indifference.  Charges should have been brought against the other three participants (I am loathe to refer to them as "men") in Troy's murder, and Richie and anyone else who learns the details of this case knows this to be true.  Tampa law enforcement botched the investigation and inexplicably allowed the cases against these other three participants to become stagnant and inactive.  I am more that confident that a special prosecutor will have all of the evidence and sworn statements necessary to bring charges against them.  This may be a gross over-simplification, but all you have to do is make this appointment.
 
I believe anyone can find some way to relate to Troy McPeak and his brother Richie, especially anyone who is a parent and/or a sibling.  The horror of Troy's murder and the plight of Richie and his family in the aftermath should move us all.  I have no doubt that the crime scene and autopsy photos and details of Troy's murder caused you to have a reaction like they have all who have seen them.  Out of desperation Richie felt compelled to shock everyone into attention and hopefully action.  In the most basic concept of right and wrong what these individuals did to Troy was the most grievous wrong, and they all deserve to be held accountable and punished.  It seems so simple, but the reality is that law enforcement and the justice system in our society in the state of Florida has failed 75% (only 1:4 of the participants in his murder convicted) on behalf of Troy McPeak and his family.  Richie has been engulfed in the beaurocratic quagmire of the Florida judicial system on all levels until your office finally responded after 10 years.  This case has now become a matter of politics, and Richie and his family are now relying on you, arguably the most powerful elected official and politician in the state of Florida, to champion their cause.  They need a champion who is willing to wield the law like a sword rather than a shield within Florida's political and judicial systems.
 
Please, if there is any way possible to expedite your appointment of a special prosecutor before July 31, 2006, do so to prevent my friend Richie from undertaking such a dangerous mission.  The appointment of a special prosecutor should make it unecessary for Richie to take such drastic, desperate measures to bring adequate attention to Troy's case.  Richie and his family are still struggling to cope and live on after Troy's murder, and I know their spirits will not survive if something tragic befalls Richie on his quest to achieve justice for Troy.  Please help my friend Richie and his family.  Thank you for your time and attention to my message.
 
Sincerely,
Matthew Stephenson-Smith
  
 


Matthew A. Stephenson-Smith
