From:	vicentebush@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 11:29 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Border fence cited as deterrent to crime

Border fence cited as deterrent to crime

Complete article at: http://www.washtimes.com/national/20060720-105104-9512r.htm

    Building fences along high-traffic areas of the U.S. border with Mexico dramatically reduces crime, the president of the Border Patrol union told Congress yesterday. 

    "Drug smuggling was rampant" in the border area just south of San Diego, said T.J. Bonner, national president of the National Border Patrol Council, before a fence was constructed. "Anarchy reigned, and there was no semblance of control over that section of the border." 

    Mr. Bonner said that after the fence was built, with surplus military steel landing mats, drug seizures tapered off and the crime rate fell sharply. 

Reader comment:
We need to secure our borders, build fences, eliminate benefits and punish employers who hire illegal aliens. Drying up the benefits and job market would encourage many illegal aliens to return to their country of origin. A program to give citizens a reward for reporting employers who hire illegal aliens would speed up reverse migration. The IRS has a similar program that allows citizens to receive a reward for reporting tax cheats.

Pls pass along.  

From:	John Schmidt <schmidtj@verizon.net>
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 11:24 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Are you committed to civil rights or are you a criminal?

Dear Govenor Bush:
 
Your brother's assertion during his appearance at the NAACP convention  of his "family committed to civil rights" reminded me that in July 2004, the US Civil Right Commission voted to open a civil and criminal investigation of your administration for knowingly renewing a racially-biased scrub of voter rolls.  The reports I remember stated that you personally ordered this new purge of "felons" from the voter rolls.  This scrub may have also violated a settlement agreement you signed with the NAACP.
 
The Commission turned that case over to the Justice Department, run by your brother's personal counsel, two years ago, yet no investigation has begun.  Your brother then promptly replaced everyone on the Commission that voted to investigate you.
 
Is this a cover up?  Have you been contacted by the Justice Department in regard to this matter?  Do you think that the people of Florida will just "forget".  How do you think this will play with the public in any future candidacy you may pursue?
 
I would like to know.  My next email is to the Justice Department.
 
I look forward to your response.
 
Sincerely,
 
John T. Schmidt
Sarasota, FL

From:	Bill & Nancy Frey <SWAFrey@cox.net>
Sent:	Thursday, July 20, 2006 5:59 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Okaloosa Island

                                       July 20, 2006
 
 
Nancy Frey
803 Boulevard of the Champions
Shalimar,FL 32579
MailScanner has detected a possible fraud attempt from "www.swafrey@cox.net" claiming to be www.swafrey@cox.net
850/651-1550
 
          
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am making an urgent plea to you to help preserve what is part of a one-hundred-mile stretch of sugar-like sand that extends from Pensacola,FL, to Panama City, FL. The land I'm referring to is known as Okaloosa Island. It is arguably one of the most beautiful parts of this country, if not the world. If you have never visited our beaches, my husband Bill and I would love to have you as our guest so you may see for yourself!
 
Okaloosa Island is a barrier island, which separates the Gulf of Mexico from Choctawhatchee Bay. It is between the Brooks Bridge and the Destin Bridge. It is part of the Eglin Air Force Base reservation. State Highway 98 is located on Okaloosa Island, connecting these two bridges.
 
 Due to numerous repairs to this highway from inevitable hurricane damage, the sand, naturally deposited by quartz runoff from a river east of this area, is being continuously degraded.  Countless dumploads of inferior sand and rock cover up this pure, white sand when hurricane winds and water relocate them.
 
I'm a native of this area. After twenty years in the Air Force, my husband and I returned here eleven years ago. Its beaches have always been my favorite sight on earth. This stretch of sand is loved by many, including our area's military personnel. It is a source of recreation and rejuvenation, used by the public as well. As the sand of Okaloosa Island continues to be degraded, it has become obvious that no one locally has the will or the clout to solve this problem. The solution is to relocate the highway or raise it, like a causeway. My dream is to have Okaloosa Island designated a national treasure so that it will forever be preserved in its pristine state.
 
Recent rumors and circulating, which if true, would no doubt result in further deterioration of this parcel. It appears that the very existence of Eglin Air Force Base is at stake. The rumor is that the 46th Test Wing is moving to Edwards AFB in CA. The consequences are numerous. A logical conclusion is that the entire base would eventually close. What I fear most is that this most desirable piece of the Eglin reservation would then be sold to developers. They have already tried to entice Eglin to relase part of this parcel. Also, because long-range testing over the gulf would be halted, oil drillers would probably be allowed to explore this presently off-limits territory. An oil spill would be devastating, and more than I could bear.
 
Eglin is one of the most coveted assignments among its soldiers, in no small part due to our beaches. Just ask anyone who has been assigned her. Or ask the retirees who have returned.
 
First, please use your influence to preserve this beach. And please fight for the 46th Test Wing. Consider the morale of the men and women who are serving this nation, and the value of this location to them in intangible terms.
 
With warmest regards,
 
Nancy Frey
From:	lmunroeiii@comcast.net
Sent:	Thursday, July 20, 2006 5:42 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Letter from Lee R. Munroe,III

8464 Augustwood Lane
Tallahassee, Florida 32311


July 20, 2006


The Honorable “Jeb” Bush
Governor
PL05 The Capital
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0001


Dear Mr.  Bush,

The purpose of this correspondence is to respectfully request an audience with a member of your staff. My former supervisor, Mr.  Robert Crouch, and I were whistle-blowers at the Public Service Commission back in 2001.  We were both dismissed in retribution for these actions.  While we have each attempted to repair the damage done to our respective careers and reputations utilizing the judicial system, I am writing this much overdue letter because I wish to find an alternative method of resolving my matter.  I  sense that you are presently concerned with your legacy of leaving Florida a better place.  Indeed you have made many remarkable and lasting changes to the agencies under your leadership. I am also aware of your steps to alter the composition of the Public Service Commission.  However, I remain concerned about a portion of the organization that has lost sight of the agency’s mission and ethical constructs, and is placing personal agendas above service to both the citizens of
 Florida and its regulated utilities.

 My family members and I are steadfast Republicans who have supported you, your brother and your father.  My very own grandfather  was instrumental in bringing the republican party to Florida.  While I have never been interested in politics myself, many in my family are quite politically active including my late father who was mayor of Quincy for two terms.  Some of my cousins have served at high levels in the Martinez administration.  My uncle, Randolf Thrower, was the Secretary of the Treasury under President Nixon and a cousin, the late President of the Senate, Pat Thomas, was the lone Democrat of our large Gadsden County clan. (We forgave him of course because he worked so tirelessly on behalf of Florida even when he was sick with cancer.)  Like the Bushes, we Munroes were raised to view public service as an honorable means of giving back to a country that has blessed us so richly.  Regardless of the personal repercussions, I  was brought up to always do the right thing.  I bel
ieve I did just that and was then punished for doing so. 

Just like your brother George, I gave up alcohol some twenty plus years ago and dedicated myself to giving back to my community. I returned to school and earned a degree in electrical engineering  despite being dyslexic.  When I graduated, I immediately sought out public service.  I worked hard, received favorable evaluations and was promoted three times in the course of eight years.  The former executive director, Mr.  Talbot, acknowledged my problem solving skills when he awarded me the agency’s very first “mug” for outstanding service.  Additionally,  I received seven commendations from the public, two with Commission notations.

Just a few short months after the whistle-blowing, certain managers began harassing me and papering my personnel file.  They used my disabilities against me and never provided the accommodations I requested.  First, Mr. Crouch was forced out, then Mr. Talbot, and finally I was fired.  Good people who tried to assist me were demoted.  My reputation both professionally and personally has been maligned.  I have suffered a stroke, depression and post traumatic stress in addition to enormous financial loss. 
 
Mr.  Bush, I have not ever  invoked my family’s name, wealth or political standing in the past, but the seriousness of my own circumstances coupled with a genuine concern for the future of the Commission  compels me to do so now. I would very much like to continue my career in the public sector and am confident that I can make a meaningful contribution with another State agency.  My lawyer is convinced that we will prevail in court but it needn’t come to that.  I am simply asking you to have a staff member meet with Mr. Crouch and myself to hear our concerns.  If you find our story compelling, you could then direct the State’s lawyer, Mr.  Jason Taylor, to settle the case.  Following the latest round of negotiations, I was under the impression that he would like reach a settlement but may be prevented from doing so by a finance officer. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this letter and in case you haven’t been told recently, thank you for your service to the State of Florida.  Should you wish to contact me, I can be reached at either 402-2095 or 321-4779.

Sincerely,


Lee R.  Munroe, III

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I received the message below from a friend.  Even though it's an internet letter, I believe there is much truth to it and most states have experienced problems similar to California's.
 
We all know how serious our immigration problem has become and how costly it is to our society.  The so-called benefits to employers are more than consumed by higher taxes for welfare, Medicaid and low-cost housing, as well as escalating health care costs, crime, drug abuse, etc.  Our unenforced immigration law is a broken policy that urgently needs to be fixed.
 
Please support the actions necessary to correct this problem and help protect Floridans, our jobs, our welfare system and our health care system from illegal immigration.  Our collapsing healthcare system would benefit greatly from a large reduction in the indigent care services for illegal aliens.  When you do the right thing, the problems we have will be corrected and cost less to us all.  The savings will help us provide better services for our legal citizens who deserve more for their taxes.
 
Please keep immigration reform on top of our state's national agenda, the same position it holds with our fellow citizens.
 
Thanks,
 
John W Gavin, MD (ret.)
Fort Myers





Illegal Immigrants

1.  40% of all workers in L.A.County (L.A.County has 10 million people) are working for cash and not paying taxes.  This was because they are predominantly illegal immigrants, working without a green card.

2.  95% of warrants for murder in Los Angeles are for illegal aliens.

3.  75% of people on the most wanted list in Los Angeles are illegal aliens.

4.  Over 2/3's of all births in Los Angeles County are to illegal alien Mexicans on Medi-Cal whose births were paid for by taxpayers.

5.  Nearly 25% of all inmates in California detention centers are Mexican nationals here illegally.

6.  Over 300,000 illegal aliens in Los Angeles County are living in garages.

7.  The FBI reports half of all gang members in Los Angeles are most likely illegal aliens from south of the border.

8.  Nearly 60% of all occupants of HUD properties are illegal.

9.  21 radio stations in L.A.  are Spanish speaking.

10.  In L.A.County 5.1 million people speak English.  3.9 million speak Spanish 
    (10.2 million people in L.A.County).

(All 10 of above taken from the Los Angeles Times)

11.  Less than 2% of illegal aliens are picking our crops but 29% are on welfare.

From:	Judy Batten <jbatten@marineconcepts.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 20, 2006 3:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	The Boatbuilding Industry from a 25yr Vet

Dear Governor Bush,
I am astounded at what is happening to the boatbuilding industry in my 
home state! I have been employed in the marine industry since the age of 
21 at Wellcraft Marine's Avon Park, FL facility, which was closed in the 
90's largely due to the drastic impact of the luxury tax on the company. 
I have owned my own marketing business doing work for Monterey Boats in 
Williston, Donzi in Sarasota, and more. I am now employed with Marine 
Concepts owned by Bob Long. I think you may remember Bob as being the 
President of Wellcraft Marine for over 17 years.
This all said, I am daily watching boat manufacturers flee our State. 
Why?  Because nothing appears to be happening to keep them.  I am a 
Florida native and dread the fact that by the time I am able to retire, 
the State will be nothing but a peninsula of tourists in condos.
What is being done to address the issue of manufacturers in the State 
involved in this mass exodus?
In the unlikely event that you actually happen to read this email - I 
realize that I am probably not important enough to you to take time from 
your busy schedule - I would appreciate knowing what you intend to do to 
keep this industry.
Respectfully,
Judy Worth Batten
Director of Marketing

F 239-283-3332

Subject:	Speaking Request - Sarasota/Manatee Technology Conference
Attachments:	STC Press Release - 07-18-06.pdf; STC - SPEAKER LETTER--Governor Bush.pdf

Hello Carolyn,

I received your contact information from Enterprise Florida as the point
person for Governor Bush's external affairs.  My name is Ken Paulus, I am
the producer of a business/technology conference taking place in Sarasota
on August 31st.  The name of the event is called the Sarasota/Manatee
Technology Conference (www.SarasotaTechConference.com). Our goal is to
turn this into an annual event that focuses on the entire Gulf Coast of
Florida.

Attached is an invitation letter and our latest press release highlighting
just a few of the speakers and organizations involved in the conference.

I can say that for a first-time event, the response up and down the coast
of Florida has been phenomenal.  We think this would be a an excellent
opportunity for the Governor to address an audience that is critical to
the future of Florida's business and technology development success.

We have assembled a top-notch speaking lineup never before produced in
this area of the State!

Please feel free to contact me anytime if you have any additional questions.

I thank you in advance for your time and consideration.

Cheers,

Ken

Kenneth C. Paulus
Producer, Young Technology Alliance
Sarasota/Manatee Technology Conference 2006: Integration at the Crossroads

From:	La?y ?T??? GiñG?r??? Dr?a? <GINGERLEEDREAD@HOTMAIL.COM>
Sent:	Thursday, July 20, 2006 2:30 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] FORWARDING A LETTER TO THE MAYOR OF AVON PARK FLORIDA TO ALL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS OF FLORIDA.

I wrote a letter to the Mayor of Avon Park after reading about the International and National headlines of the laws the City would like to put in place concerning illegal immigration. So that people here in the County and around the State and Country can know and understand that what the Mayor is trying to do is backed by some people of his community. Here is My letter Governor Bush:
  

Dear Mayor, City Council, The Legal  AND illegal Citizens of Avon Park and Highlands County, and the whole Country at large,

Thank you all for taking the time to read my letter to you.

Point 1.

There is one thing that I have learned in my life, having lived many places here in the USA as well as abroad in other lands, and that is in order to remain a peaceful land and happy, communication is the number one issue which either makes or breaks a conversation and a community at large. America for over 200 years has not felt the need for an official language. We have official wildlife, official flags, official birds, official flowers of every state and of the Country as a whole but We are far behind in the officiating of an official language for the Country. I personally think now more then ever in order for this land to continue to enjoy all of its Freedom and Security and PEACE for ALL Americans and those who come here to Our land legally and to become Americans that we have enjoyed now for generations, we are going to have to have a means to communicate better to the world at large that’s standing at our door steps, as well as those already inside the door. Many of those who come here from other lands know before ever leaving their world that in order to thrive and survive here they must learn to speak and read English, this has been the beliefs in many countries, and just a taught courtesy and a show of respect for Our land when people of other lands enter here, and Americans have always learned other languages of other countries We were traveling to and we expect to do such, however there are a few countries of people who not only feel that learning the language that this country has majority spoke for over 200 years is unnecessary but feel that We as a Country should learn their language in order to communicate to them. This is an arrogant thought process in the belief that their people and language will soon become the dominant language spoke in the USA. I believe in helping the illegal aliens, I married one over 20 years ago and assisted him in becoming a legal citizen when I found he could not gain the information he needed to do such in order to be here in this country legally when I fell in love. He learned how to speak English before coming to Our land and he himself cannot understand people who come here not knowing how to speak English and feels that it’s a slap in the face of Americans when its expected for the populous at large to know second languages of other countries not of their origins when not in that land. The system in place works for those who use it but the problem is that most will not ever be a part of the system that puts illegal on the right tract to citizenship and as long as the government continues to provide ways to accommodate illegal aliens to thrive and survive here over the rights and needs of English speaking persons and Americans, and those who come here legally, with out applying the very same issues that those who come here legally have to pass thru and those who are here that desire to become American, are willing to learn to become such, including reading and writing English, then the masses of those who live under the laws of the land here in our country are belittled and berated. The practice of not making illegal aliens from all lands adhere to the same rules the rest of Us here born in the USA have followed and might possibly took for granted up till now, today assumed was based on the language of the majority of the past 200 years, English. Now as you can see I am not the best at writing and speaking English my self, but I hope that my words have reached each one of you as you go forward in making the tuff decisions for us all and pray that you know that me and my family back the Mayor of Avon Park in his efforts against all odds and hope you all will have the courage to take the road less traveled for the better ment of all the people in this Country but especially the English speaking from all lands of the world as well as Americans. We do not feel that We as an American and Legal Resident Alien are being racist, biased or prejudice in our thoughts on this issue. I have a right to speak up and state My opinion to you as an American, as well as those who are on the other side of the fence and opinion legally do, but illegal aliens are not afforded the same rights because they have not pledged to the Constitution or flag of this Country or respect either so why does the government accommodate those who don’t as though they have? 

Point 2.

Big business has lived off the backs of the poor person from other countries far to long with agriculture bringing in people from other lands to provide cheap labor when the American work force of Americans and Legal Aliens are not even being given a chance to work in such a trade in today’s times. When was the last time you seen a ad in the local news paper that asked for fruit pickers for the orange crops in the area ? Or how about a ad to go reap sugar cane down south during season? I’ve lived here half my life and I’ve yet to see any, so before Big business comes to My government and news papers and community officials complaining they don’t have enough workers to do a job here I suggest reaching out to the available workforce of Americans and Legal Aliens that are already here in the community, county, cities and USA like the regular business owner here who has to put an ad in the paper to gain a work force and you just might not go with 10 million sum odd oranges not being picked.(Course you will now be forced to pay a fair wage to legal working citizens and cut your profits.) Dont blame the loss of illegals for the issue but more the government that has put a ban on all oranges being shipped outside the state as being one of the main reasons oranges are still on the trees. Both me and my husband picked fruit in our pasts as a week end second job until the groups of illegal aliens and groups of tempt workers from outside the country undercut the wages we were earning in the fruit picking business to the point that a second job was not even profitable to have doing it. I felt sorry for the legal emmigrants and americans who used this income as their main support because there very livelihood was cut out from under them by big business going outside the country for cheap labor and the illegal alien. I’m a simple woman of simple means but I know the issues the Mayor and Council are taking to task and I know it will be a very ruff and hard one to fight but again me and my family stand by you 100% on the issues We all are facing here. God bless America and God bless you all in your actions, and thank you again for serving our community.

Sincerely Gingerlee Mitchelllindo and Kalvin Lindo

Subject:	Suggestion to solving illegal immigrant issue

Dear Mr. President and Governors,
 
July 20 ,2006
 
I would like to make a "SIMPLE" suggestion for solving the national problem regarding illegals in the USA. I will try to be brief and am hoping each of you personally gets to read this email. My name is Frank Savalli, I am a 58 year Italian-American republican from the Midwest (Grand Rapids, Michigan) and transplanted to South Florida 6 years ago. I live in a very affluent area called Aventura. I spent most of my working career as an executive in a smaller corporation in the Midwest before starting my own consulting business. I live in a county(Dade) that is 60+% Hispanic and have to listen "often" to the negativity re: immigration issues. I know each of you must be aware of the huge underground economy that flourishes in this country and in your states with illegals working "under the table." Some of my conservative friends back in Western Michigan would suggest we round them up and deport them all. They view the crisis as one of illegals taking jobs from Americans. Reality is if you were to "round them all up" (at least in So. Fla.) the economy would fall flat on its face down here and I suspect the same would be true in So Cal or Texas. The thousands (probably millions) of workers in restaurants, the trades, etc., can't be replaced by Americans; there aren't enough "willing workers" left to take some of these jobs. Prices will go skyrocketing. Now the crazy Midwestern think we're just talking about migrant fruit pickers..they have absolutely no idea just how much this area and I suspect other areas have come to rely on this underground worker.
 
So I ask, is there anyway you "Key National Figures" could work together and announce together a national solution (a way to turn all the negativity the republicans are getting and the Bush's are getting down here, and in other areas I'm sure)?? What if you could suggest a way to turn the negative into a positive????....by coming up with a plan that will allow conditional amnesty. Each illegal would come forward and register, get a temp      Soc. security number, and be allowed to legally stay and work in the USA.  Future immigrants coming would have this blueprint to follow so we're not back in the same situation 10 years down the road.   The Conditions: they must be employed if they are over X age, and PAY TAXES on their "full" income. Now think of all the lost income taxes and lost Soc security taxes in the country right now due to this underground economy..if  then a bipartisan appointed committee could prepare the projections of added taxes to collect I can't image any democrat voting against this idea. The ultra conservative republican wouldn't even think about saying no to more taxes dollars coming in without having to raise taxes. Every 6 months they would have to come in a show their pay stubs to some office to continue their amnesty. After X years of doing this successfully they have now proven their worthiness to become citizens. This sure seems like a WIN-WIN situation for everyone involved: The country, the illegals, the economy, the Bush's, the Republican Governors most affected. It sure would be great to hear the Hispanics down here not saying things like "Bush is so slow to help us" or the democrats would help us more if they were in power. With the Hispanics now growing into the countries largest minority..it would be great if they would more unilaterally feel they owe their ultimate citizenship to the Republicans. I hope you ALL can jump on this ASAP before some other politician comes up with something similar and takes your potential thunder away for their own political aspirations. Thank You for your time and consideration...I'm not looking for any notoriety on this matter     what-so-ever...you may all feel free to suggest it was your own concept. Good Luck and God Bless 
America.
 
Sincerely,
 
Frank Savalli

Subject: [FL_LoS] Florida's Legislature Should Follow Colorado's Example 
Reply-To: fllos@freeflorida.org 

Gov. Bush should call a special session to do in Florida what Colorado has done. The news item below was received from F.A.I.R.  If every state and city did this, many illegal aliens would decide they should go back home voluntarily. 
Susan M. Lamb 
5846 Mt. Carmel Terr., #313 
Jacksonville, FL 32216 
  
Colorado Governor Bill Owens called a special legislative session to focus on the problem of illegal immigration. That special session, which ended last week, resulted in the passage of some of the toughest immigration legislation in the country. In particular, the special session intended to address a proposed ballot initiative passed during the regular legislation session that the Colorado Supreme Court subsequently struck down. However, during the special session, members of the Colorado Legislature decided that instead of re-writing the ballot initiative and sending it to the voters in November, they would pass legislation with similar language. The new law, which will go into effect August 1st, requires individuals to demonstrate their legal presence in the U.S. before receiving state and local benefits. In addition to this new law, the Colorado Legislature passed several other immigration bills, including one that requires all contractors servicing state or local agencies to attest they are using the Basic Pilot Program. "It simply puts teeth into existing federal regulations," Governor Owens stated. "Nobody I know is content with today's status quo." Andrew Romanoff, the Democratic speaker of the Colorado House added, "Washington should take Colorado's hint." 

Why keep checking for Mail? The all-new Yahoo! Mail Beta shows you when there are new messages._______________________________________________ 
Fllos mailing list 
Fllos@freeflorida.org 
http://mail.freeflorida.org/mailman/listinfo/fllos_freeflorida.org

From:	Robert M. Kuschel <robert@adoptionplacement.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 19, 2006 3:58 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; 'Jeb Bush'
Cc:	Kaplan, Mark; lucy.hadi@dcf.state.fl.us; 'DRAWDY.ANN.S09'; Lt. Governor Toni Jennings; hopper.tara.s31@flsenate.gov; 'BROWN.CINDY.S09'
Subject:	Adoption Placement - Follow Up

Hello Governor Bush,

 

I hope this email finds you doing well. 

 

I wanted to follow up with you regarding our licensing issue. I understand that you have asked Mr. Kaplan to review this matter. I have also been told that Ms. Hadi is investigating the matter as well. Since that time Shane DeBoard, DCF attorney in District 7, has dismissed all actions against us in that district. However, the revocation in Broward County still stands.

 

Unfortunately, this has become a very urgent situation. Without taking too much of your time, I want to outline a couple of the factors that are now involved:

*	Families’ adoptions are being significantly delayed. Children are waiting in orphanages. We know of at least one that has died due to the unavailability of adequate healthcare in the orphanage. The child would likely have lived if the adoption could have been finalized.
*	The agency is in a financial hole that is approaching the point of being insurmountable. We are behind in our lease and have not made payroll for five weeks. At this point, we are nearly $200,000 in the hole.
*	All of our staff are in significant financial straits. We are all behind in our personal bills to the point of possibly losing vehicles and having our credit affected negatively.
*	Our staff members are being affected medically. Our insurance was cancelled due to non-payment of premiums. One employee just required major surgery and was forced to proceed without insurance. She also has three children that are now not covered. Personally, I am epileptic and can’t afford my anti-seizure medication. My wife and children are also without insurance.

 

As I’ve mentioned numerous times, I don’t understand the actions that were taken by DCF officials in District 10. No children or families we ever endangered by our actions. I continue to be confused by the severity of their intervention – an outright revocation. I am especially befuddled, because recent events involving severe sexual and physical abuse of children in day care and foster homes – some resulting in the death of children – were not initially met with the same severe consequences as those given to Adoption Placement. 

 

For example, the Kid’s Palace Day Care Center’s Director, Joshua Palin, was arrested for at least 12 counts of child molestation. According to reports, the Center’s license was initially SUSPENDED following his arrest. It was not until later that their license was revoked – following an investigation. Why was our license revoked on the spot without even as much as a phone call? Many other instances, in which DCF has openly admitted fault, involved care providers who were not adequately supervised and ultimately abused or neglected children in some fashion – some resulting in death. Several of those facilities are still operating. It is also true that several felons in the state of Florida have been issued licenses to operate Day Care Centers. I trust you can understand my confusion in light of these facts.

 

I am not asking for anything other than the ability to become licensed in District 7. I’m not asking DCF to admit any wrongdoing, and I’m not interested in anyone losing their jobs or anything of that sort. I am not seeking any public intervention or attention. I am simply asking that the revocation in District 10 be withdrawn so that we can pursue licensure in District 7.

 

I know that we are scheduled for a DOA hearing in August. Unfortunately, I don’t think the agency, or its staff, can survive that long. And even if we could, we can not afford adequate representation to assist us in that matter. As such, I am respectfully requesting that action be taken at the soonest possible moment.

 

Once again, I appreciate your consideration as well as the time you have taken to look into these issues and reply to me previously. I am looking forward to hearing from someone in your staff as soon as possible.

 

Respectfully,

 



 

  _____  

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: This transmission contains confidential and/or legally privileged information from Adoption Placement, Inc. intended only for the use of the individual(s) to which it is addressed. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, copying, or distribution of this information or the taking of any action in reliance on the contents of this transmission is strictly prohibited. If you have received this transmission in error, please notify us immediately.

 

From:	Judy Cullinan <JMC@pdmiami.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 19, 2006 3:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Judicial Candidate for the 11th Circuit, County Court, Yvonne Colodny

July 19, 2006

Dear Governor Bush,

It is with great pleasure that I write to recommend Yvonne Colodny for a county court judicial position.

Yvonne possesses the qualities that are essential in a judge: fairness, knowledge of the law and professionalism. Mature beyond her years, Yvonne is the quintessential defense attorney. She passionately advocates for her clients while demonstrating respect for the judicial system and maintaining a professional relationship with her adversaries.

As a new lawyer assigned to the Domestic Violence Unit of the Public Defender’s Office, I was fortunate to have Yvonne as my trial partner. Yvonne guided me through my very first trials and served as my mentor in the Public Defender’s Office. She has taught me many things over the last five years and her role in my development as an attorney has been crucial. Yvonne taught me how to conduct a good cross examination, she taught me the significance of punctuality and civility in the courtroom and she taught me the important thing a new lawyer can learn: always be prepared. 

As a training attorney Yvonne positively influenced many young attorneys. Her trainees depend on her ability to analyze a case, conduct research and to communicate effectively with clients. They know that they can rely on her to thoroughly prepare a case, have the correct case law and effectively communicate with even the most difficult client or attorney. 

Yvonne exhibits the character and skills expected of a member of the judiciary. She has passion for the law, respect for the judicial system, encyclopedic knowledge of the law and empathy for the human condition. 

Sincerely,

Judy Cullinan, Esq.

From:	Hamilton Barry S CTR USAF 46 TW/TSRM <barry.hamilton.ctr@eglin.af.mil>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 19, 2006 11:07 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	KEEP THE EGLIN TEST WING HERE

Governor Bush,
  hello & hoping all is well with you and your family. i am writing today with concerns of the test wing here at Eglin moving to Edwards AFB in california. i cannot stress enough to you that this is not a good thing. we at Eglin feel that this is not a strategic move at all not to mention the disruption of the lives of so many personnel that have dedicated themselves for many years to this fine base. we whole heartedly feel that we are an integral part of national security and not just time card punchers. the compassion and dedication of the individuals i see on a daily basis is overwhelming and is what compels me to write to you. i know at all levels whether it is in industry, government, or private enterprise there is a need to look at ways of saving money, even in our own homes we draw a budget up to save and put away. but sometimes we have to evaluate the bottom line and ask how much we can save but at what cost. do we simply abandon the people who made us what we are today so we can save money or make more money. the loss of this test wing would put people into a local job market that doesn't support their individual skills or pay structure that they have or had have. many of us love this area and cant see moving away from it for their own personal reasons. its a wonderful place for raising families and enjoying all types of activities from fishing/hunting to water sports off all types. i know you've been here and are familiar with the area. the Destin and fort Walton beaches are among the best here in Florida. we all have roots here and want to stay in this area. a lot of us have elderly parents here and other family that we don't want to leave from. the majority would have to relocate if this move occurs and that is far reaching to not only the individual but on the local economy level as well. on a personal note, my job has afforded me to travel all over the states and the world over the years, I've been to a lot of nice places and have seen a lot of this country but of all the places I've been, i have never seen any place i would rather call home than right here. so i am asking as supporter who has voted for your dad, your brother, and yourself to please show your support for us in the test wing at Eglin to do all you can to keep the move from happening. thank you so much and god bless.
                                         Barry Hamilton
                                         Shalimar, FL

From:	PAULA PATTERSON <paulae1950@earthlink.net>

Subject:	The New Medicaid Perscription Plan

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am a 56 year old African American woman who has lived in Florida for the last eleven years.  I have a work record of 22 years as an Administrative Assistant.
 
In 2005, I received disability (after fighting for it for three years) for a heart problem and uncontrollable high blood pressure.  At the time, I was receiving my medication through the Share of Cost plan through the Orange County Health Department, as well as $259.00 in Food Stamps.  When my disability came through, they stopped the Food Stamps stating that I made too much money (I was receiving $1,083.00 for disability).  Somehow, I managed to make it through.
 
In 2006, Social Security increased my disability to $1,120.00 then put me on the new Medicaid Part D Prescription Plan.  I must pay either $2.00 or $5.00 per prescription.  As you can see from the list below, most of my prescriptions are not generic so I have to pay $5.00 for them.
 
My problem (and complaint) is my rent is $750.00 alone, leaving me with a balance of $370.00 to pay for electrical, water, telephone, cable and food which of course, is impossible.
 
I am writing you for some help.  This month, I couldn't afford to get my medicine.  I take meds for my heart, blood pressure, depression, acid reflux, etc.  Yesterday my doctor attempted to get me an emergency two week supply of meds for my blood pressure, which is very high.  He was denied because I have this new medication plan.
 
Governor Bush, I'm not in the habit of asking for help; I can usually find a way around a problem, but this one has me stumped.  You see, if I don't get this medicine, I will most likely have another heart attack (I've had two), stroke, etc.  I have been without my meds for two weeks now and I am suffering severe headaches.
 
If you know of an agency or anyone who can help me obtain my meds, I would appreciate it.  I thank you for your time.

From:	Gael <potterharrymom@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 5:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	U.S. immigration policies

Mr. Bush,
 
As I'm sure you are aware, immigration has hit a nerve with legal residents of the United States regardless of their ethnicity.  My family immigrated from Europe before the Revolutionary War, and my ancestors fought for our freedom.  I believe they fought for the right for others to legally immigrate and improve their circumstances through hard work and sacrifice.  The borders overflowing with illegals lining up to take advantage of our social programs funded by working, legal, Americans is not what I believe they fought for.  It is certainly not what my active-duty husband signed up to do.  If you polled our military, you'd be hard-pressed to find any who support the current policy that allows illegals from Mexico no real consequences for breaking our laws.  They are not held to the standard of conduct expected by the rest of us, and they stand to gain so much for such relatively little risk.  Then they have the gall to make demands.  Listen to the voices of the legals making demands and you will hear a resounding chorus that the illegals go home.  
 
I believe in a hand up and not a hand out.  We have far too many legal citizens at the welfare trough, and now it's bait to lure, particularly citizens of Mexico, more to the feeding frenzy of something for nothing.  First, our welfare system is a mess.  Those who take should have to give and work for it.  You may refer to the welfare system of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints for an excellent model of this.  Those able-bodied adults who take from the system return by cleaning buildings, doing yard work, or whatever work can be done to earn the help they receive.  We now have not only far too many legal citizens, and increasingly more illegals, lining up for whatever they can get at the cost of all of us who work.  No illegal should be eligible for assistance of any kind.  The only thing they should receive is transport back to their country as quickly as possible or time in jail.  I'd rather have my tax money spent to jail them and send them home than to teach them to teach their children how to mooch off the rest of us, thus breeding generations of people incapable of feeding themselves.  They will be a far stronger people if forced to provide their own livings in their country than if we teach them to beg for hand-outs.  As a Republican, you should understand that.  However, I've heard complaints that your own marriage resulted in the Bush family taking a more lenient stance toward immigration.  
 
Besides the negative affects on our economic health that illegal aliens from Mexico cause, there is the more troubling risk to national security.  As my husband gets ready to deploy and talks of the increased terrorist activity and their purpose being to try to find and stop terrorists I have to wonder what is going on in our government.  Why would we spend so much money sending our troops all over the globe before defending our own borders?  It's such an obvious open door for terrorism that it's probably in the first chapter of Terrorism For Dummies.  
 
The message I want you and all of our government on state and national levels to get is very simple.  Either you crack down on illegals strong, or be prepared to see a shake-up in our government come election day.  The smart politician will listen to the people who are strongly speaking out that English is THE language of this country, and Illegals are unwelcome.  The legal immigrants of this country had to work for it, although certainly in many cases, not hard enough.  We dole out too much to assist legal immigrants, but right now I'd settle for a crack-down on illegals.  I share my feelings about this with you, because like everyone else, I suspect you'll make a run for the White House.  I'm not the only one who thinks there is a certain amount of family pressure facing you on this.  Personally, I don't think so many from one family is a good thing for the White House.  Regardless, the candidate who gets my vote is the one taking a real stand on this issue, even if that candidate is from a 3rd party or from a family logging too much White House time for my taste.  
 
Sincerely,  
Gael McGraw


PotterHarryMom 
Mairyn 8 
Connor 12
Cameron 14

From:	goodtimeddie@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 1:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Seeing Today’s Immigrants Straight

Seeing Today’s Immigrants Straight

Complete article at: 
http://www.city-journal.org/html/16_3_immigration_reform.html

The proponents of amnesty have manufactured an artificial crisis. They say that it is imperative to legalize the millions of illegals here now, so that the illegals can “come out of the shadows.” In reality, the minor inconveniences imposed by illegal status are nothing more than what the illegals bargained for. Illegal aliens have no legitimate claim to be legalized before the country makes sure that its border control is working. 

Enforcement must precede a liberalization of immigration rules—which is why “comprehensive” immigration reform (the conservative code word for amnesty and increased levels of immigration) is not the solution to our border crisis but rather a guarantee of continued anarchy. Amnesty and the impossibility of enforcing a complicated new immigration scheme will undermine border control, just as they did in 1986. The first item of business on the conservative agenda should be enforcing the law already on the books. 

Reader Comment: 
While the vote for amnesty was 62-36 only 19 of the 62 senators who voted Yea are up for reelection in 2006. By placing special interests ahead of the interests of the country these senators have shown they are unfit for elected office. From:	area01 <area01@cox.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 12:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Deny Proposed Move of 46 Test Wind From Eglin AFB

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Office of the Governor
The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

As a resident of North West Florida, I am very concerned about the latest
talks of the 46 Test Wing (TW) possibly moving to Edwards AFB, CA.  As I’m
sure you already know, Eglin’s and the 46 TW’s missions have been studied,
scrutinized and validated in both Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) 1995
and BRAC 2005.  This latest proposed move to somehow circumvent the latest
BRAC recommendations comes as a complete surprise and has many Eglin AFB
employees and Florida residents very upset and concerned.

Serving as the focal point for all Air Force conventional Weapon and
Armament (W&A), Eglin AFB is responsible for the Research, Development,
Acquisition, and Test & Evaluation (RDAT&E) of all air-delivered weapons.
This is possible for three main reasons: The first being the synergies
realized from the co-location of the Air Force Research Lab’s Munitions
Directorate (Research), Air-to-Air and Air-to-Ground Weapon Systems Wings
(Development/Acquisition), 46 TW (Development Test), and 53rd Wing
(Operational Test) at Eglin AFB; the second being the irreplaceable,
contiguous, and highly instrumented 724 sq miles of land ranges and over
120,000 sq miles of water ranges; and the third being state-of-the-art test
facilities such as McKinley Climatic Laboratory, Guided Weapons Evaluation
Facility, and the Preflight Integration of Munitions and Electronic Systems.

Several BRAC 2005 recommendations have other geographically located W&A
facilities realigning to Eglin AFB to further complement and strengthen
Eglin as a full spectrum W&A RDAT&E Center. The impact of these BRAC
recommendations will: increase W&A life cycle and mission related
synergies/integration; increase efficiency; reduce operational costs; retain
the required diversity of test environments; and facilitate multiple uses of
equipment, facilities, ranges, and people.

As a resident of Florida and a taxpayer, it makes absolutely no sense to
move the 46 TW to Edwards AFB.  If the truth be known it will likely cost
the taxpayer a significant amount of money to establish only a subset of the
capabilities that currently exist within the 46 TW at Eglin AFB with no
chance of cost savings now or anytime in the future.

As governor of this state, I am asking for your help to ensure the 46 TW
remains at Eglin AFB, FL to safeguard world class RDAT&E for future Air
Armament Weapons, the livelihood of thousands of Florida residents, and the
economy of Northwest Florida.

Sincerely,
Nick & Rita Monte
148 Old South Dr
Crestview, Fl 32536

From:	Susan Lamb <yankeereb1948@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 2:26 AM
To:	John Peyton; Senator Bill Nelson; Bense, Allan; Governor Jeb Bush; Sen. Nancy Argenziano; Bean, Aaron; Carroll, Jennifer; Davis, Don; Fields, Terry; Gibson, Audrey; Hill, Tony; Jordan, Stan; Sen. James E. King, Jr.; Kravitz, Dick; Senate President Tom Lee; Lynn, Evelyn; Mahon, Mark; Pickens, Joe; Proctor, Bill; Warren Alvarez; Elaine Brown; Richard Clark; Sharon Copeland; Michael Corrigan; Lad Daniels; Daniel Davis; Reggie Fullwood; Ronnie Fussell; Arthur Graham; Kevin Hyde; Suzanne Jenkins; Glorious Johnson; Mia Jones; Pat Lockett-Felder; Lake Ray; Lynette Self; Art Shad; Gwen Yates
Subject:	Florida's Legislature Should Follow Colorado's Example

Gov. Bush should call a special session to do in Florida what Colorado has done. The news item below was received from F.A.I.R.  If every state and city did this, many illegal aliens would decide they should go back home voluntarily.
Susan M. Lamb
5846 Mt. Carmel Terr., #313
Jacksonville, FL 32216
 
Colorado Governor Bill Owens called a special legislative session to focus on the problem of illegal immigration. That special session, which ended last week, resulted in the passage of some of the toughest immigration legislation in the country. In particular, the special session intended to address a proposed ballot initiative passed during the regular legislation session that the Colorado Supreme Court subsequently struck down. However, during the special session, members of the Colorado Legislature decided that instead of re-writing the ballot initiative and sending it to the voters in November, they would pass legislation with similar language. The new law, which will go into effect August 1st, requires individuals to demonstrate their legal presence in the U.S. before receiving state and local benefits. In addition to this new law, the Colorado Legislature passed several other immigration bills, including one that requires all contractors servicing state or local agencies to attest they are using the Basic Pilot Program. "It simply puts teeth into existing federal regulations," Governor Owens stated. "Nobody I know is content with today's status quo." Andrew Romanoff, the Democratic speaker of the Colorado House added, "Washington should take Colorado's hint."

Good Morning Governor Bush!
 
Having received so many letters from students of the 151 eagle-mascot elementary schools across the state, I feel confident that you have heard about the Florida students' American Eagle & Literacy Challenge (initiated by St. Augustine's Timberlin Creek Elementary.)
 
We are excited about the funds and awareness the students are raising for Florida's Early Learning Coalitions, the Governor's Family Literacy Initiative, and the American Eagle Foundation.
 
We are also excited about the Florida essay contest entitled; “How Reading Makes Me A Better American” / “Como Lectura Me Hace Un Americano Mejor.” 
 
Attached is an invitation to our Statewide Kickoff tentatively set for Friday, September 29, at 8:45am.  (Of course, if another date and/or time works better we will gladly change it.)
 
Also attached is the letter U.S. Congressman Ander Crenshaw wrote to First Lady Laura Bush, in support of this initiative, and the request for her to serve as the National Ambassador of Literacy.
 
There are many groups and celebrities joining this initiative like NASA (who is sending an astronaut for the Kickoff), the 5 million-membership service organization -- Fraternal Order of Eagles, the Boy Scouts, and bald-eagle Challenger who will perform a spectacular free-flight.  There are also strong possibilities of appearance by celebrities like Dolly Parton and Miley Cyrus (aka Disney Channel's "Hannah Montana.")
 
But...nothing is more important to our students than the desire for our Governor of the best state in the nation to come be a part of our great "Mayberry Day" festivities on September 29!
 
Sincerest thanks for your consideration!
 
Kim Kendall
TCE PTO American Eagle & Literacy Challenge Chair

From:	NPyle@highlandstoday.com
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 9:46 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Illegal Immigration Relief Act

Hi,

The city of Avon Park is contemplating an ordinance that would make English the official language of city government and would allow fines and revoke business permits on businesses that rent or do business with illegal immigrants.

I was hoping to get a statement from the governor on this ordinance. It passed on first reading June 26 and is due for a final vote, Monday, July 24.

Thanks in advance,

Nancy

 

Nancy Vickers-Pyle

-----Original Message----- 
From: owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com [mailto:owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com] On Behalf Of Jeb Bush 
Sent: Sunday, July 16, 2006 6:20 AM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 14, 2006 

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor 
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here: 

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news 

The text version of the e-newsletter is below. 


INAUGURAL MEETING OF SPACE FLORIDA BOARD OF DIRECTORS HELD IN TALLHASSEE 

On Monday, I chaired the inaugural meeting of the Space Florida Board of 
Directors.  Established by House Bill 1489, Space Florida houses the state's 
existing space and aerospace entities and will coordinate all space-related 
issues in Florida.  The Space Florida board will provide leadership and 
advocacy and actively work to strengthen the state's position in the civil 
and military aerospace sectors. Space Florida was among the recommendations 
put forth by the Governor's Commission on Space and Aeronautics. Growing 
Florida's economy through the space and aerospace industries is critical to 
the state's long-term prosperity. Space Florida will lead our state's 
efforts to continue attracting aerospace businesses that create quality, 
high paying jobs for Floridians. 


ORLANDO HOSTS FIFTH ANNUAL JUST READ, FLORIDA! LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE 

On Monday, I joined more than 3,500 superintendents, principals, reading 
coaches and district staff for the fifth annual Just Read, Florida! 
Leadership Conference.   During the three-day conference, state and national 
leaders, reading experts and guests share reading education strategies and 
best practices. Governor Bush was also joined today by Florida State Board 
of Education Chairman Philip Handy, Just Read, Florida! Director Evan 
Lefsky, Ph.D. and renowned author and screenwriter Antwone Fisher, who 
shared the importance of literacy and his personal struggle learning to 
read. Florida's commitment to high-quality instruction and accountability is 
changing the statewide landscape, not only in our schools, but in our 
communities. I am proud that Florida leads the nation in rising student 
achievement and with each year our students are continuing to close the 
achievement gap. When education leaders, teachers and parents work together 
to ensure the success of our students, we contribute to the overall strength 
and success of our state. 
      

FLORIDA REPORTS LOWEST CRIME RATE IN 35 YEARS 

On Tuesday, Florida Department of Law Enforcement Commissioner Jerry Bailey 
and I released the state's 2005 Annual Uniform Crime Report and announced 
Florida's index crime rate has reached a 35-year low.  The index crime rate 
dropped by 3.7 percent in 2005, compared to 2004. I applaud the hard work of 
Florida's law enforcement officers who put their lives on the line each day 
to protect the residents of our state, and this report highlights the 
results of their efforts.  This report shows that staying tough on crime 
works. 


STATEWIDE LAW ENFORCEMENT RADIO SYSTEM FULLY IMPLEMENTED 

On Friday, I announced the full implementation the Statewide Law Enforcement 
Radio System (SLERS).  SLERS gives more than 6,500 law enforcement officers 
the ability to communicate with their peers throughout the state using a 
central radio system.  With this new system, officers from various state 
agencies are able to effectively communicate with one another on one system. 
By providing a single system, Florida is able to provide law enforcement 
officers responding to an emergency with a more efficient means of 
communications and the ability to talk to one another in real time. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO THE DASIE BRIDGEWATER HOPE CENTER 

Congratulations! 

To read more about this week's winner, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/7989 


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES 

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

Thank you.

that they use to get at Eglin, also in less time than what it takes out west. The facility in which I work, the J-PRIMES an anichoic chamber, may not be one of a kind but the qaulity and workmanship is 
surpassed by none, just ask the Project Officers that have had the misfortune of testing out West. The BAF  is a much bigger chamber but not better. The McKinsley Climatic Lab is one-of-a-kind and it 
to is slated for closure. Most of the tests done at these two facilities are of sensity nature so further elaberations are not premitted. It has been said that the Test Wing is out of money ( what happen to 
the money?) and this is a way of cutting back on exspenses, no problem, these two facilities are SELF SUBSTAINING, that's right, we are so good at what we do that we have all the business that we
can handle. The Climatic Lab has a customer for the next twenty years. Yes I know that we all are small parts of the big picture, and that there are alot of things that we don't and can't know YES, YES

high stress and fear of life for my family and myself, which triggers my 
mental disorder (PTSD), which is service connected.  I am under doctors care 
for global, chronic/severe PTSD and have to take three (3) different 
anti-depressants daily.  I have recently been boarded for disability 
compensation for that PTSD and hear loss through Veterans Affairs.  I am 
awaiting a rating, but have been told that it would be 70+% for the PTSD and 
10% for the hearing loss since of their severity. It also appears that I 
would be found 100% disabled with the combination of these disabilities 
coupled with status of UI.  I can p0rovide you or your staff copies of 
letters from the Vet Center here in Maryland of my conditions.  I have been 
unable to hold a job in the private sector since my retirement in 1992.

of my awards and decorations awarded me for service to our country.  (All of

From:	Michael Miller <michaelmiller214@msn.com>

Subject:	Position to Help Haitians

MICHAEL L. MILLER
610 COURTNEY DRIVE

Dear Mr. Bush:
 
 Greetings!  I’m writing to you from Tampa, FL.  I have heard the news of how you have had various committees and task forces to help the people of Haiti.  I am writing to you today to request a position to help the people of Haiti.  I would be willing to work either in Florida or in Haiti.  I love the country of Haiti and the people of Haiti.  
 
 I grew up in Pittsfield, Illinois.  Since 1976, I have traveled to Haiti on various humanitarian aid trips.  Using only my own money, I accomplished several things.  I had an orphanage in Jeremie, Haiti.  I taught floral design and English as a second language.  I helped many Haitians start small businesses to support their families.  I gave tours of Haiti to missionaries and helped to translate for them.  For a time in 1987, I worked with the prime minister of Haiti, Jean-Baptiste Hilaire, performing research to find industries to start and plants to grow which would give people jobs.  All of these projects were to help the Haitian people to be able to live in their own country and support themselves.  If the situation were better in Haiti, everyone would want to stay there.  If it were not for the politics in Haiti which allow for the crimes and the poverty,  Haiti would be a paradise.  
 
 On August 18, 1996, I married Martine Bernard a Haitian national.  We have been blessed with two beautiful daughters, one 7 and one 3 years old.  We moved to Tampa, Florida in November, 2003.  Since being here, I have worked at a few jobs and even started a business, which failed due to lack of capital…so far I have not been able to support my family, not to mention not being able to help the dear people of Haiti.  
 
 I hope to someday start a nonprofit organization to help children in Haiti with nutritious food and proper schooling.  I would also like to have a place in Tampa to help the children of Haitian immigrants learn the American cultural differences, budgeting, English, computers, etc. which would help them to assimilate into the American culture.  It seems that the children of many immigrants are left to themselves while their parents are both working two or three jobs just to make ends meet.  These children many times fall in with the wrong crowds which give them the wrong start in life here.  I hate to see these children with so much potential, in a country with so much to offer, have their lives ruined.  
 
 If you could help me get a position helping the Haitian people in any way, so I could also earn enough money to support my family, I would be eternally grateful.  I speak fluent Creole, I have a bachelor’s degree in business management, an associate degree in liberal arts, and I have years of experience translating Creole/English in our church and for missionaries in Haiti.  I am very familiar with the Haitian culture.   
 
 Thank you for your consideration.   
 
     Sincerely,
 
 
 
     Michael L. Miller

From:	monty wilson <mwilson5@valp.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 16, 2006 10:28 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	46th Test Wing

To the Honorable Jeb Bush,

 

This week a team of Air Force evaluators came to Eglin to tour our test sites that are slated to be moved to Edwards.  What they saw were the sites, many very simple in appearance, that have developed and tested the most sophisticated and highly accurate weaponry in the history of warfare.  What they didn’t see were the thousands and thousands of miles of underground data lines, signal and control lines, coaxial cable and the vast fiber optics grid that form the calibrated link to mesh the entire range into a synchronized data gathering complex of unparalleled accuracy – down to the specific angle, minutes, seconds and arcs of angles.  

 

They also did not see the highly specialized engineers, technicians and other professionals, many of which have spent entire careers devoted to making the impossible happen time and time again.  NO price can be put on the talent and professionalism at risk of being lost!

 

To abandon the 46th Test Wing’s vast assets, and try to recreate it thousands of miles away (in range of North Korean missiles) would take years and cost many times any projected savings.  Please don’t allow our national security to be put at such extreme risk over something that appears to be a savings – ON PAPER ONLY!

 

Respectfully,

 

Monty Wilson

34 year veteran of the Eglin Test Range

From:	Paul Cothran <paedco@earthlink.net>

Governor Bush:
    During your trip to the UK, please do not miss the "Best Kept Secret in Europe", WALES.  Cross the Severn Bridge and enter an enchanted land that few, if any, travel agencies tell you about.  You can stay in Cardiff and drive through the surrounding countryside to see the most beautiful land in the UK, filled with quaint cottages, historic pubs, green hills covered with sheep and cattle and every few miles you will find still lived in castles or castle ruins.  I promise you it will be an experience you will never forget.  I was stationed there with the Army 1996 - 1999, commanding a depot at Caerwent and my daughter has lived there for 18 years with her Welsh husband in Newport.  England, Scotland and Ireland are publicized, but Wales is the Garden spot of the UK.

Monta Reilly

From:	Charles Schrader <Charles.M.Schrader@cba.ufl.edu>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 9:29 PM
To:	George Bush; vice_president@whitehouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; mayor@ocfl.net; district5@ocfl.net; Constantine, Lee
Subject:	Re: Positions on Issues

> 1)    Immigration reform (most important issue for the next election):
>
> a.     REAL ENFORCEMENT OF IMMIGRATION LAWS, including detention  
> and deportation of illegal aliens (aka "undocumented workers") and  
> visa overstays within 48 hours. It must include Police at all  
> levels of government in the enforcement & deportation process.
>
> b.     National ID cards w/ Guest worker program.
>
> c.     Get the Army Corps of Engineers to build a southern border  
> fence. There is plenty of money to refill sand on beaches for condo  
> owners, but not direction and resources to support national security?
>
> d.     Shut down illegal border crossings & prosecute companies  
> that hire illegal aliens. We spend billions of dollars a year on  
> national defense and someone could just drive a nuke across the  
> border.
>
> e.     No more non-emergency public education & health services.  
> They should get those services from their own communities and  
> governments in their own countries.
>
> f.      No bi-lingual education. It is incumbent upon new LEGAL  
> arrivals to learn English.
>
> g.     No housing assistance. They need to petition their own  
> governments for those kinds of services.
>
> h.     Voter Fraud. People should have to show legally certified  
> photo identification to vote. Are we the only country on earth that  
> doesn't require ID proof for national elections? How much fraud is  
> tolerable?
>
> i       Bottom line, people need to apply legally & get permission  
> to enter our country. Citizens of other countries should not be  
> extended US Constitutional rights because they have not signed on  
> to the social contract or pledged allegiance to the flag of the  
> USA. The most civility they deserve is to be treated humanely as  
> they are deported back to their homelands.
>
> 2)    Stronger protection of property rights against eminent domain  
> abuses. No confiscation of property to give to other private  
> owners. Also, better comprehensive compensation for small business  
> owners who are impacted by eminent domain. Taking their location  
> often destroys their businesses.
>
> 3)    Health care reform. I support electronic record-keeping for  
> medical records, Medicaid transformation, consumer driven health  
> care, and liability reform. Also, right now people think medical  
> care is a right and are willing to pay $50-$90 per month for cable  
> television, but cry “working-poor“ when it comes to contributing to  
> their own health care costs. That's not a good thing either.
>
> 4)    Stronger privacy rights, including making it illegal for  
> companies to sell consumer information to foreign companies.
>
> 5)    Eliminate unnecessary federal programs like HUD & FannieMae.  
> The market is mature enough and accessible that it does not need  
> government ownership & management of housing. Wasteful programs.
>
> 6)    Tax reform. I support eliminating the current income tax  
> system in favor of a national sales tax.
>
> 7)    Social Security Reform: I support being allowed to put a  
> portion of my social security contribution into private accounts.
>
> 8)    Education reform: eliminate the multiple layers of  
> bureaucracy between the federal level and the local level.
>
> 9)    Support democracy in the Middle East and stay the course in  
> Iraq to aid them in getting up and running, but I would like to see  
> additional political solutions to reduce our military obligations.  
> They are supposed to soldier, not police. Also, thank Mr. Rumsfeld  
> for his service. He is doing a fantastic job.
>
> 10) Additional investments in the energy and military budgets for  
> alternative fuels like hydrogen cells. I believe our significant  
> dependence on oil is a national security risk and we should do what  
> we can to mitigate it.
>
> 11) Work to re-incorporate patriotism education.
>
> 12) Balance budget through health reform, tax reform, and a line  
> item veto for the President.
>
> 13) Stay aggressive in the war on terrorism, including additional  
> pressure on Iran and North Korea.
>
> 14) Support faith based community initiatives.
>
> 15) Scrap the current space shuttle program and get something new.  
> Their whole organization looks like a huge waste of money. Who  
> cares about Mars?!
>
> 16) Reduce tax burden. Government services are the first or second  
> largest expense of nearly every household in America.
>
> 17) Clean environment and green technology. Clean water, land, and  
> air are a fundamental right.
>
> 18) Litigation reform. There is a lot of waste, fraud, and abuse  
> with the legal system paying incredible amounts of money to  
> facilitate frivolous legal actions. If individuals and groups (like  
> ACLU) want to bring lawsuits to court, they should not be  
> reimbursed with taxpayer money for their actions. They can exercise  
> their rights with their own money, not public funds.
>
> 19) Stronger protection of Second Amendment rights, including right  
> to carry in all 50 states and employment protections for legal  
> firearm owners. The Second protects the First Amendment.

From:	gctest@bellsouth.net
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 6:22 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Illegal immigration

Dear Governor,
I am writing you in hopes that you will count my voice as that of Americans who one day will care what is happening to this country, but at present do not voice their opinion.  Unfortunately Americans have proven to be short sighted, lazy, and have short memories.  They tend not to take the time to voice their opinion unless it directly affects them, and even then it must be of substantial and immediate consequence.  Specifically I am speaking of the illegal immigration problem, and the effect it is having and will have on America.

I am a law enforcement officer her in South Florida and have been so for 13 years.  Prior to being a police officer here, I was in Military Intelligence for 9 years, also dealing with illegal immigration to a certain extent.  From my unique perspective I would like to convey to you how frustrating it is to deal with and watch what is happening in this Country, particularly South Florida.   It is my hope that you will exercise what influence you can to help protect our state and this country from continued unchecked immigration.

There are two primary areas of concern for us in South Florida, those that are happening in other areas of the U.S., and those happening right here.  In my honest opinion, as a citizen of the U.S., and as a law enforcement officer dealing with this quite frequently, I think the issues need to be handled in a similar and fair manner.  That is to say that the immigration laws should be enforced equally across the boards.  Those that have entered illegally in the past should not be granted any form of immunity.  To do so would set a precedent, both socially and legally, that would dictate concessions to those that violate our borders in the future.

With regard to the issue of Cuban immigration, and the crimes they commit with impunity while doing so, it really should be stopped.  I can’t emphasize the tremendously demoralizing effect on law enforcement personnel it has when these people conspire to smuggle, (crime #1) break the law to enter the country (crime #2), and yet they do not get charged with anything.  To make the matters worse, if they threaten the Coast Guard or other LEOs with sticks, etc. (crime # 3, felony) they get taken to dinner by the Mayor of Miami and get gifts on TV.  To top it all off, even those that didn’t make it to shore during that episode get to stay, … just another slap in the face of the law and those trying desperately to enforce it. 

It is very frustrating to hear irrational justification for allowing these people who come illegally to stay, such as “this Country was founded on immigration …” Many things have changed in the past 200+ years, and that is why the laws have changed to deal with those changes.  Those that believe in this argument must then also believe that slavery should also be permitted, because back when this Country was founded it was an accepted practice.  There should be no speed limits, as there were none when the Country was born.  The list can go on and on, and is ridiculous, just as is the claim that we should allow unchecked immigration now because it was allowed centuries ago! 

In closing I would like to say I have nothing against these people that come looking for a better life.  If I lived where they live, I would probably do the same thing.  That doesn’t make it right though.  In reality there are many countries in the Caribbean that are worse off than Cuba.  If I were from those countries I would be irate over the fact that I get “repatriated” no matter what, when the Cubans get to stay, even when they break all sorts of laws to get here.  I am not advocating allowing all others to stay, I feel all immigration should be applied for and achieved legally, meeting predetermined objectives.  

Probably the worst part of the whole situation is that the U.S. Government pays the smugglers (indirectly) to bring in the illegal refugees!   If the American population in mass knew that their tax dollars and social security dollars are going to subsidize the smuggling of illegal refugees, they would be quite upset!  Not to mention the fact that these illegal refugees are given Medicare, Social Security, business loans, etc, all without paying in a dime, it would really send the average American into a tirade.  How come the Federal Govt. does not make this fact commonly known to the American public?  Don’t they have the right to know they pay for smuggling efforts and illegal immigration?  The sad part of all this is, the problem would go away over night if the Federal Govt. stopped funding the smuggling.  It is one of the easiest problems to cure, and yet it continues.

Please do not support any sort of “amnesty” or reward people for violating our borders.  Please do away with the “wet foot/dry foot” policy and the Cuban Adjustment Act.  Set reasonable immigration standards that will protect our Country.  These standards should be fair and impartial, and all people desiring to immigrate to our land should have to abide by them, and we should NEVER pay smugglers to bring in illegal immigrants or reward people for committing crimes as they enter our Country.  Thank you.


Sincerely,

Glenn C. Test

From:	Della Bruens <dellabruen@atlantic.net>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 2:03 PM
To:	Jim Fowler BOCC; Nancy Williams, Secretary; Susan Jackson, BOCC; Sue Farnsworth, Planner; Dennis Damato BOCC; Dianne Terry; Gary Bartell , BOCC; Cynthia Jones, County Planner
Cc:	Mr. Bertoch; Joyce Valentino BOCC; Mike Wright Chronicle; Vicki Phillips, BOCC; Gary Maidhof, Dir. Development Services; Governor Jeb Bush; Jenette B. Collins, AICP/BOCC; Kimberly Bruce, BOCC
Subject:	Fundamental Character of Old Homosassa

Subject:  July 11, 2006, 3-2 vote Homosassa Riverside Resort expansion approval

 

To Citrus County Commissioners Bartell, Damato, Fowler :

 

It has come to my attention that, at the Commission meeting July 11, 2006, you three Commissioners approved expansion plans for the Riverside Resort in Homosassa, Florida, with two fellow commissioners casting two Nay votes.

            I am shocked, appalled, dismayed, and insulted that you have blatantly ignored the over 1,200 petitions, letters and e-mails of your constituents in opposition to this project which violates the Old Homosassa District Overlay, part of the Citrus County Comprehensive Plan.

1.         This project is located in our Coastal High Hazard area absolutely forbidding this kind of development, 

2.         is directly on the Homosassa River, 

3.         is on environmentally sensitive acres, 

4.         is in a Hurricane evacuation route, 

5.         is in an area not zoned for commercial as the prospective new construction of 72 high-priced condominiums for private ownership will top 4 stories when the now height limits are 2 stories above parking,

6.         this expansion will negate the old cracker-style buildings, thereby destroying the effects of Old Homosassa as it is today,

7.         this project is too big.  The State program, Waterfronts Florida, is aimed at protecting the historical integrity and feel of old Florida Coastal Communities like Homosassa.  

8.         High-priced commercial and residential development here will destroy the old buildings and docks as they are now.

9.         this acreage is designated for only six (6) units per acre residential with the projected  4 story condominiums equaling more than eleven (11) units per acre.

10.       this project will overtax the roads, overtax the river, overtax the boat ramps and river traffic.

11.       Since Old Homosassa is a fishing village, this project will be detrimental to the continuation of employment in the fishing industry as it is today.

12.       If this project goes forward as planned, the original residents who lack the income to live on high-priced waterfront property face eviction from their homesteads.

 

Della A. Bruens, Crystal River, Fl. dellabruen@atlantic.net July 14, 2006
