From:	Christa Grammas <quill2fin@gmail.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 8:45 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Gary Diviney
Subject:	DOER ACT and EGLIN TEST WING RELOCATION

Governor Bush,

I am writing to ask you if you have made any connection between the recent (June 14) testimony of Colleen Castille to the Committee on Resources and the subsequent passage of the DOER act (June 29) and the recent announcement of the test wing closure at Eglin Air Force Base. 

I am aware that a major part of Ms. Castille's testimony included the problems and issues that could arise from Florida offshore drilling with the test wing here off the Florida coast.  I am also aware that the chairman of the Committee on Resources is a California congressman, Richard Pombo (R-CA)  As Edwards Air Force Base is the other major test facility in the country, and California's Edwards AFB will surely gain from our state's loss at Eglin, I wondered whether this connection was being made in you or your office. 

I am not reading this information in any of the news articles I have read about the potential closure. I am aware that the BRAC was kind to Eglin in November and this news is sending some north Florida communities reeling from shock. 

I have always been a supporter of yours and imagine that the federal government is utilizing the DOER act and this move to manipulate the economic success of Florida and allow greater access to Florida's waters, while relieving Ms. Castille of a large argument she made against offshore drilling.   
I, personally, am not concerned about offshore drilling. Our states currently have great success drilling in the middle of Illinois cornfields with little effect on the crops coming up there, and I know we can certainly use the fuel, especially with the mid-east situation and again now the Israel situation as it stands. 

However, I do have a significant interest in the possible decision to kill or relocate the test wing from Eglin, and would like to hear what you have to say about this development.

Thank you for your time and consideration, 

Christa Grammas Carter
Student, Levin College of Law - University of Florida 
850-628-6682
352-846-5219
quill2fin@gmail.com
301 Diamond Village #10
Gainesville, FL  32603

AJ has visited your office with Noah's Ark of Central Florida for the past two years when they have served as pages in the House of Representatives.

He has been the "manager" of the varsity baseball team for the past three years and is looking forward to being a part of the team again this year.

From:	COA-AS Communications <communications@counciloftheamericas.org>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 7:27 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] In Remembrance of Ambassador William T. Pryce

 


In Remembrance

of

Ambassador William T. Pryce

1932-2006

 





It is with sadness that the Americas Society and the Council of the Americas informs their members and friends of the passing of Ambassador William T. (Bill) Pryce this past Tuesday, July 11, 2006, at his residence in Alexandria, Virginia.  

 

He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Joan M. Pryce; daughter Kathy Pryce; sons Jeffrey and Scott Pryce; sister Katherine P. Collins; and five grandchildren.

 

Friends may call on Sunday, July 16 from 2 to 3 and 6 to 8pm at the Demaine Funeral Home; 520 S. Washington Street, Alexandria, VA.  Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 17 at 11am at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, 228 S. Pitt Street in Alexandria, VA.  

 

Bill Pryce served as Vice President of the Washington office of the Council of the Americas from February 1997 until his retirement in January 2003.  Ambassador Pryce came to the Council following a career as a Foreign Service Officer who specialized in Latin America.  His last overseas assignment was as U.S. Ambassador to Honduras, where he played a major role in advancing U.S. business interests and in resolving outstanding expropriation disputes.  Prior to Honduras, he was Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs and Senior Director for Latin America and the Caribbean at the National Security Council.  He contributed to the development of the “Enterprise of the Americas” strategy of increased trade and investment concurrent with debt reduction, and helped negotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement.

 

Earlier Washington assignments included service as alternate U.S. representative to the Organization of American States and representative to the Economic and Social Council, and special assistant to the Under Secretary of state for Economic Affairs.  His overseas assignments in addition to Honduras have been to Mexico City, Moscow, Panama, Guatemala and La Paz.






                                
             
William R. Rhodes
Chairman
                                                                  

 



Susan Segal
President and CEO

From:	Jody Hill <jhill@jdhillinc.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 10:57 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit in and for Seminole County, Florida

July 13, 2006
 

Governor Jeb Bush
PL 05 The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

 
Re: Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit in and for Seminole County, Florida
 

Dear Governor Bush:
 
As a business owner for more than twenty years, and a resident of Seminole County, I am writing to ask your help in a matter I consider to be of importance for our community. That is the appointment of of our next Circuit Court Judge for the Civil/Family division in Seminole County. 
 
I feel it is vital to ensure that those we elect are honest, fair, qualified for the position they seek to fill, have a love of their community, and a genuine concern for the well-being of the people that reside there. Currently, I am an active member of the Manufacturers’ Association of Central Florida, and volunteer my time to serve on the Advisory Board for the Small Business Development Council. I like to help make a positive difference where I live and work, and I believe Louise Zeuli is like-minded.
 
This brings me back as to why I believe Louise Zeuli is the natural choice to fill Judge Stephenson’s seat in the civil/family division. Louise grew up in Sanford – she is not a transplant. She knows the people, the problems they face, and the issues with which they must deal. Louise can be tough when needed to be, yet she is always fair. In her Practice of Law, Louise has chosen to specialize in mediating – finding fair solutions that work for all parties of interest, rather than to use the law as a tool for people to spite one another, or for her own personal gain. 
 
Her background as a Critical Care Registered Nurse, Advanced Registered Nurse Practitioner (ARNP), and as an Educator/Teacher, clearly exhibits her caring and compassionate side. Her twenty-three years as a general civil litigator proves that she has an extensive knowledge of the law, and is highly qualified to serve as our next Circuit Court Judge.
 
As someone who has volunteered for a number of worthwhile organizations that assist in areas such as raising money for the purchase of capital equipment for local hospitals, the rescue and rehabilitation of injured and orphaned wildlife, and organizations that assist the physically and mentally challenged in living independently, I understand the sacrifice it takes to help make a difference.
 
Louise’s community involvement and service includes:
- Volie Williams’ Inns of Court, Program Chairperson, past President, current Board Member
- Board of Director Member for Seminole County Legal Aid Society, Inc.
- Seminole Community College’s Community Advisory Board Member: Lecturer to their nursing students on legal liabilities
- Rotary Club of Seminole South, Board of Directors
- Chairperson of Community Service II Committee, which reviews and allocates charitable donations to worthy charities in the community
- Volunteer to help feed the homeless
- Rotary Club member and volunteer for Habitat for Humanity
 
As a member of this community and a registered voter, I ask you to help make a difference in ensuring that our next Circuit Judge is someone who will be fair, uphold the law, and who has the ability and desire to make a positive difference in our community. Please recommend Louise Zeuli for 18th Judicial Circuit Court Judge – Civil/Family Division, Seminole County.
 
Best Regards,

Jody E. Hill, President
J.D. Hill, Inc.
314 Krider Road
Sanford, FL 32773

 
Jody E. Hill
J.D. Hill, Inc.
314 Krider Road
Sanford, FL 32773
Phone: 407-320-9957
Fax: 407-321-5293

From:	Mnicp2@cs.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 1:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Is Governor already left for Ireland? I pre-recorded a piece for Irish Language

radio today:
   
For:  Radio na Gaeltachta (RnaG)

Dear Governor:

The programme is supposed to be aired  Friday at 1.30pm Irish Time, (8.30am here) on an Irish Language Programme called An Samhradh Thoir, presented by Sean o hEalai on Radio na Gaeltachta in Gaelic.


I spoke about the State having the lowest unemployment figures in the country at 3%.
The dedication to Education, the recent Teacher of the Year Award and how thrilled the recipient is at the prospect of meeting the President later on.

The interest Mrs. Bush has in the Arts and the recent scholarships.  How she is a Catholic and that the Governor is a convert. 

That the Governor of Florida is deeply religious and truly a saint, a very fine person indeed.

The presenter tried to run down the President and said that isnt what people think of his brother the President,  but I finish by saying "not true",  they are both from the same deeply religious family,  so the two of them have to be the same,  just have to be the same.

The only Repulican to be elected as Governor for a second term ever.

That I do not believe that he will not run for President,  it was he who went out to inspect the devestation after the tsunamai.
(I do not know how much of above will be used as it was pre-recorded)

I hope you will run for President as after the case of Terri Schiavo we know that the Devil is alive and well in the United States and only you can run him out of the country.  I believe the prophesies have also stated that the Church will be under severe attack after the reign of this present Pope.

With 45 million Irish Americans in the country, the present President did not seem to look at his Irish roots and ancestors (former Irish President Erskine Childers supposed to be a distant relative?).  The Clans of Ireland's office where information can be got on our ancestors and surnames used to be located in the Taoiseach's office in Kildare Street, Dublin.

I was told by the presenter that you will be at the K Club so I hope you enjoy your Golf there.
As you will be in the Dublin area,  please do what you can to have them bring you to see the Church and the coffin of Matt Talbot who is very much the patron saint of Dublin.
As per my last email,  if you go to Southern Ireland,  see the Rock of Cashel perhaps go through a little town called BANSHA which was the parish of another great Irish hero, the late FATHER JOHN HAYES who founded the Irish Rural Organisation called Muintir na Tire. His family lived under bushes after being evicted from their home,  yet he went on to study for the priesthood, becoming a priest against all the odds.  If you should be able to go to Bansha  or anywhere in Tipperary please ask for and have a photo op eating a slice of Irish Soda bread and jam in memory of Father Hayes who said that in his poor starving childhood,  the greatest treat in the whole world that a child could get was a slice of bread and jam.  He even started a jam factory in Bansha.
The book on his life is just wonderful but I do not know if it still available.

Holy Cross Abbey,  Tipperary contains a portion of the true Cross.

Castles:
Rock of Cashel,  Cahir Castle,  Bunratty has within the grounds homes of the various type of Irish person from the past, and Dromoland is now a hotel and totally fabulous.

The bed in which Ann Boleyn (wife of King Henry 8th. mother of Queen Elizabeth 1st.) slept in when she was a young girl on vacation with the Butler family in South Tipperary, the owners of Cahir Castle,  is located in some big house in South Tipperary (I do not know which big house, but perhaps Tom Woods a guide at the Rock of Cashel may know).

In Dublin, Kilmaingham Jail is now a tourist center.  It was here that Grace Gifford married her sweetheart, the poet Joseph Mary Plunkett just hours before he was executed after the rebellion in 1916 when we got our freedom.
The song Grace has been made famous by the Irish Tenors.  De Valera, 2nd President of Ireland escaped execution unlike the 16 others because he was an American Citizen. 

Moore Street at the back of the General Post Office in O'Connell Street used always be an outdoor market where one heard a rich variety of Dublin accents calling out for customers to buy the fish, etc.

Visitors to Dublin must also eat fish and chips.  The best fish and chips in the world are supposed to be available in a shop up at the back of Dublin Castle,  near Christ Church Cathedral.

Somewhere near there in Fishamble Street, your wife will be interested to know that  Handel wrote the Messiah.  People do not know that it was written in Dublin when he visited there.
Irish Dancing:
6 Harcourt Street now houses Conradh na Gaeilge.  Downstairs is the only Irish speaking pub.  Upstairs on 3rd. floor is the office of The Irish Dance Commissio,  which governs Irish dancing all over the world.  This tiny office was once the office of Michael Collins who fell out with De Valera (details to be seen in the film Michael Collins).

I hope that above arrives in time or that you will be able to get your email while on the trip.  I hope that you have a wonderful time in my country.
Kind regards
Maire Peters
(Irish Language Media, living in Naples, Fl.)

From:	Marilyn Sessions <msessions@homesavingsbnk.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 12:35 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Request

Good Morning Governor Bush

 

I am the 2004 Portage County Ohio Bush-Cheney Chair and am writing to make you aware of a solar panel project happening with Schneller, Inc of Kent, Ohio and Pinellas Park, Florida.  Following is a short description of the project and our request is for a representative (we were hoping you!) to be present at the ribbon cutting (date to be determined based on your schedule).

 

Schneller, Inc. headquartered in Kent, Ohio is the world leader in aircraft interior manufacturing and has facilities in Kent, Ohio, Pinellas Park, Florida and Paris, France.   I was fortunate to be part of the Schneller team for 8 year before coming to Home Savings Bank and am writing on their behalf.   

 

Schneller is in the midst of launching a new product line called Veritas ResinArt Panels.  Schneller is one of three global licensed manufacturers capable of using a patented technology that allows them to encapsulate materials in an environmentally friendly resin.  The resin contains up to 25% post industrial recycled content, contains no harsh chemicals and can be recycled.  The Veritas product line was introduced into the market place this past April at the Hospitality Design Expo in Las Vegas, has already won a “Best of NEOCON” trade show award in the architectural product category this past week in Chicago.  Veritas has already been featured in a variety of publications including the New York Times, Interior Design Magazine and Contract magazine to name a few.   Schneller has chosen the Pinellas Park, Florida facility as the manufacturing site of the Veritas product line.  They have already added head count to their manufacturing plant and expect this trend to continue for the foreseeable future.  They strive to be a green manufacturer and in conjunction with this product line have announced plans to install photovoltaic roof solar panels. They have teamed up with Solarpath Energy Systems of Miami, Florida to design and install the panels at the Florida facility.  These panels will greatly reduce dependence from the power grid and reduce carbon dioxide emissions into the environment. Schneller anticipates these panels will be installed by the end of June and would like to hold a “Flipping On The Switch” ceremony in July with as many local public officials as possible.  A firm date has not been set for this ceremony allowing the date to be adjusted based on the schedule of the Governor’s office.  

 

Any assistance you can give would be greatly appreciated.  Good for Florida – good for Ohio.  Thanks much in advance.

 

 

Marilyn Sessions

Human Resource and Training Officer

Home Savings Bank

142 N. Water St. 

Kent,OH  44240

330-677-6026 ext. 229

msessions@homesavingsbnk.com

2179 Briawood Circle 
Panama City, Fl., 32405 


Governor Jeb Bush 

Dear Governor Bush, 
I'm writing you to appeal the denial of my daughter for a 
Bright Future's Scholarship. My daughter, Megan Lester, was denied Bright Future's Scholarship because she had neither foreign language nor the correct English class. 

I'm a colonel in the United States Air Force, retiring this fall after 30 years of service. I have been a Florida resident since attending Florida State University in 1971, where I received my undergraduate and graduate degrees. I have been stationed overseas consecutively since 1996 when my daughter was in the fifth grade. She attended middle school in Belgium and graduated from high school in Australia, where she attended the preeminent private school in the country. Megan has always been an outstanding student, as evidenced by her 3.8 grade point average at Gulf Coast Community College in Panama City. The one "B" she's gotten in three semesters was in her drama class. She scored an 1160 on SAT's and 26 on the ACT's. Megan took all the English classes appropriate for Australia, but could not take a foreign language due to the fact that Australians take primarily Asian classes which are started in elementary school. There were no beginning language classes available to high school students. Megan has however, completed three college semester classes of Spanish. 

Sir, the entire process has been very frustrating. We first applied for the Bright Future's Scholarship over a year ago and the application was lost. We reapplied and were told that we needed to go to a professional company to have Megan's Australian grades interpreted into American standards. After a lengthy process it was denied based on the fact that Megan did not meet the proper English or language requirements. 

Sir, we appreciate your time and attention in this matter.  Of note, while I have no proof, I think that my wife and I were the Florida absentee balloters that got your brother elected president.

Sincerely, 
RICK W. LESTER, Colonel, USAF 
1st Air Force Inspector General

From:	Mnicp2@cs.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 1:00 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	re: trip to Ireland.  For Atn of Governor Bush

Dear Governor:

I just got an email from Irish Radio letting me know that you are going over to Ireland on Friday.  As usual, I will have nothing but the greatest praise for you.  I do not know if you will get this before you leave, I hope so.

If you have any special message or even a little greeting for the Irish speaking public, I will be thrilled to pass it on for you via radio.

I hope you get to meet  Eamon o Cuiv, the grandson of the late  President De Valera who is a great hero of mine.  In his early 20's he left his very comfortable lifestyle in Dublin and went to work and live in Connemara at a farmers co-op so that the Irish Language speaking people there would have a better life.  We call him  Young Dev.

It would be wonderful if they could bring you to either see the coffin of  Matt Talbot or the Laneway where he died on his way to Mass.  He will eventually become a saint.  He came from a very poor family and worked at a mill.  In his younger days he drank a lot and is now the saint that people pray to for their families who have addictions.  He is very much the patron saint of Dublin but he let me down badly when he let Terri Schaivo die.

You will probably see the General Post Office in O'Connell Street, Dublin where the fighting took place in 1916 and as a result we got our freedom.

Knock, Co. Mayo is where the Blessed Virgin was said to appear on the Gabel End of the Church there.  

Holy Cross Abbey in Tipperary has a portion of the True Cross on display.  It is tiny but you can actually see it.

Holy Cross Abbey is not far from the Rock of Cashel  where my ancestor,  King Brian Boru, the King of Munster. (from Ahearne, brother of King Brian Boru who had a son called Floinn and his son was Raith from whom my grandmother's family, The McGraths are descended).  My ancestor Bishop Miller McGrath is buried on the Rock of Cashel).  Close to the Rock of Cashel, as you approach it from Dublin and look down to the right, that land belongs to Vincent O'Brien the famous race horse trainer where JR Ewing (Larry Haggman) and other famous people have their horses trained.
I do not know if our greatly loved prime Minister Bertie Ahearne knows that King Brian Boru, King of Munster, who was killed at the battle of Clontarf in 1014 had a brother called Ahearne?

Gaelic Greetings:

Ta athas orm a bheith anseo  = I am pleased to be here.
Phonetic:   Thaw awhas orm (like worm without the w) a veh onsho.
                  Thaw awhas orm a veh onshow.
----------------

Gura Maith agaibh = Thank You All  
Phonetic:  Gorra Mawh Agiv

-------------
Gura Maith agat, A Thaoiseach =  Thank You Taoiseach.
Phonetic:  Gorra Mawh aguth, A Heeshoch.

-----------
On a toast raising a glass:   Slainte  (Good Health) = phonetically Slawnte.
You can reply by also saying just Slawnte.

------------
Slan =  Goodbye.
Phonetic:  Slawn

-------------
Famous Dublin Characters:   Forty Coats (A vagrant).  Old Bang Bang ran from Church to Church saying Bang Bang both in the 1920's.

Molly Malone one of Dublin's best known songs...a ficticious character, a fish seller:  "she wheeled her wheelbarrow through streets broad and narrow".

Dicey Riley:  another song about a ficticious person: 

"Poor Auld Dicey Riley, she has taken to the sup,
Poor Auld Dicey Riley,  she cannot give it up,
It's off each morning to the hop, then she pops in for another little drop.

The relatively new sculpture near Trinity College is nicknamed "The Flousie in the Jaccouzi".

If you land in Shannon,  they may take you to Dromoland Castle home of the O'Brien Chieftain, Conor O'Brien, Lord Insequin.  (Some of the family were called Heffernan and Quinn,  thus the town in Co. Clare called Quinn and thus the title Lord Insequin).
The Blind Poet Liam Dall O'Heffernan, of the Lord Insequin family wrote a poem Called Kathleen Ni hUallachain which became the secret name for Ireland and a painting of a woman called Lady Lavery depicted Kathleen Ni hUallachain on the old Irish Pound Note now out of circulation,  you will be using Euro coins now.  If Mrs. Bush is going with you,  this is somewhere she should see.  Very interesting but not as beautiful is the nearby Bunratty Castle.  If given a choice,  go to Dromoland Castle.

-------------


If there are any other Gaelic words that you need,  I will be thrilled to send them to you.  Every year in the past I called the White House Speech Writers Dept. and asked if they needed any words for your brother the President for his St. Patrick's Day speech and nobody ever called me back.

I hope you will really enjoy your visit to Ireland.

Kind regards,
Maire Peters (from Ireland, living in Naples)

Subject:	46th Test Wing Relocation from Eglin AFB to Edwards AFB

Gov Bush- I am the proud spouse of a retired Air Force member who currently works with one of the civilian contractors who support the 46th Test Wing out of Eglin. I am deeply concerned with the articles in the paper regarding moving the test wing to Edwards AFB. The impact not just to our family and others but to the local business as well will be devastating. For starters if he loses his job we won't be able to afford our house payment along with thousands of others thus forcing us to try and sell which will in turn flood the market making it impossible for anyone to sell their home. Many people will probably have to file bankruptcy as they cannot afford to live in and support the local economy with the loss of those jobs. Those jobs are what brought the majority of these folks here in the first place.  This will also impact the schools which will impact the teacher’s positions, funding etc. since that is based on numbers of students.  Another thing that concerns us is the time frame-could they have made it any shorter? This is toying with people’s futures and puts people's lives in turmoil. When you have that many people involved it also hurts the job market/prospects that will be available.  Granted military will be moved but what about the rest of us? But even many of those military families own property here. I truly hope that serious consideration is given to impact that this decision has on our lives and futures here as well as the local businessmen who depend on our support year round.  The tourist industry does not support this area year round; it is we the "locals" who do this.  We are hoping that if enough people voice our concerns, maybe something can be done and you are one of the "go to people" we are hoping can help with this.   I look forward to your prompt response regarding this situation.

 

Respectfully,

From:	Pgilbertsr@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 4:56 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	U.S. Flag Code & Flag Etiquette

Dear Governor Bush:
 
     The United States Flag Code specifies that the Flag is to be flown at half-staff in mourning for designated principal government leaders and upon Presidential Order.
 
 
     In the event of the death of a present or former official of the government of any
State territory or possession of the U.S., the Governor of that State, territory, or 
possession, may proclaim that the National Flag be flown at half-staff.  And, that
ONLY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OR A STATE GOVENOR HAS THE
AUTHORITY TO ORDER THE FLAG BE LOWERED TO HALF-STAFF.
 
 
     The National Flag Foundations (NFF) has issued guidance on this subject in order to preclude good-faith misunderstanding or abuse of the Flag Code and Flag Etiquette, both of which are all too often violated by Civilian and Government Officials.   For Example:  Janet Reno, while U.S. Attorney General, ordered the American Flag flown at half-staff in honor of several DEA Agents who had died. The Flag Code does not give her the authority to issue that Order.  In addition, the Mayor of Pittsburg, Pa., ordered Flags flown at half-staff to honor the victims of a plane crash.  A well itentioned gesture, for which no authority exists.
 
 
     The NFF points out that these 'GOOD-FAITH" misunderstandings are not to criticize or embarass anyone, but rather, to head off growing trivialization of this memorial salute, and to preserve the dignity and significance of flying the U.S. Flag at half-staff, and believe that proper respect for our Flag must be maintained, no matter the circumstances.
 
 
     I feel it is a violation of the Flag Code and Flag Etiquette when Sheriff Ed Dean of Marion County, orders the Flag flown at half-staff.  He recently ordered the Flag to half-staff upon the death of a retired Police Officer and has on similar occasions in the past,  without, to my knowledge, authorization from you, the Governor.  He and other Officials take it upon themselves to lower our Flag to half-staff without the proper authorization.
 
 
     It appears to me that remedial action pertaining to the proper Flag Etiquette and Flag Code needs to be addressed.
 
 
     Sincerely, 
 
     Phil Gilbert

 INVITATION TO GOVERNOR BUSH
 
July 10, 2006
 
Governor Jeb Bush
Plaza Level 05, the Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am sending you this letter as an invitation to the Capitol Fellowship Breakfast hosted by The Christian Leadership Council, Inc., on Tuesday, November 21, 2006, 7:00 am, at the Tallahassee Civic Center.  The Christian Leadership Council is a non-profit, non-lobbying 501(c)(3) organization whose purpose is to minister to Florida’s key leaders with the message of Jesus Christ.  As you will recall, Dr. Ravi Zacharias was our guest on April 4, 2006.  Since the legislature will meet in organizational session and conduct swearing-in ceremonies, the leadership team felt this was an excellent opportunity to minister to returning and new governmental leaders and their families.  We especially would like to have you there to express our appreciation to you and to assist in the program with welcoming new governmental leaders to the Capitol. The Civic Center has been reserved for the morning of November 21st at which time there will be provided a  breakfast, a short musical program, and a guest speaker for incoming governmental leaders.  It would be our honor to have you attend and be a participant on the program.  The program will consist of prayer, Scripture reading, introducing speakers, opening remarks, and welcoming remarks.  If you will do us the honor of attending, you may decide what part of the program you would like to do.  
 
As of this date, the invited guest speaker to the Capitol Fellowship Breakfast is Actor Jim Cavaziel of The Passion of the Christ directed and produced by Mel Gibson.  There are several reasons why he was selected, among them include, he is a man with a powerful story to tell; he is not an extremist nor politically biased; and his part in this movie captured the attention of audiences all over the world.  
 
Mr. Tim Ireland is chairman of The Christian Leadership Council, Inc.  He is a former representative having served fourteen years in politics and ran for two State-wide offices.  He has a heart and mission to serve legislators through his ministry of presence, Bible studies, prayer breakfasts, and special events.  He joins a core group of representatives and senators who meet regularly in the Capitol for prayer and fellowship. The Christian Leadership Council is not affiliated with any other group or denomination, but strives to ministry to those who want to find the Lord or grow closer to our Savior Jesus Christ.  While the Capitol Fellowship Breakfast will be the first of its kind, The Christian Leadership Council has hosted special events before such as assisting with Rick Warren’s visit to Tallahassee, a luncheon with Coach Bobby Bowden, and a dinner event with Ravi Zacharias, a Christian Apologist and international speaker.  
 
We look forward to hearing from you regarding your participation in the Capitol Fellowship Breakfast on Tuesday, November 21, 2006, 7:00 am, at the Civic Center.   I would like to follow-up this letter of invitation with a phone call to discuss more details with you or answer any questions you may have.  You may return email confirmation of your willingness to attend and if you would like to be a part of the program.  I am also listing my phone number if you chose to communicate in that manner.  Thank you for considering The Christian Leadership Council’s invitation to this function.  We are looking forward to serving you and members of the legislature in the near future.
 
God Bless,
 
 
 
Neil Dodson, Administrative Assistant
The Christian Leadership Council, Inc.

CONTACT: Richard K. Wagner
(850) 644-1033; rkwagner@psy.fsu.edu    

By Barry Ray
July 2006
NIH TURNS TO FSU FOR TOP RESEARCH ON LEARNING DISABILITIES

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Florida State University has been awarded a $6-million grant from the federal government over five years to fund research efforts aimed at more effectively understanding, predicting and preventing the development of learning disabilities such as dyslexia in children, it was announced today.

The grant will fund the creation of a National Institutes of Health (NIH) Multidisciplinary Learning Disabilities Center at FSU. The center, which will be one of only four in the nation, represents the NIH's flagship research program for learning disabilities.

Dyslexia is a learning disorder marked by impairment of the ability to recognize and comprehend written words. Although once thought of as visual disorder, scientists now know that the condition's manifestations - misspellings, reversing letters and words, even writing backwards - spring from an inability to recognize sounds, not visual cues.

"Many kids with reading disabilities really aren't identified until the second grade," said Richard K. Wagner, FSU's Alfred Binet Professor of Psychology and a Distinguished Professor of Psychology. As the principal investigator for the NIH grant, he will oversee the work of the Multidisciplinary Learning Disabilities Center.

The center will enable FSU researchers to conduct behavioral and genetic studies involving thousands of Florida children with dyslexia. The center will be an arm of FSU's Florida Center for Reading Research (www.fcrr.org), which was itself established in 2002 as a cornerstone of Gov. Jeb Bush's "Just Read, Florida!" initiative to have all schoolchildren in the state reading at their grade level by the year 2012.

"Our hope is to develop ways of diagnosing dyslexia and other learning disabilities at a younger age so that these children have greater chances of leading a happy, productive and successful life," Wagner said. "And it's a phenomenal opportunity for FSU because we will get to participate in the NIH's premier research into dyslexia."

Wagner said the center will conduct several studies involving large numbers of volunteers. In one of these, FSU researchers will identify a sample of 500 Florida families with members who have severe reading problems. In addition to educational and psychological testing, DNA samples will be taken from the volunteers to examine possible genetic components of their learning disabilities.

FSU also plans to perform a large-scale study of twins.

"We will be searching for 9,000 sets of twins from throughout the state," Wagner said. "After we identify them, we will seek parental permission to access their school records. Specifically, we will be looking for variability in their reading skills."

In addition to Wagner, nearly two dozen faculty members and post-doctoral researchers from FSU's departments of psychology and communication disorders, College of Education, and Florida Center for Reading Research, as well as four molecular geneticists from the Yale University School of Medicine, will participate in five major research projects under the NIH grant.

"For more than 20 years, Rick Wagner has been a leading scholar in the areas of learning disabilities, dyslexia and cognitive psychology," said Joseph K. Torgesen, director of the Florida Center for Reading Research. "I am delighted that he will have the opportunity to put his expertise to use in overseeing such important research into the study of dyslexia."

The Dyslexia Research Institute ( www.dyslexia.com/faq.htm) estimates that from 10 percent to 15 percent of the U.S. population has dyslexia, yet only five out of every 100 dyslexics are recognized and receive assistance. The institute also states that approximately 60 percent of individuals diagnosed with attention deficit disorders (ADD) also are dyslexic; however, their learning and language differences often are unrecognized because only the behavioral aspects of ADD are addressed.

###


Joseph K. Torgesen
W. Russell and Eugenia Morcom Chair of Psychology and Education
Florida Center for Reading Research at Florida State University
227 N. Bronough Street, Suite 7250
Tallahassee, FL 32301
850-644-7752

From: Slager, Heather [mailto:Heather.Slager@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, June 27, 2006 1:20 PM
To: Laura Foster
Subject: RE: Status of notary application
Thank you for contacting the Governor’s Notary Section!  Since the appointment of a notary is a discretionary act, there are no set criteria to guarantee a notary appointment.  (Please refer to section 117.01, Florida Statutes)  Additionally, the Governor does not give reasons for appointing or denying anyone an appointment.  You can either reapply for a commission or write the Governor's General Counsel requesting reconsideration at the address below.  Again, there is nothing that can be done to guarantee a notary commission appointment.
 
If you have any additional questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.
 
Address:
Executive Office of the Governor
Office of the General Counsel
209, The Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-0001
 
Sincerely, 
Heather Slager
Notary Education Coordinator
Office of the Governor, Notary Section

Per procedure, we sent your notary application to FDLE for a background check on April 11, 2006.  A background check takes approximately 60 days to complete and be returned to our office. From:	monty wilson <mwilson5@valp.net>
Sent:	Monday, July 10, 2006 5:46 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	EGLIN

246 Chicago Avenue

Valparaiso, FL 32580

July 10, 2006

 

Governor Jeb Bush

The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399

 

To the Honorable Jeb Bush;

 

Thank you for all you’re doing to save the 46th Test Wing, and I emphatically encourage you to double your efforts to keep this critical asset at Eglin, where it belongs.  Please remember that both the security of our nation, and the jobs and lives of thousands of professionals and technicians, hinge on the outcome of this decision.  You don’t replace 3,500 or more high tech positions with 200 wage-grade jobs and have a resulting “wash” job-wise, as is being promoted by the proponents.

 

Please keep in mind that the figures showing monetary savings do not tell the whole story.  One of the many aspects of such a move that isn’t shown in the figures will be the increase in costs passed on to the Government by vendors and support groups of weapons that have located offices and plants within close proximity of Eglin.  For example:

 

The management and support team for the GPS “GYPSI” project is located in Melbourne, FL, and members drive up from there for testing on a regular basis.  If testing is moved out west, they would be required to make regular cross-country flights to California.

 

Also, the management office for the Hellfire missile test project is located at Redstone Arsenal in Alabama.  Just two weeks ago that team drove about six big trucks down to Site C-7A to begin work on an upcoming test.  To provide the same support out west would require a massive cross-country trip of several days instead of one.

 

There are dozens and dozens of other established links to the Eglin area also that are not reflected in the financial justifications also, plus the cost of rebuilding what we already have!

 

Keep fighting for us Governor Bush.  Now is not the time to move this critical function within range of North Korean missiles, or to disrupt the flow of weapons development.  Also keep in mind that ONLY Eglin offers three routes of access for test – the Gulf, the Atlantic and by land.  All three are used, especially in Cruise missile testing.  Edwards can’t provide but two, nor does it have our massive Gulf Test Range for large-scale supersonic testing.

 

Respectfully,

 

Monty Wilson

 

Valparaiso, FL

From:	Johnson Linda F CTR USAF 46 TW/TSRM <linda.johnson.ctr@eglin.af.mil>
Sent:	Monday, July 10, 2006 2:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Emailing: otto.pdf

Please read the enclosure and reconsider closing, moving the Climatic Lab to Edwards.

From:	bfogarty7@cox.net
Sent:	Monday, July 10, 2006 2:00 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Urgent, The Loss of Eglin AFB's 46th Test Wing and the Proposed Immediate Closure of the McKinley Climatic Laboratory!

Dear Governer Bush
 
    I am writing to you asking you for your immediate assistance in a matter of utmost importance and urgency.      
    As you may already be aware, there is a movement in the Air Force to shut down some of Eglin AFB's facilities and transfer most, if not all of Eglin's 46th Test Wing and it's mission from Eglin AFB in Florida to Edwards AFB in California.  This cannot be allowed to happen.  
    As you may also be aware, the attempt at siphoning off Eglin's mission and it's assets and having them transferred to Edwards is not a new one.  This has been a reoccurring attempt for several years now.  What is different about this time and this event is the underhanded and back-door way in which this has taken place. 
    They have sneaked this up the ladder and gained Air Force approval without the Test Wing, or the Test Wing's contractors knowledge or being allowed in on the discussion. 
    For these facilities to be shut down and for the Test Wing's mission to be moved to Edwards would devastate this area's economy. 
    While I am concerned for the welfare of my local area, the future of Eglin and the long-term growth of this area, my immediate concern is for my job at one of the facilities that have been targeted for immediate closure. 
    Although you may be aware of this attempt to move the 46th Test Wing, you may not be aware however, that there are three facilities located at Eglin that have been targeted for immediate closure.  Those are the McKinley Climatic Laboratory (Climatic Lab), the Pre Integration of Munitions and Electronics faciltiy (PRIMES) and the Guided Weapons Evaluation Facility (GWEF).  
    They have been targeted to be shut down by October 1 of this year (2006).  From what I have been told, the decision to shut down these facilities is going to occur sometime in early August.  These actions have only been brought to the public's attention this past Friday (July 7th) via an article that was published in the Northwest Florida Daily News of Fort Walton Beach, Fl.  This is merely days away from being decided.  It is not an understatement to say that this is very alarming and requires your immediate attention.  
    The decision to permanently close these facialities is a grave one.  As you may already be aware, the McKinley Climatic Laboratory is a one of a kind facility that is unique, not only to the Air Force, but to the entire world.  The capabilities of this facility alone cannot be duplicated anywhere else in the world and it would a national tragedy to lose that unique capability. 
    Not only is the Climatic Lab a national asset and an asset to the Department of Defense, but is a profitable asset to the Air Force, Eglin, and the 46th Test Wing.  The Climatic Lab has a testing schedule of customers fully booked for the next two years with an extremely heavy work load projected for the next 5 years.  There is also, already in place, a 30 million dollar contract with the Air Force and Raytheon to test the ACM/ALCM six times a year for the next 24 years here at the Climatic Lab.  The Climatic Lab's customers are not only DoD (Air Force, Army and Navy) and DoD contractors such as Raytheon, but companies such as Ford, Chrysler, Pratt & Whitney, Bombardier and more than several civilian aircraft companies that are all regular and repeat customers of the Climatic Lab also.  With the permanent loss of facilities such as the Climatic Lab, where else will these customers go?  It would appear that no one at the decision level cares what happens to these customers.  A cavalier attitude such as that canot be tolerated in any enterprise, much less in the United States Air Force.  
    From what I understand, the rational being used to promote this agenda at this attempt, is that the Air Force needs the money to buy aircraft and "realigning" Eglin would allegedly accomplish this task.  However, this reasoning only sounds like the latest excuse to legitimize the attempt at the siphoning off of Eglin's missions and assets.  As stated earlier, this is not the first time this has been attempted. 
    There are plenty of legitimate arguments for not allowing this to happen.  Many of them are economic and budgetary.  It just doesn't make economic sense to permanently close these facilities, lose their capabilities forever and move these missions to Edwards where operating costs are staggeringly higher there at Edwards than here at Eglin.  
    The personnel, the infrastructure, the capabilities, the weapons research and the facilities are already in place at Eglin AFB.  It doesn't make economic or budgetary sense to destroy that. 
    The 46th Test Wing and it's facilities have recently been scrutinized and have survived BRAC.  It has survived BRAC because it was determined that the Test Wing and all of it's facilities are an asset to the Air Force and the Department of Defense and it would not be cost effective to relocate or close any part of it's existing mission.  Being that the BRAC determination has alredy and recently been made, then why now is this attempt to dismantle Eglin AFB being made?    
    It does not make sense for the Air Force to make a decision of such short term economic gain at the cost of permanently destroying in-place capabilities, resources, personnel and facilities.  
    Once again, sir, I cannot adequately express the gravity and the immediacy of this situation.  My job and my immediate capability to provide for my family is in immediate jeopardy.  I am pleading for your help and assistance in this utmost important and urgent matter.  Thank you.  
 
Sincerely, 
Bruce A. Fogarty
Contract Employee w/Indyne, Inc.
@ the McKinley Climatic Laboratory
Eglin AFB
 
My Contact Info:
119 Berger Place 
Fort Walton Beach, Florida, 32548
H, 850-243-1775
C, 850-240-0311
W, 850-882-5914
Email:  bfogarty7@cox.net

Dear Governor Bush, 
I am writing to you in support of the appointment of Louise B. Zeuli to the 18th Circuit Court Bench in Seminole County, Florida. 

I have known Ms. Zeuli for a period exceeding 12 years, having used her legal services in several matters.  I also assisted her with several cases in my professional capacity.  Both my wife, Sandy, and I were very impressed by Ms. Zeuli and found her to be extremely professional in all our legal dealings.  I distinctly remember being amused at the reactions of "the other side", being irked when Ms. Zeuli repeatedly found errors in their documents, due to their sloppy work.  We were quite satisfied on all occasions by her attention to detail and professional manner and congratulated ourselves with picking a great attorney to represent us. 

During my life, I have been privileged to meet several people I have described as "large souls".  These are men and women who live beyond themselves in the community of mankind; Louse Zeuli is one of these people.  Ms. Zeuli has participated in a large way with a variety of civic organizations, community groups, and beneficial charities.  She spends many hours involved with the Seminole County Legal Aid Society and assisting students at Seminole Community College.  Ms. Zeuli's years of experience as a Registered Nurse have also provided her with a unique perspective and a wealth of knowledge far beyond that of legal matters. 

In my many years, while serving as a juror on civil and criminal cases (I always get elected foreman), I have had the opportunity to observe many judges on the bench.  The traits I have admired in several judges, intelligence, fairness, common sense, and respect for the law, are all personified in Louise Zeuli.  I personally believe that she will make a fine addition to the Circuit Court bench and hope you will grant her appointment. 

Jack Finucan
Ernst & Young / Orlando
Office Services Coordinator

From: owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com
[mailto:owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com] On Behalf Of Governor Jeb
Bush
Sent: Saturday, July 08, 2006 6:47 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 7, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader,
Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDIANS USING SAFETY BELTS

On Thursday I announced that a record number of Floridians are using
safety
belts. The Preusser Research Group recently reported that 80.7 percent
of
drivers and their front seat passengers are using safety belts on
Florida
highways.  Overall, safety belt usage rates in Florida have climbed more
than 20 percent since 2000. A vast majority of Floridians are using
safety
belts. Wearing a safety belt saves lives. It is the single most
effective
way to prevent injuries and reduce fatalities in motor vehicle crashes.
For
more information on Florida's 'Click It or Ticket' safety belt campaign,
please visit www.clickitfla.com.


CHRISTA CALAMAS APPOINTED SECRETARY OF THE FLORIDA AGENCY FOR HEALTH
CARE
ADMINISTRATION

On Thursday I named Christa Calamas as Secretary of the Florida Agency
for
Health Care Administration (AHCA). Calamas most recently served as the
General Counsel for AHCA.  The appointment is effective July 8.
Previously,
she served as Assistant General Counsel to Governor Bush from 2002 to
2005.
Calamas replaces Secretary Alan Levine who was recently selected as the
new
CEO of the North Broward Hospital District. Christa's extensive
experience
in health care policy continues to be a great asset to my
administration. I
am confident Christa will continue the good work done by Secretary
Levine as
Florida implements landmark Medicaid reform, leads the nation in public
reporting of hospital information and begins the process of creating
networks for electronic medical records. All three of these priorities
will
fundamentally improve the way health care is delivered in our state. For
more information on Florida's consumer-driven health care initiatives,
please visit http://ahca.myflorida.com or www.floridacomparecare.gov. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO ALICIA CRABTREE

On Wednesday I recognized Alicia Crabtree of Melbourne as this week's
Points
of Light Award recipient.  For over three years, Alicia has dedicated
her
time to volunteer efforts at the Melbourne Children's Home Society, an
organization designed to prevent child abuse and neglect. I am proud to
recognize Alicia for the tremendous impact she has had on the lives of
others less fortunate. She has given selflessly of her time and
resources
for the enhancement of others.  Alicia is to be commended for her
extraordinary commitment to the community and should serve as an example
to
us all.  For more information, or to nominate, go to
www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/7975


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

Subject: NDAA Point Paper for Gen Riemer



All,



            Gen Riemer has requested a point paper on NDAA to support an 
upcoming meeting with the Florida Congressional Delegation.  Specific 
interest is on the Intent vs. Impacts of the NDAA language.



            I'd like to include several specific examples: GWEF, JPRIMES, 
McKinley, BISS, ASTTE/MSTTE, CIGTF, NRTF, King Hangar/CSAR-X as demonstrable 
cases.  Impacts on DLRs or the Flying Hour program may be considered if 
appropriate.





INTENT VERSUS IMPACT

OF

FY03 NATIONAL DEFENSE AUTHORIZATION ACT

(NDAA)

SUBTITLE D. SECTION 232:

OBJECTIVE FOR INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING

OF

TEST AND EVALUATION FACILITIES



PURPOSE:  Provide specific examples of the impacts to the 46TW as a result 
of NDAA 2003



BACKGROUND - NDAA INTENT:

-           Funding Objective (1) was to "fully fund" institutional and 
overhead costs of MRTFB activities through Major Test and Evaluation support 
and investment accounts (Program Element (PE) 65807 and 64759F for the Air 
Force), Central Test and Evaluation Investment Programs (CTEIP) (PE 64940D), 
and facilities restoration, modernization and sustainment PE'S (65976F AND 
65978F).

-           Funding Objective (2) was to insure that DoD elements would only 
be charged the direct cost for their use of MRTFB resources.

-           HQ/TE Guidance, MRTFB Customer Charging Policy, dated 1 October 
FY05 stated that costs supporting a single customer are to be considered 
direct costs.  Costs supporting multiple customers are generally considered 
indirect costs.

-           Intent was to ameliorate rising or fluctuating costs and produce 
stable rates within the MRTFB-provided services.

-           Congress provided no additional funding to implement the 
institutional funding mandate; within the Air Force, the primary source of 
funding was to direct transfer from the acquisition programs.





IMPACTS:

-           Charges to Commercial Customers were intended to include 
institutional and overhead charges under funding objective (2) of NDAA 2003. 
However, since the implementation of NDAA, most Test Group commercial 
customers have sought and obtained sponsorship letters from DoD 
organizations justifying use of MRTFB resources at the government rate, thus 
shifting those expenses from a reimbursable basis to internal, unit funding. 
The resulting impact to the 781TS, National RADAR Test Facility (NRTF), has 
been an unfunded bill for the indirect cost of tests performed for 
commercial customers.  For FY06 the shortfall amount is $1M.

-           Before NDAA, the 746 TS provided a week of GPS jamming 
environments during a semi-annual event known as "Jamfest" for a variety of 
customers.  Each customer was charged a $5K to $10K "entry fee" to use the 
GPS jamming environment, as well as any additional direct costs for their 
program.  Customer feedback showed Jamfest fulfilled a need for a low-cost 
way to test navigation and weapons system performance in the presence of GPS 
jamming.  However, as a direct result of NDAA, customer funds already 
received for Jamfest IV (scheduled for Nov 2006) were returned and the 746 
TS reverted to using limited, in-house funds to provide a reduced-scope for 
Jamfest IV and has canceled subsequent Jamfests.   Additionally, 
collaborative testing in general has become difficult to conduct because any 
cost common to two customers is not direct to either, and is therefore 
unfunded.

-           NDAA also prevents customers from paying for capability upgrades 
if that capability will eventually be used by another customer.  In the 
past, our overall test capabilities gradually grew due to investments made 
by specific customers to meet their needs that had residual value and use to 
later customers.  As a specific example, upgrades needed for the Joint 
Precision Approach and Landing System (JPALS) test can not be funded by the 
program under NDAA are currently not funded by any other source.  We are 
attempting to find other funding sources but the likelihood remains that 
test accuracy will be compromised.  Another example is the AT-38 rear 
cockpit instrumentation rack.  These racks used to be funded by the first 
customer to require it and available to all customers afterwards.  Under 
NDAA, this is no longer possible and all customers will suffer.

-           Under objective (1) of NDAA, customers can no longer support I&M 
efforts that could be utilized by multiple users at the MRTFBs.  As a 
result, MRTFBs have less flexibility and must utilize the Air Force Test 
Investment Planning and Programming (TIPP) for I&M efforts.  Unfortunately, 
the TIPP process was not modified to account for NDAA changes and is not 
flexible enough to accommodate testing timelines.  The impact is 
insufficient funds to cover I&M projects at the 746 TS.

-           NDAA drives the FHP.  Prior to NDAA we had a flying program that 
cost about $23M of which half was DBA and we earned the rest through RBA 
earnings through adjusting flying hour rates.   Under NDAA we cannot charge 
the customer other than direct costs, so a significantly higher percentage 
of the $23M must be paid for with DBA.  Because we have no real earning 
capacity any more a fully funded FHP is required.  The result is now we have 
to get requirements from customers a year out so we can get sufficient hours 
(dollars) allocated from AFMC.  We then have to build our test and training 
inside that budget.  If new customer test requirements arise during the 
year, we may have to turn them away - in the past we could have always taken 
on their work since they were paying.  So, even though Gen Martin was 
driving toward a FHP before NDAA, NDAA now demands operating on a FHP and 
significantly reduces test flexibility in the process.

-           Implementation of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) 
of 2004 has created multiple unintended consequences for many ground test 
facilities and capabilities such as the Joint Pre-flight Integration of 
Munitions and Electronics Systems (J-PRIMES), Guided Weapons Evaluation 
Facility (GWEF), McKinley Climatic Laboratory, and Multi-spectral Test and 
Training Environment (MSTTE), Armament Systems Test and Training Environment 
(ASTTE), and Base Installation and Support System (BISS).

o          These facilities and capabilities provide unique test and 
training capabilities and capacity to ensure customer requirements are met

o          Prior to NDAA each facility and capability could charge indirect 
charges to customers to offset maintenance, utilities, supplies, 
enhancements, and upgrades thus reducing DBA requirements based on facility 
and business demand

o          Under NDAA these indirect charges can no longer be applied to DoD 
customers

o          RBA decreases due to inability to charge indirect costs to 
customers

o          Results in increased DBA requirements for FY07 and out years

o          Many customers are willing to pay indirect costs in order to keep 
these critical high-demand capabilities available; NDAA directly prohibits 
this.

o          All of these facilities, whose operation was fiscally sound 
pre-NDAA, are now at considerable fiscal risk despite a customer base 
willing to pay for access to the test resources offered, but who are 
prohibited from doing so under NDAA because the direct costs are not 100% 
attributable to a single customer.



SUMMARY AND DISCUSSION



Unfortunately the ground test facilities and capabilities are falling victim 
to a "Perfect Storm" scenario, wherein the provisions of the NDAA coupled 
with the established POM process produces difficult fiscal pressures.  With 
severe FY07 budget cuts outlined in PBD 720, and the inability to charge 
customers indirect charges, it is extremely unlikely that many of the above 
facilities and capabilities will remain viable.  This will have a severe 
impact on test range and facility customers.  If these facilities and 
capabilities were not part of the MRTFB and thus not under NDAA rules it is 
extremely likely the capabilities could remain viable and continue to 
support most of the facility customers at a reduced capacity despite budget 
cuts and PBD 720.



The implementation of NDAA, specifically the methodology to accomplish 
funding transfers to support the MRTFB, and the elimination of indirect 
charges to the customers, produces austere fiscal management pressures.  As 
an example, based solely on these fiscal parameters, it would be in the best 
fiscal interests of AFMC to completely divest of all possible MRTFB assets, 
discontinue funding, and avert any further funding transfers from the AF 
acquisition programs, and if capacity and access were not an issue, utilize 
MRTFB assets operated by the other services.  In this manner AFMC could 
redirect funds to other crucial areas, limit or eliminate transfers from the 
acquisition programs, and only be forced to fund the direct costs associated 
with mission-critical services previously provided by AFMC-operated 
components of the MRTFB.  This is a completely unrealistic scenario for 
obvious reasons (OSD and the other services would certainly strenuously 
object, corresponding transfers may be demanded, and capacity remains a huge 
issue), but it highlights the 'tendency limit' of a process.  These 
difficulties, of course, span the entire MRTFB.



In fact, to a certain degree elements of this scenario are already 
occurring, as AFMC (through institutional direct budget funding) is forced 
to subsidize a whole host of test and training customers whose parent 
organizations did not contribute to the operation and maintenance of the 
MRTFB infrastructure within AFMC.  The missions of the 'non-AFMC' users may 
be compelling and vital (AFSOC, 33rd FW, 53rd WG, AF and DoD training, 
etc.), however, these missions themselves are not within the AFMC core 
mission. The programming implications are clear and counter to our national 
defense interests with respect to the strategic maintenance of these MRTFB 
assets.



The core of the difficulty is that under the pre-NDAA business model, a 
complex fiscal strategy evolved wherein customers supported the MRTFB assets 
via demand for test range resources and services.  The complexity at Eglin 
is illustrated and compounded by the wide scope of customers supporting and 
utilizing the range.  Under NDAA, it is now extremely problematic for the 
services to adequately resource MRTFB assets because the budget transfers a) 
do not directly relate to a bottom-up MRTFB requirement analysis, and b) 
they rely on 'future test requirements' throughout the FYDP which are 
ambiguous at best and absent in other cases (example AF non-acquisition or 
other service test or training requirements and corresponding 
non-transferred funds).  This results in the 'owner' of the MRTFB assets 
assuming an increasing burden of subsidizing a significant percentage of the 
current and future test and training customers, with no clear resolution of 
this funding difficulty available under the existing rule-set (POM process 
coupled with NDAA).



If this situation persists and results in a reduction in overall MRTFB 
assets, the results could include AF and other service program delays, 
increased difficulty in meeting developmental and operational test 
requirements, difficult fiscal problems for maintenance of key MRTFB assets 
required by other range customers (cross service customers, training 
customers to include AFSOC, 325th, 33rd, and JSF as examples), and increased 
costs as direct budget saved in reductions is transferred via out-of-cycle 
costs to other sources and to prime contractors, who may absorb some of the 
capacity shortfalls.

From:	brandi and jesse barefield <4nicebares@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 9, 2006 11:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please don't move the 46th

Dear Governor Bush, 

 

I am writing you today asking for your immediate assistance on some disturbing news I have learned. The last two days there have been articles in the North West Florida Daily News about the closure and relocation of the 46th Test Wing at Eglin Air Force Base, Florida to Edwards Air Force Base in California.  I am a contracted civilian employee with Indyne Inc. and work at the McKinley Climatic Lab as a HVACR Mechanic/Operator.  In the paper today it shows that the McKinley Climatic Lab, Pre-Integration of Munitions and Electronics (PRIMES), and Guided Weapons Evaluation Facilities (GWEF) are scheduled to close on October 1, 2006.  This is the first step in moving or standing down of the 46th Test Wing at Eglin AFB, FL. The remainder happens over the next six years.  This process does not seem economical to me. It will cost MILLIONS to relocate the 46th Test Wing. I know that the Climatic Lab has the next two years booked with an extremely heavy work schedule projected for the next five years.  Also we have a $30 million contract with the Air Force and Raytheon to test the ACM/ALCM six times a year for the next 24 years. The word I received today from our Civil Service Director over the Climatic Lab is that the Air Force has stated that they do not care about the customers. They can find somewhere else to go!  A definite decision about our fate will be made around Aug. 1, 2006. These facilities of the 46th Test Wing have survived BRAC in recent history because it is not cost effective to relocate or close.  Why now is this happening?  Just three years ago there was a movement to shut down the Climatic Lab and the cost was around $20 million just to shut down a profiting facility.  There is no other facility in the world like the McKinley Climatic Lab. We service the military and the civilian world with the testing we do.  To lose the 46th Test Wing and some of its rare testing facilities could come at great cost not only to the local community but the entire country.  I cannot even imagine the ripple down effect that this situation will have on this community. What makes no sense to me is that the personnel, infrastructure, and capabilities are already in place at Eglin AFB, FL. It doesn’t make economical sense to destroy that, and destroy 1500 civilian jobs in the process.  

  I thank you for your utmost attention in this matter. I will be awaiting your reply on what you can do to help all of us with the 46th Test Wing.  

  You can reach me by Email at home 4nicebares@earthlink.net  or work jesse.barefield.ctr@eglin.af.mil . Thank you again for you time.

Sincerely,

 

Jesse A Barefield

 
 
 
brandi and jesse barefield
4nicebares@earthlink.net
EarthLink Revolves Around You.

From:	Sophie Meyer <bscweski1@cox.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 9, 2006 2:56 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Eglin 46 TW Disbandment

Dear Mr. Bush,                                                     

 

      I am an employee of the Operation and Maintenance contractor at Eglin Air Force Base.  I have worked on the contract for 22 years, supporting our military weapons testing and developing by rising as early as 2:00 A.M. and staying as late as 12:00 P.M., through freezing rain and boiling sun, missing many family outings, vacations and birthday celebrations, all in order to accomplish “the mission”.  I never complained through the years, though, because I always thought I was helping my country; this was my sacrifice and, even though I wasn’t an active duty military member, I felt very proud of what I and my fellow team members accomplished here at Eglin.

      Now, if the latest Air Force budget realignment plan is approved, that mission will no longer be being accomplished at Eglin.  All my years of sacrifice will mean nothing, and our community of Eglin workers who have always put “duty before all else” will be left with nowhere to turn for their future.  You see, we’ve built homes, lives, relationships, a community here at Eglin.  We are brothers and sisters dedicated to giving our all in order to produce the very best results for the military that we possibly can.

      On that note, I have personally heard many of our project officers remark that they will never go back out west to test again, if they have any choice in the matter.  They remark that they get 100% results here, and in a much shorter turnaround time than out west.  Also, they get much more accurate data here than out there.  I have heard this comment within the last 2 months.  

      The armament community here at Eglin is unique in that a weapon can be visualized, designed, prototyped, built, tested and deployed all right here in one location.  There is nowhere else in the armed forces that a weapon can be taken from the cradle to the battlefield in one place.

      Eglin is also unique because it has three areas from which an item can enter the test areas – the land ranges, the Gulf ranges, and the Atlantic Ocean.  Other bases can offer only two.

 The elimination of thousands of high wage jobs would result in a downward moral, fiscal and spiritual decline that this area has never known.  The new jobs that BRAC promises to bring to the area in the form of training missions will not begin to make up for the loss of high wage, high intellect jobs that will be shifted to the western bases, although there is no guaranty that the engineers and scientists working at Eglin will relocate there.

      Our community would suffer greatly from the “training base only” plan.  The knowledge base that would be lost to other areas as the Eglin scientists and engineers leave to find other jobs would not only be devastating to the future of the Armed Forces weapon development, but to the Eglin community as well.  Along with the knowledge exodus would come the entrance of the temporary duty mindset and morals exhibited in the Jacksonville, Pensacola and Tampa areas.  These areas have all been victims of the training base mentality and subsequent degradation of family oriented communities.  We do not want our community to become the next victim.

      Finally, putting all the weapons development and testing capabilities at one single range would greatly diminish the quantity of actual testing accomplished every year.  There simply is no way that one base can accommodate all the testing that is done at the present time using Eglin and the western ranges.  A great percentage of testing needs would be unmet, and therefore directly affect the weapons development of our armed forces.  Our country would quickly fall behind in weapons development, putting us at risk of no longer being the world’s greatest military might, and, therefore, vulnerable to attack.

      I urge you to do everything in your power to protect Eglin and our community from the possible cuts that the Air Force thinks will enhance its capabilities, but as you can see from the points I’ve made in this letter, will actually not only hurt the Eglin community, but our country’s well being as well.

 

Sincerely,

 

Sophie Meyer

From:	Cliff Meyers <chm7171@cox.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 9, 2006 6:55 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Eglin Air Force Base

Dear Governor Bush,

 

My name is Cliff Meyers and I am employed at the McKinley Climatic Laboratory at Eglin Air Force Base in Ft. Walton Beach Florida.  

 

I don’t know if you are aware of the effort underway to move the 46th Test Wing from Eglin to Edwards AFB in California.  This proposal will put at least 3400 people out of work here in NW Florida and the economic impact will be felt greatly.  The types of jobs lost include highly trained technicians, engineers, scientists and upper management.  Not lower class paying jobs.  

 

The reason for the move from what we hear is that Eglin is going to become a training base and that up to 3000 personnel will be coming with this effort.  But what isn’t being told is that these folks will be temporary, doing their training and then leaving the area and that these folks are the lower wage military grade personnel and will not make the economic impact on the area that the ones who were laid off did.  Plus, these training personnel are not area voters.  The ones being laid off are.

 

I know the job of the military does not lie with the governor but you do have and ear in Washington.  

 

This effort is being driven hard by the Air Force Material Command.

 

Many rumors are flying around the work place and I am not one who throws rumors to the wind but there are a lot of questions going unanswered and all of the facts are not being addressed.

 

I don’t know how familiar you are with the McKinley Climatic Laboratory.  It is a one of a kind facility which produces climatic conditions to have the ability to perform climatic testing on aircraft and other items and equipment in the Department of Defense inventory as well as for commercial customers, domestic and foreign.  We are the largest test facility of this kind in the world and a national asset.

 

Many livelihoods will be lost if this effort is allowed to continue forward and the economic impact, or lack thereof, to the area will be greatly felt for years to come.

 

I know you have many items on your agenda that takes your time but I hope you will spend just a few moments looking in to this and gathering as much information as you can.

 

Thank you for your time and if I can provide you any information please let me know.

 

Regards,

 

Cliff Meyers

Eglin AFB, FL

Subject:	McKinley Climatic Lab - Eglin AFB

The local newspaper (Northwest Florida Daily News) reported Friday and again today that the 46 Test Wing may be downsized and moved to Edwards AFB.  Just a few years ago plans were being made by Col. Sager  who was the 46 Test Wing commander at Eglin at that time to close the Climatic Lab.  I contacted the newsroom editor at the Daily News and asked  if they were aware of this and was told no but that they would  look into it.  I talked with the news editor a few days later and found out that their questions surprised Col. Sager and his staff as though they preferred the public not be made aware of their plans.  Also, I understand he had closed other programs at other bases prior to coming to Eglin.   I contacted your office through a mutual friend and I believe you made a visit to Eglin a few days later.  It appeared at that time that the plans to close the climatic lab were being done in a very quiet manner just as it's being done again today.  Much of the news coming out today sounds exactly like what was being told by Col. Sager when he previously tried to close the lab.  Col. Sager left Eglin and went to Wright-Patterson.
   
My husband as well as many other men and women depend on their jobs.  Many of us grew up here and have raised or are raising our families here and depend on Eglin for our livelihood.  Reports are that 5% of contractor personnel will be eliminated as of October 1, 2006.  Most of that 5% were born and raised here in Okaloosa County.  
 
It's my understanding that a decision will be made by August 1st and again appears as though someone may have been intending the public not be aware until it was too late.  Many millions of dollars have been spent at the lab in recent months to help secure and test some of our major weapons systems and according to reports the last two years have made money for the air force.  It would be a shame to close a facility such as the lab and cost men and women their jobs in order to earn a star.  And, if a facility such as the climatic lab can be shut down and the 46 Test Wing moved, how soon will Eglin be picked apart?
 
I'm asking that you please check into this.  It just appears that one, perhaps several, have an agenda that doesn't include Eglin AFB.  I appreciate anything that you can do, as do others who will be affected if this plan goes through.
 
Thanks,
Noma Holloway

you want all of your Military Testing moved to one place?

costly to close the Lab than keep it open. The Lab has a work schedule that 
will support its operation. It is a SHAME that Someone up-line in OUR Military

Governer Bush,
   As you are probably aware, there is a movement afoot to move the 46 Test Wing from Eglin Air Force Base to Edwards Air Force Base in California. I am an employee of Indyne Inc. working for the 46 Test Wing at the McKinley Climatic Laboratory. We feel all of the facts are not being considered. The cost of testing at Eglin is substantually less than testing at Edwards. We have been through 2 BRAC"s and a few GAO studies that have proven the cost savings. As to my situation, The Climatic Lab has been in service since 1947, and is the only facility of it's kind in the entire world.

From:	Darren <ddhag@mchsi.com>
Sent:	Saturday, July 8, 2006 4:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush

Governor Jeb Bush, 

 

All I can say is Unbelievable.  That was my reaction to the official announcement of the “possibility” of the 46 Test Wing (TW) moving to Edwards, California.  I would like to see an investigation into what’s really happening.   About 3-4 years ago the Air Force changed the way the 46 TW acquired its budget.  Basically it aligned the Wing with the rest of the Air Force, receiving its entire budget from the DOD.   As I understand it, a large portion of the Test Wings budget was from contractors paying the wing to test its munitions (small portion from DOD).  For the most part we were self sufficient.  So, my question is, why the change?  IF money is a factor for the move to Edwards then why change the wing’s budget?  You can’t claim shrinking budgets and realignment as the answer if the budget is coming from outside the DOD.  I believe there’s more here than meets the eye.  As you know, the water ranges currently utilized by Eglin is under siege.  In my opinion this move is a big part of that.  IF the move happens, the bombing range in the gulf will become essentially a training range which will lessen its importance.  No longer will we be able claim its “Vital to National Defense”.  This will leave the water ranges wide open for offshore drilling.  If drilling in the gulf would return gas to pre-Ivan prices then in my opinion it would be for the best, but I am afraid the price of gas will never drop below $2.50 again.   My interest in this is that I am a civil service employee on Eglin; Florida is my home and has been since 1990.  Please, I implore you; fight this with all the means at your disposal. 

 

Thanks for your time and service, 

 

Darren Haggard

Navarre Florida
