From:	John Turnipseed <jatseed@comcast.net>
Sent:	Saturday, July 8, 2006 1:07 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Mike Clark; Wayne Ezell
Subject:	Return of Navy to Cecil Field

Dear Governor Bush,
I am writing you to request your assistance with the issue of the return of the Navy to Cecil Field (CF).  You took the initiative in August 2005 by leading the Florida delegation to the 2005 Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) Commission to advocate for the return of the Navy to Cecil Field as an economic boon for all of Northeast Florida.  Later, Mayor Peyton and the Jacksonville City Council “cut the legs” off your positive efforts by yielding to “small group” (the Better Westside Project (BWP), disgruntled citizens of the Westside of Jacksonville) politics, a pattern he and the majority of the membership of the City Council have followed since their election. Mayor Peyton wrote the BRAC Commission, AFTER they had decided to recommend the return of the Master Jet Base (MJB) to Cecil Field IF Virginia Beach, VA and their NAS Oceana base failed to meet preconditions for retention of the MJB, essentially “reneging” on the agreements made in SWORN TESTIMONY to the BRAC Commission, and foreswearing the possibility of the Navy return to Cecil Field in favor of a “misguided and largely ineffectual” effort to seek new tenants for Cecil Commerce Center (CCC).
The 2005 BRAC Final Report, with the CF option included, was submitted to the President, he forwarded it UNCHANGED to the U.S. Congress, both houses of the U.S. Congress passed it UNCHANGED, and the President signed it into LAW.  In June 2006, the Department of Defense (DOD) Inspector General (IG) found Virginia Beach, VA, and the State of Virginia were NONCOMPLIANT with the preconditions for retaining the MJB at NAS Oceana, and the door was wide open for the Navy to return to CF.  To qualify for the return of the Navy to CF, the State of Florida and Jacksonville had to do two things: 1. They had to ASK FOR RETURN; and 2. They had to comply with three preconditions in the 2005 BRAC LAW as quoted below:

“if the State of Florida appropriates sufficient funds to relocate commercial tenants presently located at Cecil Field, Florida, appropriates sufficient funds to secure public-private ventures for all the personnel housing required by the Navy at Cecil Field to accomplish this relocation and turns over fee simple title* to the property comprising the former Naval Air Station Cecil Field, including all infrastructure improvements that presently exist, to the Department on or before December 31, 2006”

“*The State of Florida may not encumber the title by any restrictions other than a reversionary clause in favor of the State of Florida and short-term tenancies consistent with the relocation of the Master Jet Base to Cecil Field.” 

Mayor Peyton and the Jacksonville City Council (JCC) have persisted in their “misguided and ill-informed” pursuit of the CCC option, and continue to sign up new commercial tenants, and allocate former CF land to prospective new developments: a new Florida Community College of Jacksonville (FCCJ) Westside Campus; a Bridgestone-Firestone Regional Distribution Center; and future “unnamed, secret, significant tenants” who are still “in negotiations”.
A group called Concerned Citizens for Cecil Field (CCCF), advocates for a referendum to decide this issue, and advocating the return of the Navy to CF, was started in late June 2006 led by Bill Gay Jr. of W.W. Gay Mechanical Contractors, Inc.  Also in late June 2006, a group of Jacksonville African-American ministers have come out expressing their advocacy for the additional jobs (publicized as 12,000 jobs with an annual payroll of $800 million) which the Navy return to CF would provide.  If a referendum is conducted, and the majority of the voters of Duval County advocate return of the Navy to CF ( rather than continue the pursuit of the CCC and future commercial tenants), can the citizens of Jacksonville count on you to call a Special Session of the Florida Legislature to consider (and hopefully pass) legislation for those measures and funding by the State of Florida required to be compliant with the 2005 BRAC LAW by the deadline of 31 December 2006?  If the majority of the registered voters in Duval County advocate by referendum return of the Navy to CF, will you support that action, and will you exert the power of your office to prevail upon Mayor Peyton and the JCC to abide by that vote, and take the actions necessary to COMPLY WITH THE 2005 BRAC LAW to return the Navy to CF?
I respectfully request that, as a “lame duck” Governor with NOTHING TO LOSE, and a fellow Republican, that you do all in your power to get Mayor Peyton and the JCC to change their minds and support the return of the Navy to CF.  You have stated in the past that “this is a local decision”, but if a referendum shows that the majority of Duval County voters favor the return of the Navy to CF, I hope that you will pressure the 19 people (Mayor Peyton and 18 of 19 JCC members) who are currently BLOCKING return, to abide by the will of the majority of Duval County voters.
In October 2005, I can see where the Mayor and the JCC may have thought the “odds” were against the return of the Navy to CF, and therefore, the prior course of converting CF to CCC, and pursuing future commercial tenants there was a “low risk” choice.  At present, there is virtually NO RISK to pursuing the Navy return to CF, except a COURT CHALLENGE by the State of Virginia.  Such a challenge in the Courts would challenge the whole BRAC Process. It would also pit Virginia against all the “winners” (States who retained or gained bases) in BRAC 2005 who would oppose any such challenge.  The Federal Government has “Eminent Domain” to legitimize their RIGHT to return the Navy to CF IF the State of Florida is COMPLIANT with the 2005 BRAC LAW preconditions.  No challenge in the Courts by a “perceived WRONGED” Florida property owner would be prohibitive unless the Federal Government consented to the lawsuit.
If current tenants at CCC were offered “comparable land” at Jacksonville International Airport (JIA) on the Northside, and were compensated for “relocation expenses” in accordance with 2005 BRAC LAW, they would likely not object.  Jacksonville has been trying to attract businesses to the Northside for years, and this move could be a “boon” to the JIA area as well as provide job opportunities to many nearby African-American citizens.  The return of the Navy to CF could provide an economic stimulus to Northeast Florida as a whole of $8.8 BILLION over 11 years in direct payroll alone, with whatever “economic multiplier” you want to use to project the total impact on the area’s economy.
I implore you to take whatever ACTIVE ROLE which you can to facilitate the return of the Navy to CF, which you CORRECTLY perceived in August 2005 as being in the long term interest of all of Northeast Florida.  There are no “long term” LOSERS in having the Navy return to CF.  All disgruntled Westside landowners will either adapt to the new MJB environment (as the citizens of Virginia Beach, VA adapted to the noise of NAS Oceana), or they will be adequately compensated at Fair Market Rates if they sell and move elsewhere, since the average Jacksonville area home is APPRECIATING 10-15% per year!  12,000 new job holders at CF will make a rich “SELLERS MARKET” for existing Westside home owners.  I thank you for your support and attention to this matter.  It will make a good “legacy” for your final 6 months in office.  Sincerely, John Turnipseed, Republican, Arlington resident, Major USAF (retired).

works in my classroom.  Many listened and also put into action your 
initiatives for the same results.  You pushed me to work harder for the 
achievement of my students and it worked.  

Both my husband and I changed professions when we had children.  Both of us 
have advanced degrees and believe in the importance of education, him with a 
J.D., and myself with a M.S.  We wanted to do something that would allow us to 
spend time with our children and make a contribution to their futures, so we 
became teachers, he in science and myself in technology.  Both of us have been 
successful in creating an environment for learning and have earned several 
awards in the process, but mostly our students have achieved and will be 
successful because of the things you have pushed in Florida.  I highly 
encourage people to take on the profession of a teacher in their area of 
expertise even if only for a few years.

I met you 2 years ago in Orlando at IT Florida conference where I brought a 
student who was a product of the successful practices you initiated (Ben).  I 
had developed a magnet school where students were graduating in 3 years from 
high school.  (you may not remember it but we gave you a credit card CD that 
Ben produced about the school)  Ben has gone on to college and I am sure will 
be very successful.  I also have won the Governor's Award for Economic 
Excellence in Teaching several times.  

I just wanted you to know that you have made a significant impact on my 
husband and I and on the students we teach every day.  The education reforms 
you have pushed are outstanding.  It all came home yesterday when my 6 year

From:	monty wilson <mwilson5@valp.net>
Sent:	Saturday, July 8, 2006 9:12 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	EGLIN AFB

Dear Governor Bush;

 

As you surely know by now, the situation at the 46th TW at Eglin AFB is critical, and we may be looking at a move that would severely hurt many citizens of northwest Florida and cause a major economic crisis throughout our area of the panhandle.  The brass in Washington who are pushing this move are calling it a “wash,” due to BRAC sending troops in soon that they claim will offset the loss of our test mission.  However, this in a total “whitewash.”  You don’t eliminate thousands of high paying scientific, engineering and technical positions with 200 wage-grade jobs and maintain the economic status-quo.

 

With the war on terror, tensions in Iran, North Korea and China, now is NOT the time to risk the quality of weapons testing and development.  I can’t tell you how many Air Force project officers have left Eglin over the years amazed at the support we give them.  They are used to 70-80% data, delivered in a week to ten days out west, and can’t believe we provide the highest quality data at 100%, usually on the same day, and often instantaneously.  The fact that the last BRAC study recommended MORE testing be moved to Eglin because of our excellence makes this move by others now wanting to shut testing down entirely reek of politics rather than national interest.

 

We trust you will join this battle and work long and hard to save the Eglin community.  Please contact all the right people in Washington, and use the power of your office to let everyone from the President to the Secretary of Defense know this is move that could have a severely impact our nation’s readiness at a time when world tensions demand we remain as strong a we can possibly be.

 

Respectfully,

 

  

Brannon M. Wilson

Eglin, O&M Range Contract

Valparaiso, FL

June 16, 2006                                                                       Contact: Brandi Reddick

                                                                        305.375.5362/brandi@miamidade.gov

 

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

 

STATUE OF HENRY FLAGLER TO BE DEDICATED IN CELEBRATION OF THE 110th ANNIVERSARY OF THE CITY OF MIAMI

 

(Miami, FL)- To commemorate the 110th Anniversary of the incorporation of the City of Miami, a statue of Henry Morrison Flagler will be dedicated on the steps of the Miami Dade County Courthouse.

 

Miami Dade County Courthouse

73 West Flagler Street (south entrance)

Miami, FL 33130

Friday, July 28, 2006, 11:00 a.m.

 

The dedication ceremony will be attended by Miami Dade Commissioner Bruno A. Barreiro, District 5;  Miami Dade Art in Public Places Executive Director, Ivan A. Rodriguez; Chief Judge of the Eleventh Judicial Circuit of Florida, Joseph P. Farina; descendants of Henry Flagler; representatives from the Flagler Museum, project promoter and facilitator Frank Lopez Del Rincon, and other members of the local business and governmental communities.

 

The statue is being donated to Miami Dade County by Col. G.F. Robert Hanke, great grandson of Henry Flagler and Vice President of the Flagler Museum in Palm Beach.       Originally commissioned in 1902 by Henry Flagler’s wife, the statue was created by an unknown sculptor in Rome, whose initials are C.J.R. The statue, which depicts Henry Flagler dressed in a long coat, is cast in bronze, standing 88 inches high and weighing 930 lbs. 

 

Henry Flagler’s contributions to the State of Florida were numerous, including his promotion of Florida’s agricultural industry, establishing Florida’s tourism industry through the luxury hotels he built from St. Augustine to Miami, and perhaps most notably, the Florida East Coast Railway, a transportation system that linked the entire east coast of Florida from Jacksonville to Key West.   

 

Henry Flagler’s life truly epitomized the strength, vitality and promise of America’s Gilded Age. The statue of Henry Flagler on the Miami Dade County Courthouse steps will serve as a lasting monument to the extraordinary vision and determination that gave birth to modern Florida.

 

Images and Additional Information Available Upon Request

Miami Dade Art in Public Places

111 NW 1st Street, Suite 610 Miami, FL 33128

Ph. 305.375.5362   Fax 305.375.5345

 Commissioner May Have Violated City Harassment Policy
POSTED: 5:31 pm EDT July 6, 2006 
UPDATED: 5:36 pm EDT July 6, 2006 
ORLANDO, Fla. -- Channel 9 has learned an Orlando city commissioner may have
violated a harassment policy that she voted for. City Commissioner Daisy
Lynum voted for the harassment policy within the last three years. 
The controversy centers on Lynum, who referred to a police officer as a
"white boy." The officer had pulled over Lynum's son for a traffic
violation. 
Channel 9 looked at the city's discrimination policy to see if that
statement violated the city ordinance and if she could be disciplined. 
Lynum lead the vote for the city's harassment policy for employees, which
prohibits comments that denigrate or show aversion toward someone because of
color or race which create an intimidating, hostile or offensive work
environment. 
Top of Form 1  Bottom of Form 1	
The police union is offended by her "white boy" comment and the leadership
wants to meet with the mayor about

I did not persue this any further becuase there is no way on God's earth I can pay this. You pointed this out to Mr. Crist at the time, very realistic. You invited me to try before you left office, so here it is. I did indeed pay some court costs while in work release. I also saved the State a considerable sum by participating in a new & unique program that involved taking inmates, training them, and replacing the cleaning contractors at D.O.C. headquarters. This resulted in a savings to taxpayers of about $250,000. I am disabled, recieve no benefits from gov't. or private sources. I do try to make a living with artwork we produce. I declare this income on my taxes and thru VSA and Florida Dep't of Education, contribute 50% of sales to other disabled persons. I am not a saint, but made serious errors and regret this. You have had these issues in your own life with your children. This is sad, hard on a family, mine or yours. If substance abuse is a disease, I did not meet anyone convicted of having cancer from cigarettes in prison!!! The DOC, in fact treated me well and will provide my best references to you. Ask the staff who dealt with me personally, incl. then Secretary Moore and Mr. Wolfe. Fireworks are illegal, but multi- million dollar stores selling them abound in So. Florida, Sir. The people who buy them are arrested.
    We have a teenage daughter in the Sherrifs Youth Ranch at our own expense to try and get her on the right track, and are grateful for this program. As a father with child problems, I'm sure you must understand. I am not a whiner, don't think I deserve any thing special, but would like to vote and try to change things that need changed. I am not trying to "suck up" either. You did strike me as man with integrity, lacking in many political figures today. As a life long Democrat, for what it is worth, you would have my vote in the future. I mean that as a compliment to you personally, as the man you are. I did use the training provide by DOC to get a job promptly upon release, also further used it to get certification in home inspection, also at my own expense. I did mention this to you in Dec. that I tried to assist during our hurricane crisis by using this education, but was denied as a convicted felon!!! A person should not pay forever because of substance abuse. Child molesters, car jackers, rapists, quite possibly so. We are from the same generation, not an excuse or justification, but a fact. We have been forced to take a 2nd mortage for homeownwers ins. this week, although have never made a claim. These problems must be acted upon and voting is the essential first step. Your consideration in this is most appriceated, and regardless of outcome, our best wishes for you and your familie's future endeavors is humbly and sincerely extended. I'm trying very hard to change many things and your consideration is valuable, sir. My goal is to display my art in the Capitol Gallery and contribute to society as much as possible the rest of my life. My entire family now lives in Fla. and this all matters to me in a deep way. Sincerely, Bruce & Dottie Cook

The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street Tallahassee ,Fl. 32399-0001
 
Re. Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit in and for Seminole County, Florida.
 
Prior to retiring to Florida in 1981 I was employed for thirty years working for the Federal Government as a registered nurse at the Louise Nourse Rogers Veterans Hospital in Bedford, Massachusetts. I worked up from a staff nurse to several supervisory positions and was certified by the American Nurses Association as a Geriatric Nurse Specialist. In addition to providing direct patient care I was actively involved in support to families and other care givers after patients were discharged from inpatient care status. 
 
My present activities include participating in the Retired Senior Volunteer Program in Seminole County.
 
When I needed legal advice two years ago to update my will I turned to the Internet for Attorney Resumes before making a decision. I was really impressed with the background information which Attorney Louise B. Zeuli presented. Not only did she have excellent legal credentials but I recognized that her nursing background was a real asset in her dealings with clients.
 
My personal contacts with Attorney Zeuli confirmed my initial impression that she is a warm person who is genuinely interested in providing the best advice to her clients and she never fails to explain matters so that they are fully understood.
 
I strongly support the appointment of Louise B. Zeuli to fill the vacancy for circuit court judge in Seminole County. She is honest, even tempered, knowledgeable in many areas of the law and has been a general civil litigator for twenty three years. Additional life experiences which could be very helpful include her background as a Critical Care Registered Nurse, Advanced Registered Nurse Practitioner, Mediator and Arbitrator.
 

Sincerely,
 

Antoinette G. Jardin
 
 
 
 
 

 
From:	Tom Utterback <tom@destinlaw.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 1:44 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Expedition of Investigation supporting Application for Restoration of Civil Rights

The Honorable Jeb Bush

Governor of the State of Florida

 

Governor Bush:

 

This is the third email I have sent you regarding my application for restoration of my civil rights in Florida.  I am sorry to be such a bother. 

 

My application was filed in November 2004.  On June 16, 2006, I received a letter from Janet Keels, Coordinator of the Office of Executive Clemency, informing me that I had been accepted for restoration of civil rights without a hearing and that the file was being forwarded to Mr. Hebert for investigation.

 

My request is that you ask Mr. Hebert to expedite the investigation.  I need the Certificate so that I can take the Bar Exam on July 25 & 26 of this year.  A computer check will verify that I do not have so much as a speeding ticket since my felony in 1998. My civil rights were restored in Missouri before I moved to Florida, but the FL Bd of Bar Examiners takes the position that since Missouri prohibits ex-felons from serving on juries that I must have a FL Restoration Certificate before I can take the Bar, thereby achieving full Florida citizenship.  

 

Please understand that I hold two of the three badges of Florida citizenship.  That is, I am a registered voter and I can run for most offices, including Governor.  [I am not planning on running, however, anytime soon.  This is an attempt to instill a little levity.]

 

Reasons to consider in giving me special consideration are:

 

1.	I am already a voting Florida citizen.
2.	My application is 20 months old, so I am near the top of the pile anyway.
3.	If I cannot take the bar in July, this puts me back nearly one year in getting back to a profession I hold more dear than I ever thought possible. [Nearing 60, I agree with the President about age.  However, the years grow more precious the older you get and I have a lot to make up for.]
4.	I worked with federal authorities to atone for my behavior even after I had served my sentence.  [I don’t consider this a big deal.  I wish that I had gone to the Feds much, much earlier.  I have learned the hard way that the Marine motto – Death before Dishonor – is the only way the live – or die.]
5.	I am a good father and husband, and in committing my offense, the only persons hurt were myself and, eventually, a bunch of bad guys.  No, I do not consider myself a bad guy even though I sinned and sinned mightily.
6.	In my career and personal life I have contributed to the greater good.

 

Finally, I have asked the assistant US attorney who prosecuted me – James Crowe of the US Attys Office for the Eastern District of Missouri to forward a recommendation to you.  Mr. Crowe returns to his office on Monday, July 10, 2006.  So, if he decides to recommend that you cause my investigation to be expedited, his recommendation will come no sooner than July 10, 2006.

 

Please also know that I chatted twice with Vickie Brennan of your staff about my request and I have promised her I will not bother her again.  Please also know that I appreciate the courtesies of Ms. Brennan, Ms. Keels’ Office and the time you take to review this.  If you decide my request is without merit, I understand.

 

If I am eventually successful in gaining admission to the Florida Bar, I certainly intend to tell my story to as many in the Bar as will listen.  My negative experience, I believe, can become a positive lesson for many.  In addition, should you ever be interested, I believe my experience has given me a unique and valuable insight into several challenges facing America.  I was on the top, then on the bottom, and I have been on the road back since my fall from grace.  As the old saying goes, “What don’t kill you, makes you stronger.”  It can also make you better, if one is willing to accept the truth.

 

Thanks.

 

Tom Utterback -- Paralegal

tom@destinlaw.com

Please be advised that (1) E-Mail communication is not a secure method of communication; (2) any E-Mail that is sent to you or by you may be copied and held by any or all computers through which it passes as it is transmitted; and, (3) persons not participating in our communication may intercept our communications by improperly accessing either of our computers or another computer unconnected to either of us through which the E-Mail is passed. I am communicating with you by E-Mail at your request and with your consent. In the event you do not wish this form of communication in the future, upon your notification of same, no further E-Mail communication will be forthcoming.

July 6, 2006

400 South Monroe Street

Re:	Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee

Dear Governor Bush:

Enclosed on behalf of Frank Nutter, President of the Reinsurance Association of America, is a "Questionnaire for Gubernatorial Appointments" regarding a possible appointment to the Governor's Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee.

As you can see by the enclosed questionnaire, Frank Nutter has long years of experience in the property and casualty industry and has been President of the Alliance of American Insurers (which recently merged with the NAII to become the Property Casualty Insurance Association of America), at that time one of the three national property and casualty trade associations.  He also has chaired the National Disaster Coalition and is on the Board of the International Hurricane Center in Miami. 

The RAA is a national trade association representing property and casualty organizations that specialize in reinsurance.  The RAA membership is diverse, including broker and direct, U. S. companies and subsidiaries of foreign companies.
 
The fact that Frank Nutter has stated his interest in serving on the Committee as a representative of reinsurers indicates his awareness of the challenges facing Florida and other hurricane prone states, and his desire to make a positive contribution in solving the current homeowners' insurance crisis.  Obviously, reinsurance is a key factor in the resolution of these problems and the RAA member companies want to share their experience and advice to that end.

Mr. Nutter is currently out of the country.  He has approved the enclosed application and has authorized his signature to be appended.  Upon his return to the United States next week, a notarized questionnaire will be promptly forwarded to your office. 

Thank you for considering Frank Nutter as an appointee to the Committee.

Sincerely,


Dennis C. Burke
Vice President, State Relations

Attachment

cc:  Lt. Governor Jennings
      Frank Nutter

Vice President, State Relations

From: Slager, Heather [mailto:Heather.Slager@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, June 27, 2006 1:20 PM
To: Laura Foster
Subject: RE: Status of notary application
Thank you for contacting the Governor’s Notary Section!  Since the appointment of a notary is a discretionary act, there are no set criteria to guarantee a notary appointment.  (Please refer to section 117.01, Florida Statutes)  Additionally, the Governor does not give reasons for appointing or denying anyone an appointment.  You can either reapply for a commission or write the Governor's General Counsel requesting reconsideration at the address below.  Again, there is nothing that can be done to guarantee a notary commission appointment.
 
If you have any additional questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.
 
Address:
Executive Office of the Governor
Office of the General Counsel
209, The Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-0001
 
Sincerely, 
Heather Slager
Notary Education Coordinator
Office of the Governor, Notary Section

From:	Missynlas <missynlas@netzero.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 10:47 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	CHARTER REVIEW COMMISSION VOLUSIA
Attachments:	chartercommconcerns.doc

<<...>> 


Greetings, 

Could you please direct me to the proper information source? 

My county, Volusia, is a charter county. 

We are presently undergoing the charter review process as required by law. 

I am concerned about the results of our Charter Review Commission's planned ballot question to amend our charter. 

I have contacted my County Council and County Attorney with my concerns. 

 I have been advised that County Council has no authority over the Charter Review Commission. 

I do not see how this is clear in either Florida Statute or our  Volusia Charter. 

My letter of concerns  to the county is attached and also appears below. 

I appreciate your guidance. 

Michele Moen 
missynlas@netzero.com 
386 423 8427 
160 Ashby Cove Lane 
New Smyrna Beach, FL 32168 


DATE:   June 8, 2006 
TO:             Volusia County Council 
RE:             Volusia Charter Review Commission Authority 

Greetings County Council, 
As a Volusia voter, I have questions and concerns with regard to the authority of Volusia’s Charter Review Commission.  

Florida Statute 125.64 Adoption of charter; dissolution of commission.-- 
 (2)   The charter shall provide a method for submitting future charter revisions and amendments to the electors of the county. 

Section 1303. Charter Review. The commission shall be funded by the council and shall be known as the "county charter review commission." It shall, within one (1) year from the date of its first meeting, present to the council any recommendations for amendment of the charter. After receipt of the charter review commission's recommendations, the council shall conduct a series of not less than three (3) public hearings on the recommended changes to the charter and shall thereafter schedule a referendum on the proposed charter amendment at the next general election.

Recommend is defined by Webster Dictionary as 

                To present as deserving of acceptance 

                Advise 

                Counsel 

I believe the above charter language clearly dictates that the CRC plays a limited role in the amendment of our charter in that the charter commission members are to review the charter and present their recommendations to county council and the public for review. Thereafter, the County Council will schedule a referendum on the proposed charter amendment but no where does our charter state the proposed charter amendment will be the exact worded recommendation of the CRC or that it has to be CRC’s recommendation at all. 


To date, the CRC has drafted a ballot that I feel opposes the goal and policies of our comprehensive plan which is to keep the Natural Resource Management intact.

The CRC suggests renaming our NRMA the Natural Resource Planning Area, ultimately divided with urban planning agreements between County Council and 16 municipalities.

As a citizen of Volusia, I bring these observations to Council for two reasons: 

	1)      I was advised by a member of Council that Council must accept and place on the ballot whatever the CRC comes up with (why then the 3 public hearings?) 

	2)      The CRC NRMA recommendation has been written by an attorney who sits on the CRC and represents several large landowners who own property within the NRMA and would greatly benefit from a strategically worded ballot question. 

	I do not see anywhere in the charter where the CRC is to actually write  a ballot question but only that it make  recommendations to County Council.  Shouldn’t the county attorney actually write the ballot? 

	I hope you can clear this up for me. 


	Michele Moen 
Concerned citizen 
missynlas@netzero.com 
386 423 8427

From:	Larry Feldhusen <larryf9@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 4:28 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Yankeetown Special Election Request

Governor Jeb Bush via fax 850 487-0801
 
Deputy General Counsel, Nathan Adams, via fax 850 488-9810 and 850 922-0309
 
July 5, 2006
 
Dear Governor Bush, 
 
Please call for a special election to replace City of Yankeetown council persons who have resigned. 
 
Because of an additional resignation(s), no quorum exists and no quorum can be called in order to call to order a meeting to replace council members as contemplated under the City Charter. 
 
A special election is needed to replace these council members and should be held as soon as possible. A special election may be set through the Dept of State through Florida Statutes, Sections 100.111(5) and 100.342. 
Florida Statutes Sections 
100.111 (5)  In the event of unforeseeable circumstances not contemplated in these general election laws concerning the calling and holding of special primary elections and special elections resulting from court order or other unpredictable circumstances, the Department of State shall have the authority to provide for the conduct of orderly elections. 
 
100.342  100.342    Notice of special election or referendum.--In any special election or referendum not otherwise provided for there shall be at least 30 days' notice of the election or referendum by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, district, or municipality, as the case may be. The publication shall be made at least twice, once in the fifth week and once in the third week prior to the week in which the election or referendum is to be held. If there is no newspaper of general circulation in the county, district, or municipality, the notice shall be posted in no less than five places within the territorial limits of the county, district, or municipality.”
 
The Supervisor of Elections stated that a Special Election could be organized and held in Yankeetown in as little as 6 weeks. 
 
Thank you for your continued attention to this matter,
 
  
 
 
 
 
_________________________
Lawrence E. Feldhusen
Resident and Registered Voter, 
11 Magnolia Ave.
Yankeetown, Florida 34498

From:	Arthur Pate <arthurwpate@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 4:01 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Town of Yankeetown / reason of resignation

                                                                   Mary Pate
5608 Riverside Dr.                                                                   (352)447-2968
P.O. Box 94                                                                             arthurwpate@bellsouth.net
Yankeetown, Fl. 34498
_____________________________________________________________________________
 
 
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
After reading Mr. Warnstadt’s letter to Deputy General Council Nathan Adams, I can no longer continue to be apart of the governing body of Yankeetown after eight years of service. I would like to address some of the points that Mr.Warnstadt has made in his letter that caused me to resign. He states that I, the vice-mayor, have not attended meetings since April. I have attended meetings in April, May, and June. I have missed four of the nine posted meetings. I apologize for missing those meetings, but my husband has cancer and was in the hospital for 3 weeks in April and also caused me to miss other meetings in May and June because of his continued health problems.  I was informed before all meetings that I missed that the mayor had a quorum. She continued to include a council member who had resigned immediately on May 11th in order to make the quorum, however he chose not to make the Mayor’s quorum for two of the four meetings I missed. 
 
The mayor states in the letter that”the Town is now without the ability to make required payments to the State, to suppliers, and to execute payroll checks”. However, the mayor knew that there were still two signatures that could sign on the checks, the mayor and I. In fact, I prepared the June 15th payroll while the mayor was on vacation for two and a half weeks. All the mayor had to do was co-sign the checks for the employees. As it turned out the mayor did not return to town when she said she would and the employees’ checks were late.
 
 I believe that the town could have continued operating and moving forward with the paying of town bills and day to day operation. The mayor chose to shut down Town Hall based on Mr. Warnstadt’s letter and Nathan Adams response to that letter. The mayor could have called for an emergency meeting to hire a town clerk resulting in having Town Hall open for business. Nor did she call for an emergency meeting to fill a council seat. Also, she did not post a workshop on improvements to the town water system planned for June 30th. Instead of having a public workshop, the council members had to meet individually with the engineer in order comply with Sunshine Rules. If we had this workshop the council could have shown that we could function and have meetings. 
 
I know that it is in your hands to bring this town back together again. I hope you will consider on an emergency election for the three vacated council seats instead of allowing Mayor Johannesson to appoint the vacancies. If she appoints, she will have appointed four of the five council seats. If that happens we will no longer have a democratically elected government in Yankeetown. The people of Yankeetown have been torn apart by all the dirty politics of the last six months. A democratic election will help to heal the town by giving the people a choice in who represents them in government. Please do the right thing for the people in Yankeetown and set an election.
 
 
Sincerely,
 
 
 
Mary Pate
 
 
 
From:	Sibley, Russell <russell.sibley@sap.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 3:05 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Louise Zeuli for Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit in and for Seminole County

Importance:	High

Honorable John Ellis "Jeb" Bush, 

It has been my privilege to know Louise Zeuli for the past ten years.  During that time, she has represented me in several legal matters and has become a personal friend of my wife and I.

I am a Client Partner in a Professional Services and Software Company, which is the largest Applications Software Company in the world.  In my role, I advise CIOs, CFOs and CEOs for some of the world's largest corporations.  My primary focus for these companies is to create business processes that can be used on a global basis.

Some of the companies I have assisted are The Coca Cola Company, Eli Lilly and Company, Dupont, Walt Disney, Siemens Corporation and Colgate Palmolive.  

I realize what it takes to be effective in the business world and the importance of interpersonal skills.  These companies spent hundreds of millions of dollars in the endeavors to revamp their business process.  

Louise had the business world understanding and the interpersonal skills to make her an effective litigator and mediator to bring a consensus solution to the problems she has to resolve.

Louise has extensive legal experience which she applies to resolving business issues.  She understands that the rule of law must apply, but she strives to bring adversaries together to bring about solutions, while not fearing the courtroom, if necessary.

Here are a few of the descriptions that I would use to describe Louise: 

1. Impeccably Honest 
2. Posses a rare ability to listen before forming any opinion.  She is intent on doing the "right thing", not just pushing forward without all the facts.

3. Extensive legal experience, seemingly conversant on all aspects of the law. 
4. Well respected, both professionally and personally. 
5. Diverse life experiences, which she can draw upon for her efforts on the bench. 
6. Her demeanor is always professional. 
7. She has always been prompt and punctual for any meetings, personal and profession. 
8. My wife and I find her a delight personally and enjoy our time together. 

Louise leads a very busy professional and personal life.  But she always seems to find a way to go the "extra mile".  My schedule is hectic and I fly out of town each week.  Louise has changed her schedule and visited us at home to meet on the various issues she has resolved for us.  

I will follow this short email with a letter outlining more of my reasons for recommending Louise for this opening on the 18th Judicial Circuit.  I wanted to get this email to you so you are aware of my whole hearted support for Louise.

My wife and I are registered Republicans and want our voices to be heard in support of Louise.  It's important to know that our Republican officials in Florida are listening to the voters who placed them in office.



Russ Sibley 
Client Partner 
SAP America

I am very interested in serving on this Board and respectfully request that you consider me for any future opening.
 
Thank you for your time and the wonderful job you do for our great State!

The Honorable Governor Bush,

 

A number of years ago, perhaps 8 or 10, I served a brief period of time on the 12th Circuit Judicial Nominating Commission as a lay member.  I only went through one actual appointment when I received my notice that lay members were no longer going to be on the Commission, only Bar appointees and Governor appointees.  I would very much like to serve again, this time as your appointee.

 

The reasons the JNC selected me were many:  I am a Registered Nurse, as such, I am extremely analytical, persevering, and calm. My skills were quite handy when I ended up having to investigate a probate proceeding handled by one of the attorney-candidates.  Due to my research and interviews, I was able to uncover some blatant ethical violations that precluded this applicant from sitting on the bench.

 

I am deeply committed to a strong, unbiased and fair judicial system. I think you will find me to be just as valuable to the 12th Circuit JNC today, as I was the first time I served.  During the next round of appointments in November, I would appreciate your thoughtful consideration of me as a Governor appointee to the 12th Circuit JNC.

From:	Jack Graham <goofbalmy@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 4, 2006 2:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	fredtr@mpinet.net
Subject:	Mr. Mike Gotschall
Attachments:	Letter to Jeb.pdf

From:	Mary Ann ODonnell <maryann_odonnell@verizon.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 4, 2006 12:55 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	immigration

I agree with what's written here. We've spend many a dollar over the years to preserve what we believe in, as much blood has been spilled on many shores to do the same. Now it's time to protect our own shores and remove all those who have entered it illegally and refuse to adapt to the AMERICAN way of life. If these people can pay a coyote $3000 to transport them illegally into our country they can certainly stand in line at the immigration office and do it correctly. If they cannot denounce the country they came from they have no right to be here.
   
   
   
   
  This whole immigration debate has been covered and debated by all the talking heads, but what do real people think and know about immigration?  How does it all affect us and what should we do?  I don’t claim to have those answers, but like most problems, you can turn to history to see the right and wrong way to handle it.  Like most people, the history I know best is my own, and I’d like to share a bit of immigration history from my own life.  
  My Mothers family arrived in the colony of Pennsylvania in the late 1700’s from Germany.  Not sure why they came, I’m sure they just wanted a better life, than what they could have in the “old country”.  I’m not sure what the immigration standards where at that time, but I’m sure they followed what rules and laws there were.  They didn’t stay long in that area, and quickly set out for the frontier of Virginia, know as Kentucky.  My Mother was raised in the area near where her German ancestors settled.  My mom doesn’t speak German, or carry a German flag.  She’s an American.  Red, White and Blue to the core.  4th of July parade watcher, Apple Pie baker, and has been know to grill a good hot dog.
  My Fathers family arrived separately, in the early 1920’s from Wales.  My grandfather arrived first, with his brothers.  They went straight to work, doing all kinds of jobs, like digging ditches, to save enough money to bring over their families from “the old country”.  Since this part of the family immigrated much more recently, I know that they came to the United States to find a better life for their small son, my father.  I really couldn’t tell what the immigration laws were at the time, or how it was done, but I do know that what ever laws and rules were in place my grandfather followed them.  
  My father became a naturalized citizen of the United States of America at a time when the head of the house became a citizen, so did his dependent's.  My father was a fierce patriot, served his country during World War II, and was a highly decorated Air Man.  My father appreciated all things American, and while his parents spoke the Welsh language in private at home, his first and only real language was American English.  He worked hard and graduated from Case Western University after the war, and went on to be a successful businessman.  His love for God, Family, and Country has always been an inspiration to me.
  That’s not where my story ends, because you see I met and married a man from the Philippines, while working on an island in the British West Indies.  I stood in line, 3 months pregnant with him at the United States Embassy while applying for his working papers.  My husband was being transferred by his American company in Florida, since I did not want to have our baby in another country.  
  We waded together through the overwhelming mountains of paperwork and processes necessary to have the legal documentation for a man with a job, and a United States Citizen for a wife.  I do know what that was like, and what it entailed to legally enter the United States of America.  It wasn’t easy, but it was necessary, and we got through it.  
  My husband worked two jobs for many years so that I could stay at home with our two children.  He pays his bills on time, and his tax records are flawless.  He has never received anything from the Government by way of assistance.  He moved from the Green Card status, to Permanent Resident status, where he lingered for some time, and debated applying for citizenship.  That was a huge decision for him to make, and one that I did not want to influence.  
  It is a monumental transformation, to become an American.  It meant that he would no longer be a Filipino.  He would now be of Filipino decent, but once you become an American, that is all you can be.  He understood that, and deliberated carefully.
  My Granny passed away in Kentucky while my husband was still on the fence about his citizenship.  She left behind the small funds necessary for my husband to become a United States Citizen, along with her sincere wish that he become a United States Citizen.  That was the extra little push he needed and in January 1999, my husband proudly renounced his citizenship of the Republic of the Philippines, and took the oath of Citizenship of the United States.
  My husband is a proud, flag waving, card caring registered voter, and American through-and-through.  He is a hard working man, who speaks American English as his first language, even though he was raised to speak another language.  He has melted into the pot, and is as American as his children, who trace their citizenship as far back as the late 1700’s.  
  So what’s the moral of this little story?  What do you take away from my little history?  To me there are 3 very simple principals that stand out:
  1.      People come to the United States of America from all over the world, because they want a better way of life.  It’s not perfect, but it must be better – or they wouldn’t come here!
  2.      We are a nation of laws – that is what makes it better.  Our immigration laws should not be changed to accommodate law breakers.  There are ways to come here legally, and if you can’t do that, then sorry you can’t come.  
  3.      If you want to be truly an American – you follow those laws including immigration and you melt into the big pot of people from all over the world.  You lay down your flags and posters from other places, and you learn to use the language.  You should be proud of your heritage, and you preserve it, but you are an American first and foremost.  
  It just seems so simple to me!  If you’re here by birth, appreciate the sacrifices that were made to get you here.  If you came here on your own, it’s time to melt already, if you haven’t, and appreciate the privilege of being here.  If you are here illegally, get out.  Come back when you can do so with your head held high like so many before you, and legally cross the borders.  Legally work for what you have, and pay taxes to help us stay a great nation.
  It’s time to stand up – even quietly from your busy desk and do something.   If you agree – do something today!  I’m sending this little note to my Congressman, and Senators.  You can do the same!  Us the link below to find out how:  http://www.conservativeusa.org/mega-cong.htm
  It’s time to do something to keep America great, by keeping what great about it!  Benjamin Franklin helped change the new world over 200 years ago by spreading the word of freedom and democracy through his writings.  Not that I’m in his league by any means – but you never know what a few moments and forwarded emails can do!  Help to show the people in power that the people they govern have something to say about their country.
  Thank you!
  Kimberley Hughes Babierra

From:	Tommie <tommie@logicalchoicesolutions.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 5:19 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	H1 B Visas and Off-Shoring

Governor Bush,

 

I have long been a fan of yours.  I believe that there is no other governor in any state that can handle a crisis situation like you can.

 

What I am contacting you about today is the need to stop the flow of IT jobs out of this country and into the hands of foreign workers.  I never minded competing with other US programmers for jobs that, after all, is the America way.  What I do object to is competing with foreign IT workers.  These workers are not US citizens.  They are not even in the US in a lot of cases.

 

These workers are reported to be better qualified and more skilled than programmers in the US.  I do not for one minute believe this.  We have some of the finest universities in the world while some schools in India and other places are turning out programmers as if they were parts on an assembly line.  They look okay but they are flawed.  They are trained too fast and given just what they need to get by.

 

As a US programmer, I find that it is almost impossible for me to compete with workers from India who are getting paid what we here would consider slave wages.  They are working in what are called body shops (not unlike a sweat shop).

 

Please take some time to research this issue.  Don’t get your information from any source that is currently passing both H1 B visas and off-shoring as the future of IT.  There are many misconceptions and many outright lies.  One of the biggest lies to date is that using H1 B labor will create more jobs.  I have yet to figure out how they come up with that one since if you send programming jobs overseas or give them to workers temporarily in this country and you pay them less, what jobs will that create?  Jobs as overseers?  Not my idea of a fun job, how about you?  Besides you will only need approximately 1 overseer for every 10 to 20 programmers, so that does not sound like a good ratio to me.

 

Our universities have already seen a decline in the number of programmers and other IT fields leaving their doors.  Soon there will be no IT jobs left here in America and we can’t be cutting edge and a leader and innovator in the Tech industry if we have no one to do the dreaming, creating, and innovating.

 

There is a lot more that I could say but I will just make a few suggestions as to where to begin your research.  Check out the contract for hire sites, they are full of Americans competing with foreigners for jobs and usually losing because we can’t charge $1 per hour and make a living.  Check out the job hunting sites, they are full of programmers looking for jobs.  Some of these people have been looking for a job in their chosen field for several years.  Check out sites like Programmers Guild, they have done extensive research and have done their math correctly on the salaries being paid to these workers, the number of jobs leaving this country each year, and have good solid rebuttals to the lies being told to the American people.

 

I understand that you are busy but this issue could mean a bright future for our country or the beginning of the end.

 

Thank you,

 

Tommie Burchfield

727-515-4717

From:	rjasonc <rjasonc@gmail.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 2:56 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Tax Reform Committee

Dear Governor Bush,

 

It is my understanding that you often read your own email and this is a commendable trait in an elected official, considering most officials are so distant from their constituents.    I am emailing you as a supplemental to my recent application submitted to Celeste Lewis for the Property Tax Reform Committee.

            I am a native Floridian, born in Tampa in 1970.  Though I resided in Atlanta for a few years as a child and went to college in NY, the vast majority of my life has been spent in Florida.  I have extensive family ties in Florida with grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins all residing here.  My family runs the spectrum in types of employment, from retired US Custom's agent to homemaker, from public school teacher to student, from entrepreneur and business owner to career employee with the phone company.   As for myself, I have been involved in the Information Technology industry for 15 years but am undergoing a mid-life career change.  I have been admitted and will be attending Florida State University's College of Law starting this fall. 

            My interest at being on the Property Tax Reform Committee stems from my interest in private property rights.  I was active in a campaign locally to protect private property from abusive eminent domain actions and applauded your signing the state law significantly curtailing such activity.   Property taxes can have similar deleterious effects by forcing owners to take some action.  Whether forcing long time homesteaders to stay in their residence, because they can't afford to move into a similar home with the increased property taxes, or, as the situation existed prior to Save Our Homes, home owners maybe forced to move because they can no longer afford the property taxes on their skyrocketing home values, it must be acknowledged that property taxes have an effect on the free market in real estate.   

            My own interaction with property taxation has been multifaceted.   I have been both a home owner and commercial property owner.  Currently I lease an apartment and am significanty impacted by the property taxes paid by the apartment complex.    I, and other tenants, don't benefit from any form of homesteading or Save Our Homes.  With the recent sale of my commercial property and the cooling off of the home real estate market, I am once again looking to purchase a home and property taxes certainly will have an impact on my decision making process.   

            You'll note, if you review my application, that I am a registered Libertarian.   While I do hold specific philosophical ideas about taxation, I am also a pragmatist.  I will work within the committee to arrive at a practical consensus solution that benefits Florida's citizens, taxpayers and property owners. 

Thank you for considering me in this opportunity to serve the people of Florida.  

 

-- 
Robert Jason Cronk

Gentlemen:  The Palm Beach Post made reference to Steven Bromstrop, inmate K63957, who has asked the State of Florida Clemency Board to hear his appeal to reduce his sentence to house arrest, so he can become a public speaker and tell young people about his ERROR in judgement.
 
On behalf of all victims of drunk drivers, DO NOT release this person, nor reduce his sentence any further.  His CHOICE on the terrible evening was his alone.  The other young people CHOSE to ride in a car with a SOBER and licensed individual.  Their untimely death
was caused by a person who had no care about his life nor that of other individuals  Miss McKinney will forever be in mental and physical pain when she relives that day.  
 
The families according to the law, regardless of age, sex, or color  DESERVE to see the person who caused their pain, receive the full punishment allowed under the law.  He already has had his sentenced reduced, but apparently this is not sufficient for his so called convenience.
 
Let him and his family continue to have the billboard placed in the community while he endures hs legal sentence.  This visual reminder willl have more impact on the people who see it on a daily basis then one speech.  As a high school teacherI, in the 1980"sI  with the permission  of Wanda Yarboro,my  principal, had the opportunity to lead the FIRST DRUNK DRIVER ASSEMBLY.  We listened to speakers and gave out breathalazers to all the student who in turn PROMISED not to let themselves or their friends drive while intoxicted.
The impact and the message was very emotional and strong.  That is until the next FRIDAY evening when the parties continued.  Martin County has a very high rate of drinking and drug consumtion.  DO NOT send a message to our young people that all you have to do is have money and a GOOD lawyer to get your sentence reduced so you can become a public speaker.    Send the message that  "ALL  Will be punished," (William Shakespeare) who do not obey the law and they will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.  
 
In 1978 my son was hit by a drunk driver, comatosed and in rehab for 18 months.  He lives today with a closed head injury and the loss of his potential.... at that time no laws protected him. The driver who drove at 5:30 in the afternoon got  a slap on the hand and a fine... and we got $10,000 from his insurance company.... A life full of potential taken way for the remainder of his life, dependent on his parents and social security to llive  his life as a  handicapped individual.  So you can see that I have  a stake in this community and the lives of other innocent victims.  DO NOT reduce his sentence or you will make a  laughing stock of this case.

From:	PAT PASCUZZO <PATPASCUZZO@MSN.COM>

Subject:	[*] R.S. SHIVER

DEAR HONORABLE GOVERNOR BUSH, IN A PRIOR E-MAIL I FAILED TO MENTION THE FACT THAT A LONG TIME, THE LONGEST TIME IN FACT, CITY OFFICIAL IN FLORIDA CITY. A MAN NAMED R.S. SHIVER IS LIVING IN HOMESTEAD AT 1420 EGRET ROAD WHILE CLAIMING A HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION IN FLORIDA CITY. IT IS A RUNNING JOKE THAT HE GETS AWAY WITH THIS BECAUSE THE HOMESTEAD HOUSE IS ON A LAKE AND THE FLORIDA CITY HOUSE IS A RUN DOWN RESIDENCE WITH MISSING CURTAINS, OVERGROWN GRASS, ETC. I HAVE CONTACTED LAW ENFORCEMENT ABOUT THIS BUT NOBODY WANTS TO DO ANYTHING ABOUT IT AS HIS SON WAS THE MIAMI DADE COUNTY MANAGER, BEFORE RESIGNING IN DISGRACE AND WAS THE HOMESTEAD MAYOR PRIOR TO THAT CITY BEING DECLARED INSOLVENT. THE MAN HAS TO LIVE IN THE CITY WHERE HE IS ELECTED AND HE HAS NOT DONE THAT, THE CITY OF HOMESTEAD HAS ISSUES I HOPE ARE BEING ADDRESSED BUT IT SEEMS TO TAKE A LONG TIME. ANY EFFORT AND PRESSURE FROM THE TOP LAW ENFORCEMENT CHIEF IN THE STATE IS GREATLY APPRECIATED. PATRICK A PASCUZZO 507 SE 23 DRIVE HOMESTEAD, FLORIDA 33033

From:	tom carter <tomccarter@att.net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 2, 2006 1:18 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit for Seminole County

The Honorable John Ellis Bush                                                     Sunday, July 02, 2006
 
Re: Appointment of Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit for Seminole County
 
Dear Sir,
 
My name is Thomas Carter. I am an ex-corporate officer of several different companies in the supply chain / logistics field. My job was to set up and manage companies to manufacture for and supply McDonald’s restaurants in Latin America. I (we) opened Mexico, Brasil, Guatemala, and Puerto Rico to McDonald’s. In the course of my corporate role, I have been to court in several countries and experienced the best and worst of attorneys and judges. Louise Zeuli exemplifies the best of the attorneys and would I believe, carry that over to the bench. 
 
I met her while volunteering in Dispute Resolution Services for the 9th Circuit in Orlando. She too volunteers her time in that circuit as a mediator in civil cases. I have worked with her now for four years. She is one of the very few attorneys that I know, who I would recommend to the bench. 
 
Ms. Zeuli is tireless, energetic, and thoughtful in her decisions. I have never seen an ethical lapse. I am in contact with approximately six or seven attorneys per day and ethical lapses are all too common in their zeal to advocate or protect their own ego. While clearly an articulate and intelligent attorney, Louise has a common touch with parties in dispute resolution conferences. She has the ability and desire to foster self-determination between the parties. She works easily with both attorney and pro-se parties. 
 
A personal observation that I value and find in Louise is that she interacts well with clerical support staff in the court, is patient, and shows them due respect; not a common trait in busy attorneys and judges.
 
While I cannot speak in detail to her technical legal ability, a review of her resume indicates legal experience and leadership roles exceeding many of our current judges. Everything about her indicates she will play an ever expanding role in the community and still be the “best of the best” as a judge. She is the type of judge who will help the 18th Circuit become the icon the 9th Circuit has, “a respected and well known model for judicial practice”.
 
I believe Louise has ideal characteristics for a judge. With her energy, she will be able to handle the all too heavy case load while not losing sight of the humanity of the parties. She is compassionate but will enforce the rule of law. 
 
It is difficult to find truly qualified people like Louise who are willing to make the sacrifices necessary to serve on the bench. We will all be better off if Louise is appointed to the 18th Circuit Court Bench. 
 
Please do not let this opportunity escape us. Louise Zeuli will bring tireless energy, ethics, honor, and respect to the position of Circuit Judge in the 18th Circuit.
 
Appoint Louise B. Zeuli, Esquire to the Circuit Court Bench in the 18th Judicial Circuit for Seminole County. 
 
 
Respectfully, 
 
 
Thomas C. Carter
 
Program Specialist and Volunteer, 9th Judicial Circuit.
Court House Suite 120
425 North Orange Avenue
Orlando, Fl 32801
From:	Camilleabb@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, July 2, 2006 12:33 PM
To:	lclement@umd.edu; NANCYNAN850@aol.com; famm@ix.netcom.com; Governor Jeb Bush; Lt. Governor Toni Jennings; Governor Jeb Bush; jasmash7@yahoo.com; Sschl25@aim.com; snoozie63@hotmail.com; kane2@cox.net; FCERAV@aol.com; LoveAlttl@aol.com
Subject:	(no subject)
Attachments:	newest Pam letter7-06.wps

July 02, 2006
 
To Whom It May Concern:
 
I am a close family friend of Pamela Reynolds, who has been imprisoned now for over a year, she was sentenced to a mandatory minimum sentence for a drug offense, she has been denied her appeal and now was denied a sentence modification.  Pam is a first time offender with a record of good behavior while serving her time. She is 53 years old and has led a pure, honest good life until this incident.  A family woman , a treasured loyal friend, a caring compassionate person who has done so much for others all her life. I   appreciate your giving me your time to hear my plea for justice. 
 
First I want to tell you that I have seen the destruction drugs and the lifestyles attendant thereto produce. It is a terrible and painful thing to witness and unfortunately too many of us have been close enough to those who have made these mistakes. It hurts so many that have nothing to do with that lifestyle, yet love those who have fallen. 
 
My friend has made a serious mistake in her life and better than anyone she knows this. Her mistake has led to a lot of pain for herself, her family and friends. All of us are anguished by this and wish she had had the resolve to not have fallen. However we cannot change the past and must look to the future with the hope that her life will regain the positive direction she has always maintained. 
 
I  would like to take this moment to tell of this woman’s accomplishments, filled with a great deal of unselfish work for others. Her commitment and devotion as a teacher for almost thirty years and also as a coach. Pam lived for her students, she helped so many for so many years never wavering always putting others needs ahead of her own.  Pam  a caregiver to an ailing aunt who had Alzheimer’s disease,  she moved her in with her to allow for her final years to be filled with love and comfort. Pam is a wonderful Mother and grandmother to her daughter Megan and her three grandson’s all who have different degrees of MS.  Pam’s absence in their lives is now what is most painful. The absence of their grandmother during these early years is not something that could ever be replaced. This year and a half has already been too much.   A volunteer in her community for many events, for years Pam was always there ready to help.   She has overcome some of life’s hardest challenges, serious life threatening illnesses to herself, her Mom, Daughter and Grandchildren, cancer has plagued her and her family,  losing her youngest sister to a battle with cancer just a few years ago. She is a woman with a  very big heart always helping others, a kind compassionate, loving woman this is who Pam is. Anyone who knows her knows this of her.
 
My friend had no record prior to this and will  never  cross such a line again.   She knows her mistake has caused all of us great pain and is more than remorseful. All of us Pray for her daily and need her back home with us. For we all in a sense have been punished to a different kind of imprisonment. The pain is deep and the loss is great. 
 
 I just hope that you can see the person I know and see that there is the hope and promise of redemption for her.  Be certain that my friend will walk the path back to freedom from this evil and be grateful for a chance to begin rebuilding her life.
 
I am not familiar with these matters and wish I never had to write this letter, but as a friend and a Christian I have a duty to her (and society). Knowing her I know she is not only remorseful, but repentant and willing to do anything the court would mandate to regain her life. She has given to so many for so long. I hope that you can see the good in her even now, while incarcerated Pam has been a mentor to many.  Helping others, tutoring them, assisting in the teaching and education of those less fortunate. Just speak with the teacher she assists at Gadsden Correctional and hear what he has to say of her.
 
We are already paying the price drugs cost us in so many ways, having Pam incarcerated is not helping anyone. 
 
You have a task I would never wish to have, one that balances justice with compassion, truly it must be a difficult one indeed. I place my trust in You and Pray for Him to grant you wisdom and guidance in this matter. 
 
Please I beg for any guidence to allow for  parole or for clemancy to be given now.
 

Respectfully submitted, 
 
 
 
Camille Abbamonte
 

Pamela Reynolds  154206
Gadsden Correctional Facility
Quincy,  Florida
 
Operation Sandshaker 11/03
Pensacola Beach Florida
50 plus arrested
Some with same charges completely dismissed with no probation, while others face very harsh punishments
Pensacola News Journal    
Leo Thomas ESQ.

From:	Wkiandra62@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, July 1, 2006 6:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Pardon

Dear Governor Bush:
My name is Schmeka Walker I am a thirty year mother of two, struggling to survive in today's society. About nine years ago my husband, cousin, and I had an argument over a personal issue. And things got out of hand, the police were called by me and I ended up getting arrested. I had did nothing wrong other than being hurt and disappointed in the two of them. And when I asked them to leave my mother's property over seven they insisted on dis cussing the issue and proceeded to enter the property. When inside I was choked and held against my will. when I escaped I ran to my neighbor's house and called the police. By the time they arrived I was in the front yard waiting, while being taunted and called names by the both of them. When approached by the police I was to upset to talk so he asked me to sit in the back of the car to calm down. and he went over and spoke to the both of them after awhile he came over to the car opened the door "I replied Thank you!" and got out of the car He placed my arms behind me and told me I was being arrested for aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. I had a breakdown in the back seat and all of this was done in front my five year old daughter and my five month old son. To make a long painful story short, I bailed out, obtained a lawyer lost my job over it, couldn't afford the lawyer and their advice to me was to change my plea from not guilty to guilty and take the withheld adjudication and eighteen months of probation. The lawyer told me I would never have a record and it wouldn't affect my job. All that was a lie and for the next four years, I couldn't obtained a decent job over eight dollars per hour. I was young,scared,and uninformed and I trusted my lawyer when he only wanted to break even after knowing I lost my job. This was my first offense and the original charge was decreased, only to discover this would follow and haunt me the rest of my life. Right now I am a divorced preschool teacher struggling I am enrolled in college to become certified teacher with The Broward County School Board. And last year this case was heard before The Broward County Child Care Licensing Agency with taped testimony from my husband and I that he and my cousin lied out of anger and spite. My record was sealed only within Broward County and only for child care facilities. It is hard to apply for a lease or a decent job and I am trying to better my self for my kids and to be a voice and example to single mother's every where that we can succeed in life with hard work and determination. And to send a message to people every where that justice still prevails no matter how long its been. I never got my right to a fair trial I was innocent of the charge and still am, I just want what every American wants a life for me and my children. I am asking you to help me obtain or grant me a pardon. I promise with the help of God I will work hard and do whatever it takes to follow through stipulations,rules,court preceding and I will travel if I have to. The life that my children and I could have is in your hands please I beg you to consider the life we have right now full of struggle, heartache and tears when I think of where we should be in life right now. More so God has given me a gift and talent with children, and there is a great need of teachers that care about the welfare of the child not just a paycheck. I have the heart of teacher If I can't teach I don't know what else I would do. I also plan to relocate to Georgia after college to purchase my first home for my children and I. And it would be a waste of time and money, to go to college and not gain employment because of my background. Please take into consideration that I am a positive influence in my community, church and family. PLEASE HELP ME TO PURSUE MY DREAMS AND WALK INTO MY DESTINY!!!!!!!
